narrative: On November 16, 2020, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wayne Aoki conducted an unannounced Case Management inspection to the Group Home (GH) via televisit, (in accordance with PIN 20-05-CRP) and met with Wendy Barron. Based on interviews conducted and documentation provided it has been determined Escalon Home is operating beyond the conditions and limitations specified on the license, clients #1, #2 and #3 (see LIC 811 for confidential names list) are above the age 18 years old which is beyond the conditions and limitations of your license. Based on the LPA’s observations, interviews and records review which were conducted, there is a preponderance of evidence to substantiate a violation of regulation based on Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5 and are being cited on the attached LIC 809D A copy of the report and Appeal Rights was provided to the FFA

On 1/20/23 at approximately 2:00 p.m. Licensing Program Analyst(LPA) Jacqueline Carmona and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez conducted a component II meeting regarding the above facility. LPM and LPA met with the Applicant Shairene Evans and Administrator Keeana Ram at the regional office. The program statement and documents discussed were as follows: LIC 200 Application -Do you have Partnership Agreement? -Verify age range LIC200 (Program statement states ages 8-18 LIC 200 states ages 3-17) -Fire Clearance Approved and states all 4 clients are ambulatory but your program statement states you will allow 1 non ambulatory. (Might need to edit pg. 53) LIC 215 -Finger prints (Only Keena Ram is associated to facility) LIC 308 -We need to know who is going to be the facility manager (who would take over when administrator is not there) and social worker -Resubmit with Facility number LIC309 -Board members are required (have meetings /minutes every quarter and the board members make decision) LIC401 -Verify if this is a profit or not profit organization because if its nonprofit the LIC401 should not have a net profit -Cost for First Aid? (Regs require facilities to have a fully stocked first aid kits) -Fringe benefits Continue to page 2

LIC401a -Missing LIC401a LIC402 -Resubmit with facility number LIC 403 -Figures transferred from 403a are incorrect (correct on the LIC 403a the value) LIC403a -Property #2 value? LIC 404 -Have 2 LIC 404 one that’s a photocopy and one sent back with LLC information but its not signed and filled out by financial institution (Can you submit to financial institution?) LIC500 Please resubmit with: -Applicant -Administrator -Social Worker -Facility Manger -Direct care staff (once hired you can add) LIC503 -TB Test (for all staff) -Health Screening (for all staff) LIC610 -Add CCL sec II -Add all staff members in sec I LIC 999 -Ambulatory vs non ambulatory -Windows and exits not noted -Utility Shut off not noted -Clients in each room not noted -Gates not noted First Aid Certificate -None provided (we need all staff that will be working there to be first aid certified) Continue to page 3

Program StatementSEC 1 - Chief executive officer signature required LIC9106 -Talk to provider about accepting male and females SEC2 -Sign LIC9106 SEC 3 -How will client be assessed upon entry to the facility (intake procedures) - Days and hours of operation are not stated in Program Statement -No procedures for Medical Emergencies (Might want to add that staff will have knowledge of each client IPP’s Individual program plan /Needs and Service Plans) SEC 5 -No optional services provided SEC6 -No indication on TB test -Dental and psychiatric emergencies not indicated SEC 7 - No indication of how vehicle insurance and registration are maintained -No indication of restraints i.e. car seats (depending on age verified in our Com II meeting) -No indication of how facility will ensure vehicles utilized for transporting clients would have not been smoked in weather car was in rest or in motion SEC 8 - Program Statement states you will allow “communicable infections that we may accept include but are not limited to HIV” (page 51). In Sec 2 Program Population it states you won’t accept HIV clients. Please clarify. - States you accept Traumatic Brain injury page 52 but don’t have it checked off on page 53 - Page 61 under “Client Records” states you won’t send email with client’s full name and DOB, but CCLD needs that information on 24 Hr. incident reports. -Did not identify sign in and sign out procedures - Will the facility accept emergency placements? - Did not include Licensing Agency Rights (Personal Rights) Continue to page 4

SEC 10 -No indication of the Policies & Procedures being provided to children & authorized representatives -No indication on signed policies and procedures maintained in the child’s records -No indication of Written removal/discharge record developed & maintained by Social Work Staff SEC 11 -More detail on home visits/ overnight visit policy (How will medications be handled? How will staff make sure the individual taking client is cleared to take client from the facility? Specify more on the sign out and sign in procedures) -Did not indicate when visits are not permitted SEC 12 -You state alcohol might be allowed for 21 yr old’s (pg. 78) but there should be no alcohol allowed in facilities -No indication of the Policy of allowing children to be unsupervised away from the facility including issuing passes to children. - No indication of Curfews (school nights, weekends, holidays, or other times) - No indication of dating other children in placement - No indication of completing Homework (engaging in tutoring, etc.) - No indication of chores and cleaning of own personal space (bedroom) - No indication of dress Code (at home and in school) - No indication of prohibited behaviors (generally what behaviors are prohibited in the home) - No indication of use of electronic devices (times when not permitted) - No indication of reasonable and Prudent Parent Standard Application SEC13 - Positive Discipline Policies – other discipline permitted -Applied Behavior Analysis (ABA) and Positive Behavioral Supports (PBS) but how often is this updated? -No indication of conditions for use of Discipline (and what types) -No indication of type of Discipline NOT permitted (corporal punishment and/or personal rights) -No indication of discipline Policies provided to Placing Agency Continue to page 5

SEC14 -Page 90 states CCL will be notified within 7 days but the regulations state next working day for reporting manual restraints documenting and reporting regulation below: -Page 86 formatting under ABC Tracking is off -No indication of assessment of underlying unknown medical or physical conditions precluding use of restraints SEC15 -As soon as you loose sight you need to contact Law Enforcement -No indication of how facility will have a post incident review and use of manual restraints -No indication of runaway training plan SEC16 -Provide facilities forms for complaints/grievances and how they will go about addressing them with clients SEC17 -No indication on Allowance policy -No indication of requirements for handling cash resources upon discharge SEC 18 -chores paid or unpaid (mentions offer incentives but what are they?) -How is the facility going to notify clients if they are paid for chores? SEC 19 -Portion size -Times of meals and snacks -Provide menus weekly SEC 20 -How the facility allows clients to have a say in choices or articles of clothing -Optional personal hygiene items (itemized list on LIC 401 states only $15 a month?) SEC 22 -No indication of number of hours administrator will be preforming administrative functions (it is indicated in SEC 21) SEC 23 - Lines of supervision (does not indicate how administrator or House lead will provide supervision) Continue to page 6

SEC 24 -Need to specify where the training is taken and who is designated to do training for new employed training, on the job training IPP’s, DSP and continuing education (classroom setting?) SEC 25 -Copies of the articles of incorporation -No indication of names of all members of the Board of Directors -No indication of names and positions of any paid staff who are board members or related to board members. SEC 26 -Elaborate that volunteer are not allowed to supervise clients alone -What will volunteers be doing (does not indicate that volunteers will be conducting the same duties as support staff) -Will volunteers be left alone with clients? SEC 28 (Place LIC 999 in this section) -Ambulatory vs non ambulatory -Clients in each room not noted SEC 29 -Ask about board of directors The Applicant Shairene Evans and LPA Carmona agreed the revised Program Statement be submitted by 2/20/23.

On June 17, 2021, at 9:50 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sam Raissi conducted a Pre-Licensing inspection for the facility license and met with applicant (Administrator), Thuy Tran and (House Manager), Anthony Tran. The entire facility was toured inside and out. Four (4) clients are currently residing in the home. The applicant is providing care for a capacity of four (4) children, ages five (5) through seventeen (17) years, ambulatory only. The home is set up as follows: This is a single-story home with three (3) bedrooms, two (2) bathrooms, a living room, a dining room, and a family/recreational room. Bedroom #1- (2 beds, 2 dressers, and closet space). Bedroom #2- (2 beds, 2 dressers, and closet space). Bedroom #3 (2 beds, 2 dressers, and closet space). There were appropriate furnishings in the home. The bathrooms were checked and in operating condition. The faucets will be used by the children were tested and delivered hot water at a temperature of [Kitchen 106.3, Bedroom Bathroom 106.5, and Bathroom 106.5] degrees. The kitchen trash was covered to stop the transmission of communicable diseases or odors. LPA Raissi observed adequate food storage space and a supply of at least two days of perishable foods and a week of nonperishable foods. The gas stove, the smoke detectors and carbon monoxide alarms were tested and operable. The emergency numbers are posted in a prominent location. The home has a locked container where medications are stored. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are stored in the kitchen cabinet that is locked and inaccessible to children. The storage area is in the garage.

The first aid kit was checked and found to be complete. The front and backyard were inspected and found cleared of hazards. There were no pools and/or bodies of water on the premises. The applicant in the home received fingerprint clearances. The applicant had a current health screening report with TB test. The applicant had current CPR and First Aid certificates and the appropriate training hours. The applicant stated there were no guns and weapons in the home. The applicant stated that she has a valid California Driver's license, registration, and insurance. On this date, Evergreen Group Home is recommended for licensure on a provisional basis. The home is within Title 22 Regulation Standards at this time. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was left with the Administrator.

On October 4, 2021, at 10:30 am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sam Raissi conducted a Pre-Licensing inspection for the facility license and met with the applicant(s) [Thuy Tran and Anthony Tran]. The entire facility was toured inside and out. No one is currently residing in the home. The applicant(s) are interested in providing care for a capacity of 4 children, ages 5-17 years, ambulatory only. The home is set up as follows: This is a single-story home with 4 bedrooms, 2 bathrooms, a living room, a dining room, and a family/recreational room. There were appropriate furnishings in the home. The bathrooms were checked and in operating condition. The home does not have any food at this time as there are not any clients in care. The kitchen trash was covered to stop the transmission of communicable diseases or odors. The stove, the smoke detectors and carbon monoxide alarms were tested and operable. The emergency numbers will be posted in a prominent location.The home will be having a locked container where medications will be stored. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions will be stored in the garage that will be locked and inaccessible to children.

There is a storage area in the yard. The first aid kit was checked and found to be complete. The front and backyard were inspected and found cleared of hazards. There were no pools and/or bodies of water on the premises. The applicant in the home received fingerprint clearances. The applicant had a current health screening report with TB test. The applicant had current CPR and First Aid certificates and the appropriate training hours. The applicant stated there were no guns and weapons in the home. The applicant stated that she has a valid California Driver's license, registration, and insurance. The applicant was informed that the household kitchen knives need to be locked and inaccessible to clients. Obtain placement document documents and the Health and Education Passport for each client. Must maintain a separate, complete and current record or file for each child. Report unusual incident/injury (LIC) 624 to Licensing and the Placement Agency within 24 hours by phone, fax, or email and seven days in writing. Telephone service shall be readily accessible in the home at all times. Once this applicant(s) obtain the Fire Clarence a Provisional Licensee will be granted. The home is within Title 24 Regulation Standards at this time. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was left with the applicant.

On March 7, 2022, at 10:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vaishali Singh-Sood, conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility for the purpose of conducting a Post-Licensing inspection. LPA Singh-Sood met with Administrator Thuy Tran, of Evergreen Group Home and both toured the facility, inside and out. The Group Home is licensed to serve four clients, ages 5-17 years. Currently in placement are four clients. All three clients were at school during the inspection. This facility is a one story house, consists of 4 client bedrooms and 2 client bath. LPA Singh-Sood observed at the time of this inspection, the facility to be clean, safe, and sanitary. All fire alarms, and carbon monoxide detectors were in good working condition, and the fire extinguisher is current. This LPA reviewed the staff and client files, medication logs, and they had the necessary forms. The files are kept locked to ensure confidentiality. Food supply, linens and fire extinguisher were observed. There is sufficient perishable food for over two days and nonperishable food for over seven days. Toxins and sharps are properly stored. Medication storage and procedures were also reviewed. The following documents are posted in the facility: facility license, emergency disaster plan, facility sketch, menu, activity calendar and personal rights poster. According to Ms. Thuy, there are no weapons, and/or bodies of water at the facility which meets title 22 regulations. There are currently no exceptions on file, and there have not been any deficiencies cited in the past year. The applicant in the home received fingerprint clearances. The applicant had a current health screening report with TB test. The applicant had current CPR and First Aid certificates and the appropriate training hours. The home is within Title 24 Regulation Standards at this time. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was emailed to Ms. Thuy at 12:00 PM.

On November 28, 2022 at 9:30AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vaishali Singh-Sood arrived at the above facility, for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection of Evergreen Group Home. LPA met with Thuy Tran, Administrator, and Anthony Tran,Licensee, who assisted with the inspection of the home. At the time of the inspection two staff and zero clients were present. Both staff and LPA toured the home both inside and out. Currently residing in the facility are four clients. The facility is licensed to care for six children ages six to seventeen years old. All clients must be ambulatory. This is one story home, located in a residential area. The facility was as follows: four client bedrooms, all three are equipped with twin size beds, adequate lighting, closet and drawer space. This facility contains two client bathrooms, one family room, kitchen, laundry area in garage, and dining area. Facility has an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable food. Facility provides nutritious between meal snacks, and has a up to date menu. At 11:35 AM water temperature was measured at 109 degrees Fahrenheit in the kitchen sink and 105 degrees Fahrenheit in the hallway bathroom and 107 degrees Fahrenheit in the second bathroom. Kitchen and both bathrooms are within the required temperature range. LPA Singh-Sood reviewed four Client files, and four Staff files. LPA Singh-Sood reviewed over the medication records with Mr. Tran.

A review of staff records indicates that all facility staff associated to the facility received fingerprint and child abuse index check clearances. LPA Singh-Sood reviewed four staff . There were no deficiencies cited on today's inspections per California Code Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6. As such, an exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were discussed and emailed to Administrator Ms. Tran at 3:30 PM.

On November 28, 2023 at 10:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vaishali Singh-Sood arrived at the above facility, for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection of Evergreen Group Home. LPA met with Debra Emery, Caretaker, who assisted with the inspection of the home. At the time of the inspection zero and zero clients were present, besides Ms. Emery. Additionally four cleaners were present cleaning the home. Both staff and LPA toured the home both inside and out. Currently residing in the facility are three clients. The facility is licensed to care for six children ages six to seventeen years old. All clients must be ambulatory. This is one story home, located in a residential area. The facility was as follows: four client bedrooms, all three are equipped with twin size beds, adequate lighting, closet and drawer space. This facility contains two client bathrooms, one family room, kitchen, laundry area in garage, and dining area. Facility has an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable food. Facility provides nutritious between meal snacks, and has a up to date menu. At 1:35 PM water temperature was measured at 109 degrees Fahrenheit in the kitchen sink and 115 degrees Fahrenheit in the hallway bathroom and 114 degrees Fahrenheit in the second bathroom. Kitchen and both bathrooms are within the required temperature range. LPA Singh-Sood reviewed three Client files, and four staff files. LPA Singh-Sood will have to return to the facility to conduct an additional staff interview, review medication logs, and review P& I funds due to staff not being present who can provide access to the information. LPA will return to finish the annual on a later date. LPA conducted an exit interview with Ms. Emery, at 4:00 PM. A copy of this document was emailed to Administrator, Anthony Tran.

At 2/13/2024 at 10:50AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood and LPA Brenda Rodriguez conducted an unannounced visit to the licensed facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct the SB484 psychotropic medications inspection. LPAs were informed by Thuy Tran via phone that no staff or clients were present in the facility. At 11:22AM, LPAs met with Anthony Tran, Licensee, who assisted during the inspection. During the inspection, there was one staff and no clients present. The facility currently had a census of three clients, one client had met psychotropic medications inspection criteria. LPAs conducted a walk through of the facility. LPAs did not observe physical plant deficiencies. LPAs reviewed the file and centrally stored medications for one client. LPAs did not interview the client because they were not present at the time of the inspection. During the file review, LPAs observed that the facility was not utilizing a separate psychotropic medication administration record (PMAR) for two of the medications. LPAs delivered a Technical Violation for California Code of Regulations 84070(b)(13), Children's Records. LPAs reviewed five staff files, LPAs did not observe deficiencies with the staff files in regard to the medications inspection. LPAs conducted two staff interviews. The psychotropic medications inspection is not currently finished, LPAs will attempt to interview one client. LPAs conducted an exit interview with Anthony Tran, Licensee, at 1:00PM whose signature confirms the receipt of this document.

On November 20, 2024 at 10:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vaishali Singh-Sood arrived at the above facility, for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection of Evergreen Group Home. LPA met with Licensee, Anthony Tran, who assisted with the inspection of the home. At the time of the inspection, one sick client was present, and one staff . Mr. Tran and LPA toured the home both inside and out. Currently residing in the facility are four clients. The facility is licensed to care for four children ages six to seventeen years old. All clients must be ambulatory. This is one story home, located in a residential area. The facility was as follows: four client bedrooms, all three are equipped with twin size beds, adequate lighting, closet and drawer space. This facility contains two client bathrooms, one family room, kitchen, laundry area in garage, and dining area. Facility has an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable food. Facility provides nutritious between meal snacks, and has a up to date menu. San Andreas Regional Center (SARC) was last here in May. At 1:00 PM water temperature was measured at 111 degrees Fahrenheit in the kitchen sink and 116 degrees Fahrenheit in the hallway bathroom and 117 degrees Fahrenheit in the second bathroom. Kitchen and both bathrooms are within the required temperature range. LPA Singh-Sood reviewed four Client files, and four staff files, medication logs, and P& I funds. An exit interview was conducted with Mr. Tran, at 3:30 PM. It was noted there were no deficiencies cited on today's inspection, and a copy of this report was provided to Mr. Tran.

On October 8, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Bernice Karnsithong and Licensing Program Manager (LPM), JoAunne Griffin arrived at the facility unannounced for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required Inspection. LPA met Breann Sumser, Assistant Program Coordinator. who granted access to the facility and a tour of the facility was conducted. The facility is licensed to care for six children ages 10-17 years, ambulatory only. At that time of the inspection there were no clients present at the home. This is a two-story home, located in a residential area. The facility was set up as follows: lower level consists of two bathrooms, living room (common area), staff office, one bedroom and a fully equipped kitchen with stainless steel appliances. LPA observed that there are sufficient supplies of staple nonperishable foods for a minimum of one week and fresh perishable foods for a minimum of two days. LPA observed that the upper level consists of three bedrooms (2A, 2B, and 2C) and two bathrooms. There is an additional second structure that can be accessed from the main facility through the upstairs or entry from the outside rear of the facility. Upper level of this structure consists of three additional rooms which are used as office space for therapist and Program Coordinator and Assistant Program Coordinator. Lounge area is equipped with a sofa and loveseat. The lower level of this structure is identified as the Enrichment Center (Game Room). This structure consists of one bathroom, group area, and multimedia space (Music Studio). Toilets, sinks and tub/showers are in safe, clean, and operating condition in all bathrooms. There is no wall heater in the home. Home is equipped with central air and heat. Dining area is equipped with a table and 8 chairs. Due to COVID-19 protocols, dining table consists of four chairs and table. Hot water measures within a safe range. Continued on LIC 809-C

The home was inspected, and the following was observed: There are no swimming pools, jacuzzis, or ponds on the premises. All outdoor passageways and open porches are free of obstruction. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions, and poisons are inaccessible to clients and locked in the staff’s storage room. There were four fire extinguishers that were placed throughout the home; last inspection was on December 3, 2020. There are toiletries and personal hygiene products stored in the client’s bathrooms. First Aid kit was complete with all required supplies. Facility was provided with grievance/complaint poster and advised to post in all common areas. There were no bars on the windows at the time of the inspection. LPA reviewed four staff personnel files during this inspection. LPA observed one expired First Aid/CPR certification; staff was advised, and training was completed during inspection. LPA interviewed Staff #1 and Staff #2. Emergency Disaster Mass Casualty Plan: Current and available for review. Emergency Disaster Mass Casualty Plan: Designation/staff assignments current. Facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. Smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were working properly in the facility. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division 6, Regulation 84061 (e) Reporting Requirements. Documents to associate Staff #3 have been requested. Based on record review, Staff #3 is currently not associated as Administrator. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations Title 22 Division 6, Regulation 84063 (a)(10) Accountability. Based on record review, documents were not available during inspection. Exit Interview was conducted, Appeal Rights and a copy of this report will be mailed later.

On October 27, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Charmetha White arrived at the facility unannounced for the purpose of conducting a 2 Year Required Inspection. LPA met with Program Coordinator, Love Fisher who granted access to the facility and a tour of the facility was conducted. The facility is licensed to care for six children ages 10-17 years, ambulatory only. At the time of this inspection there were four (4) clients residing in the home. The facility is a two-story home 4-bedroom, 5-bathroom house, located in a residential area. The facility is set up as follows: the first floor consists living room, dining room, kitchen, staffing office, one (1) ADA bedroom, two (2) bathrooms, and the laundry room. The second floor consist of three (3) bedrooms and two (2) bathrooms labeled men and women. Additionally, a two level second structure can be accessed from the main facility through the upstairs floor or an outside entrance located in the back of the home. The second structure top level consist of a lounge area and three additional rooms which are used for the therapist, program coordinator, and extra storage. The lower level consists of a multimedia room, a game room, group area, and one (1) bathroom. Living room: is furnished with couch, chair, and a mounted flat screen television. Dining room: is furnished with a wooden table and eight (8) chairs. Kitchen: is equipped with a 6-burner gas operated stove, a microwave, refrigerator/freezer, a dishwasher, and a pantry. Laundry room: is located next to the back door and is equipped with washer, dryer, and a sink. Staffing office: is equipped with computers, chairs, and two (2) desk, phone, and locked cabinets. LPA observed the locked cabinets contained client files, medications, and sharps. Addtionally, medication requiring refrigeration is kept a small refrigerator inside the staffing office. The staffing office remains locked and made inaccessible to clients. Garage: is detached and was observed to be used for extra storage. Lounge area: sofa and chair. Recreational area: contains game room, group area, and multimedia space, and one (1) bathroom. Backyard: is equipped with a basketball hoop and a ping pong table. Report continued on LIC 809C.

Bedroom 1: is located on the first floor and is Bedrooms 2A, 2B, and 2C: are located on the second floor and are equipped with two (2) twin size beds, a lamp, six (6) drawer dresser, and windows. In lieu of closet space, each bedroom has an adjustable single rod for client’s belongings. Bathrooms: All bathrooms were checked and found to be in good repair and working order. The carbon monoxide and smoke detectors were tested and found to be in working order. First Aid Kit was checked and found to be complete. The facility has 6 regulation fire extinguishers. The facility has a working telephone readily accessible. Menu is posted in kitchen area and facility has non-perishable foods for one-week, and perishable foods for two days. Overall LPA observed the facility to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. The front yard and outdoor recreation area were clean and free of debris. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps and open porches were unobstructed. There are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the facility. The home has central air and heat. The temperatures in client rooms and common areas were found to be between 68 - 85 degrees (F). Disinfectants/cleaning solutions and poisons are stored and inaccessible to clients. The facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. LPA discussed and advised the Licensee to ensure the following: Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency or the Foster Care Ombudsperson, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. All posting requirements for Group Home Licensure and Emergency Plan were met. The Program has a total of five staff. LPA will return at a later date to review staff files as staff files are not located at the facility. The Program currently has a total of four clients. LPA interviewed all four clients. LPA will return at a later date to review client files. LPA observed a camera in the living room, dining room, hallways, and outside perimeter. There are no deficiencies observed or cited at this during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted with the Program Coordinator, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

On June 21, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White arrived at Everychild Foundation Emergency Shelter Youth for a Plan of Correction (POC) inspection, to verify corrections of the deficiency cited during the Annual/Required inspection dated January 12, 2023. LPA met with Program Coordinator, Love Fisher regarding Type B deficiency 80066(e)(1) as licensee was unable to deliver staff files for review during the inspection. The POC was corrected on 01/25/2023, when licensee made staff files available for review during an Annual Continuation inspection. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and POC letter was provided to the Program Coordinator.

met_with: Facility Administrator (FA) Program Director (PD) Facility Manager (FM)
narrative:
On 12/11/2020 at 10:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Kevin Sauk made an unannounced visit to Evolve Treatment- Azucena facility for the purpose of conducting a Required Annual Inspection. Due to the Coronavirus Outbreak, LPA conducted a virtual inspection via Microsoft Teams, at 10:30am, with the Facility Administrator (FA), the Program Director (PD), and the Facility Manager (FM), who granted access into the facility, and who provided a tour of the entire physical plant inside and out. This facility is designed to accept privately placed children and will be licensed to provide care/supervision for six (6) ambulatory only clients, ages 12-17 years. There is a camera waiver on file. This is a two-story house equipped with four (4) bedrooms, five (5) bathrooms, living room, school room, group room, two (2) staff offices, laundry/Meds prep room, Medication room, kitchen, dining area, outdoor seating area, converted garage and enclosed pool. All of the following bedrooms were observed to have adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting in the room: [See Confidential Names form (LIC811), dated 12/11/2020, for names of clients and staff] Bedroom #1: is vacant, and is equipped with two twin size beds, and an attached bathroom #3. Bedroom #2: sleeps C4, and is equipped with one twin size bed. Bedroom #3: sleeps C3 and is equipped with two twin size beds. Bedroom #4: sleeps C2, and is equipped with one twin size bed, and attached bathroom #4. Bathroom #1: Is located downstairs inside the group room and is only used by guest when visiting the facility during group meetings. This room is kept locked at all times. This room is also used by the facility nurse/facility manager to prepare the medication for the clients; after preparing the medication for the day, the mediations are moved to the Laundry Room, which is also locked at all times. Bathroom #2: Is located to the right when entering the hallway from the kitchen. Bathroom #2 is only used by clients. Bathroom #5: Is located upstairs inside of the staff office and it only used by the facility staff. All bathrooms were checked and observed to be clean, safe, and in good repair. (Continued on LIC809-C)

(Continued from LIC809, page 1) LPA Sauk also observed the following: Living Room: There is one sofa, three (3) sofa chairs, mounted TV, and a covered fireplace. In the living room there is also a door that can be used to access the out door seating area. School Room: This is an open space area located to the left when entering the facility. There is ample seating for clients to do their school work. Dining Area: There is a table with eight (8) chairs. Group Room: This room is located to the right when entering the facility and is equipped with ample seating nine (9) chairs, mounted white board, and a mounted TV. Kitchen: There is a stove with six (6) burners all working at this time. There is a detached oven currently working at this time. There is a microwave and refrigerator/freezer. The food service in the home is adequate with perishable/nonperishable food supplies. The cleaning solutions are made inaccessible to the clients and stored/ locked under the kitchen sink and in the hallway closet. All trash cans have tight lids on. Staff Offices: One of the two staff offices is located downstairs and the other one is located upstairs to the left when walking up the stairs. Laundry/Medication Adminsitration Room: There is a dryer and washer. This room is also used to store and administer clients medications for the day. This medication room is kept locked at all times and only available to the facility nurse. Converted Garage: The garage is being used as a gym and can be entered through the inside of the facility. Outdoors: There is an outdoor seating area and an enclosed pool. Therapy bungalows: There are 2 detached bungalows, which were observed to be clean, safe, and in good repair, located next do the driveway of the facility, and are used by the therapists, and therapy sessions. Overall, the home is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. The home has a first aid kit stored inside a locked cabinet in the medication room. One of fire extinguishers is located in the kitchen area fully charged and the other fire extinguisher is located upstairs mounted to the wall next to the staff office fully charged. Disinfectants and poisons are inaccessible to the clients in care they are kept locked at all times. All knives and sharp objects are made inaccessible to the clients in care locked in a security box inside the closet in the upstairs staff office. Chef logs out the knives when they will be used. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide are operable. There is a working telephone line available for clients to use. The yard is free of debris and hazardous material. All posting requirements have been met. The home will operate within capacity and limitations of license. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. Exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

Minors are not allowed hygiene items Confidential interviews revealed conflicting statements regarding whether clients are not allowed hygiene items. Interview information revealed that clients are given hygiene boxes that contain toothbrush, toothpaste, soap, shampoo, conditioner, deodorant, lotion, and other products which are available when the clients request them. Confidential interviews stated that clients are provided razors to shave but under the supervision of staff. It was noted in the facility’s program statement that staff can withhold hygiene items from clients and provide them upon the request of the client depending on the client’s level. Staff open minors’ personal mail Confidential interviews indicated that the therapist keep all mail, unopened until the clients’ next one-on-one therapy sessions. It was also disclosed that clients are required to open their letters in front of staff to make sure there is no contraband and confirmed that staff do not open clients’ mails. Other confidential witnesses were unaware of the mail process and could not speak to this allegation. Some confidential witnesses stated that the clients open their personal mail in front of staff, and others stated the clients’ primary therapists open their mail for them to screen letters and packages for contraband or triggering content. Minors not receiving an allowance Confidential interviews revealed that none of the minors received allowance during their residency at this Group Home. Per Facility Representative(s), the purpose of not providing clients allowance was to reduce the ability of incoming contraband. Facility Representative(s) also indicated that clients did not have a need for allowance as the Program provide the necessities for clients. Confidential interviews revealed that although allowance is not given, the facility provide for clients’ needs which includes items while on outings. Minors are denied access to personal property Confidential interviews revealed that clients are denied personal property based on scheduled activities and for their safety. Some personal items are stored locked in a cabinet and made available to clients upon request. Per Facility Representative(s) some items such as razors require direct supervision, while other personal items (such as books, clothing and etc.) are not allowed to be possessed by clients because the item could trigger client’s behaviors or jeopardize their safety while in treatment.

Based on the confidential interviews, observation, and record review, it has been determined that although the allegations that minors are not treated with dignity; minors are not allowed hygiene items; staff open minors’ personal mail, minors not receiving an allowance, and minors being denied access to personal belongings may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. The program statement has been updated to ensure that the clients’ needs will be met based on their individual assessments per Title 22 Group Home Regulations. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was provided to Devorah Weiss.
investigation_findings: 13On 12/02/2021 at 10:35 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Miguel Gomez arrived at the facility to deliver the findings of a complaint investigation. LPA Gomez met with Administrator, Devorah Weiss and discussed the investigative findings. On June 7, 2021, the Department received a complaint alleging minors are not treated with dignity; minors are not allowed hygiene items; staff open minors' personal mail; minors are not receiving an allowance; minors are being denied access to personal property. Confidential interviews were conducted with 4 staff and 4 of 6 clients. Facility’s Program Statement, Plan of Operation, Parent Handbook and Training Manual were reviewed. The following information was obtained during the course of the investigation: Minors are not treated with dignity Confidential interviews revealed conflicting statements that clients must leave the bathroom door ajar while using the restroom. Some confidential interviews reported that the clients did not have to leave the door open while using the restroom and other interviews stated that clients must leave the bathroom door ajar while using the restroom. It was noted in the facility’s program statement that staff are to ensure that the clients keep the bathroom door ajar when using the restroom.

narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olivia Rosas made an announced inspection to the Evolve Treatment, Azucena on 12/16/21 at 11:00am for the purpose of conducting Annual Inspection. LPA Rosas met with Staff#1(S1) who granted access to the facility and an inspection of the facility was conducted together. The Evolve Treatment, Azucena is a therapeutic treatment program that’s designed to accept “Private Placement's” for a length of 30 - 45 days and is licensed to provide care supervision for six (6) youths, ages 12-17 years; ambulatory only. Individuals mention in this report are identify on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated 12/16/21. Temperature and health checks are conducted at the entrance in the sign-in area. The home is set-up as follows and LPA inspected the following: This is a two-story home with four (4) bedrooms, five (5) bathrooms, art room, school room, kitchen/family room, dinning room, converted garage (gym), medication/laundry area, three (3) therapy rooms, group room, two (2) staff offices, outdoor seating area, and pool. S1 states that there are no guns or weapons on the premises. There is a pool on the premises that meets regulation requirements. There are 26 facility cameras on the premises, and an approved Camera Waiver on file. The facility has hand sanitizer dispensers for use. The home is set up as follows: Bedroom #1: Is occupied by two (2) clients, the bedroom is equipped two (2) twin sized beds, with one (1) closet. This bedroom has a bathroom. Bedroom #2: Is occupied by one (1) client, the bedroom is equipped with one (1) twin sized bed, with one (1) closet. This bedroom has jack-n-hill bathroom that is locked from this bedroom. Bedroom #3: Is occupied by two (2) clients, the bedroom is equipped two (2) twin sized beds, with one (1) closet. This bedroom has a jack-n-hill bathroom that is locked from this bedroom. Bedroom #4: Is occupied by one (1) client, the bedroom is equipped one (1) twin sized beds, with one (1) closet. This room has a bathroom. Bathroom #1: Is located downstairs inside the group room and is only used by guest when visiting the facility during group meetings. Bathroom #2: Is located to the right when entering the hallway from the kitchen. Bathroom #2: is only used by clients. The bedrooms have alarm door system on the windows. LIC 809-C Page 1 of 3

Bathroom #3: Is located upstairs in Bedroom #1. Bathroom #4: Is located upstairs inside of Bedroom #4. Bathroom #5: Is located upstairs inside of the staff office and it only used by the facility staff. All bathrooms were checked and were in operating conditions. The faucets that are used by the clients were tested and delivered hot water at a safe temperature range. Living Room: There is one sofa, three (3) sofa chairs, mounted TV, and a covered fireplace. In the living room there is also a door that can be used to access the out door seating area. School Room: This is an open space area located to the left when entering the facility. There is ample seating for clients to do their school work. Dining Area: There is a table with eight (8) chairs. Group Room: This room is located to the right when entering the facility and is equipped with ample seating nine (9) chairs, mounted white board, and a mounted TV. Kitchen: There is a stove with six (6) burners all working at this time. There is a detached oven currently working at this time. There is a microwave and refrigerator/freezer. The food service in the home is adequate with perishable/nonperishable food supplies. The cleaning solutions are made inaccessible to the clients and stored/ locked under the kitchen sink and in the hallway closet. All trash cans have tight lids on. Staff Offices: One of the two staff offices is located downstairs and the other one is located upstairs to the left when walking up the stairs. Laundry/Meds Prep Room: There is a dryer and washer. This room is also used by the facility nurse/facility manager to prepare the medication for the clients. This room is kept locked at all times. Medication Room: Is located downstairs. This room is used to store and administer clients medications. The medication room is kept locked at all times and only available to the facility nurse. Converted Garage: The garage is being used as a gym and can be entered through the inside of the facility. Outdoors/Backyard: There are two small bungalow converted to be used as a therapy room. LPA also observed an outdoor seat area available for clients to use, one square table with chairs all around. The facility has a pool with a fence that is at least five feet high and has a fence does not obscure the pool from view. LPA Rosas and S1, observed the gate door to swing away from the pool, with self-close and self-latching device located no more than six inches from the top of the gate. The outdoor perimeter front yard, side yard and backyard were inspected and found cleared of debris and hazards materials. The passageways and porches are unobstructed. LIC 809-C Page 1 of 3

LPA observed non-perishable foods for one week and perishable food for two days. The home has a first aid kit stored inside a locked cabinet in the medication room. One of the four fire extinguishers is located in the kitchen area fully charged and the other fire extinguisher is located inside the laundry room fully charged on November 9, 2021. The third fire extinguisher is located next to bedroom #3 mounted onto the wall and the fourth fire extinguisher is located next to the staff office mounted onto the wall fully charged. Disinfectants and poisons are inaccessible to the clients in care they are kept locked at all times. All knives and sharp objects are made inaccessible to the clients in care locked in a security box inside the closet in the staff office upstairs. The Chef logs out the knives when they will be used. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide are operable. There is a working telephone line available for clients to use. All posting requirements were met, (food menu, regulations, licenses, emergency disaster plan, Children’s Personal Rights, and Ombudsman). The facility has a working telephone and youths can use the telephone unless restricted by court order. The Facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. Facility has a current, written plan of operation. Facility personnel are instructed to report violations of personal rights. Licensee will report changes in the plan of operation affecting service to youths. Licensee will report youth injuries requiring medical treatment. LPA Rosas received by email a copy of copy of Register of participants, Current Census, Personnel Report (LIC 500), Emergency Disaster Plan Protocols, Emergency Disaster Plan for Children's Residential Facilities (LIC 610C). LPA Rosas was not able to review client or staff files during this visit and will return to continue with the annual inspection. LPA reviewed Fire Drill log and Emergency Disaster Plan. The facility keeps files and documents in digital system called KIPUERM. A review of Facility's Personnel Report Summary on 12/13/2021 indicates that all personnel have criminal record clearance has obtain the necessary clearances with DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse Response. LPA Rosas by email the following PINS to S1 PIN 20-17-CRP: New Background Check Requirements, Assembly Bill 819 (Chapter 777, Statutes of 2019), PIN 21-20-CRP: Statewide Launch of New Inspection Tools for Children’s Residential Licensees, PIN 21-05-CRP: The Family Urgent Response System (FURS). There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

narrative:
On October 6, 2022, at 10:15 AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's) Lucero Jauregui, Eduardo Barragan and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Ann Valenzuela conducted an announced annual facility inspection. LPA's and LPM met with Margaret Gutgselll, Clinical Program Director who provided LPA's and LPM with a guided tour of the facility both indoors and outdoors. On February 23, 2023 at 9:00 AM LPA Lucero Jauregui returned to the facility to amend report. The facility is a four-bedroom four bathroom (for client use) in this two story home. The first floor consists of staff office, bedrooms (one, two, three and four), group therapy room, school room, dining room, kitchen, laundry room/nurse station and a two car garage that will be used as an Art Therapy room instead of garage. Bedrooms two and three will serve one client each and bedrooms one and four will serve two clients each. All beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. There are two upper wings to the facility which house the Program Director’s office on the upper right wing and two therapy offices on the upper left wing. There are two additional separate buildings on the grounds, one is a three-car garage that has been transformed into a gym for residents and the other is the pool house. The pool house will remain locked and will only be used for storage, clients will not have access to the pool house. The Gym for residence will be locked as well. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/toys/books/games were observed for children’s recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and CONTINUED...

carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. The hot water temperature was measured in the main bathroom and is currently 111.0 degrees which is in ration. Facility has cameras in common areas of the facility (27 cameras were noted on the premies of this facility.) Facility has a pool which is appropriately fenced and secured with a mesh fence. The enclosure was measured to be 5 feet with a self-latching gate that swings outward. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. LPA observed the following items posted Personal Rights, Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policy, Facility sketch, Activity Schedule, Menu, Staff Schedule and Emergency Plan. However a deficiency was observed with the medications. LPA's observed and took a video of multiple medications that were transferred between containers and were pre-packaged for multiple days in advance. Prior to inspection LPA's and LPM reviewed personnel files to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title 22 Regulations. Clinical Program Director advised that all client records will be kept electronically. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. All licensing fees have been paid and are current at this time. Given the contradiction of the medication guide and the ambiguity of being issued a citation and a technical violation for the same deficiency, the Department will dismiss the citation and uphold the two technical violations. A exit interview was conducted. A copy of the report was discussed and provided along with appeal rights to Margaret Gutgsell, Clinical Program Director.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Latricia Rogers conducted a case management inspection on March 26, 2024, based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 10 out of 13 Residential Counselors and 5 out of 5 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 13 Residential Counselors and 2 out of 5 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated March 26, 2024). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA L. Rogers observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Margaret Gutgsell, Program Director.

On March 13, 2025 at 10:35 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacob Salem conducted an unannounced visit to the above facility for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection and met with Dajah Lockett, Manager. LPA reviewed five client files (C1-C5), which are on a secure electronic system. The client files reviewed contain required information and records, including pre-placement screenings, personal rights and facility policy acknowledgements, and medication logs. LPA reviewed staff files (S1-S5), which contain the required background clearance and demographic information, health screenings, and qualifications. LPA inspected the facility’s physical plant, including personal rights postings, health-related services, buildings and grounds, food services, telephones, indoor and outdoor activity space, and furniture, fixtures, equipment and supplies. The home is clean, in good repair, and free from observable risks to clients' health, safety, and personal rights. The home is a two story building with four client bedrooms and four client bathrooms which are set up as follows: Bedroom #1 has two twin beds and sleeps two clients, bedroom #2 has two twin beds and sleeps two clients, bedroom #3 has one twin bed and sleeps one client, and bedroom #4 has one twin bed and sleeps one client. All client bedrooms except for one have attached bathrooms and showers, and there is an additional shower upstairs that can be used to ensure other client bedrooms are not passed through for clients assigned to the fourth bedroom to use the shower. There is a kitchen and living room, multiple vitiation room areas, staff office and storage closets, and backyard/patio with pool and recreation equipment. Due to time constraints, the annual is being extended to conduct an staff and client interviews. An exit interview was conducted and a signed copy of this report was provided to Dajah Lockett, Manager.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Robin Sullivan conducted an unannounced post-licensing inspection on 12/02/2021 at 11:00 AM. During the inspection LPA met with Gauri Sanchez, Clinical Program Director who assisted with the inspection. LPA Sullivan conducted a walk-through of the facility both inside and out. Facility staff-client ratio at time of inspection is one staff per three clients. LPA reviewed three client files and four staff files. Two staff and three clients were interviewed. Three clients were present in the facility at the time of the inspection. LPA observed the following during the inspection: · Sharp items are stored in a locked container inside the facility manager’s locked office. · Chemicals and cleaners are stored inside a locked closet. · Medications are stored in a locked cabinet inside the locked laundry room. · The facility has four bedrooms, two are double occupancy and two are single occupancy rooms. Individual twin beds have a mattress, mattress cover, top and bottom sheets, blankets and a pillow. Adequate supply of linens, and bedding were observed. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings. · Facility water was tested and is within 105 to 120 degrees Fahrenheit. · The dining room has a large table with eight chairs to accommodate all clients. · Combination smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were observed and operational throughout the facility and in the bedrooms. The facility is equipped with an automatic sprinkler system in case of fire and fire extinguishers were observed to meet regulations. Appropriate forms, including client rights are posted in view of clients. · A swimming pool is fully enclosed by a 5’ fence with a self-closing gate. · The yard is clean and free of hazards. · There are adequate indoor and outdoor activity spaces. The following was discussed during the inspection: inform Community Care Licensing (CCL) of staff changes and update LIC 500 (personnel report) as needed. LPAs observed COVID-19 precaution postings, hand sanitizer, and masks. The facility will require temperatures of visitors and staff to be taken upon entrance and logged in a sign-in sheet. The facility meets Title 22 Division 6 Regulations at this time. An exit interview was conducted and documents left at the facility.

The investigation revealed that clients are required to conduct body checks multiple times a day. During a body check, clients remove one piece of clothing at a time, gives the clothing item to staff who then feels/checks the clothing for items of self-harm or contraband. Clients remove all clothing except their undergarments. When clients are dressed down to their underwear, they are then required to do three jump squats. Clients then re-dress. Three clients stated body checks are done each time they return from an outing and every night before they go upstairs to bed. Two staff stated that body checks are conducted the day of initial admission, each time clients return from an outing, and before going to bed. Staff report that all clients are required to conduct body checks for safety. The Program policy states that based on a physician’s assessment and the individual needs of a client; body checks may be conducted. One client did not receive a medical assessment nor a treatment plan because they had only been at the facility for 3 days, and the client submitted to body checks. Although all the assessments had not been completed, the facility was within the timeline for completing them, including the Needs and Services Plan. Additionally, the client’s parents signed admission paperwork outlining their policy, including the body checks. There were additional conflicting statements regarding under clothing that is expected to be worn during the body checks. There was conflicting information regarding statements made in the complaint narrative and from those interviewed for the complaint. Based on the confidential interviews, observation, and record review, it has been determined that although the Allegation; Minor was not accorded dignity in their personal relationships with staff and other persons may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED.

On July 19, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Caplinger conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility for the purpose of conducting the annual inspection. LPA met with Jessica Lawrence, Facility Manager, and Gauri Sanchez, Program Director. Walk through was conducted all together. During the course of this inspection, LPA observed the facility to be clean, safe and sanitary. Seven staff and six clients were present during inspection. All required postings were observed in the entryway. The facility is equipped with 4 bedrooms for client use and 3.5 bathrooms. Two bedrooms are equipped with two beds and two bedrooms are equipped with one bed each. The facility was observed with a school room, a living room for relaxation and visits, a group therapy room and laundry room. The home has a large kitchen which opens to the main family room/group space. Kitchen was observed with a stocked fridge and freezer with adequate food supply and perishables. A smaller fridge with snack items was observed in the living room available to the clients for snacks. Menu was observed posted. Home was observed with a garage being utilized for a work out room with an extra fridge being used for extra frozen items. Three therapist rooms were observed. The backyard was observed with a fenced pool area. Over the counter medications, first aid supplies and a refrigerator for medication that may need cold storage are all locked . First aid kit is properly stocked. There are several cupboards in the bathrooms and hall with an abundance of linens, towels and hygiene supplies. Gas and water shut off valves were observed labeled. There are no firearms on the premises. All sharp objects and chemicals were observed locked to be inaccessible to clients. Fire extinguishers were observed throughout the facility and have all been inspected. Facility has a current fire inspection and carbon monoxide detectors were in working condition. Water temperature is set at 117 degrees. Faucets and showers take a long time to heat up but get to over 105 degrees after several minutes. Staff and client files are kept secure. Report continues on LIC 809-C

The facility has a binder for up to date disaster plans and documented drills. The facility currently has six clients, four full time clinicians, and 18 staff. LPA will return to complete the inspection tool. CARE Tool in progress. The following domains were completed: Physical Plant, Operations, Emergency Intervention, and Disaster Preparedness. No deficiencies were noted at this inspection. Exit interview was conducted with Guari Sanchez, Program Director, and a final copy of this report will be emailed to the facility.

On 10/6/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Caplinger, conducted an unannounced inspection to the above facility for the purpose of conducting a Case Management regarding an incident that occurred on 7/1/22. LPA met with Gauri Sanchez, Administrator, to discuss the incident and review findings from the 7/20/22 Case Management conducted regarding the incident. LPA conducted a walk through to observe the facility inside and outside. Current census is 6 youth. Youth and staff were on an outing during the inspection. Facility was observed sanitary and in good repair, the kitchen was stocked with adequate food, fire extinguisher and detectors were in compliance, and the facility does not have weapons. The facility pool was observed with an enclosed fence with a self-latching gate. Based on confidential interviews regarding the above incident, staff violated the youth’s personal rights by yelling profanity at youth, making inappropriate comments regarding sexual behavior observed in movies, and touching the youth by patting down during body checks when the facility has a “no touch” policy. Personal Rights standard 84072(d)(11) is cited on the attached 809-D. Exit interview was conducted with Gauri Sanchez, Administrator, where this report, 809, 809-D and Appeal Rights were reviewed, and a final copy of all forms were left at the facility.

On 10/12/23 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman conducted a Case Management Inspection. Facility citation violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, regulation 80061(b) Reporting Requirements. During an inspection on 5/23/23 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman interviewed Amara Reddick Clinical Program Director who stated they have been the Administrator since December 2022 and Kelsey Shaffer, the former Administrator, is not at the facility. Amara Reddick called Devorah Weiss Compliance Officer who spoke with LPA. Devorah Weiss confirmed Kelsey Shaffer is not physically on the premises. deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 80061(b) Reporting Requirements Upon the occurrence... a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours.... This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based upon record review, the licensee did not report an incident occurred 4/28/23 and was not reported by 5/1/23 but reported on 5/4/23; an incident occurred on 5/17/23 and was not reported by 5/18/23 but was reported on 5/19/23; and an incident occurred on 5/29/23 and was not reported by 5/30/23 but was reported on 6/5/23; and an incident occurred on 7/1/23 and was not reported by 7/3/23 but was reported on 7/6/23 which poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.

84064(c) Administrator Qualifications and Duties. The administrator shall be on the premises for the number of hours necessary to manage and administer the facility in compliance with applicable law and regulation. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: During an inspection on 5/23/23 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman interviewed Amara Reddick Clinical Program Director (S1). S1 stated they have been the Administrator since December 2022 and will attend Administrator training beginning in two weeks. S1 stated Kelsey Shaffer, the former Administrator (S3), is not physically here in the facility. LPA asked S1 when was the last time S3 was here. S1 stated, “I don’t know.” LPA asked since you’ve been here how many times has S3 been here. S1 stated, “I have never seen S3 on site.” S1 called Devorah Weiss Compliance Officer (S2) and LPA spoke with S2. S2 stated S3 is on zoom regularly to manage the facility but S3 has a medical condition that does not allow her to travel or physically be on the premises.

and one reporting party and records reviewed were consistent that staff did not provide a safe environment by not being able to maintain line of sight at all times, other staff did not assist the residential counselors with supervision, the staff were unable to prevent children from harassing other children even when the staff had prior knowledge of these actions, children could not utilize their coping skills to mitigate their escalating mental health issues as there was not enough staff present to allow them to do such as going for a walk, going to a quiet room and the administrator was on site approximately once a month. investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Dara Campos conducted an unannounced complaint inspection with the above facility on 7/24/25 at 10am and met with Ben Connolly, Operations Manager. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver complaint findings for the above allegations. On 4/29/24 LPA met with Angel Jandoc Facility Nurse and Operations to initiate a complaint investigation. During the course of the investigation, the following documents were gathered and reviewed Client Roster, LIC500 Personnel Report, Current LIC610C, Pre-Admission Assessment, Placement agreements, client Information/Face Sheet, Master Treatment Plans, Medical report, Incident Reports for three children dated 3/27/25, 4/6/25, and 4/16/25, Case Notes for six children and schedule of staff work hours for March and April 2025, weekly progress emails for one child dated 4/4/25, 4/11/25 and 4/18/25, and staff work schedules for 6/23/25-7/6/25 show approximately 22% of shifts were worked by one staff. Confidential interviews conducted between 4/29/25-7/11/25 with four children, eight staff

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 84065.5(c) Staff/Child Ratios If the children require special care and supervision because of age, problem behavior or other factors, the number of on-duty child care staff shall be increased. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based upon ten out of 13 confidential interviews conducted and records reviewed the facility staff could not maintain line of sight at all times, other staff such as the nurse, therapist and chef were onsite but failed to assist the residential counselors with supervision, the staff were unable to prevent clients from exhibiting aggressive, intimidating, harmful behavior towards each other demonstrating patterns of conduct that negatively impacted the safety and well-being of each other. The insufficient staffing impacted the program’s ability to effectively respond to the clients’ individual needs when triggered. Furthermore, the administrator was only on-site physically approximately once a month which poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.

narrative: On 7/24/25 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Dara Campos conducted a case management inspection. Upon a review of the facility’s program statement dated 10/11/21 the LIC9106 dated 4/22/21 states the facility will not accept developmentally disabled children. Confidential interviews conducted between 4/29/25-7/11/25 with four children, eight staff, and records reviewed of three children’s (C2, C5 and C6) Pre-admission Assessments and Master Treatment Plans show the facility admitted children with developmental disability, more specifically Autism Spectrum Disorder between 3/24/25 to 6/23/25. The Welfare and Institutions Code Section 4512(a) defines Autism as a developmental disability. In addition, a record review of six children’s Master Treatment Plan for C1 dated 4/3/25, C2 dated 3/5/25, C3 dated 4/11/25, C4 dated 4/14/25, C5 dated 4/21/25 and C6 dated 3/31/25 are missing the signature of the authorized representative. The Facility was issued a citation in violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 06, regulation 84068.2(d)(1) Needs and Services Plan.

LPA observed posted forms in the facility: Personal Rights forms, and California “See Something Say Something Poster” and Disaster plans were posted throughout the facility. LPA observed in the pool area appropriately fenced and secured with a mesh fence. The enclosure was measured to five-foot-high feet, self-closing access gate that opened away from the pool, with a self-latching device. It was reported that the week of April 14, 2024 – April 20, 2024, C2 had been engaging in violent behaviors while at the facility. It was reported C2 hid underneath an unknown client’s bed and woke them up by kicking them underneath the bed, had thrown a chair at unknown staff, made threats to harm other clients, and left the facility more than once on unapproved absence. The report also included information that C2 made comments to C1 which caused C1 emotional disturbance; however, facility staff did not report the information to C1’s authorized representative. Regarding the allegation that staff did not prevent minor from engaging in inappropriate behaviors, a review of pertinent records revealed C2 had three incidents in April 2024 which involved making threats and attempting to engage in a physical altercation with clients in care. A confidential interview revealed C2 was taking medication that led to dysregulation and property damage. The confidential interview revealed C2 struggled to get along with peers, which would lead to confrontations, but did not reveal any physical incidents. A review of pertinent records and a confidential interview did not reveal any incidents in which C2 was found under a client’s bed, however, there was a reported incident in which C1 left the facility on unauthorized leave after running out of the door. Regarding the allegation that facility staff did not prevent minor from making inappropriate comments towards other minors, a review of pertinent records revealed C2 made comments of wanting to harm clients in care which resulted in confrontation between clients. The review of pertinent records and a confidential interview both revealed staff engaged by intervening and deescalated the situations by creating separation between clients. A review of pertinent records and a confidential interview did not reveal any incidents in which C2 made comments to C1 which caused C1 emotional disturbance. Regarding the allegation that staff did not notify minor’s parent of incidents, a review of pertinent records and a confidential interview revealed no incidents in which C2 was involved. The review of pertinent records revealed incidents that were reported regarding C1 involving other minors in care. A confidential interview revealed the facility provides notification to all necessary parties within 24 hours if involving law enforcement. Additionally, the confidential interview revealed that staff did not provide notification to authorized representatives of clients who were not involved in an incident, due to confidentiality reasons, but clients would sometimes share with others what happened in the facility, even if notification was not required. CONTINUED...

Based on interviews and review of records, the allegations that staff did not prevent minor from engaging in inappropriate behaviors, staff did not prevent minor from making inappropriate comments towards other minors, and staff did not notify minor’s parent of incidents are all unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged allegations occurred. An exit interview was conducted with Tamara Fleck-Myers, Administrator. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided and reviewed with Tamara Fleck-Myers, whose signature on this report confirms receipt of these documents.

It was reported that the facility had clients in care that would leave unauthorized, and there were clients who required one on one supervision, and it was unclear if staff were present at the facility to provide supervision. During the investigation confidential interviews revealed the facility had staff present daily that would provide clients with care and supervision. Confidential interview revealed there were two clients who left the facility unauthorized during the reported time, and a review of pertinent facility records confirmed their unauthorized leave. The review of records revealed that on both occasions, staff were unable to utilize prior de-escalation techniques due to attending to other clients, however, confidential interviews did not yield evidence to confirm lack of supervision was a reason for the clients’ unauthorized leave. Based on interviews and record review, the allegation staff are not providing the minors adequate supervision is unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to provide the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted with Rachel Henry. A copy if this report and appeal rights were provided and reviewed with Rachel Henry, Operations Manager, whose signatures on this report confirms receipt of these documents.
