On December 9, at 2:30 p.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Cameo Banks made an announced televisit to Evolve Treatment Centers, Calabasas for the purpose of conducting an Annual Required Inspection. LPA, met with Lindsay Brasile, Clinical Program Director and Devorah Weiss, Compliance Officer via Microsoft Teams. A virtual tour of the facility was conducted together. This facility is designed to accept privately placed children and will be licensed to provide care/supervision for six (6) ambulatory only clients, ages 12-17 years. On this day the census is four (4) clients. This is a two story house located in a residential area. There are four (4) bedrooms, five (5) bathrooms, a living room, school room, group room, two (2) staff offices, kitchen/dinning area, medication/laundry room, an attached garage and backyard. The home is set up as follows: Bedroom #1: Is located upstairs. The room is equipped with a twin size bed. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting in the room. Bedroom #2: Is located upstairs and is occupied by Client #1 and Client #2. The room is equipped with two twin size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting in the room. There is also a bathroom connecting Bedroom #2 and Bedroom #3 however clients can only access the bathroom through one side which is through Bedroom #3. Bedroom #3: Is located upstairs and is occupied by Client #3. The room is equipped with a twin size bed. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting in the room. There is also a bathroom connecting Bedroom #3 to Bedroom #2 however clients can only access the bathroom through one side. Bedroom #4: Is located upstairs and is occupied by Client #4. The room is equipped with two twin sizes beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting in the room. Bathrooms: There are two (2) bathrooms downstairs and three (3) bathrooms upstairs. All bathrooms were kept locked and required a key for entry. All bathrooms were checked and were in operating conditions. Report Continued on LIC 809-C.

School Room: Is an open area with three desk and three computers used for clients to complete school work. There is also a round table with five (5) chairs in the center. Group Room: There is a private room with chairs where clients and therapist meet as a group. Living Room: There are two sofas, small center table, and TV. Furniture seems to be in good conditions. There are also two sofa chairs located to the left once entering the facility. Staff Offices: Staff Office #1: Is located downstairs to the right once entering the home. There is a desk with desk chair, a sofa, two individual sofa chairs, small center table, a bookshelves, and drawers/cabinets. Staff Office #2: Is located upstairs. There is three desks with a computer, a sofa with two sofa chairs, mini fridge, center table and two lamp tables. There is also a covered fire place. Therapy Rooms: Is located downstairs and next to the medication/laundry area. There is a desk with desk chair, a sofa, and two individual sofa chairs. Therapy room #2: Is located downstairs but can only be accessed through the outside of the home. There is a desk with desk chair, a sofa, a large sofa chair, and a little table to the side. Kitchen: There is a table with eight (8) chairs where clients can sit to eat their meals. There is a stove/oven with six (6) burners and center grill all working at this time. There is a microwave and refrigerator/freezer. The food service in the home is adequate with perishable/nonperishable food supplies. The trash can has a tight lid on. Medication/laundry room: There is a washer and dryer. Detergents are stored inside the locked cabinets. The medication is kept locked at all times and only staff administering medications have access to the medications. Medication/laundry room is kept locked at all times. Garage: The garage can be accessed through the inside of the house and has been converted into a gym/art room. There are several pieces of gym equipment available for client use. There is also a refrigerator/freeze used to store extra food. Backyard: There is an outdoor seating area as well as a table with six (6) chairs. LPA also observed a cover over the pool and the jacuzzi is empty. The home has a first aid kit stored inside a cabinet in the kitchen. The facility has a total of five fire extinguishers which are all full. Report Continued on LIC 809-C.

Facility is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps and open porches are unobstructed. Swimming pools, hot tubs, spas, or similar bodies of water in facilities serving children are made inaccessible to clients. Disinfectants/cleaning solutions and poisons inaccessible to clients. Temperatures in rooms that clients occupy are maintained between 68 and 85 degrees (F). Hot water temperatures is maintained between 105 and 120 degrees (F). All knives and sharp objects are made inaccessible to the clients in care locked in a security box that is stored inside staff office #2 upstairs. Chef logs out the knives when they will be used. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide are operable. Children in care are supervised & protected at all times. Facility has non-perishable foods for one week and perishable foods for two days. Medications locked and accessible only to employees supervising stored medications. Children not restricted in telephone use except by court order. Children accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Children live in a safe, healthy, comfortable facility and are treated with respect. Children can contact the licensing agency or foster Care Ombudsperson in confidence without threats or punishments for making complaints. Children attend school, extracurricular, cultural and personal enrichment activities. Facility maintains client cash resources, personal property and valuables. LPA unable to review Children’s records at this time due to nature of visit being conducted virtually. Children and staff files will be reviewed at a later date. Adults working/residing in the facility have DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances. Adults working/residing in the facility have Child Abuse Index Checks. Facility operates within license conditions & limitations including capacity limitations. There were no deficiencies cited at this time of the visit. Exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to Facility Manager.

It was noted in the facility’s program statement that staff are to ensure that the clients keep the bathroom door ajar when using the restroom. Minors are not allowed hygiene items Confidential interviews revealed conflicting statements regarding whether clients are not allowed hygiene items. Interview information revealed that clients are given hygiene boxes that contain toothbrush, toothpaste, soap, shampoo, conditioner, deodorant, lotion, and other products which are available when the clients request them. Confidential interviews stated that clients are provided razors to shave but under the supervision of staff. It was noted in the facility’s program statement that staff can withhold hygiene items from clients and provide them upon the request of the client depending on the client’s level. Staff open minors’ personal mail Confidential interviews indicated that the therapist keep all mail, unopened until the clients’ next one-on-one therapy sessions. It was also disclosed that clients are required to open their letters in front of staff to make sure there is no contraband and confirmed that staff do not open clients’ mails. Other confidential witnesses were unaware of the mail process and could not speak to this allegation. Some confidential witnesses stated that the clients open their personal mail in front of staff, and others stated the clients’ primary therapists open their mail for them to screen letters and packages for contraband or triggering content. Minors not receiving an allowance Confidential interviews revealed that none of the minors received allowance during their residency at this Group Home. Per Facility Representative(s), the purpose of not providing clients allowance was to reduce the ability of incoming contraband. Facility Representative(s) also indicated that clients did not have a need for allowance as the Program provide the necessities for clients. Confidential interviews revealed that although allowance is not given, the facility provide for clients’ needs which includes items while on outings. Minors are denied access to personal property Confidential interviews revealed that clients are denied personal property based on scheduled activities and for their safety. Some personal items are stored locked in a cabinet and made available to clients upon request. Per Facility Representative(s) some items such as razors require direct supervision, while other personal items (such as books, clothing and etc.) are not allowed to be possessed by clients because the item could trigger client’s behaviors or jeopardize their safety while in treatment

Based on the confidential interviews, observation, and record review, it has been determined that although the allegations that minors are not treated with dignity; minors are not allowed hygiene items; staff open minors’ personal mail, minors not receiving an allowance, and minors being denied access to personal belongings may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. The program statement has been updated to ensure that the clients’ needs will be met based on their individual assessments per Title 22 Group Home Regulations. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was provided to Devorah Weiss.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olivia Rosas made an announced inspection to the Evolve Treatment, Calabasas on 12/16/21 at 9:00am for the purpose of conducting Annual Inspection. The Evolve Treatment, Calabasas is a therapeutic treatment program that’s designed to accept “Private Placement's” for a length of 30 - 45 days and is licensed to provide care supervision for six (6) youths, ages 12-17 years; ambulatory only. Individuals mention in this report are identify on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated 12/16/21. On August, 5, 2021 the Department received a Unusual Incident/Injury Report (LIC624) reporting that several employees tasted positive for COVID and due to various unvaccinated employees needing to quarantine per Cal-OSHA guidelines, this facility did not have enough staff to continue serving clients. The clients that were in placement one (1) was discharged and two (2) clients were transferred to Evolve Agoura with the full permission and acquiescence of their caregivers for continuing of care. Due to the lack of staff and not having a administrator the Evolve Treatment, Calabasas will be closed till further notice. Upon the facility obtaining new staff, and administrator the facility will notify the Department. LPA Rosas was not able to complete Annual inspection due to facility not being in operation. LPA Rosas discussed with and advised when the facility reopens, if any changes or modifications to the program or facility physical plant need to be submitted to the Department for review and approval before implementing the new changes or reopening. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

C1 reported, not waiting to eat, and was taken to be assessed. C1 was medically assessed and medically clear to return to treatment. On 08/30/022, C1 faint during beach outing. C1 was taken to Urgent Care and completed lab work and vital signs. C1 was assessed by Urgent Care and prescribed medication. Based on the interviews conducted and documentation gather no further information is needed. LPA Rosas interviewed C1 and obtained discharge summaries of Urgent Care and Emergency Room visits. CCLD has determined that there has been no violation in the SIR. LPA observed adequate perishable/nonperishable food supplies. Facility has Administrative Facility Waiver on file. A review of Facility's Personnel Report Summary on 09/08/2022 indicates that all personnel have criminal record clearance has obtain the necessary clearances with DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse Response. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

On December 12, 2023 at 9:37am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson made an announced inspection to the Evolve Treatment, Calabasas for the purpose of conducting a 2-Year Annual Inspection. The Evolve Treatment, Calabasas is a therapeutic treatment program that’s designed to accept “Private Placement's” for a length of 30 - 45 days and is licensed to provide care supervision for six (6) youths, ages 12-17 years; ambulatory only. There is a swimming pool which meets licensing regulations. There is a camera and Naloxone waiver on file. This is a two-story facility located at 423 Woodbluff Road in Monte Nido California. LPA Wilson was greeted by staff (S1) who allowed entrance into the facility. At 9:59am, LPA Wilson was greeted by the Operations Manager (OM) who provided LPA with a tour of the facility. Individuals mentioned in this report are identified on the Confidential Names List [see LIC811 dated 12/12/2023.] LPA Wilson observed the second story: There are 7 smoke detectors 2 carbon monoxide detectors. Thermostat 63 degrees. Water temperature averaged between 100-105 degrees. Staff Office 1: This large area has three (3) desks for Operations Manager, Nurse and staff use. There is a full bathroom with large tub, sink and toilet. The sharps log is kept here and filled out by chef staff. In the storage area, there are client files over 5 years additional hygiene supplies and emergency supplies, bottled water, emergency and first aid kits, fire extinguishers and smoke alarm. All fire extinguishers were inspected in November of 2023. Postings observed by LPA were, Facility license, staff contact information. program schedule, hot line emergency numbers Covid information, waiver on file, facility sketch, evacuation plan, LIC610C, and weekly drills posted on calendar. Accreditation is current (CARF) Bedroom 1 Is unoccupied. There is a smoke alarm, twin bed, closet and two (2) cabinets. Bedroom 2 is occupied by (C3). There is a smoke alarm, two (2) twin beds, closet and two (2) cabinets. (continued on 809C page 2)

Page 2 Hallway closet with clean bed linens Bedroom 3 is occupied by (C1). There is a smoke alarm, two (2) twin beds, closet and two (2) cabinets. There are cabinets with clean bathroom towels. Bedroom 4: is occupied by (C2)There is a smoke alarm, two (2) twin beds, closet and two (2) cabinets. There are locked hygeine products for each client in client boxes, telephone and books LPA Wilson observed the first story: 10:03am Education Area: Has three (3) desks and round table and six (6) chairs Group Room Area: For group theraputic services Office 2: Clinical Directors Office has a smoke alarm Office 3: Therapist Office has one (1) on suite bathroom and smoke alarm Supply Closet: contains cleaning supplies and is locked. Client Bathroom: There is a client restroom with sink and toilet. 11:00am Garage: has gym equipment table for crafts , closet with water heater and fire extinguisher telephone Outdoor Area: Clean and free of debris and hazards. Therapists Office: has one desk, couch and smoke detector and separate heating/cooling HVAC Facility Vehicle: 2018 Toyota Sienna Current vehicle registration and insurance with Ace Company and Property and Casualty dated to expire on 12/20/2023. There is a 5ft perimeter fence. There are outdoor couches (3) for 8 persons and table with 6 chairs, pool equipment in storage box grill pool key in lock box 11:12am Laundry Room: medications stored here PRN kept in a locked cabinet individual packets controlled medications are double locked. There is a medication dispensary room with nursing, school and art supplies, fire extinguisher and personal cubbies. Living room: This is a large space with furniture for six (6) persons, TV Fireplace unused and decorated for Christmas (continued on 809C page 3)

Page 3 Kitchen: Table with six (6) chairs Cooking island, telephone, covered trashcans. Refrigerator is set at 40 degrees.Pantry has 2 weeks non perishable food and first aid kit. There is a sink, stove with six (6) burners and grill, Instapot, toaster, two (2) microwave ovens and dishwasher all in good repair. Client refrigerator with snacks available and fresh fruit on top. LPA Wilson reviewed following during the inspection: LPA Wilson requested the following forms for review, Register of Youth (LIC 9020), which was created during the time of the inspection, Personnel Report (LIC 500), Emergency Disaster Plan (LIC610C), Emergency Intervention Plan, vehicles registration and auto insurance. In addition, written menus, staff weekly schedule. Current Census is (3) residents, Staff Records Review: LPA ensured Administrator Certificate was current. LPA reviewed the Personnel Report (LIC 500) and confirmed that Direct Care Staff Ratio present for the three (3) clients in placement. LPA confirmed that all staff have required criminal record clearance. DOJ, FBI and Child Abuse Response, which meet qualification. LPA Wilson was able to complete three (3) staff file reviews (S1, S5, FA), one (1) client file review (C2), one (1) staff interview (OM) and one (1) client interview (C2) A review of Facility's Personnel Report Summary on 12/11/2023 indicates that all personnel have criminal record clearance and have obtained the necessary clearances with DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse Response. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with staff (OM) and a copy of this report was emailed to the facility.

On 09/19/2024 at 09:59 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson made and unannounced visit to the above listed facility in order to conduct a case management incident inspection, regarding SIR dated 09/01/24. During the course of the incident investigation, it was revealed that on 9/1/24 the youth (C1) was encouraged to use an Ice-Dive TIPP skill to help regulate their behaviors. LPA Wilson interviewed clients (C1, C2, C3 and C4) as well as the Operations Manger (OM) Client did do an ice dive. The client had no safety or personal rights concerns. LPA Wilson inspected (2) bathrooms with Maintenance Technician (MT) regarding client concerns over mold, which no mold was observed by LPA. There are no deficiencies at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeals rights were discussed and left with licensee Operations Manger (OM) whose signature on this form confirm receipt of these documents.

On November 18, 2024 at 9:27 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson made an unannounced visit to the above listed facility, in order to conduct a case management incident inspection, regarding SIR dated 11/06/24. During the course of the incident investigation, it was revealed that on 11/06/24; due to the Malibu fires, SoCal power pre-emptively turned off all power in this region. The decision was made to move all clients; six (6) from the Calabasas facility and six (6) from the Agoura facility to the Evolve Aura location in Tarzana, which had three (3) clients in care. The number of clients (12) total; did not return to their homes until 11/08/24 which resulted in the licensee not operating in accordance with the Emergency Disaster Plan terms specified in the Plan of Operation. Further, due to the number of clients (15) total; there was not sufficient accommodations, furnishings and equipment to meet clients needs. A (2) deficiency Type A has been determined at this time. The following deficiencies have been cited. (See LIC 809D) An exit interview was conducted and Plans of Correction was developed and reviewed with the licensee. A copy of this report and appeals rights were discussed and left with licensee. (S1) whose signature on this report confirms receipt.

Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Madeleine Fremont and AmyLe Tran conducted an announced inspection of the facility on 12/01/2020 at 1:30 PM. Due to COVID-19 restrictions LPAs conducted this inspection via Microsoft Teams. LPA Fremont met with Alexa Boffoli, Administrator and were joined by Evolve Compliance Officer Devorah Weiss The Group Home is licensed to serve six clients, ages 12-17 years old. The current census is 3 ambulatory clients. The purpose of this inspection is to comply with regulatory requirement that a visit is conducted prior to transitioning from a provisional license to a regular license. Adm. took LPAs on a virtual tour of the facility both inside and out. At the time of the inspection there were 3 clients and 8 staff present. This is a split level home, located in Danville, CA. The facility was as follows: 4 client bedrooms (2 single occupancy and 2 double occupancy), observed with adequate lighting and space for clothing. The facility contains 4 bathrooms, one living room, kitchen, dining area, group therapy room, and a study room/classroom. The home also has 4 offices. There is 1 fireplace that is non-operational (gas has been disconnected.) There are 41 cameras in total, 23 inside in common areas and 18 outside. LPAs observed at the time of this inspection, the facility to be clean, safe, and sanitary. The temperature inside the home is 72 degrees Fahrenheit which is in required temperature range. There was sufficient perishable food for two days and nonperishable food for 7 days. An emergency food supply is kept in the kitchen. Toxins and sharps are properly stored. Smoke detectors are in all rooms and hallways and they are all linked, and carbon monoxide detectors are located throughout the home. Fire extinguishers are located in the kitchen, garage, hallway, facility manager's office, and by the front door. The pool is surrounded on all sides by a fence, which has a self-latching closure. Medication is stored in locked cabinets in the nurses’ station.

The Centrally Stored Medication Log and Medication Administration Records were both observed to be in locked cabinets in the nurse's station. 3 first aid kits are located throughout the facility in the nurse's station, kitchen, and emergency bag. Water temperatures of client faucets are as follows: -Kitchen sink: 116.1 -Bathroom 1 sink: 115.5 -Bathroom 2 sink: 115.9 -Bathroom 3 sink: 113.5 -Bathtub: 108.3 -Shower: 107.4 The temperature of the refrigerator was observed to be 30 degrees Fahrenheit and the freezer was set to -0.4 degrees Fahrenheit. Gas shutoff was located in the backyard, and water shutoff was located in the front yard. Amendments to the Program Statement were provided on 5/5/2020 to bring it into compliance. Since then, there have been no concerns or complaints. Currently although the department was unable to conduct an on site comprehensive inspection prior to issuing a permanent license, the facility has had no regulatory complaints regarding the services the Group Home has been providing. LPA Fremont reviewed one current client and one staff members file on 11/23/2020. Group Home Provisional License status will be updated today, 12/01/2020, and a copy of the new license will be sent to Administrator Alexa Boffoli when it is available to be printed. As a result of this visit, there were no title 22 deficiencies observed. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to Alexa Boffoli, Administrator. LPA Fremont requested that a copy of the report be signed and sent back to LPA for the file.

narrative:
At 10:15AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madeleine Fremont initiated an unannounced Required Annual Inspection with Evolve Treatment Center, Danville. LPA Fremont met with Compliance Officer Devorah Weiss, who helped facilitate this inspection. Currently in care are 4 ambulatory clients. One additional client was being admitted at the end of the day. Due to unsafe weather and avoiding interrupting Christmas activities for the clients, LPA Fremont informed the licensee that the inspection of the home's physical plant would take place on a later date. LPA requested the following records to be provided over email for the staff and client records review portion of the inspection: 10 staff records and all client records. Inspection was paused and will be completed after the Christmas Holiday. _________________________________________________________________________ On 12/27/2021 at 12:55AM, LPA Fremont traveled to Evolve Treatment Center, Danville to complete the home's required annual inspection. LPA met with Facility Manager Stacy Guerrero, who helped facilitate this inspection. Currently in care are 4 ambulatory clients. During this inspection, LPA Fremont toured the facility inside and out. The home is a split level home located in Danville, CA. The home had 4 client bedrooms (2 double occupancy; 2 single occupancy), which were all observed with comfortable furnishings and lighting. Each room had more than the required closet/shelf space to store their personal belongings and clothing. The facility contains 4 bathrooms, one of which is located in the staff offices downstairs and is not accessible to clients. (CONTINUED ON LIC809-C)

During this visit, LPA Fremont inspected 10 staff files and 4 client files. All client files were complete with all required documentation. The following staff files were missing the items listed below (see LIC811 - Confidential Names dated 12/27/2021): - S2 - missing TB test - S6 - missing LIC503 Health Screening and TB test - S7 - missing LIC501 Personnel Record - S8 - missing LIC501 Personnel Record, LIC503 Health Screening, TB test - S9 - missing LIC503 Health Screening - S10 - missing LIC503 Health Screening Regarding these missing documents, the licensee was issued two LIC9102 Advisory Notes: 1. For missing documents such as LIC501 and LIC503, the licensee was issued an Advisory Note - Technical Advisory for Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, Section 80066(a)(10) - Personnel Records (please reference LIC9102 - Advisory Note dated 12/24/2021). 2. For missing tuberculosis tests, the licensee was issued an Advisory Note - Technical Advisory for Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, Section 80066(a)(11) - Personnel Records (please reference LIC9102 - Advisory Note dated 12/24/2021). At this time, no deficiencies were cited. Two Advisory Notes were issued to the licensee. An exit interview was conducted, Appeal Rights provided and discussed and a copy of this report was emailed to the licensee, whose signature confirms receipt.

The home has a living room, kitchen, dining room, group therapy room, and study/school room, all of which are comfortably furnished with adequate lighting. The home has 4 staff offices. There is one fireplace located in the school room, which is inoperable (gas disconnected). There are 41 cameras in total on the property - 23 inside in common areas and 18 on the exterior of the home. All camera views have been submitted to and approved by Community Care Licensing to ensure no camera points into a bedroom or bathroom window. LPA Fremont observed the home to be clean, safe, and sanitary. All walkways are unobstructed and free of debris. The thermostat was set to 71 degrees. In the kitchen, LPA observed at least 2 days of perishable food and 7 days of nonperishable food. There is also a variety of snacks available to clients upon request. An emergency food supply is kept in the kitchen. The refrigerator and freezer were set to the proper temperatures, and there is a temperature log on each that staff sign off daily to ensure the proper temperature is maintained. Toxins and sharps are properly stored and inaccessible to clients. There are smoke detectors located in all rooms and walkways, and all are operable and linked together (one alarm going off will trigger all others). Carbon monoxide detectors are located throughout the home and are operable. Fire extinguishers are located in the kitchen, garage, hallway, facility manager's office, and all have been inspected and approved by the fire department. The pool is surrounded on all sides by a fence, which has a self-latching closure. Medication is stored in locked cabinets in the nurses’ station. The Centrally Stored Medication Log and Medication Administration Records were both observed to be in locked cabinets in the nurse's station. 3 first aid kits are located throughout the facility in the nurse's station, kitchen, and emergency bag. All faucets which are accessible to clients were observed to be between 108-111 degrees Fahrenheit. The gas shutoff is located in the backyard, and the water shutoff was located in the front of the house. (CONTINUED ON LIC809-C)

Based on records review and interviews with staff and clients that show the facility has been utilizing a 1:6 staff-to-child ratio instead of the 1:3 ratio noted in the Licensee's Plan of Operation, and reports that there was at least one incident when clients were left without staff at the facility for at least 30 minutes during a staff medical emergency, the allegation "Facility does not have adequate staffing" is found to be substantiated. A deficiency was cited per Title 22 Regulations, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 3, Section 80022(k) - Plan of Operation. Please see attached LIC9099-D for details. At this time, one deficiency was cited. An exit interview was conducted with Ms. Hooper, who signed this report. Appeal Rights provided and discussed, and a copy of this report was emailed to Administrator, Devorah Weiss at 12:30 PM.

LPA met with __ in person and Devorah Weiss by telephone, who helped facilitate this inspection. Currently in care are 2 ambulatory clients. On 02/08/2023, the San Jose Children's Residential Program Regional Office received a complaint for Evolve Treatment Centers Walnut Creek with one allegation: "Minors are left without supervision." This complaint was assigned to and investigated by LPA Fremont. Based on records review and interviews with staff and clients that show the facility has been utilizing a 1:6 staff-to-child ratio instead of the 1:3 ratio noted in the Licensee"s Plan of Operation, and reports that there was at least one incident when clients were left without staff at the facility for at least 30 minutes during a staff medical emergency, the allegation "Facility does not have adequate staffing" is found to be substantiated. A deficiency was cited per Title 22 Regulations, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 3, Section 80022(k) - Plan of Operation. Please see attached LIC9099-D for details.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 80022(k) Plan of Operation: The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation and may be cited for not doing so. This requirement was not met as evidenced by:Based on records review and interview with staff and clients, between November 2022 and February 2023, there were several instances where the facility by employed a staff/child ratio of 1:6 instead of the 1:3 ration noted in the Licensee's Plan of Operation. This poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.

narrative: On 12-12-23 10:09, Licensing Program Analysts George Karkazis conducted an unannounced Annual/Random inspection at listed facility. LPA met with Niekachi Nwogu, Clinical Program Director and toured the facility inside and out. The Group Home is licensed to serve 6 clients. Present during the inspection were 6 staff and 3 clients. At 10:15AM LPA Karkazis reviewed client and staff files. All staff and client files are complete and in good order. At 1:00PM, LPA Karkazis toured the facility. LPA Karkazis observed 4 bedrooms and 4 bathrooms. LPA observed facility license, personal rights, facility sketch, meal menu, and other forms posted on the walls throughout the facility. LPA Karkazis tested the water temperature and found it to be 117 degrees which is in range. The thermostat read 68 degrees which is within range. Sharps were locked and chemicals were safely stored. There were two days of perishable foods and seven days non-perishable foods present. The medication was stored and locked in the nurse's office in a locked safe. The facility is in good repair and clean. LPA Karkazis interviewed 4 staff and 2 clients. At 1:20PM LPA Karkazis toured the backyard. There were no open bodies of water. The backyard was in good repair and clean. At this time there were no deficiencies. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed and a copy of this report was given to Niekachi Nwogu, Clinical Program Director.

investigation_findings: 13On 7/17/2025 at 2:45 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina conducted a complaint investigation visit to deliver findings. LPA met with facility nurse Chynna Hooper and explained the purpose of the visit. The Administrator was unavailable; however, the facility nurse was authorized to sign the report. Based on confidential interviews, incident reports, and record reviews, the allegation that the licensee failed to maintain sufficient staff to ensure adequate supervision of minors is SUBSTANTIATED. This violates Title 22, Section 80078(a) – Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision, and Section 84065.5(c) – Staff/Child Ratios. Multiple incidents were noted indicating a need for increased staffing ratios to meet client needs. Although the plan of operation outlines a 1:6 staff-to-client ratio, this was not sufficient to ensure client safety. Please refer to LIC 809-D for additional details. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were discussed, and a copy of this report was provided to facility nurse Chynna Hooper, whose signature below confirms receipt.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision: (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews, observation, and record review the facility did not ensure supervision during a high risk incident which posed an immediate risk to the health, safety, or personal rights of residents in care.

84065.5(c) Staff/Child Ratios: (c) If the children require special care and supervision because of age, problem behavior or other factors, the number of on-duty child care staff shall be increased. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and incident reports the facility failed to increase on-duty child care staff to address clients exhibiting escalated behaviors, including staff assaults and AWOLs. This poses an immediate risk to the health, safety, and personal rights of residents in care.

narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPAs) Madeleine Fremont and Carolyn Flynn conducted an announced inspection of the facility on 11/13/2020 at 1:50 PM. Due to COVID-19 restrictions LPAs conducted this inspection via FaceTime. LPAs Fremont and Flynn met with Jessica Longoria, Administrator. The Group Home is licensed to serve six clients, ages 12-17 years old. The purpose of this inspection is to comply with regulatory requirement that a visit is conducted prior to transitioning from a provisional license to a regular license. Adm took LPAs on a virtual tour of the facility both inside and out. At the time of the inspection there were five clients and seven staff present. This is a two story home, located in the hills of Gilroy. The facility was as follows: three client bedrooms, observed with adequate lighting and space for clothing and equipped with full size beds. The facility contains eight bathrooms (seven in the home and one in pool house), one living room, kitchen, dining area, and a study room/classroom. The home also has four offices. three are used for "counseling, visits, and therapy" areas. There are four fireplaces that are all non-operational (gas has been disconnected.) There are 39 cameras in total, 23 inside in common areas and 16 outside. LPAs observed at the time of this inspection, the facility to be clean, safe, and sanitary. LPAs observed the "Hot Water Log" which documents water temperature weekly. The temperature inside the home is 70 degrees Fahrenheit which is in required temperature range. There was sufficient perishable food for two days and nonperishable food for 7 days. Toxins and sharps are properly stored. Smoke detectors are in all rooms and hallways and they are all linked, and six carbon monoxide detectors are located throughout the home. The pool has a cover that is controlled by a key that only Administrator, Facility Manager and Pool maintenance have, it is strong enough to walk across. The cover is on at all times when the pool and is not in use. Medication is stored in locked cabinets in the nurses’ station which is located on the bottom floor only

accessible to the staff. The Centrally Stored Medication Log and Medication Administration Records were both observed to be in locked cabinets in the nurse's station. Three first aid kits are located throughout the facility with the emergency to go bags, nurses’ station, and a spare in Facility Manager's office. Amendments to the Program Statement were provided on 5/5/2020 to bring it into compliance. Since then, there have been no concerns or complaints. Currently although the department was unable to conduct an on site comprehensive inspection prior to issuing a permanent license. The facility has had no regulatory complaints regarding the services the Group Home has been providing. LPA Flynn reviewed one current client and one staff members file on 11/13/2020. Group Home Provisional License status will be updated today 11/13/2020 to a regular license by LPA Flynn. A copy of the new license will be sent to Jessica Longoria on 11/16/2020. As a result of this visit, there were no title 22 deficiencies observed. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to Jessica Longoria, Administrator. LPA Flynn requested that a copy of the report be signed and sent back to LPA for the file.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carolyn Flynn conducted an unannounced Case Management Visit with Devorah Weiss, Compliance Officer for Evolve Gilroy via Microsoft Teams at 1:00 PM on Tuesday 4/20/2021. The purpose of the visit was to review over the Administrator changes that are being made at the Gilroy location. On April 13, 2021 at 4:24 PM, LPA Flynn received an email informing LPA that Jessica Longoria would not be returning to the Gilroy location when the facility re-opened and that they do have a new program director, which was not named, that is not currently ready and would need to complete the Administrator Course. In the meantime, Evolve would like to have Alexa Boffoli, who is the current Danville Administrator act as the named administrator for Gilroy as well. LPA Flynn agreed and asked that all requirements for Alexa Boffoli be sent to LPA Flynn for review and issue a change of administrator notice. At this time LPA Flynn asked when the Gilroy location would re-open. On April 19, 2021 at 6:13 PM, LPA Flynn received an email from Devorah Weiss, stating that they Gilroy location re-opened on 4/19/2021 and that files for Alexa will be sent on 4/20/2021. LPA Flynn issued a Technical Advisory Note regarding Section 84061 – Reporting Requirements. LPA Flynn requested in writing an update on the status of the changes to the Program Statement, Client Handbook, and Training Material regarding pregnancy testing. These updates were due on April 12, 2021 as per an email date 3/11/20201 at 8:23 AM from Licensing Program Manager (LPM), Saxon Turner sent it to Devorah Weiss, Kelsey Larson, Michelle Gross, and Del Sabzerou all of Evolve and cc’ing LPM Helga Wong. As a result of this visit, there were no title 22 deficiencies observed. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to Devorah Weiss, Compliance Officer. LPA Flynn requested that a copy of the report be signed and sent back to LPA for the file.

met_with: No one present on facility grounds
narrative: At 2PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madi Fremont traveled to Evolve Gilroy to conduct an unannounced Case Management Inspection. LPA did not meet with any staff or other representative of the program. On September 30, 2021, the San Jose Children's Residential Program Regional Office received a letter from Evolve's Compliance Officer, Devorah Weiss. In this letter, Ms. Weiss reported that due to ongoing struggles brought about by the COVID-19 pandemic, the home located at 2560 Butch Drive in Gilroy, CA would be surrendering it's license and closing permanently. The purpose of LPA Fremont's unannounced Case Management Inspection on 10/26/2021 was to confirm that no clients or staff were present on the grounds before the facility is closed permanently in Community Care Licensing's Licensing Information System. LPA walked the grounds of the facility located at 2560 Butch Drive, and did not see any staff or clients present. There were no cars in the driveway, all windows and doors were shut, and there were no lights on in any of the buildings on the property. LPA Fremont confirmed with Licensing Program Managers Helga Wong and Carolyn Flynn that no clients are currently placed at Evolve Gilory, and the facility appears to be closed permanently. No deficiencies observed or cited. This document will not be signed by a facility representative as none were present on the property at the time of this inspection.

AT 9:57AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madi Fremont traveled to Evolve Lafayette to conduct an unannounced Annual Inspection. LPA met with Administrator Brandi Ellis who helped facilitate this inspection. Currently in care are 5 ambulatory clients, all of which were present at the time of this inspection. During this inspection, LPA toured the home inside and out. The home is a 2 story house with 3 bedrooms, all of which are double occupancy. The home also has 5 bathrooms. Client Rights and Grievances were posted inside the front door for the facility. LPA confirmed that the bathroom downstairs off the main living room would remain unlocked for use at all times. The facility was observed to be clean and in good repair. LPA observed COVID-19 signs posted throughout the facility. There was a hand sanitizing station inside the front door. The front door is self latching with a dead bolt lock. There are security alarms on all client bedroom windows, and cameras in the interior and exterior of the home for security. Cleaning supplies, chemicals, and poisons are kept locked and inaccessible to clients. The weekly menu was on display in the kitchen. The home's emergency food supply was observed in the kitchen pantry, as well as dried food. The pantry door will remain locked. LPA observed at least 7 days of nonperishable food and at least 2 days of perishable food in the home. Exit signs were observed over all exit doors. The First Aid kit was observed in the nurse's station and contained all required elements. Laundry detergent is kept locked in a cabinet inside the laundry room. Medications are to be kept locked inside a safe, inside a locked cabinet, in the nurse's station, which will also remain locked. Client hygiene items and extra linens are kept in the hallway by the client bedrooms downstairs. (CONTINUED ON LIC809-C)

All client bedrooms were observed to be clean and furnished with two twin beds each, and ample storage space for client belongings. The downstairs thermostat read 69 degrees Fahrenheit, and the upstairs thermostat read 70 degrees Fahrenheit. LPA measured the water temperature of the kitchen sink, which read 118 degrees Fahrenheit. LPA also measured the water temperature of the downstairs client bathroom sink, which measured 129.9 degrees Fahrenheit. A deficiency was cited per California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 7, Section 80088(e)(1) - Furniture, Fixtures, Equipment, and Supplies. Please see the attached LIC809-D for details. LPA also toured the backyard, and observed a pool with a retractable pool cover, which Administrator Brandi Ellis walked over to show it can support the weight of an adult. The pool cover is controlled by a key. The emergency water and gas shutoffs are located by the facility mailbox. The home backs up to a hill that slopes down from the property, which is bordered by a wooden fence. Fire extinguishers were observed in the gym, in the kitchen, at the top of both sets of stairs, outside the downstairs bathroom, and in the living room downstairs. All were inspected and approved in April, 2021. Smoke/Carbon Monoxide detectors were observed in the kitchen, dining room, in the upstairs therapy offices, and the clinical program director's office downstairs, and at the tops of both sets of stairs, and outside every client bedroom. Primary Therapists office are located upstairs. Exit plans are located at the top of the stairs, outside client bedrooms downstairs, and inside the front door. The home has an upstairs balcony, which will remain locked at all times and is not permitted for client use. All client bathrooms and bedrooms have frosted windows for privacy. The breaker and fuse boxes are located in the facility gym (garage) downstairs. All walkways were free from obstructions. No firearms on the property. LPA inspected 3 client files and 3 staff files, which were all complete with all required elements. At this time, one deficiency was observed and cited. An exit interview was conducted, Appeal Rights provided and discussed, and a copy of this report was emailed to Administrator Brandi Ellis, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

deficiencies.title: - Furniture, Fixtures, Equipment, and Supplies
deficiencies.description: (e) Hot water temperature controls shall be maintained to automatically regulate temperature of hot water delivered to plumbing fixtures used by clients to attain a hot water temperature of not less than 105 degrees F (40.5 degrees C) and not more than 120 degrees F (48.8 degrees C).

narrative: Minors are not treated with dignity Confidential interviews revealed conflicting statements that clients must leave the bathroom door ajar while using the restroom. Some confidential interviews reported that the clients did not have to leave the door open while using the restroom and other interviews stated that clients must leave the bathroom door ajar while using the restroom. It was noted in the facility’s program statement that staff are to ensure that the clients keep the bathroom door ajar when using the restroom. Minors are not allowed hygiene items Confidential interviews revealed conflicting statements regarding whether clients are not allowed hygiene items. Interview information revealed that clients are given hygiene boxes that contain toothbrush, toothpaste, soap, shampoo, conditioner, deodorant, lotion, and other products which are available when the clients request them. Confidential interviews stated that clients are provided razors to shave but under the supervision of staff. It was noted in the facility’s program statement that staff can withhold hygiene items from clients and provide them upon the request of the client depending on the client’s level. Staff open minors’ personal mail Confidential interviews indicated that the therapist keep all mail, unopened until the clients’ next one-on-one therapy sessions. It was also disclosed that clients are required to open their letters in front of staff to make sure there is no contraband and confirmed that staff do not open clients’ mails. Other confidential witnesses were unaware of the mail process and could not speak to this allegation. Some confidential witnesses stated that the clients open their personal mail in front of staff, and others stated the clients’ primary therapists open their mail for them to screen letters and packages for contraband or triggering content. Minors not receiving an allowance Confidential interviews revealed that none of the minors received allowance during their residency at this Group Home. Per Facility Representative(s), the purpose of not providing clients allowance was to reduce the ability of incoming contraband. Facility Representative(s) also indicated that clients did not have a need for allowance as the Program provide the necessities for clients. Confidential interviews revealed that although allowance is not given, the facility provide for clients’ needs which includes items while on outings. Minors are denied access to personal property Confidential interviews revealed that clients are denied personal property based on scheduled activities and for their safety. Some personal items are stored locked in a cabinet and made available to clients upon request. Per Facility Representative(s) some items such as razors require direct supervision, while other personal items (such as books, clothing and etc.) are not allowed to be possessed by clients because the item could trigger client’s behaviors or jeopardize their safety while in treatment Based on the confidential interviews, observation, and record review, it has been determined that although the allegations that minors are not treated with dignity; minors are not allowed hygiene items; staff open minors’ personal mail, minors not receiving an allowance, and minors being denied access to personal belongings may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. The program statement has been updated to ensure that the clients’ needs will be met based on their individual assessments per Title 22 Group Home Regulations. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was provided to Brandi Ellis.

narrative: On 7/27/2023 at 10:40AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood conducted a case management visit to the licensed facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct a case management visit regarding an incident reported to Community Care Licensing (CCL) on 7/26/2023. LPA met with Savannah Sullivan, Operations Manager. Based on the incident report, a client in care had alleged that they had engaged in inappropriate touch with another client and had felt uncomfortable about the incident. LPA requested both client's Needs and Services plans, shift notes from 7/21/2023 and 7/22/2023, contact information for the reporting party, and contact information for on-shift staff members. One of the two clients involved had discharged to their other facility. LPA conducted five confidential interviews. LPA conducted an exit interview with Savannah Sullivan, Operations Manager at 11:50AM.

Based on confidential interviews and record review, the staff was outside the opened door at the time of the incident and the night shift resumed their 15-minute checks starting at 10PM. Based on record review, the facility protocol is to observe by listening during hygiene time and ensure that youth keep their doors open. According to confidential interviews, immediately after being aware of the allegations, the facility staff had separated the two clients involved, conducted support sessions for the clients, and moved one client to another home. The facility had also updated their facility protocol to include visual check-ins during hygiene time. The allegation that staff did not provide supervision when clients have inappropriate sexual behaviors in the facility has met the preponderance of doubt and is therefore substantiated. Based on the staff members following their protocol, and the actions taken by the facility after the incident occurred, LPA did not provide the facility with a citation. LPA conducted an exit interview with Elijah Aquilina, Residential Counselor at 11:50AM whose signature confirms the receipt of the document.
investigation_findings: 13On 9/6/2023 at 11:38AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood conducted an unannounced visit to the licensed facility. The purpose of the visit was to deliver the finding for the above allegation. LPA met with Elijah Aquilina, Residential Counselor. LPA initially closed this complaint as unsubstantiated on 8/4/2023. During the course of the investigation, LPA conducted twelve confidential interviews. LPA reviewed C1 and C2's treatment plans, shift notes for 7/21/2023-7/22/2023, incident reports, and facility's program statement. Based on confidential interviews, C1 and C2 did engage in sexual behaviors in the facility. Based on confidential interviews, three of the four interviewed remembered the door being open at the time. The same three interviewees had stated that the interaction happened in about 15-minutes. Based on confidential interviews, the sexual behavior happened during "hygiene" time between 9-10PM before the 15-minute checks are conducted between 10PM-6AM.

On March 27, 2025, at 11:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the above-referenced facility to follow up on a submitted Incident Report (IR). LPA met with Renee Nunes, Clinical Program Director. At the time of the visit, seven staff members and five clients were present. During the inspection, LPA interviewed the Program Director to obtain additional details regarding the incident and to clarify updates in the incident report. LPA verified that proper follow-up procedures were conducted through a review of shift notes and interviews. The IR was submitted regarding an incident that occurred on March 6, 2025. According to the report, (C1) experienced suicidal ideations and jumped from a staircase inside the facility. The Program Director explained that C1 became upset after being denied a home pass. At the time of the incident, C1 had only been at the facility for one week and was not yet eligible for a pass. While a risk assessment was being conducted, C1 suddenly got up without warning and ran toward the staircase. LPA confirmed that proper procedures were followed both before and after the incident. Prior to the jump, the county mobile crisis team (A3) had been contacted and was in route, as C1 was not complying with the established safety plan. During the visit, the Program Director provided LPA with copies of the safety plan and risk assessment for review. After the jump, staff promptly assessed C1’s injuries and ensured that the client remained in place until emergency medical services (EMS) arrived. Due to C1’s behaviors, a higher-level treatment facility was deemed necessary, and C1 has not returned to the facility. No violations of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6 were cited during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Renee Nunes, Clinical Program Director.

On August 12, 2025, at 2:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the above-referenced facility to follow up on a submitted Incident Report (IR). LPA met with Alisa Anhold-Tung, Primary Therapist. At the time of the visit, eight staff members and five clients were present. During the inspection, LPA interviewed the Primary Therapist to obtain additional details regarding the incident and to clarify updates in the incident report. LPA verified that proper follow-up procedures were conducted through a review of shift notes and interviews. The IR was submitted regarding an incident that occurred on August 5, 2025. According to the report, staff discovered a napkin containing an unknown pill in the therapist’s bathroom. Through confidential interviews, it was learned that a pill matching the one found in the therapist’s bathroom was also discovered in a client’s pants pocket along with THC vape pen. Interviews further revealed that clients have access to the therapist’s bathroom either before or after a session, or when other bathrooms are occupied. As a follow-up to the incident, the home will continue to conduct body and drug checks on the suspected client. Immediately after the initial discovery, staff conducted a full house sweep and body checks, which led to the discovery of a matching individual pill in one of the clients’ bathrooms. Through confidential client interviews, no one was able to confirm the identity of the pills. The suspected client was not present at the time of the visit. No violations of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, were cited during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Alisa Anhold-Tung, Primary Therapist.

investigation_findings: 13On 12/02/2021 at 11:15AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madeleine Fremont arrived at the facility to deliver the findings of a complaint investigation. LPA Fremont met with Administrator Taylor Culbertson and discussed the investigative findings. On June 7, 2021, the Department received a complaint alleging minors are not treated with dignity; minors are not allowed hygiene items; staff open minors' personal mail; minors are not receiving an allowance; minors are being denied access to personal property. Confidential interviews were conducted with 5 staff and 4 of 6 clients. Facility’s Program Statement, Plan of Operation, Parent Handbook and Training Manual were reviewed. The following information was obtained during the course of the investigation: (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

narrative: Of the 5 clients that were interviewed regarding these allegations, all 5 clients stated they were given sufficient time for showering and personal/hygiene care. All clients reported that they were allowed more time for showering and hygiene based on their progress in the program, but that even at the minimum amount of hygiene time allotted after admission was enough time to complete their hygiene routine. Both staff who were interviewed reiterated this, reporting that even if the kids ran out of time in the bathroom, they were still given time outside of the bathroom with a vanity mirror to complete any hygiene tasks they had left. Of the 5 clients who were interviewed regarding these allegations, all 5 clients reported to this agency that they felt safe at Evolve, they had staff they were comfortable confiding in if needed, and that none of them had experienced any sort of sexual harassment from staff or other clients during their stay. All clients interviewed stated that supervision was heavily enforced and that they were never out of sight from staff, except when using the bathroom or showering. This agency has investigated the allegations (1) "Minor sexually harasses another minor;" and (2) "Minor not afforded sufficient time to perform personal care," and has found that although these allegations may be true or are valid, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated, based on LPA's inability to contact the clients named in the original complaint at the time it was received. At this time, no deficiencies are observed or cited. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to Administrator Taylor Culbertson and Regional Nurse Ieshaa Ragland, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.
investigation_findings: 13At 12:30PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madi Fremont traveled to the home above for the purpose of conducting an unannounced complaint investigation inspection. LPA met with Regional Nurse Ieshaa Ragland, who helped facilitate this inspection. Currently in care are 7 ambulatory clients. (1 client was admitted this morning, and one client was discharged this afternoon. On 11/03/2021, the San Jose Children's Residential Program Regional Office received a complaint for Evolve Walnut Creek with two allegations: (1) "Minor sexually harasses another minor;" and (2) "Minor not afforded sufficient time to perform personal care." This complaint was investigated by LPAs Christopher Rollins and Madi Fremont. Over the course of this investigation, LPAs conducted interviews with 2 staff and 5 clients. LPA Fremont also attempted to interview all 6 clients who were present in the facility at the time this agency received this complaint, but was unsuccessful in making contact with any of those 6 clients. (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

13At 9:45AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madi Fremont traveled to the home above for the purpose of conducting an unannounced complaint investigation inspection. LPA met with Chloe Jimenez in person and Devorah Weiss by telephone, who helped facilitate this inspection. Currently in care are 3 ambulatory clients. On 02/08/2023, the San Jose Children's Residential Program Regional Office received a complaint for Evolve Treatment Centers Walnut Creek with one allegation: "Facility does not have adequate staffing." This complaint was assigned to and investigated by LPA Fremont. Based on records review and interviews with staff and clients that show the facility has been utilizing a 1:6 staff-to-child ratio instead of the 1:3 ratio noted in the Licensee"s Plan of Operation, and reports that there was at least one incident when clients were left without staff at the facility for at least 30 minutes during a staff medical emergency, the allegation "Facility does not have adequate staffing" is found to be substantiated. A deficiency was cited per Title 22 Regulations, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 3, Section 80022(k) - Plan of Operation. Please see attached LIC9099-D for details. At this time, one deficiency was cited. An exit interview was conducted, Appeal Rights provided and discussed, and a copy of this report was emailed to Devorah Weiss and Chloe Jimenez, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 80022(k) Plan of Operation: The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation and may be cited for not doing so. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on records review and interviews with staff and clients, between November 2022 and February 2023, there were several instances where the facility by employed a staff/child ratio of 1:6 instead of the 1:3 ration noted in the Licensee's Plan of Operation. This poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.

narrative: On 10/30/2023 at 2:17PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood conducted an unannounced visit to the licensed facility. LPA was conducting an unrelated visit to the facility and was informed about an incident that occurred on 10/28/2023 where a neighbor had pointed a gun at the youth in care. LPA met with Savannah Sullivan, Operations Manager who helped facilitate the inspection. LPA conducted twelve confidential interviews. LPA requested copies of the staff schedule, daily notes, incident report, Needs and Services Plans, C1's face sheet, staff contact information, and security camera footage. At this time, further information is necessary. LPA conducted an exit interview with Savannah Sullivan, Operations Manager at 2:48PM whose signature confirms the receipt of this document.

According to seven confidential interviews and record review, the staff members on shift had separated the other clients in care from the one client that was having a behavioral episode (C1). According to these interviews, one staff member maintained engagement with C1 during this episode. According to record review and confidential interviews, the staff member working with C1 had called law enforcement when they had lost sight of the client. LPA was unable to interview C1 as they were hospitalized and then placed on long-term respite care. Based on two confidential interviews, the two interviewees relayed they did not have concerns with the facility's supervisory level of C1. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the clients in care were adequately supervised during the reported incident. The allegation that staff did not provide supervision of the clients to ensure health and safety in the facility may or may not have happened; however, it has not met the preponderance of doubt and is therefore unsubstantiated. LPA conducted an exit interview at 12:33PM over the phone with Devorah Weiss, Compliance Office. Compliance Officer approved that Candace Cruz, Senior Primary Therapist sign off on the report.
investigation_findings: 13On 12/13/2023 at 11:55AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood conducted an unannounced visit to the licensed facility. The purpose of this visit was to deliver the findings for the listed allegation. LPA met with Candice Cruz, Senior Primary Therapist. During the course of the investigation, LPA conducted sixteen interviews from October 30, 2023 to December 12, 2023. LPA reviewed C1's Needs and Service Plan, shift notes, staff schedule, and the Contra Costa County Sheriff's Office police report. Based on the record review of the staff schedule, the facility had two staff for six clients which was within ratio based on the facility's program statement. According to record review of the police report, law enforcement received an emergency call informing them that a client had eloped from the facility after a behavioral episode involving aggressive behavior and property damage.

Facility is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps and open porches are unobstructed. Swimming pools, hot tubs, spas, or similar bodies of water in facilities serving children are made inaccessible to clients. Disinfectants/cleaning solutions and poisons inaccessible to clients. Temperatures in rooms that clients occupy are maintained between 68 and 85 degrees (F). Hot water temperatures were not maintained between 105 and 120 degrees (F), hot water measured at 103 degrees. Facility Manager stated water will be adjusted today. Children in care are supervised & protected at all times. Facility has non-perishable foods for one week and perishable foods for two days. Medications locked and accessible only to employees supervising stored medications. Children not restricted in telephone use except by court order. Children accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Children live in a safe, healthy, comfortable facility and are treated with respect. Children can contact the licensing agency or foster Care Ombudsperson in confidence without threats or punishments for making complaints. Children attend school, extracurricular, cultural and personal enrichment activities. Facility maintains client cash resources, personal property and valuables. The Evolve Treatment, Vanalden is a therapeutic treatment program that’s designed to accept “Private Placement's” for a length of 30 - 45 days and is licensed to provide care supervision for six (6) youths, ages 12-17 years; ambulatory only. LPA observed ample perishable food items in the refrigerator and the pantry is fully stocked with non-perishable food items. The garage is being used as a gym and extra food storage. The garage has extra refrigerator and non-perishable food items. The Laundry room: The laundry room is enclosed adjacent to the kitchen. The laundry detergent is distributed to children individually according to the load of their laundry. Cleaning solutions and detergent are kept locked inside the cabinets. Medication Closet Area: Is located next to the kitchen and above the washer and dryer. The cabinet is used to store and administer client medications. All medication is locked and accessible only to employees supervising stored medications. Dinning Area: There is a table with ten (10) chairs. There is also a covered fire place and a mounted TV. Family Room: There is ample seating space with one sofa and three (3) sofa chairs, mounted TV and covered fireplace. There is also a sliding door to exit out in the yard. Art Room and School Room: Are located to the right once entering the facility with ample seating space, desks, and computers. Therapy Rooms: There is a total of three (3) therapy rooms. One is located next to the meds/laundry area, the other one is located next to the staff office and the third therapy room is located outside in the back yard. LIC 809-C Page 1 of 3

Backyard: There is a converted club house that is used as a therapy room. There is barbecue area with a grill. LPA also observed an outdoor seat area available for clients to use, one round table with chairs all around. The facility has a pool with a fence that is at least five feet high and has a fence does not obscure the pool from view. LPA Rosas and S1, observed the gate door to swing away from the pool, with self-close and self-latching device located no more than six inches from the top of the gate. The outdoor perimeter front yard, side yard and backyard were inspected and found cleared of debris and hazards materials. The passageways and porches are unobstructed. The facility has a first aid kit stored inside a locked cabinet in the medication/laundry area. The facility has a total of four fire extinguishers. One of the fire extinguishers is located in the kitchen area fully charged and the other fire extinguisher is mounted to the wall between the kitchen and dinning room. Fire extinguisher #3 is located across from bedroom #2 mounted to the wall. Fire extinguisher #4 is located in the group room. Disinfectants and poisons are inaccessible to the clients in care they are kept locked at all times. All knives and sharp objects are made inaccessible to the clients in care locked in a security box inside the locked cabinets in the family room. All posting requirements were met, (food menu, regulations, licenses, emergency disaster plan, Children’s Personal Rights, and Ombudsman). The facility has a working telephone and youths can use the telephone unless restricted by court order. The Facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. Facility has a current, written plan of operation. Facility personnel are instructed to report violations of personal rights. Licensee will report changes in the plan of operation affecting service to youths. Licensee will report youth injuries requiring medical treatment. A review of Facility's Personnel Report Summary on 11/29/2021 indicates that all personnel have criminal record clearance has obtain the necessary clearances with DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse Response. LPA Rosas was not able to review client or staff files during this visit and will return to continue with the annual inspection. The facility keeps files and documents in digital system called KIPUERM. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

Minors are not allowed hygiene items Confidential interviews revealed conflicting statements regarding whether clients are not allowed hygiene items. Interview information revealed that clients are given hygiene boxes that contain toothbrush, toothpaste, soap, shampoo, conditioner, deodorant, lotion, and other products which are available when the clients request them. Confidential interviews stated that clients are provided razors to shave but under the supervision of staff. It was noted in the facility’s program statement that staff can withhold hygiene items from clients and provide them upon the request of the client depending on the client’s level. Staff open minors’ personal mail Confidential interviews indicated that the therapist keep all mail, unopened until the clients’ next one-on-one therapy sessions. It was also disclosed that clients are required to open their letters in front of staff to make sure there is no contraband and confirmed that staff do not open clients’ mails. Other confidential witnesses were unaware of the mail process and could not speak to this allegation. Some confidential witnesses stated that the clients open their personal mail in front of staff, and others stated the clients’ primary therapists open their mail for them to screen letters and packages for contraband or triggering content. Minors not receiving an allowance Confidential interviews revealed that none of the minors received allowance during their residency at this Group Home. Per Facility Representative(s), the purpose of not providing clients allowance was to reduce the ability of incoming contraband. Facility Representative(s) also indicated that clients did not have a need for allowance as the Program provide the necessities for clients. Confidential interviews revealed that although allowance is not given, the facility provide for clients’ needs which includes items while on outings. Minors are denied access to personal property Confidential interviews revealed that clients are denied personal property based on scheduled activities and for their safety. Some personal items are stored locked in a cabinet and made available to clients upon request. Per Facility Representative(s) some items such as razors require direct supervision, while other personal items (such as books, clothing and etc.) are not allowed to be possessed by clients because the item could trigger client’s behaviors or jeopardize their safety while in treatment

Based on the confidential interviews, observation, and record review, it has been determined that although the allegations that minors are not treated with dignity; minors are not allowed hygiene items; staff open minors’ personal mail, minors not receiving an allowance, and minors being denied access to personal belongings may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. The program statement has been updated to ensure that the clients’ needs will be met based on their individual assessments per Title 22 Group Home Regulations. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was provided to Devorah Weiss.
investigation_findings: 13On 12/02/2021 at 10:35 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Miguel Gomez arrived at the facility to deliver the findings of a complaint investigation. On June 7, 2021, the Department received a complaint alleging minors are not treated with dignity; minors are not allowed hygiene items; staff open minors' personal mail; minors are not receiving an allowance; minors are being denied access to personal property. Confidential interviews were conducted with 3 staff and 5 of 6 clients. Facility’s Program Statement, Plan of Operation, Parent Handbook and Training Manual were reviewed. The following information was obtained during the course of the investigation: Minors are not treated with dignity Confidential interviews revealed conflicting statements that clients must leave the bathroom door ajar while using the restroom. Some confidential interviews reported that the clients did not have to leave the door open while using the restroom and other interviews stated that clients must leave the bathroom door ajar while using the restroom. It was noted in the facility’s program statement that staff are to ensure that the clients keep the bathroom door ajar when using the restroom.
