On July 24, 2024 at 2:35pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson made an unannounced Case Management Incident Inspection to the above listed facility, regarding SIR dated 07/18/24. LPA was greeted by the Facility Nurse (FN). During the course of the incident investigation, it was revealed that on 07/18/24, staff (S1) had provided client (C1) a double dosage of medication acetaminophen. Per (FN) it was mistaken for Ibuprofen and the facility's Medical Director provides the general recommended dosages for acetaminophen. LPA Wilson inspected the MAR in Kipu, which was recorded according to regulations. LPA Wilson interviewed (FN). The licensee ensured staff was re-trained, new visuals and rules were posted in the office where medications were passed (photos taken). A Technical Violation was issued. An exit interview was conducted and report left with licensee. (FN) whose signature on this form confirm receipt of these documents.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kevin Sauk arrived at the above facility, for the purpose of conducting a Required Annual inspection. Due to the Coronavirus Outbreak, conducted a virtual inspection via Microsoft Teams, at 10:00am, with the Facility Administrator (FA), Compliance Officer (CO), and the Facility Manager (FM), who granted access into the facility, and who provided a tour of the entire physical plant inside and out. The Licensee provides care and supervision to six, ambulatory only children, ages 12-17 years old. General overview: The is a 4 bedroom (2 single occupancy, and 2 dual occupancy), 8 bathrooms, elegantly furnished two-story home with a one program director's office, one facility manager's office (which was converted from the Master Bedroom, and located on the 2nd floor), 1 therapist office located in the home, and 1 therapist office located in a detached guest house in the backyard, a living room, dining room, kitchen, family room, garage (used as a gym), laundry area, and a large entertainer's backyard. There are 23 facility cameras on the premises, and an approved Camera Waiver on file. There are no security bars on the windows. There are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the home. Medicines are inaccessible to children. All smoke detectors were tested and are operating properly in the home at the time of visit. Carbon Monoxide alarms, were observed and functional in the home at the time of the visit. There are numerous fully charged fire extinguishers available. Outdoor activity space free of obstructions. Water temperature measured within safe temperatures. First aid kits were checked and complete with scissors, tweezers, thermometer, gauzes, antiseptic and 1st Aid Manual. All posting requirements for the Licensee’s Foster Care License have been met. The Group Home license was observed in the Facility Manager's office, located on the second floor; this license shall be posted, instead, in a more prominent, publicly accessible location in the facility. There are covered fireplaces in the home where the key for the gas is locked in the nurses station. 1st Floor: The first level of the home includes the following: LPA observed a carbon monoxide detector in the hallway. 1/2 bathroom: immediately adjacent the front door entrance, and observed to be clean and in good repair. (Continued on LIC809-C, page 2)

(Continued from LIC809, page 1) Laundry area: equipped with a washer and dryer, the electrical panel, a fully charged fire extinguisher, and plenty of cabinet space. Therapist office: equipped with a full bathroom, desk, computer, couch, chair, and closet in good repair. Garage: locked except when in use, finished, and converted from 4 garage spaces, equipped with a plenty of locked cabinets for storage, carbon monoxide detector, phone, tread mill, free weight station, machine weight station, table with 8 chairs and art supplies, a refrigerator/freezer, and a wall that closes off the water heater and exit door to the backyard. This exit door to the backyard is locked and accessible only through the backyard and only by staff. Living Room: with a securely covered fireplace with plenty of seating, a fossball table, a TV, and Christmas tree. School area: converted from the home's dining room to be used for school purposes, and equipped with a fully charged fire extinguisher, six desks and chairs, and two computers. Program Director's Office: locked for authorized staff only, and equipped with a phone, a printer, a sitting area with views to the backyard, a door that has direct access to a locked Nurse's station. Nurse's station: adjacent to and direct access from the Program Director's office, and the kitchen. The station was converted from the "Butler's Pantry". It is equipped plenty of cabinet space (some with locks) to store emergency foods, first-aid kit, medical supplies, over-the-counter medication, and a separate portable lockbox to store prescription medication. Another lockbox was observed, which will be used for medication requiring refrigeration. Kitchen: equipped with a refrigerator/freezer, dual oven, a functional 6 burner gas range stove, and plenty of cabinet space. Knives / Sharp objects are stored in a locked drawer space. Chemicals and cleaning solutions are kept in locked cabinets under the sink. Another sink is observed in the kitchen island, where a functional electric 2-burner stove is stationed as well. One of the cabinets has a barbeque grill with exhaust that probably won't be used by the chef. A microwave, dishwasher, toaster oven, and coffee pot were also observed. A weekly menu was posted in the kitchen. The perishable and non-perishable foods were in short supply, and should have at least 2 days of perishable foods, as well as 7 days of non-perishable foods on hand at the facility at all times. Breakfast area: equipped with a round table with 8 chairs, and bay windows. Elevator: non-functional, will not at all be in use or operational, observed to be empty, locked, and equipped with a gate and a disconnected phone. (Continued on LIC809-C, page 3)

(Continued from LIC809-C, page 2) Family Room: utilized as a group therapy room equipped with a tv, eight chairs situated in a circle, a portable closet where games will be stored, a weekly activity schedule posted, and a secure cover on the gas fireplace. This room has an exit into the backyard. Closet: (under the stairs) used for storage of cleaning supplies, and client luggage. The entrance of the home opens up into a grand foyer and a circular staircase. Atop the staircase, a wall that has been built per Joint Commission's request, which was observed with a door that has a lock only on the staircase side of the door; this door can always be opened from the inside. LPA also observed locks on the outside of all three bedroom doors (located on the 2nd floor), which can always be opened from the inside. 2nd Floor: The second level of the home includes the following: Fully charged fire extinguisher observed on top of the staircase. Extra linens are kept in cabinets in the hallway outside of the bedrooms. Facility Manager's office: which has been converted from the home's master bedroom, is equipped with a sitting area, covered fireplace, a full bathroom that has a sauna, and equipped with a large locked walk-in closet which will be used to store client files, and other supplies. Two closet doors were observed; one to the elevator equipment, and one to a camera system where the screen displays the view of all 23 cameras. 4 bedrooms observed to each have its own bathroom, and with sufficient lighting, drawer and closet space, comfortable mattresses, and clean lines, blankets, and pillows. Bedroom # 1– adjacent to the Facility Manager's office, and has a door that is connected to the Facility Manager's office, which will remain locked at all times. This bedroom has no windows, but has access to a large full bathroom that has plenty of windows with a view to the backyard. This bedroom is currently vacant, and equipped with a separate thermostat, two twin beds, and no closet, but plenty of dresser space. Bedroom # 2 – adjacent to Bedroom #1, is equipped with a full bathroom, and two twin beds, where client (C1) currently sleeps. [See Confidential Names form (LIC811), dated 12/08/2020, for names] Bedroom # 3 – adjacent to Bedroom #2, is equipped with a full bathroom, and one twin bed, where client (C2) currently sleeps. [See Confidential Names form (LIC811), dated 12/08/2020, for names] Bedroom # 4 – adjacent to Bedroom #3, is currently vacant, and equipped with a full bathroom, and one twin bed. (Continued on LIC812-C, page 4)

(Continued from LIC809-C, page 3) The Exterior consists of the following: POOL: Located in the backyard, there is a fenced and gated pool on the premises that meets regulations. Licensees have installed a guardian pool fence that meets the American Society for Testing and Materials standards. The applicant understands after each use of the pool, the guardian pool fence must be placed back around the pool and secured to ensure inaccessibility to pool. When pool is in use by children, applicants will ensure that individual supervising children in the pool area is Water Safety trained. LPA observed alarms on all doors leading to the pool. The backyard also consists of the following: tennis court with one basketball hoop; an area which will be used as a garden; a grassy area with 2 gazebos; a short concrete bridge that crosses over a shallow, drained waterfall canal, and that empties into a drained pond filled with potted plants; a large detached air conditioned building used as a therapy office equipped with a fully charged fire extinguisher, covered fireplace, smoke alarm, carbon monoxide detector, phone, desk, couch, chair, electrical panel, and 3/4 bathroom. The front yard also had a drained waterfall emptying into a pond, which has been filled with dirt and used as a garden. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Facility Administrator (FA), in order to obtain FA's signature. Signature will be on file.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olivia Rosas made an announced inspection to the Evolve Treatment, Aura on 12/02/21 at 10:00am for the purpose of conducting Annual Inspection. LPA Rosas met with Staff#1(S1) who granted access to the facility and an inspection of the facility was conducted together. The Evolve Treatment, Aura is a therapeutic treatment program that’s designed to accept “Private Placement's” for a length of 30 - 45 days and is licensed to provide care supervision for six (6) youths, ages 12-17 years; ambulatory only. Individuals mention in this report are identify on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated 12/02/21. Temperature and health checks are conducted at the entrance in the sign-in area. The home is set-up as follows and LPA inspected the following: This is a two story home with four (4) bedrooms, eight (8) bathrooms, living room/school room, two (2) therapy rooms, two (2) office rooms, medication room, laundry room, group room, dining area, converted garage (gym), tennis court, and a gated pool. There are 23 facility cameras on the premises, and an approved Camera Waiver on file. There are no security bars on the windows. S1 states that there are no guns or weapons on the premises. There is a pool on the premises that meets regulation requirements. The facility has hand sanitizer dispensers. Living Room/Dining room/Kitchen: LPA observed to be clean and organized; equip with living room furniture including a dining table. There is a stove with five (5) burners all working at this time. There is a detached oven that is also working at this time. There is a microwave and refrigerator/freezer. The sharp knives are kept locked in a lock box located inside the staff office closet upstairs. Some of the cleaning solutions are kept locked under the sink and the rest is stored and locked upstairs in the staff office. The trash cans have tight lids on. LPA observed ample perishable food items in the refrigerator and the pantry is fully stocked with non-perishable food items. LPA observed enough perishable and Non-perishable food items for seven (7) days. The facility provides three (3) nutritious meals, snacks, and special snacks to the youth. All disinfectant/ poisons chemicals are properly stored inaccessible. There is a private chef that comes to the facility and prepares all meals for the youth. Report continues on LIC 809-C Page 1 of 3

Converted Garage: The garage can be entered through the inside of the house using the door that is located to the right once entering the facility and through the laundry room as well. The garage is being used as a gym/art room. The Laundry room: The laundry room is enclosed adjacent to the kitchen. The laundry detergent is distributed to children individually according to the load of their laundry. Cleaning solutions and detergent are kept locked inside the cabinets. Group Room: There is ample seating for clients. Dinning Room: Is located next to the kitchen and there is one round table with nine (9) chairs. Medication Room: This room is located adjacent to the kitchen. The medication room is kept locked and only available to staff supervising and administering client medications. Staff Offices: There is a total on two (2) staff offices. One is located next to the medication room and the other one is located upstairs. Staff office located upstairs has a bathroom, storage, and closet converted to a setting area. The staff office has access to a patio that is kept locked. Therapy Rooms: There is a total of two (2) therapy rooms: One is located next to the laundry room and the other one is located outside in the converted guest room. Bedrooms (upstairs) Bedroom #1: Occupied by two (2) clients, the bedroom is equipped two (2) twin sized beds, comfortable mattresses, with one (1) closet, and one (1) bathroom. Bedroom #2: Occupied by two (2) clients, the bedroom is equipped two (2) twin sized beds, one (1) closet, and one (1) bathroom. Bedroom #3: Occupied by one (1) client, the bedroom is equipped with one (1) twin sized beds, comfortable mattresses, and one (1) closet, and one (1) bathroom. Bedroom #4: Occupied by one (1) client, the bedroom is equipped with one (1) twin sized beds, and one (1) walk in closet, and one (1) bathroom. All bedrooms have adequate lighting, adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting in the room. Bathrooms: Each of the bedrooms have a bathroom. Bathroom #5: Is located to the right once entering the facility. This bathroom is only used by clients. Bathroom #6: Is located inside therapy room #1. Bathroom #7: Is located inside the staff office upstairs and Bathroom #8 is located inside therapy room #2 outside in the guest house. Living Room/School Room: Is located to the right once entering the facility. The living room has ample seating. There is one (1) couch, two (2) sofa chairs, covered fire place and a mounted TV. The school room has desks with chairs and computers for clients to use. Elevator: non-functional or operational, observed to be empty, locked, and equipped with a gate and a disconnected phone. S1 stated they do not plan to use the elevator. Page 2 of 3

Outdoors: There is a converted guest room used as a therapy room. There is propane grill in good condition also observed to be secure and safe. The facility has a pool with a fence that is at least five feet high and has a fence does not obscure the pool from view. LPA Rosas and S1, observed the gate door to swing away from the pool, with self-close and self-latching device located no more than six inches from the top of the gate. There is a pond located in the backyard that has no water and is empty. The outdoor perimeter front yard, side yard and backyard were inspected and found cleared of debris and hazards materials. The passageways and porches are unobstructed. The facility has a first aid kit stored inside a locked cabinet in the medication room. One of the four fire extinguishers is located in the kitchen area fully charged and the other fire extinguisher is located inside the laundry room fully charged. The third fire extinguisher is located next to bedroom #3 mounted onto the wall and the fourth fire extinguisher is located next to the staff office mounted onto the wall fully charged. Disinfectants and poisons are inaccessible to the clients in care they are kept locked at all times. All knives and sharp objects are made inaccessible to the clients in care locked in a security box inside the closet in the staff office upstairs. The Chef logs out the knives when they will be used. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide are operable. There is a working telephone line available for clients to use. All posting requirements were met, (food menu, regulations, licenses, emergency disaster plan, Children’s Personal Rights, and Ombudsman). The facility has a working telephone and youths can use the telephone unless restricted by court order. The Facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. Facility has a current, written plan of operation. Facility personnel are instructed to report violations of personal rights. Licensee will report changes in the plan of operation affecting service to youths. Licensee will report youth injuries requiring medical treatment. A review of Facility's Personnel Report Summary on 11/29/2021 indicates that all personnel have criminal record clearance has obtain the necessary clearances with DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse Response. LPA Rosas was not able to review client or staff files during this visit and will return to continue with the annual inspection. The facility keeps files and documents in digital system called KIPUERM. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

It was noted in the facility’s program statement that staff are to ensure that the clients keep the bathroom door ajar when using the restroom. Minors are not allowed hygiene items Confidential interviews revealed conflicting statements regarding whether clients are not allowed hygiene items. Interview information revealed that clients are given hygiene boxes that contain toothbrush, toothpaste, soap, shampoo, conditioner, deodorant, lotion, and other products which are available when the clients request them. Confidential interviews stated that clients are provided razors to shave but under the supervision of staff. It was noted in the facility’s program statement that staff can withhold hygiene items from clients and provide them upon the request of the client depending on the client’s level. Staff open minors’ personal mail Confidential interviews indicated that the therapist keep all mail, unopened until the clients’ next one-on-one therapy sessions. It was also disclosed that clients are required to open their letters in front of staff to make sure there is no contraband and confirmed that staff do not open clients’ mails. Other confidential witnesses were unaware of the mail process and could not speak to this allegation. Some confidential witnesses stated that the clients open their personal mail in front of staff, and others stated the clients’ primary therapists open their mail for them to screen letters and packages for contraband or triggering content. Minors not receiving an allowance Confidential interviews revealed that none of the minors received allowance during their residency at this Group Home. Per Facility Representative(s), the purpose of not providing clients allowance was to reduce the ability of incoming contraband. Facility Representative(s) also indicated that clients did not have a need for allowance as the Program provide the necessities for clients. Confidential interviews revealed that although allowance is not given, the facility provide for clients’ needs which includes items while on outings. Minors are denied access to personal property Confidential interviews revealed that clients are denied personal property based on scheduled activities and for their safety. Some personal items are stored locked in a cabinet and made available to clients upon request. Per Facility Representative(s) some items such as razors require direct supervision, while other personal items (such as books, clothing and etc.) are not allowed to be possessed by clients because the item could trigger client’s behaviors or jeopardize their safety while in treatment.

Based on the confidential interviews, observation, and record review, it has been determined that although the allegations that minors are not treated with dignity; minors are not allowed hygiene items; staff open minors’ personal mail, minors not receiving an allowance, and minors being denied access to personal belongings may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. The program statement has been updated to ensure that the clients’ needs will be met based on their individual assessments per Title 22 Group Home Regulations. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was provided to Devorah Weiss.
investigation_findings: 13On 12/02/2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Miguel Gomez arrived at the facility to deliver the findings of a complaint investigation. LPA Gomez met with Administrator, Devorah Weiss and discussed the investigative findings. On June 7, 2021, the Department received a complaint alleging minors are not treated with dignity; minors are not allowed hygiene items; staff open minors' personal mail; minors are not receiving an allowance; minors are being denied access to personal property. Confidential interviews were conducted with 4 staff and 4 of 6 clients. Facility’s Program Statement, Plan of Operation, Parent Handbook and Training Manual were reviewed. The following information was obtained during the course of the investigation: Minors are not treated with dignity Confidential interviews revealed conflicting statements that clients must leave the bathroom door ajar while using the restroom. Some confidential interviews reported that the clients did not have to leave the door open while using the restroom and other interviews stated that clients must leave the bathroom door ajar while using the restroom.

narrative: On 4/14/23, at 9:18am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson made an unannounced visit to this facility, for the purpose of conducting a Case Management inspection to address concerns regarding an order to individual of immediate exclusion. LPA Wilson was met by S2, who provided a tour of the facility indoors, and outdoor grounds. (7) staff members were present in the facility with (6) clients. S2 provided a staff roster (Evolve Aura Contacts List) (2) staff present in the facility were not included on this list: S3 and S6, but were listed on the LIC500. An order of immediate exclusion was issued by CDSS office April 6, 2023 to inform the facility that, unless notified otherwise in writing by CDSS, staff (S1) must immediately be removed from any contact with clients and not be physically present in any agency or home licensed/approved by the Department. [See Confidential Names form (LIC811), dated 4/14/23 for names.] LPA Wilson received a Personnel Report (form LIC500 from Staff #4 and Staff #5, which does not show S1 associated to this facility. Guardian Report shows that S1 was separated, on 04/10/2023, and is no longer associated to this facility. LPA Wilson also received notification that S1 was terminated from employment, effective 04/10/2023. Based on evidence obtained, LPA Wilson has verified that S1 is no longer present, or employed with any Evolve Growth Initiatives facility. Individuals mentioned in this report are identify on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated 04/14/23. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. Exit Interview conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

Group Room #1/School Room contains ample seating, activity stations, fireplace, six desks and computers for client education use. Storage Closet stored paper goods not limited to paper towels and other supplies. Garage/Gym house gym mat and equipment, table and chairs, extra storage fridge. Bathroom #1 is a half bathroom with toilet and sink in functioning order. Laundry Room contains washer, dryer, sink and locked cabinets that stores additional cleaning and laundry supplies. Emergency dried food supply is also stored in cabinet. There is a door that leads to the garage. Therapist Office contains a couch, chair, and desk. Locked Closet containing inactive elevator. Staff does not have keys. Group Room #2 contained eight seats, TV, retired fireplace, and re-purposed bar area that stored additional activity supplies, contraband, sports equipment, and sunscreen. (See LIC809-C Page 1 of 3 )

Dining Area contained adequate seating and table in good repair. Kitchen contained two sinks, dishwasher, microwave, five burner stove top, double oven and refrigerator all in good repair. Trashcan had secured lid. LPA observed adequate dinnerware and utensils for clients, accessible snacks for in between meals and posted weekly meal plan. Refrigerator and freezer operating at temperatures within regulation and is observed to have perishables for two days and food items dated. Pantry observed to have non-perishables for one week. Med Room contained locked cabinets that stored PRNs, prepped medications for clients, first aid kits with required supplies and additional aid to administer medication and offer first aid. Behind a locked cabinet contains a safe that facility nurse has access to. Med log is stored electronically on Kipu. There is a locked door that leads to PD office. PD(Program Director) Office contains desk, shelf a couch and two chairs. Exterior contains propane grill, table, and ample seating that clients may eat at, three HVAC units located on side of the facility along with utility shutoff valves and outdoor trashcans. There is a pool on site with a locked gate at least 5ft and door opens outwards. There is also a tennis court, basketball hoop and two gazebos. Electrical panel is stored west of building. The facility utilizes a 2017 Toyota Sienna to transport clients in working condition and current insurance and registration. Second Floor Stairway/Entry contains extra storage cabinets and client hygiene bins. Blocked door to decommissioned elevator, door to staff office and client bedrooms. Bedroom #1 rooms C3. It contains two twin beds, six dresser unit and additional bedside drawers. There is a locked closet door that an offsite staff has key to. Ensuite bathroom contains double sink, toilet and tub/shower combo with running water not exceeding the maximum temperature. Bedroom #2 rooms C2. It contains two twin beds, two dressers and closet. Ensuite bathroom is equipped with drawers for storage double sink, shower, separate tub(non-functioning), and toilet with running water not exceeding the maximum temperature. (See LIC809-C Page 2 of 3 )

Bedroom #3 rooms C4. It contains one twin bed, two dressers and locked closet. Ensuite bathroom is equipped with single sink, shower/tub combo and toilet with running water not exceeding the maximum temperature. Bedroom #4 rooms C3. It contains one twin bed, two dressers locked door to staff office. Ensuite bathroom is equipped with shower, separate tub(non-functioning), double sinks, toilet, and bidet(non-functioning) with running water not exceeding the maximum temperature. Staff Office contains two desks, additional storage closet that housed PPE equipment, IT closet housing network related equipment, walk in closet for extra supplies and linen, sunroom with chairs, balcony access. Ensuite bathroom contains staff bathroom, non-functioning sauna, cabinet storage for additional hygiene supplies and staff items. Several fire extinguishers are found throughout the facility. Fire alarms were tested at the time of visit and is operable. Facility temperature does not exceed 80 degrees. Facility was granted waiver for cameras that are found in the facility common areas. LPA obtained staff and client roster and LIC610. Staff have guardian clearance. LPA conducted confidential interviews with S1 and C2. (See LIC811 [Confidential Names]) Due to time constraints LPA will return to complete file review. Facility is clean, safe, and in good repair. No deficiencies will be cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to program director. (LIC809-C Page 3 of 3)

On 01/08/24 at 09:55 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jhane Haynes made an unannounced visit to the above facility for the purpose of conducting a case management inspection. LPA met with Jospeh Raya- (OM) who granted access to the facility and discussed the late reporting of an incident that occurred on 11/25/2023 and reported to the department on 12/07/2023. Written reports must be submitted within seven working days to the department. Compliance Officer Devorah Weiss(CO) met with LPA and CO discussed plan of correction. CO took responsibility for late reporting. CO also shared facility's incident report training PowerPoint, IR cheat sheet and list of employees that completed training. Per California Code Regulations Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, one deficiency will be cited. See LIC809-D for details. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with OM.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in (1) below...a written report shall be made to the shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event. This requirement was not met by: Based on observation, interview, and record review the licensee did not comply with the section cited above by not submitting written report within seven working days which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to persons in care.

narrative: On May 24, 2024 at 12:58pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson made an unannounced Case Management Incident Inspection to the above listed facility, regarding SIR dated 05/19/24. LPA Wilson interviewed (FN and CD).(LIC811 dated 05/24/24). A (1) deficiency has been determined at this time. The following deficiency has been cited. (CD) whose signature on this form confirm receipt of these documents.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 80075(5)(B) - Health Related Services (5) If the client's physician has stated in writing t... the licensee shall be permitted to assist the client with self-administration, providing all of the following requirements are met: (B) Once ordered by the physician the medication is given according to the physician's directions. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Staff (S1) had not prepared, or reported dosage given of medication in MAR and did not sign off on Kipu, which resulted in staff not administering medication to (C1) according to the physician's directions, resulting in (C1) receiving a double dosage of medication.

narrative: On November 18, 2024 at 12:22 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson made an unannounced visit to the above listed facility, in order to conduct a case management incident inspection, regarding SIR dated 11/06/24.LPA was met by (CO) and (PD). During the course of the incident investigation, it was revealed that on 11/06/24; due to the Malibu fires, SoCal power pre-emptively turned off all power in this region. The decision was made to move all clients; six (6) from the Calabasas facility and six (6) from the Agoura facility to the Evolve Aura location in Tarzana, which had three (3) clients in care, which resulted in the licensee operating the facility beyond the conditions and limitations, as specified on the license. A (1) deficiency Type A has been determined at this time. The following deficiency has been cited. (See LIC 809D) An exit interview was conducted and Plans of Correction was developed and reviewed with the licensee. A copy of this report and appeals rights were discussed and left with licensee. (CO) whose signature on this form confirm receipt of these documents.

It was alleged that a staff physically abused a facility client resulting in an injury, and a facility client sustained an injury due to neglect by facility staff. The investigation revealed that a facility client was in a bathtub thrashing around, kicking his legs, throwing his arms around and hitting the bathtub with his fist along with trying to kick and hit staff with his fists. The client alleged that a staff, Reference #1, pulled his arm to restrain him during the incident causing an arm injury. Reference #1 stated that the client sustained the injury from hitting the wall with his left fist and denied intentionally hurting the client when he assisted the client out of the bathtub during the episode. Another staff who assisted with the client during the episode denied witnessing Reference #1 physically abuse the client. Confidential documents obtained ruled the injury as accidental. Based on the information gathered, although the allegations may have happened or is valid, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegations was not met, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. A copy of this report, Confidential Names Form and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection.

met_with: Amanda Allen, Administrator; Jose Cortez, Facility Manager; Stacy Krebs, Trainer
narrative:
On April 26, 2022, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Jean Herring arrived at the facility at 10:40 AM for the purpose conducting an unannounced Annual/Required inspection of the facility. LPA met with Amanda Allen, Administrator; Jose Cortez, Facility Manager; Stacy Krebs, Trainer. The group home is licensed to serve three (3) male/female developmentally disabled clients, ages 7 - 17. Facility has no children placed at this time. Physical Plant This facility is a one-story home with three(3) bedrooms, an office, two (2) full bathrooms, kitchen, dining, and living room. The license is posted in a prominent, publicly accessible location in the facility. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are locked in a cabinet located next to the bathroom. Sharps and knives are locked in the office. Facility has non-perishable foods for at least one week and perishable foods for at least two days. Facility provides at least three(3) meals per day. Facility stores and locks medications in the office closet. Facility's first aid kit meets the requirements. All kitchen, food preparation, and storage areas are kept clean and free of rodents and other vermin. Carbon monoxide detectors and smoke alarms were tested and observed to be operable. Facility provides basic laundry services. Room temperatures are maintained at a comfortable temperature. The hot water temperature was tested and measured at 126 degrees F. Fire extinguisher is fully charged. All toilets, hand washing and bathing facilities are maintained in safe and sanitary operating condition and meet the requirements. Each client has his/her own bedroom. All beds are in good repair and supplied with pillows and linens which are clean and in good repair. Facility maintains and implements written complaint procedures and the procedures are posted in a publicly accessible location in the facility. (cont...)

Disaster Preparedness Plan Facility has a current LIC 610C Emergency Disaster Plan. Facility conducts disaster drill at least once a month The drills are documented and the documentation is maintained in the facility for at least a year. Facility maintains an emergency and disaster plan and register of clients with contact information for each client's responsible party and physician. Emergency Intervention Plan Facility maintains a monthly log of each use of manual restraints that contains all required information. The log is available for review by the Department upon request. LPA observed documentation of Emergency Intervention Training and on-going training. Client Records LPA reviewed one (1) client record (C1- last client discharged from the facility). Client records are available to the licensing agency to inspect, audit and copy upon demand. Client records contain required information including, but not limited to: Identification and Emergency Information; Admission Agreement; consent forms; needs and services plan and/or Individual Program Plan; medical assessment; TB test; dental, vision, medical, and psychological reports; personal property and valuables; personal rights forms; and medication administration records. During this inspection, the following deficiencies were observed: - Facility does not have an updated emergency and disaster plan that includes procedures required by HSC 1565(a)(7); HSC 1565(e) and HSC 1565(f). - Hot water temperature reading was at 126 degrees F. These pose a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to clients in care. Deficiency citations were issued. A signed copy of this report was provided to the facility along with LIC 809Ds, LIC 811 (Confidential Name/s list) and Appeal Rights. These pose a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to clients in care. Deficiency citations were issued. A signed copy of this report was provided to the facility along with LIC 809Ds, LIC 811, and Appeal Rights.

The LPA reviewed the following documents: Falcon Grove Crisis Home Employee, Phone List, Register of Facility Clients, Personnel Report (LIC500), Kern County Department of Human Services (DHS) - Child Protective Services (CPS) Child Abuse Hotline (CAHL), Kern County DHS - CPS Screener Narrative, Kern County DHS - CPS Emergency Response Notice of Referral Disposition, San Joaquin County HSACSB - CAHL, San Joaquin County HSACSB Screener Narrative, San Joaquin Emergency Response Notice of Referral Disposition, Client Ref. #1 Behavioral Treatment Plan/Individual Program Plan, Special Incident Reports, Bakersfield Police Department Report. Ref. #2 denied the allegations stating that Ref. #1 targeted and threatened them, because Ref. #2 chose to work with the other client at the facility. The investigation revealed that the witness did not recall the incidents or the name of the perpetrator, although the witness continued to allege that they were hit and cursed at. The investigation revealed that CPS found the allegations to be Inconclusive. Bakersfield Police Department was unable to determine if an offense occurred due to conflicting statements and Ref. #2 having a history of making false accusations. A review of records indicates that Ref. #1 has a history of threatening staff, engaging in inappropriate attention seeking and actions of self-harm. There were no witnesses to the allegations and the LPA was unable to corroborate the allegations. So, although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies to be cited regarding this allegations. A copy of this complaint was provided to the facility representative.

Confidential interviews revealed Client #1 (C1) and Client #2 (C2) expressed to feeling “uncomfortable” with S1 after an incident that occurred in April 2020. Witness interviewed revealed there was an incident in which S1 asked C1 and C2 to go into a room of the facility and S1 closed the door. It was disclosed that while in the room, S1 asked to hug C1 and C2 and touched their backs. Additional interviews revealed S1 was in the room with C1 and C2 but S1 did not hug or touch C1 or C2 inappropriately. Based on interviews and records review, the allegation that facility Staff #1 (S1) touched Client #1 (C1) and Client #2 (C2) in an inappropriate manner, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of the LIC 9099 report was emailed to Denise Samano for signature. Original signed report will be placed in facility file. investigation_findings: 13On October 12, 2020, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lorena Valenzuela made telephone contact with First Street Home Program Administrator Denise Samano to deliver the finding of the complaint investigation for the above allegation. The investigation included a records review of five of five client records. Due to the COVID-19 virus a tele-inspection of the group home was conducted on June 6, 2020 at 3:45 PM. In addition, LPA Valenzuela interviewed a Program Administrator, three Child Care Workers, and two of five clients. LPA Valenzuela was not able to interview Client #1 (C1) and Client #2 (C2) due to not being able to locate them. On September 21, 2020, LPA attempted to interview Client #3 (C3), however, C3 refused to be interviewed by LPA Valenzuela. On May 26, 2020, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging facility staff touched foster child in an inappropriate manner. It was reported Staff # 1(S1) touched a foster child’s shoulder and rubbed their back.

narrative:
Messages were sent by the facility manager to all staff to notify management of any accrued bank fees associated with the returned check. Confidential interviews disclosed that the reason for a delay in payroll is that Corporate office was waiting to receive their payments from San Bernardino County Behavioral Health. Per confidential interviews, this delay in payroll brought upon a hardship on at least one staff not able to come to work due to lack of funds to put gas in car. Per letter from Executive Director, San Bernardino County sent a letter stating a delay in payment for the beginning of the fiscal year 2020/2021 which put an undue burden on the program to delay payroll from September 9th to September 15th. Per confidential interviews and record review, the licensee was not able to maintain the level of funds necessary to cover the costs of operation, causing financial hardships for the facility staff. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the allegation of facility having financial issues is substantiated. Facility is cited for violation of Title 22 California Code of Regulations, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 06, Section 84063(a)(3): Accountability. The licensee was not able to maintain the level of funds necessary to cover the costs of operation, causing financial hardship for the facility staff, which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to clients. Exit interviewed conducted. A copy of this report, LIC 811 and appeal rights were given and explained to Program Manager Denise Samano. This report was emailed to Denise Samano, Program Manager for signature. Original signed reports will be placed in facility file.

facilities. Confidential interviews reported that C1 & C2 haven’t ate any expired food. Confidential interviews revealed that three meals are served daily and snacks in between the meals. In addition, confidential interviews disclosed that if C1 & C2 don’t like what’s on the food menu then they are given other meal options. On 09/22/2020, LPA Davis observed unexpired adequate perishable food for 2 days and nonperishable food for 7 days. LPA Davis observed a full cabinet of can goods and a variety of food in the kitchen cabinet and the back closet located in the clinic, refrigerator of food (milk, eggs, etc.), and one freezer located in the laundry room full of a variety of meats. Based on confidential interviews and LPA observations, the allegation staff not providing adequate food service to minors (C1 & C2), may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interviewed conducted. A copy of this report, LIC 811 and appeal rights were given and explained to Program Manager Denise Samano. This report was emailed to Denise Samano, Program Manager for signature. Original signed reports will be placed in facility file.
investigation_findings: 13On November 04, 2020 at 10:38 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Cheraki Davis, conducted a tele-inspection due to COVID 19 with Denise Samano, Program Manager of East Valley Charlee (licensee), to discuss the investigative findings for the allegation listed above. On 09/22/2020 at 1:18 PM, LPA inspected the physical plant and no current safety hazards were observed. During the investigation, LPA obtained copies of records that included: bank statements and pay stubs for employees, a letter from San Bernardino County, a letter from Executive Director, and food menus. Interviews were conducted with Administrator (AD), clients (C1 & C2), and five staff (S1, S2, S3, S4, & S5). On 09/15/2020, Community Care Licensing received an allegation that facility is having financial issues. Information obtained during the interviews indicate that there was not enough funds to cover payroll; pay day was on 09/07/2020 and the checks began to “bounce” due to insufficient funds. On 09/04/2020 & 09/08/2020 messages were sent by the administrator to all staff to not cash their checks until September 15th. Then on 09/14/2020 messages were sent by the administrator to all staff to not cash their checks until September 17th.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Section 84063(a)(3): Accountability. (a) The board of directors shall be active in ensuring accountability, and shall perform, at a minimum, the following duties: (3) Assess and maintain the level of funds necessary to cover the costs of operating the group home; This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and record reviews, licensee was not able to maintain the level of funds necessary to cover the costs of operation, causing financial hardship for the facility staff, which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to clients.

narrative:
On 11/09/2020, at 10:11 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lorena Valenzuela conducted a pre-arranged pre-licensing tele-inspection, as a result of COVID-19 related restrictions. On 01/11/2019, the facility listed above submitted an application to transition the currently licensed group home facility to a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). The application, application documents, Plan of Operation and Program Statement have been reviewed by Community Care Licensing (CCL) LPA Lorena Valenzuela and Continuum of Care (CCR) Policy Analyst Patrice Coleman. The facility tele- inspection was conducted with the facility Program Administrator, Denise Samano. The home is a one-story residence with three bedrooms, one staff office, one therapist office, and three bathrooms. The tele- inspection included an observation of the following: 1. Yard is clean and free of debris or observable hazards. 2. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials. 3. Chemicals stored in a locked cabinet inside the laundry room. 4. Locked and centrally stored medications observed in the staff office in a locked closet inside a locked cabinet. 5. First aid kit complete, including manual was inside the staff office in a locked closet. 6. Adequate storage space was observed for linens. 7. Individual beds in good repair, equipped with clean mattresses and pillows observed. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens in good repair. 8. Facility has three client bedrooms, double occupancy. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings including closet space, drawer storage and a desk for each client. 9. Adequate food storage space observed. Supply of two days of perishable foods and a week of nonperishable food items were observed. (continued on page 2)

10. Weekly menu posted and accessible to clients. 11. Dining room equipped with large table and chairs accommodating all clients. 12. Facility has two full client restrooms in this home and one staff restroom, all are operable. 13. Hot water measured within required range. Program Administrator Denise Samano measured the water temperature using a thermometer. 14. All smoke detectors tested and appear to be in proper working order. 15. Carbon monoxide detector was observed and tested. 16. Fire extinguishers properly charged. 17. Adequate supply of additional bedding and linens observed. 18. Facility maintains a current fire clearance. 19. Knives are stored in the staff office in a locked closet inside a container with a lock. 20. Appropriate forms posted in view of facility clients. 21. Facility does not have any open bodies of water. 22. Per the Program Administrator, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. The following items were discussed with Program Administrator Denise Samano, by LPA during the inspection: 1. LIC 500 reviewed to ensure appropriate staffing ratios, including Administrator, Facility Manager, Social Work personnel, and Direct Care staff. The facility does not utilize Peer Partners at this time. 2. Program Administrator Denise Samano will be present on-site a minimum of 20 hours per week. 3. Facility procedures for 30-day updates of Needs and Services Plans discussed. 4. Facility is to ensure all clients considered for future placement have been assessed and meet placement eligibility requirements. Facility has a process in place to contact authorized representatives to ensure assessment for clients’ continued placement. 5. Facility is to update all client admission agreements to reflect the STRTP rate. 6. Facility is to obtain Mental Health Program Approval (MHPA) within 12 months of effective date of the provisional licensure, will keep the department updated as to MHPA status, and will provide appropriate documentation to the department upon approval. (continued on page 3)

During the tele-inspection, LPA Lorena Valenzuela interviewed the Program Administrator to ensure staff understanding of the STRTP program requirements. It was recommended by LPA that all line staff be trained on keeping confidentiality of a client's gender identity, expression and orientation; what the Emergency Intervention Plan is; purpose of Children and Family Team meetings; and Reasonable Prudent Parent standards, prior to the STRTP conversion. In addition, during the tele-inspection LPA Valenzuela discussed with Program Administrator Denise Samano the following revisions needed to the facility’s Plan of Operation (POO) and Program Statement (PS) submitted on 10/09/2020. Below the revisions requested is how the facility will meet the requirement. Program Statement (PS) Section 4 - Core Services and Supports CCR Question: Does EVC have written agreements or contracts with external agencies? Such as Career Pathways. If so, please attach the agreement(s) with the final version of your PO/PS. Per ILS § 87022.1(b)(6) and ILS § 87078.1(b)(1-2) PS *The facility has some written agreements with external agencies and will submit those to CCL. and CCR. The facility will obtain written agreements for the external agencies for which they don’t have written agreements for. Section 11- Complaints and Grievances CCL Question: It is indicated if a complaint or grievance arises, there will be mediation between the involved staff and client. Will there be a neutral third party involved the mediation? (PS, page 38) *The facility will revise this section to reflect the complaint procedure for each of their facilities. Section 22 - Emergency Intervention Plan (Runaway Plan) CCL Review 10/19/20- Facility did not provide name and qualifications of Behavior Management Consultant who assisted in plan preparation (PS page 80, Article 10.3 ILS 87095.22, 87001(b)(1).) *The facility will revise the PS to include the name and qualifications of the above mentioned consultant. (continued on page 4

Plan of Operation (POO) Section B - Administrative Organization CCL Review 10/14/20-Missing- Staff Therapist qualifications regarding experience requirements. Facility provides the education requirements for Social work personnel per ILS, however, facility is missing the work experience requirements (POO page 11-12, ILS 87065 (c) (1) (C-F)) *The facility will review this section to ensure the work requirements for the social work personnel are included. Section E - Policies Regarding Child Abuse/Neglect Reporting CCL Review 10/14/20-Facility does not provide specific procedures and practices on how it will ensure the administrator does not impede or prohibit mandated reporting duties. (POO: page 40-41, ILS 87022 (b) (7) (A-C)) *The facility will revisit this section to ensure the administrator or other staff do not impede mandated reporting duties. -End of Revisions Requested- LPA Valenzuela advised the facility of the following steps. The facility agreed to the PS/POO revisions due date of 11/18/2020. The facility was advised to contact LPA Valenzuela or CCR Policy Analyst Coleman with any questions regarding the revisions requested. The facility was informed that failure to complete the agreed upon actions may result in denying the application to convert the facility to a STRTP. The facility was advised that the STRTP provisional licensure request will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. A copy of this report was emailed to Denise Samano for signature. Original signed report will be placed in facility file.

narrative:
Regarding the allegation of staff not ensuring FC1 arrive to school on time, documents obtained revealed that FC1 was late to school 33 times in a period of 65 days. Confidential interviews corroborated that FC1 did not wake up on time in the morning, which caused FC1 and other residents to also be late to school. Regarding the allegation of staff failing to provide FC1 with appropriate clothing, information received revealed FC1 was observed wearing a shirt that was too small for FC1 which exposed FC1’s midriff area. Witness interviews corroborated FC1 was observed wearing clothes that was too small. Based on witness interviews and documents review, there is a preponderance of evidence to prove the facility staff failed to ensure that Foster Child # 1 (FC1) arrived to school on time and failed to provide FC1 with appropriate clothing. The allegations are, therefore, found to be substantiated. The facility is being cited for violation of Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Section 84072 (d) Personal Rights and for violation of Section 84072 (6)(A) Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and LIC 9099-D was emailed to Denise Samano for signature. Original signed report will be placed in facility file. Appeals Rights were emailed to Denise Samano.

Confidential interviews revealed FC1 was seen with stains on FC1’s clothing that appeared to be from days before. Furthermore, the stains did not appear to be recent food stains and the stains were “crusted” on FC1’s clothing. Additional information received indicated the facility staff ensured FC1’s clothing was laundered, however, FC1 would sometimes mix dirty clothes with clean clothing. Witness interviews revealed FC1 was not observed wearing dirty clothing. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation facility staff failed to ensure Foster Child #1 (FC1) is wearing clean clothing while in care may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was emailed to Denise Samano for signature. Original report placed in facility file. Appeals Rights were emailed to Denise Samano.
investigation_findings: 13On November 9, 2020, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lorena Valenzuela made telephone contact with First Street Group Home Program Administrator Denise Samano to deliver the findings of the complaint investigation for the above allegations. Due to the COVID-19 virus, a tele-meeting was conducted by using a video conference application. During the investigation, LPA reviewed client records, school attendance records, a San Bernardino County Investigation Narrative, as well as toured the facility on November 21, 2019, at 8:56 AM. LPA interviewed two staff, six of six clients, and four County Social Workers. On November 13, 2019, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging facility staff failed to ensure minor arrives to school on time and staff failed to provide minor with adequate clothing. Specifically, it was reported Foster Child #1 (FC1) is “chronically late to school” and FC1 has been observed “wearing clothes that is too small”.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: (d) Personal Rights The licensee shall ensure...each child … is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code...16001.9... This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and records review, the facility did not ensure FC1 attended school on time. FC1 was late 33 times out of a 65-day period, which caused disruption to FC1’s school attendance and educational stability. This poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.

(6) (A) Personal Rights. To be provided...adequate personal items… which includes their own: Clothing items, provided the clothes are age appropriate. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and records review, the facility did not ensure FC1 was provided clothing that was adequate in size and age- appropriate. This poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.

facility_name: FRED FINCH YOUTH CENTER - NEW YOSEMITE
narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Rollins conducted an unannounced annual inspection at Fred Finch Youth Center-New Yosemite. During the inspection, LPA met with Mar Smith Senior Director (SD). The group home is licensed to served 4 clients ages 8-17. The facility consists of 4 bedrooms (4 single occupancy) and 4 bathrooms (3 client and 1 staff). The facility also has a activity and staff room. At 10:45 AM, LPA Rollins toured the facility with SD inside and out. LPA observed the kitchen is clean. Hot water in kitchen, bathroom and shower measured at 113.4 degrees F which is currently between 105-120 required degrees F. The facility has plenty of non perishable and non- perishable food supply. All items in the refrigerator are correctly labeled and no spoiled food was found. Medication, cleaning supplies and knives are locked away in a secure location. There are enough folks, spoons, plates and cups. All passageways are unobstructed. All smoke detectors are up to date and working. The facility is clean, safe and sanitary. There are no firearms on the property. There are no bodies of water on the property. The facility is maintained at a comfortable temperature. Personal rights, floor plan, food menu and Emergency disaster forms were posted in clear view. Fire Extinguisher was up to date and carbon monoxide was in good working shape. LPA observed all activity logs and emergency policies to be up to date.

At 12:00 PM, LPA reviewed three client files with SD. LPA observed all three client files and found no deficiencies. Needs and services plan are updated. The documentation is in the clients files are complete. LPA observed medication logs to be updated and current. At 1:00 PM, LPA observed eleven staff files with SD and found no deficiencies. Staff have completed there 20 hours annual training. All staff documentation is current. LPA reviewed staff training documents with SD and found all training to be up to date and all certificates to be complete. During inspection, LPA receive an updated copy of the LIC 500 Personnel Report and updated Emergency Disaster Plan (LIC 610 C) to maintain their file current. A review of Licensing Information System on July 29, 2021 indicates that all facility staff associated to the facility had DOJ, FBI and child abuse index check clearances. Per Title 22 Regulations, no deficiencies were cited during the inspection. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was left at the facility.

facility_name: FRED FINCH YOUTH CENTER - NEW YOSEMITE
narrative:
Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) George Karkazis and Alyssa Ng conducted an unannounced Annual/Random inspection at Fred Finch Youth Center. LPA's met with Mar Smith, Senior Director (SD) and toured the facility, inside and out. The group home is licensed to serve four clients. Currently in placement are three clients. Present during this inspection were three clients and two staff. At 10:50, LPAs walked over to the New Yosemite house. When walking in, LPA saw four bedrooms, single occupancy, and three bathrooms. Two of the bathrooms were for clients and one is for staff. LPA's observed the facility license, client’s personal rights, facility sketch, facility rules, and other forms posted on the walls throughout the facility. LPA interviewed two of the clients in care and two staff. LPA reviewed client and staff files which was updated and in order. All staff were fingerprinted and had child abuse index check clearances. LPA tested the water temperature and found it to read 114.4 degrees, which is within range. At 11:00 AM, LPAs toured the backyard. There were no open bodies of water or debris. LPAs noticed a wooden fence surrounding the backyard. One plank was missing. There was a swing and a seesaw with rubber shavings on the bottom. LPA noticed two window screens that were broken from the clients back window. LPA advised SD to get the screens and fence repaired immediately. SD stated that there was a work order for the fence and that she will have maintenance replace the screen immediately. ------CONT. ON 809C-----------

When coming back into the facility, LPA noticed the vent was coated with dust. LPA advised SD to have the vent cleaned. SD said that she will have maintenance clean it right away. At 12:15, LPA walked into the kitchen and noticed that the facility menu was not posted anywhere. When asked about the facility menu, SD mentioned that it was in the main kitchen which is adjacent to the house. SD printed an updated menu and put it on the refrigerator in clear view. There was sufficient 2 day perishables and 7 day non-perishable. Sharps and chemicals were located in staff closet. The medication was also locked away and stored in the staff room. During staff and client interviews, it was disclosed that the fence has been broken for at least three weeks. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 80087 (b) Buildings and Grounds. See attached 809-D. At this time, 1 deficiency and 3 technical violations were cited during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed and a copy of the report was left at the facility with Mar Smith, Senior Director.

facility_name: FRED FINCH YOUTH CENTER - NEW YOSEMITE
narrative: On 2/2/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit at the facility regarding a background clearance. LPA met with Residential Supervisor Theresa McNeally and informed of the purpose of the visit. During a file review, LPA observed that a staff member did not have a criminal background clearance associated to the facility. S1 (See LIC 811 Confidential Names List, dated 2/2/23) has worked at the facility for more than 5 working days. S1 has a clearance associated to another facility operated by the licensee, but neither facility has an approved central administrative waiver on file to allow clearances under one license to apply to other local facilities operated by the same licensee. LPA discussed the process of requesting this waiver with Residential Supervisor, who stated they will consider submitting a request. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 3, Section 80019 Criminal Record Clearance, Subsection (e). Additionally, pursuant to Subsection (g) of this regulatory section, LPA is assessing an immediate civil penalty of one hundred dollars ($100) per violation (1) for a maximum of 5 days, for a total of five hundred dollars ($500). See attached LIC 809-D and LIC 421. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was provided to Residential Supervisor Theresa McNeally, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

facility_name: FRED FINCH YOUTH CENTER - NEW YOSEMITE
investigation_findings: 13On 1/20/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility to deliver findings of an investigation of the above allegations. LPA met with Senior Director Mar Smith and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential interviews with resident, staff, and witnesses, the resident was provided food, clothes were clean, and hygiene needs were met. Based on LPA's observation of resident, resident was clean and tidy with clean and well-fitting clothes and appeared in good spirits. Additionally, resident expressed liking the facility and staff and feeling safe there. Further, authorized representatives expressed having no concerns with the care they have observed the resident to be receiving at the facility. However, after multiple attempts, LPA was unable to obtain a statement from all reported witnesses of the specific concerns regarding the care of the resident. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, based on LPA’s observations and interviews, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report provided to Senior Director Mar Smith, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

facility_name: FRED FINCH YOUTH CENTER - NEW YOSEMITE
met_with: Mar Smith, Senior Director and Brandy Hunt, Administrator
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Michelle Kyane and Licensing Program Manager Angela King conducted a case management inspection on 05/25/23 at 11:30 AM based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 19 Direct Care Staff and 1 out of 1 youth files were reviewed. 3 out of 19 Direct Care Staff and 1 out of 1 youth were interviewed.(See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, May 25, 2023). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the including the needs and services assessment, individualized risk screening and treatment care plans. The licensee uses trauma informed and evidence based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Kyane and LPM King observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed with Senior Director Mar Smith and provided to Administrator Brandy Hunt.

continued from LIC 9099 Other documents viewed stated the interviewee said the incident never occurred. During confidential interviews, inconsistent information was provided. Some interviewees stated that the incident was immediately reported within regulation while others did not find out about the incident until a later time. LPA conducted document research and found inconsistent information. Proper notification by the facility was sent to CDSS within regulation, while client representatives state they learned of the incident hours later. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that staff did not properly report the incident involving minor in home. Therefore, the above allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. Regarding the allegation minor was not permitted scheduled visit: During the course of the investigation, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) conducted confidential interviews with staff, clients, and conducted document research. During confidential interviews, inconsistent information was provided. Most interviewees stated that the meeting was missed by accident and rescheduled two days later. A representative stated that the meeting was purposely missed and not rescheduled. LPA conducted document research and found no evidence to support that minor was not permitted scheduled visit. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that minor was not permitted scheduled visit. Therefore, the above allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. continued on LIC 9099

continued from LIC 9099-C Regarding the allegation that minor’s dietary needs are not being met: During the course of the investigation, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) conducted confidential interviews with staff, clients, and conducted document research. Other interviewees stated that there is no specific dietary meals provided to meet the client’s needs. LPA conducted document research and found no evidence to support that minor’s dietary needs are not met. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that minor’s dietary needs not being met. Therefore, the above allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. On October 26, 2021 at 10:00am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin arrived at the Freedom House for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required inspection. LPA was met by Lydia Quintanilla and allowed to enter the facility. The inspection is as follows: Front door entry leads into the living room where the clients personal rights, facility profile and grievance policy and forms are posted for clients to see. There are two rooms off the living room. One contains several computers for the clients use and the other is a game room with a pool table and a small weight room for clients use. The kitchen has a large stove with a hood that has a sprinkler system. Clients use the stove for independent skill building but for the most part staff cooks for the clients. The refrigerator was clean and has a two day supply of food. The pantry has plenty of food and can goods. There is a weeks worth of non perishable foods as well. The facility receives food through InstaCart and Homies Unidos. There is a room with a Subzero freezer and an additional refrigerator for food storage. There is a locked closet that contains tool and cleaning supplies that is inaccessible to clients. There is another room that has lockers for the clients to store personal items. There is a bedroom downstairs used for overnight staff use only. There are two bathrooms downstairs as well. Upstairs. There are 8 bedrooms upstairs only 1 is in use at the time of the visit. The rooms are very big and spacious. The client had plenty of clothing and storage room for him to store them away. There is a room used for storage that stays locked that contains hygiene products and stationary, backpacks and other donated school supplies for the clients. Linen is kept in the staff room downstairs. There is a fire alarm pull station and an unlocked exit door on either end of the hall. There are 3 bathrooms upstairs and 3 showers for the clients. Cont on 809-C

There is an attic door that leads to a room that is empty. This door remains locked and inaccessible to clients. There is also a fire extinguisher in the hallway. The basement was very spacious and clean. The wall are decorated with art from people in the community and from some of the clients. The washer and dryer is located in the basement and can be used by the clients when supervised by staff. Knives are kept in a locked drawer in the office. The water temperature is 120 and within the state guidelines. There is a structure on the side of the house that is used for storage and inaccessible to clients. The outside has a large garden area surrounding the home. The structure is in fair shape as well as the garden. Note: There are 6 working camera angles noted by LPA on the premises. One in the hallway upstairs, one facing the door on the inside at the entrance, and four attached to the outside of the building that show the property only. Smoke detectors were noticed hard wired into the home but out of LPA's reach. The overall home inside and out was very clean and in order. Note: LPA discussed the cameras that are located at the facility. It was discussed that the cameras located inside of the facility need to be removed due to no camera waivers being permitted by CCL at this time. LPA also requested Lydia Quintanilla submit a letter regarding the outside cameras to my attention as soon as possible. There is one staff currently on duty at the facility; "S1". She is fingerprint cleared and associated to the facility. LPA will return to do staff and client file review and interviews. There are no deficiencies to report at the time of this visit. A copy of this report will be left with Administrator, Lydia Quintanilla.

On 07/16/24 at 09:25 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jhane Haynes and Licensing Program Manager Kevin Sauk made an announced visit to the above facility for the purpose of conducting a pre-licensing inspection. LPA met with Facility Administrator(FA) Audrey Hughes who granted access to the facility. Together FA, LPA and LPM toured the home inside and out. This is a single-story home located in a residential area. There are no swimming pools or bodies of water of the premises. LPA and LPM observed the following during facility tour: Entry contains posting not limited to personal rights, emergency numbers. Bedroom #1 is for ambulatory clients and contains a twin bed, drawers, desk, ceiling fan and adequate closet space. Secured Closet contains chemicals and cleaning supplies. Bathroom#1 contains functioning toilet, double sinks and shower with running water. Kitchen contains a kitchen island with seating and pantry with non-perishables with up to two weeks. The refrigerator operating temperature at 38 degrees and freezer at 0 degrees. There is operational kitchen appliances, adequate dinnerware for clients to be placed. A fire extinguisher and phone line can be found. Licensee will post weekly menu. Dining Area contained table and six chairs. Living Room contains adequate seating, rug with non-slip adhesive, TV, additional seating and desk for computer and activities. Bedroom #2 contains a twin bed, drawers, desk, ceiling fan and adequate closet space. Bathroom#2 is non-ambulatory and contains functioning toilet, sink and walk-in shower with running water. Laundry Room contains washer/dryer, cabinet space and secured exterior door to the garage. Garage contains extra laundry storage, water heater, water filter and exterior door to side of home. (Continue to LIC809-C)

Bedroom #3 is for non-ambulatory clients and contains twin bed, desk, drawers and adequate closet space. There is a an exterior door that can be opened from the inside but locked on the outside. Bedroom #4 is for non-ambulatory clients and contains twin bed, desk, drawers and adequate closet space with built-in dresser. There is a an exterior door that can be opened from the inside but locked on the outside. Emergency Closet holds first aid kit with required dressings, emergency disaster kits. Activity Room contains seating, TV, game machine, two swings and shelving for activities. There is a secured storage closet for hygiene. Bathroom#3 contains functioning double sinks, separate tub and shower with running water. Toilet is closed off. Office contains seating, desk, locked boxes for clients, secured dresser for clients files. Medications are stored and will be administered here. Exterior contains outdoor seating, umbrellas, AC unit and fruit trees. Trash is stored on the outside the house. The exterior is clear and free of debris. The fire and carbon monoxide alarms were tested and operational. Fire extinguisher can be located in the kitchen and hallway before the activity room and sprinklers located throughout home. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to the administrator.
