On 03/12/2025 at 09:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dennis Jarmin conducted an unannounced post-licensing inspection at FTBP Opportunities Home for Children. LPA met with Facility Administrator (FA) Audrey Hughes, who granted access and provided LIC 500 and LIC 9020. LPA inspected the entire facility. The Group Home is licensed to provide care and supervision for two ambulatory and two non-ambulatory children, ages 3-17 years. No swimming pools or bodies of water were observed on the premises. The facility maintains appropriate staff-to-child ratios and ensures that personnel meet training and background clearance requirements as mandated by group home regulations. Facility Overview: This single-story home is located in a residential area and includes four bedrooms, three full bathrooms, a living room, a dining room, a kitchen, a laundry area, a backyard, and a detached garage. The facility meets all physical plant safety requirements, ensuring a safe, clean, and comfortable environment for children in care. Entry: The required postings, including personal rights, emergency contact numbers, and emergency procedures, are displayed in a visible location. Bedrooms: Bedroom #1, designated for ambulatory clients, contains a twin bed, drawers, desk, ceiling fan, and closet space.

Bedroom #2 is similarly furnished with a twin bed, drawers, desk, ceiling fan, and closet space. Bedroom #3, designated for non-ambulatory clients, includes a twin bed, desk, drawers, closet space, and an exterior door that can be opened from the inside but remains locked from the outside. Bedroom #4, also for non-ambulatory clients, has a twin bed, desk, drawers, a built-in dresser, closet space, and an exterior door with the same security feature. All sleeping areas comply with spacing, bedding, and emergency egress requirements. Bathrooms: Bathroom #1 is equipped with a toilet, double sinks, and a shower with running water. Bathroom #2, designated for non-ambulatory clients, contains a toilet, sink, and a walk-in shower. Bathroom #3 has double sinks, a separate tub, a shower with running water, and an enclosed toilet. Hot water temperature was tested and measured within the required range. Kitchen: The kitchen features an island with seating, a pantry stocked with non-perishable food for up to two weeks, and operational appliances including a refrigerator set at 38°F and a freezer at 0°F. Adequate dinnerware is available for clients. A fire extinguisher and a phone line are present. The licensee will post a weekly menu. Food storage and preparation areas were clean and met sanitary standards. Perishable food supplies were adequate for at least two days, and non-perishable supplies were sufficient for at least seven days. Dining Area: A table with six chairs is arranged in the dining area, providing sufficient space for all residents. Living Room: The living room has ample seating, a non-slip rug, a TV, additional seating, and a desk for computer use and activities. The common area is well maintained and provides space for recreation and socialization. Laundry Room: A washer, dryer, cabinet storage, and a secured exterior door leading to the garage are present in the laundry area. Laundry supplies are stored securely and are inaccessible to children.

Garage: The garage contains extra laundry storage, a water heater, a water filter, and an exterior door providing access to the outside. The garage remains locked and is not used as a living space. Emergency & Activity Areas: The emergency closet holds a fully stocked first aid kit and emergency disaster kits. The activity room includes seating, a TV, a game machine, two swings, activity shelving, and secured hygiene storage. The office contains seating, a desk, locked storage for client belongings, a secured dresser for client files, and a designated area for medication storage and administration. Medications are stored securely in compliance with licensing requirements. Exterior: The outdoor space features seating, umbrellas, an air conditioning unit, and fruit trees. Trash is stored outside, and the exterior is clear and free of debris. There are no hazardous conditions observed in outdoor play areas. Health & Safety Compliance: A secured closet holds chemicals and cleaning supplies. Fire and carbon monoxide alarms were tested and found operational. Fire extinguishers are located in the kitchen and hallway. Sprinklers are installed throughout the home. All safety features meet group home regulations. Inspection Findings: No deficiencies were observed. The home remains in substantial compliance with licensing regulations. Exit Interview: An exit interview was conducted with the administrator, and a copy of this report was emailed to them.

Furthermore, it was established that staff member S3 witnessed S2 yell at C1 but did not report the incident immediately, which also posed a risk to the other minors in care. Upon discovering the incident at a later date, the facility filed an incident report to notify the required parties and conducted its own internal investigation. Despite the presence of other staff members, established policies and procedures were not followed. LPA J. Armstrong reviewed evidence, including the Special Incident Report, Police Report, and the Internal Investigation, which confirmed the allegations mentioned above. Based on LPA interviews and record reviews and evidence obtained, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Therefore, issued a citation in accordance with the California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 80072(a)(3) Personal Rights. The exit interview was conducted with Audrey Hughes and a copy of this report was provided to the facility. (Continued on LIC 9099D)
investigation_findings: 13On July 10, 2025 at 10:15AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Justine Armstrong and Aimee Moratalla conducted an unannounced visit to the FTBP - Opportunities Home for Children to deliver their investigation findings. LPA J. Armstrong met with the Administrator Audrey Hughes, and together they discussed the findings. On May 16, 2025, Community Care Licensing received a complaint alleging the following incidents involving the care of a minor: 1. Staff handled the minor roughly 2. Staff locked the minor outside the facility for an extended period 3. Staff yelled at the minor 4. The staff's behavior poses a risk to minors in care. During the investigation, LPA J. Armstrong conducted confidential interviews and reviewed relevant documents. After evaluating all statements and information gathered, the allegations were substantiated. The evidence confirmed that the minor (C1) was handled roughly by being locked outside the facility by staff member S2. (Continued on LIC 9099C)

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 80072(a)(3) Personal Rights To be free from corporal or unusual punishment, infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature, including but not limited to: interference with the daily living functions... This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on Confidential interviews with staff and clients Staff #1's conduct failed to provide necessary supervision and protection to minors by locking the minor outside the facility and handling the minor in a rough manner.This poses an immediate health, safety and personal rights risk of harm to children placed in care.

met_with: Clinical Director, Joy Lewis and Administrator, John Lewis
narrative:
On October 21, 2021 at 9:35, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmetha White arrived at Growth Extended, Inc. Group Home for the purpose of conducting an Annual Required Inspection. LPA met with Clinical Director, Joy Lewis and Administrator, John Lewis who granted access to the location and together a tour of the entire facility was conducted both inside and out. The facility is licensed to provide care and supervision services for six (6) children ages 12-17 years old, ambulatory only. The census at the time of the inspection was three (3). The program accepts Private Placement clients only. The facility is a two story 6-bedroom, 4-bathroom house which includes a Living room, Dining room, Kitchen, Laundry area, a Classroom, a Front office, Staffing offices, Meeting/Conference room, and a Backyard patio. The home is set up as follows: Living room: Is equipped with a piano, couch, and chairs. Dining room: Is equipped with a table with seating for 8 people. Kitchen: Is equipped with a round glass table with 4 chairs. There is a stove/oven with gas burners all operable, a refrigerator/freezer, a dishwasher, and a microwave. The home was observed to have one-week supply of non-perishable and two days of perishable foods, including nutritious snacks, and the weekly menu is posted. The trash can is equipped with tight fitting lid. Laundry area: Is located next to the kitchen. It is equipped with a washer/dryer, found to be in working order, and a locked storage cabinet containing all sharp knives, disinfectants, and cleaning solutions. The laundry room also has a door leading to the backyard. Den: Is located off the hallway and is used for group sessions. It is equipped with ample seating, bookshelves, and a TV. Individual client lockers are located near the backdoor right next to the classroom area. Front office: Is equipped with a desk, 3 chairs, a sofa, and a locked file cabinet. Meeting/Conference room: This room is located outside in the back of the home. It is equipped with a conference room table that has ample seating, a television, and a bathroom. Nurses Office: Is located along the hallway between the Den and the Kitchen, across from the bathroom. It is equipped with a desk, computer, chair, sofa, and locked cabinet where all prescribed medications are locked and centrally stored. Medications are accessible only to employees supervising stored medications. The facility does not have any medications that need to be refrigerated. Report continued on LIC 809C.

Backyard patio: Is equipped with patio furniture and ample seating. Garage: has been converted into the facility’s classroom. It is equipped with Bedrooms: The home has 6 bedrooms which are all located on the second floor. Three (3) rooms are used as client bedrooms, each of client bedroom is equipped with two twin sized beds, and there is adequate closet/drawer space in each room. The three remaining rooms are utilized as follows: two rooms are used as staff offices, and one room is used as a client therapy room. Bathrooms: The home has a total of 5 bathrooms. One bathroom located along the hallway between the den and the kitchen, the second bathroom is located next to the laundry room and it used for the staff, the third and fourth bathrooms are located on the 2nd floor of the home, and the fifth bathroom is located in the meeting/conference room found in the backyard of the home. All bathrooms were observed to be in good repair and working order. The hot water temperature was tested and found to be between 105-120 degrees (F). The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. The first aid kit was checked and found to be complete. The home has 3 regulation fire extinguishers. There is a working telephone readily accessible. Overall LPA observed the home to be clean, safe, and sanitary. The front and backyard were clean and free of debris. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps and open porches are unobstructed. There are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the facility. There was no swimming pool or bodies of water located at the facility. The facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. LPA discussed and advised the Licensee to ensure the following: Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency or the Foster Care Ombudsperson, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. All posting requirements for Group Home Licensure and Emergency Plan were met. The Program has a total of six Staff. LPA reviewed six Staff files. LPA observed all Staff records included annual personnel performance evaluations, all staff have met the education and experience requirements, and have completed the required trainings. All staff that work directly with clients have current First Aid/CPR cards in their files. LPA will return on a later date to complete review of client files and conduct client and staff interviews. There were no deficiencies noted on this date. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was signed and left with the Clinical Director.

met_with: Clinical Director, Joy Lewis and Administrator, John Lewis
narrative: On October 22, 2021 at 9:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmetha White arrived at the above location for the purpose of reviewing client records and to conduct staff and client interviews in order to complete the STRTP Annual Required Inspection which began on 10/21/2021. LPA met with the Clinical Director, Joy Lewis and Administrator, John Lewis who granted access to location and provided the files. The Program has a three clients. LPA reviewed all client files, conducted interviews with all three clients and four staff. This inspection included an overview of required Core Services and Supports and based upon inspection of facility records and interviews of staff and clients. LPA discussed the following with the Facility Manager: Incident reporting, including incidents related to Law Enforcement contacts as well as incidents involving Emergency Intervention. Discussed procedures for CFT (Child and Family Team) meetings. Licensee is meeting all requirements. There were no deficiencies noted on this date. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was signed and left with the Clinical Director.

investigation_findings: 13On 06/20/2022 at 9:30am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Bernice Karnsrithong arrived at the facility for the purpose of conducting a complaint investigation and delivering its findings. Health and safety risk assessment was conducted upon arriving. LPA Karnsrithong met with Janice Lewis, Medical Associate who granted access and tour of the facility. During the investigation of the allegations, staff was flirting with a minor in care, minors not receiving medications as prescribed, staff behavior is disruptive to minors in care, and facility not serving meals in a timely manner; LPA Karnsrithong conducted confidential interviews and reviewed documentary evidences. During the investigation statements from confidential interviews were consistent that the facility has extensive medical administration procedures and meal schedules are being followed through and monitored regularly. There were no witnesses to corroborate the allegations. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that a violation occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. Exit interview was conducted with Janice Lewis and a copy of this report will be provided.

narrative:
On 06/21/2022 at 9:30am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Bernice Karnsrithong arrived at the facility for the purpose of conducting a complaint investigation and delivering its findings. Health and safety risk assessment was conducted upon arriving. LPA Karnsrithong met with Janice Lewis, Medical Associate. The current census is six (6) at the time of the visit. The facility is located in a residential neighborhood and in a two-story home. During the visit, LPA Karnsrithong has toured the kitchen. LPA Karnsrithong observed that the food preparation area in the kitchen/dining area is clean. Food menu and client schedules are posted in the kitchen. The cabinets are being used to store non-perishable food items and kitchen supplies and equipment. There is refrigerator, stove, and sink that is operational and in good repair. During the visit, a cabinet next to the sink was observed to broken but is blocked and boarded up. LPA Karnsrithong also toured the backyard/outside area of the facility. This area is being used as additional parking for staff and storage for large movable trash bins. LPA Karnsrithong has observed that movable bins had missing or broken lids during the visit. LPA Karnsrithong has observed visible insects swarming around the trash bins as well. During the visit, LPA Karnsrithong has also checked the fingerprint background clearance and association of all staff present. It was determined that two (2) staff present at the facility during the visit does not have cleared fingerprint background clearance. It was determined during the visit that these staff present have pending fingerprint clearance applications only. (Page 1 of 2)

Based on the observations during this visit, Facility is cited for the violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, Regulation 80088 Furniture, Fixtures, Equipment, and Supplies: (1) All containers, including movable bins, used for storage of solid wastes shall have tight-fitting covers kept on the containers; shall be in good repair, shall be leakproof and rodent-proof 80019 Criminal Record Clearance (e) All individuals subject to a criminal record review pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1522 shall prior to working, residing or volunteering in a licensed facility: (1) Obtain a California clearance or a criminal record exemption as required by the Department or (2) Request a transfer of a criminal record clearance as specified in Section 80019(f) or (3) Request and be approved for a transfer of a criminal record exemption, as specified in Section 80019.1(r), unless, upon request for the transfer, the Department permits the individual to be employed, reside or be present at the facility. The purpose of the inspection was to assess Civil Penalties for staff 2 and 3 not being associated to the above facility. Copy of Report, LIC 809D, Civil Penalties LIC 421BG and Appeal Rights were given. Appeal rights were explained to the facility representative. Exit interview and plan of correction were discussed with Janice Lewis, Medical Associate. A copy of this report will be provided to the facility.

There was no swimming pool or bodies of water located at the facility. The facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. LPA discussed and advised the Licensee to ensure the following: Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. All posting requirements for Group Home Licensure and Emergency Plan were met. The Program has a total of six staff and four clients. LPA interviewed two staff and two clients. LPA will return on a later date to review client files and staff files. There were no deficiencies noted on this date. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. investigation_findings: 13On 4/14/2025 LPA J. Armstrong and LPM E. Hernandez arrived at the facility at 2:00pm. The Licensee was not present and did not answer the phone. The Findings could not be delivered today. On April 15, 2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Justine Armstrong conducted an unannounced visit to Growth Extended Inc. to conclude the investigation of the above allegations and deliver the findings. LPA met with John Lewis the Administrator and together, they discussed the investigation details. It was reported Staff mismanaged residents' medication records, Staff did not give residents their medications as prescribed, Facility does not have a vehicle to transport residents, Staff did not ensure that facility has adequate food for the residents, and Staff did not adequately supervise residents. During the investigation, the Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) conducted confidential interviews and reviewed several documents, including vehicle insurance records, the client medication roster, grocery lists for the facility, and the staff and client roster. While conducting confidential interviews, there was not enough evidence to substantiate the allegations. One of the confidential interviews reported that they received their medication daily and noted that the only time they missed their medication was during a visit away from the facility. C1 also mentioned that plenty of food is always available and that the facility never runs out of supplies. Based on the information gathered from the confidential interviews and documentary evidence, the LPA concluded that the allegations were unsubstantiated.

13On 08/30/2024, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA’s) C. White and J. Armstrong arrived at the facility for the purpose of concluding the investigation and to deliver findings. LPA’s met with Administrator, John Lewis and discussed the allegations. During the course of this investigation, LPA interviewed pertinent parties and reviewed records. Confidential interviews and records did not produce corroborating evidence to support the allegations. Staff denied the allegations and stated a staff member was present at the hospital with the client, that staff was in constant communication with the hospital, and that clients are never left unsupervised. Additionally, Client statements did not produce corroborating evidence to support the allegations. Based on information obtained, the allegations are found to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur. Exit interview completed and a copy of this report was left with the Administrator.

narrative: On August 15, 2024, a Component II Orientation was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vanessa Galvan with Applicant, Gloria Torres. The purpose of the Component II Orientation was to review the application, discuss the process, and provide the applicants with needed information. The following was addressed and discussed: · The program expectations. · An overview of the program statement. · Informed the applicants of corrections needing to be made to the application. · Revisions to the Plan of Operation/Program Statement (POO/PS) to meet regulatory standards. · Transferring and associating employees in Guardian, LPA will provide user form to applicant. The pre-licensing inspection is scheduled for 08/30/2024 at 2:30 PM. The facility is located at 1004 Pioneer Ave, Porterville, CA 93257. A copy of this report was provided to Gloria Torres.

On August 30, 2024, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Vanessa Galvan traveled to G.T. Care Homes Inc.The purpose of the visit is to conduct a pre-licensing Facility Inspection. LPA met at the facility by Administrator Gloria Torres. LPA toured the facility and observed the following listed below. 1.The facility has a staff room and is inaccessible to clients. In the staff room is where medication, sharps/knives, and client files are locked and stored. 2. In the kitchen LPA observed a fire extinguisher, first aid kit including all required items and first aid manual are included in the kit. The facility maintained a trash can with a lid in the kitchen. LPA observed a weekly menu for clients. The refrigerator temperature is 37 degrees and freezer temperature are -1 degrees. 3. The dining room has a table with chairs to accommodate the number of clients. 4. The house has four bedrooms- four ambulatory, single occupancy, all located on one single level. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings and storage space. All rooms are equipped with fire alarms and trash can. 5. The facility has adequate storage space and furniture. 6. The outdoor space has plenty of outdoor space and equipped outdoor furniture. No hazards were observed at the outdoor space. 7. The outdoor of the home was free from hazard and obstructions. 8. Adequate food storage space observed. Perishable and non-perishable foods will be available before client are placed in the facility. 9. Facility has two full bathrooms, and all are operable. Facility is to ensure water temperature is maintained between 105 and 120 degrees. All restrooms are stored with hand soap, toilet paper, and paper towels. 10. Appropriate forms posted in the facility. 11. The temperature of the facility was a comfortable temperature.. 12. Facility has extra towels and linens for all clients. 13.The facility does not have a firearm, ammunition, or weapons. Agency will make sure all staff receives a background clearance with FBI, CAIC, and DOJ and are associate in Guardian.

On December 19, 2024, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Vanessa Galvan traveled to G.T. Care Homes Inc. and met with the Administrator Gloria Torres. The purpose of the inspection was to continue the pre-licensing inspection. LPA conducted a physical plant inspection to verify the facility telephone, fireplace cover, outlet covers, and cleanup of the facility garage. LPA reviewed LIC forms, reporting requirements, Disaster Preparedness plan, training requirements and resources, post-licensing inspection requirements, and facility vehicle requirements. A copy of this report was provided to Gloria Torres at the conclusion inspection.

On July 31, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vanessa Galvan traveled to G.T. Care Homes INC located in Porterville, CA to conduct a post-licensing inspection and met with Administrator Gloria Torres. The facility was licensed on December 23, 2024. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following observations and checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials observed. All required forms are posted. The temperature of the facility was a comfortable temperature of 73 degrees. All facility smoke detectors are in appropriate working order and all fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced. The kitchen has a full-size refrigerator and is operating at a safe temperature. Facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and food menu is posted. Knives and sharps are key locked and inaccessible to clients. Chemical, disinfectants, and cleaning solutions are key locked and inaccessible to clients. The dining room is equipped with large table and chairs accommodating all clients. There are four ambulatory bedrooms, single occupancy, all located on one single level. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings and storage space. All rooms are equipped with a fire alarm and trash can. Individual beds were observed and appropriate clean linens and are in good repair. The facility has three full bathrooms and in operable condition. The bathrooms are stored with hand soap, toilet paper, and paper towels. In the staff office medications are dispensed to clients. Medications are locked and inaccessible to clients. LPA observed medications are centrally stored. First Aid kit is stored in the hallway closet and is complete with all first aid items. The facility has a staff office and is inaccessible to clients. The facility stores extra supplies of linens, personal hygiene products, and emergency food supply. There are no firearms or weapons allowed in the facility. There are no bodies of water on the facility grounds. LPA reviewed three staff files. A review of staff files indicated that all facility staff have received child abuse index clearances and fingerprint clearances. Agency staff meet the requirements of respective job descriptions. Agency Employs one Administrator, one Facility Manager, and four Direct Support Professional. LPA reviewed three client files. All required documentation were observed in the client files. There were no deficiencies or citations issued on today's inspection. A copy of this report was left with Gloria Torres at the conclusion of the inspection.

On 6/17/2021 at 9:45 am, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Jenny Mundo and Timika Martin conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility and met with the Facility Manager Veronica Heron. The purpose of the inspection was to conduct an Annual/Required inspection. LPAs Mundo and Martin conducted a tour of the inside and outside of the facility accompanied by staff at 10:00 am. This facility has three bedrooms, two restrooms and a game room for clients. There are currently four (4) clients in placement and twelve (12) group home staff. LPAs observed the following documents posted in the living room, dining room and kitchen areas: group home license, client activity schedule, staff roster and schedule, client school information, facility menu, personal rights and grievance procedures. There is a sufficient amount of perishable and non-perishable food. All cleaning supplies, knives, medication and client files are kept locked. The facility has a first aid kit and fire extinguisher that was serviced on 1/28/2021. Carbon monoxide/smoke detectors are operable and located throughout the facility. The following are kept inside the garage which is inaccessible to clients: extra perishable food items in a refrigerator, emergency supplies and cleaning supplies. LPA Martin reviewed 4 client files, LPA Mundo reviewed 5 staff files, monthly fire drills, client medication and logs. A revised copy of the facility’s emergency disaster plan was submitted and will be reviewed by LPA Mundo. A review of staff records indicates that all facility staff or other individuals who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. This facility is under the umbrella of Hope House Lic. # 191501937, so all staff criminal record clearances are associated and kept in a central administrative file with Hope House. There were no deficiencies observed during this inspection. The facility operates within the licensed capacity and limitations. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was provided to the facility representative.

On 6/15/2022 at 11:15 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jenny Mundo conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility and met with the Administrator, Wanda Magee. The purpose of the inspection was to conduct an Annual/Required inspection. The facility currently has four (4) residents in placement and twelve (12) personnel. LPA requested a copy of the following: -current LIC 500 (Personnel Report) -client/resident roster -Board minutes - LIC 610 C Emergency Disaster Plan & written disaster and mass casualty plan of action LPA conducted a walkthrough of the inside and outside of the facility at 12:00 pm. This facility has three (3) bedrooms, two (2) restrooms, a living room, a dinning area, a kitchen, a laundry room/area, a game room for clients, a garage and outdoor space. There are no bodies of water on the premises. The facility is licensed to serve up to four (4) ambulatory minors ages 12-17 years of age. PHYSICAL PLANT LPA observed the following signage posted in the living room, dining room and kitchen areas: group home license, client activity schedule, staff roster and schedule, client school information, facility menus, personal rights and grievance procedures. There is sufficient amount of perishable and non-perishable food. Disinfectant, cleaning solutions, sharps & knives and medication are kept locked in the kitchen and inaccessible to the clients. The client files are kept locked in the hallway near the bedrooms. The facility has a complete first aid kit and a fire extinguisher that was serviced on 5/22/2022.

Carbon monoxide/smoke detectors were tested and observed to be operable. The following are kept inside the garage in locked cabinets which is inaccessible to clients: extra perishable food items in a refrigerator, emergency supplies, cleaning supplies and old files. The facility’s room temperatures was maintained at a safe and comfortable temperature. The hot water temperature was tested and measured at 117.2 degrees F. There are no firearms on the premises. The facility phone system is operable. OPERATIONS Facility maintains a register of clients and the register is available upon request. The board of directors regularly conducts meeting to review and discuss the facility’s operation. The facility Program Director is the responsible and capable staff for communicating with emergency personnel in the facility. The facility has developed, maintained and implemented written complaint procedures. CLIENT RECORDS LPA reviewed four (4) client records. Client records are maintained locked onsite. CLIENTS WITH SPECIAL HEALTH CARE NEEDS There are currently no clients in care with special health care needs. Annual Continuation is required at a later date. An exit interviewed was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to facility representative.

On 6/22/2022 at 10:25 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jenny Mundo conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility and met with the Administrator, Wanda Magee. The purpose of the inspection was to conduct an Annual Continuation from the initial inspection on 6/15/2022. DISASTER PREPAREDNESS PLAN Facility maintains a current, written disaster and mass casualty plan of action. Facility conducts disaster drills at least quarterly. The drills are documented, and the documentation is maintained in the facility for at least a year. Facility maintains an emergency and disaster plan, register of clients, Individual Person Plans (IPPs)/Quarterly reports for each client, medication records, and contact information for each client's responsible party and physician. EMERGENCY INTERVENTION PLAN LPA reviewed the facility's emergency intervention plan. The facility has not used any manual restraints within the past 12 months. However, the facility has a log prepared that contains all required information when needed. Facility has an emergency intervention training curriculum. All staff members are trained on the facility's emergency intervention procedures. STAFFING RECORDS LPA Mundo reviewed two (2) staff records. Staff records are maintained in the main office, also located in El Monte. All facility staff have received a criminal record clearance or exemption and child abuse index checks. All file documentation is complete, signed and current. There are no citations assessed during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted and a signed copy of this report was provided to the facility representative.

This department has investigated the allegations, and although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that staff sexually abused a minor in care; therefore, the above allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. The Program Manager has agreed to sign and return the LIC9099. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed, and no deficiencies were cited. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was sent to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brian Bertoli conversed via phone with Program Manager Jeremiah Presinal regarding a complaint investigation at the facility. The purpose of the conversation was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. Due to current COVID-19 protocols, this visit was conducted over the phone and the appropriate signatures will be acquired subsequently. The investigation was conducted by CCIB investigator Jami Eaton. During the course of the investigation, Investigator Eaton interviewed five former residents, three staff, and reviewed documentation. Investigator Eaton attempted to interview the victim and alleged perpetrator, but was unable to do so. The alleged perpetrator provided a written statement denying the allegation. A forensic interview of the victim was reviewed. None of the staff or residents were aware of any activity related to the allegation. The investigator was unable to determine if any sexual abuse occurred. There is a lack of clear evidence to make a determination as to whether a regulatory violation occurred.

narrative: Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Brian Bertoli and David Hiett conducted an unannounced inspection for the purposes of completing an Annual/Required Inspection and met with administrator Scott Singer. A pre-screening call was done prior to arrival, and Administrator Singer indicated that one client was COVID positive and in quarantine and one staff who was also positive and was off work. Appropriate protocols were followed in the facility for the inspection and all interviews were conducted outdoors. The Physical Plant was toured inside and out by LPA Bertoli. Water temperatures were measured at 114F. Seven-day Non-perishable food supply was inspected and was found to be adequate. Two-day perishable food supply was inspected and were found to be adequate and consistent with the menu. LPA inspected bedrooms and found that there was adequate linens and each bed had mattress pads. The home is clean and in good repair. There are no firearms in the facility. There are no open bodies of water on the property. Medications are locked in the office. Toxics and cleaning solutions are in a locked cabinet. Required documents are posted. There are charged operable fire extinguishers, carbon monoxide and smoke detectors are in the facility. Client files were partially reviewed at the administration office and will be completed on another date. Per Title 22 Regulations, no deficiencies were cited during this inspection.

narrative: On 5/13/25, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins visited the facility in order to conduct a youth interview regarding an outside matter. LPA met with Director Jeremiah Presinal and informed of the visit. The visit was scheduled in advance, and Director facilitated the interview by securing a meeting location and notifying the youth of LPA's visit. LPA conducted one confidential youth interview. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Director Jeremiah Presinal.

On 5/19/2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) conducted a Technical Assistance Meeting (TA) via Microsoft Teams. Present from Harvesting Hearts was Licensee James Jones (LS). During the TA, the entirety of the revision letter, section A1-A13, B1-B18, and The Program Narrative/Statement part 3-29 was reviewed and discussed. LS had questions regarding the Partnership Agreement/Articles of Incorporation and if LS could request a DBA for the name Harvesting Hearts. LPA discussed in-service staff training, documentation of job shadowing, initial and annual review of psychotropic medication training, reviewing of children's personal rights, and documentation of training evaluation. Financial requirements were discussed and an updated LIC 401 will be submitted to LPA for a second review. LS had concerns regarding the amount of sufficient financial resources needed to operate the facility. LS will surrender Adult Residential Facility to conduct a fire inspection with the Fire Marshall. The Adult Residential Facility shares the same address as the prospective facility for Harvesting Hearts Group Home. LS disclosed to LPA Galvan the revisions are currently being worked on. The Application timeline and process were discussed during the TA. The department and the applicant/licensee agreed on a due date of June 10, 2023, for corrections to be submitted via email with highlighted changes.

Visitation, Part 14. Emergency Intervention Plan, Part 15. Runaway Plan, Part 22. Staff Qualifications, Part 24. In-service Training for Staff/Administrator · Submit Application to Guardian to associate staff. · All corrections and updates will be completed by 8/04/2022. Race Ave, Visalia, CA, 93292. A copy of this report was provided to James Jones.

On May 15, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vanessa Galvan traveled to the Harvesting Heart Group Homes located in Visalia, CA, to conduct an unannounced Case Management and met with Facility Manager, Monique Jones. The purpose of the inspection is to discuss an incident report that was submitted to the department on 05/14/2024 regarding client 1 (C1) and a review on how to properly fill out and submit an LIC624. Between the dates of May 12, 2024, and May 13, 2024, C1 was exhibited disruptive behaviors including yelling, cursing, and throwing objects. C1 refused phone calls from family and medical appointments. Teacher contacted the facility and informed facility representative that C1 made a report to their bus driver regarding the facility. LPA obtain additional information from the facility manager regarding the incidents that occurred. LPA discussed with the Facility manager reporting requirements, the need to provide details of incident, timeframes on reporting incident(s), and reviewed the LIC 624 and LIC 624LE. No deficiencies observed or cited during the inspection. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of the report and LIC 811 were discussed and provided to Monique Jones at the conclusion of the inspection.

On June 12, 2024, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Vanessa Galvan and Brinae Pointer traveled to Harvesting Hearts located in Visalia, CA to conduct a post-licensing inspection. The facility was licensed on December 8, 2023. LPA were met at the facility by Administrator Queen Jones and Licensee James Jones. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following observations and checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials observed. All required forms are posted. The temperature of the facility was a comfortable temperature of 73 degrees. All facility smoke detectors are in appropriate working order and all fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced. The kitchen has a full-size refrigerator and is operating at safe temperature. Facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and food menu is posted. Knives and sharps are key locked and inaccessible to clients. Chemical, disinfectants, and cleaning solutions are key locked and inaccessible to clients. The dining room is equipped with large table and chairs accommodating of all clients. There are four ambulatory bedrooms, single occupancy, all located on one single level. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings and storage space. All rooms are equipped with a fire alarm and trash can. Individual beds were observed and appropriate clean linens and are in good repair. Facility has two full restroom and in operable conditions. The restrooms are stored with hand soap, toilet paper, and paper towels. In the staff office medications are dispensed to clients. Medications are locked and inaccessible to clients. LPA observed medications are centrally stored. First Aid kit is stored in the kitchen and is complete with all first aid items. The facility has a staff office and is inaccessible to clients. The facility stores extra supplies of linens, personal hygiene products, and emergency food supply. There are no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. There are no bodies of water on the facility grounds. LPA reviewed three staff files. A review of staff files indicated that all facility staff have received child abuse index clearances and fingerprint clearances. Agency staff meet requirements of respective job descriptions. Agency Employs one Administrator, one House Manager, and one Direct Support Professional/house manager. LPA will need to return to the facility to review client files and conduct staff and client interviews. There were no deficiencies or citations issued today. A copy of this report was left with James Jones at the conclusion of the inspection.

narrative:
On December 8, 2020 at 9:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sethany Yem conducted an Annual/ Required Inspection for the above facility. LPA met with the the Administrator Tiffany Pineda who granted a virtual access into the facility, and who provided a tour of the entire physical plant inside and out. This facility is licensed for private placement to provide care/supervision for six (6) male and female, ambulatory only clients, ages 12-17 years. The home is set up as follows: This is two story, four (4) bedroom, four (4) bathroom home located in a residential neighborhood. There is a swimming pool on the premises that has a fence around the pool with a lock and a latch to make it inaccessible to the clients. There is also a patio next to the pool with a table and adequate amount of seating. Downstairs (main floor) has the following: There is a living room with a sectional sofa, three (3) bean bags, a flat seating that can seat two (2) with a large TV. There is a gym with exercise equipment, an intake room, two (2) therapists rooms, a storage room and a laundry room. Dining room has 11 seats with games and art activities. There is a kitchen with non-perishable foods for one week and perishable food for two (2) days. There is an emergency doorway to facilitate evacuation from the intake room, dining room sliding door, living room and dining room door. There are emergency exit signs on each exit. Bedroom #1: Is equipped with two (2) twin size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting. Bedroom #2: Is equipped with one (1) twin size bed. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting. Bedroom #3: Is equipped with two (2) full size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting. This room has an attached bathroom and current has 1 vacant bed. Bedroom #4: Is equipped with one (1) twin size bed. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting. Upstairs (2nd floor) has an area that the facility calls a classroom with 6 apple desktop computers, adequate amount of seating, a locked fireplace that is disabled, and an attached bathroom and a medication room that is locked and only accessible to employees. Report continued on LIC 809-C.

Facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps, and open porches are unobstructed. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions, and poisons are made inaccessible. There are no firearms/dangerous weapons. Temperatures in rooms that clients occupy are maintained between 68 and 85 degrees (F). Children in care will be supervised and protected at all times; Children will attend school, extracurricular, cultural, and personal enrichment activities. All smoke detectors were tested and are operating properly in the home at the time of visit. Carbon Monoxide alarms were tested and functional in the home at the time of the visit. Facility has non-perishable foods for one week and perishable foods for two days. Facility provides nutritious snacks between meals. Medications locked and accessible only to employees responsible for stored medications. Facility posts child's rights if licensed to provide foster care for six or more children. Children are not restricted in telephone use except by court order. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. Children live in a safe, healthy, comfortable home and are treated with respect. Children can contact the licensing agency or Foster Care Ombudsperson in confidence without threats or punishment for making complaints. Emergency Disaster Mass Casualty Plan: Current and available for review. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. Client and Staff files will be reviewed at a later date. Exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report is discussed and will be emailed to the Administrator Tiffany Pineda.

Based on the information obtained during confidential interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be unsubstantiated. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of the report will be emailed to the administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On December 18, 2020 at 1:47pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sethany Yem conducted a tele-visit follow-up complaint inspection with Hatteras Group Home and spoke with Administrator Tiffany Pineda. The purpose of the tele-visit was to deliver findings for the above complaint allegation. During the course of investigating the allegation of Minor sleeping on couch, LPA conducted interviews with related parties. It was reported to LPA that there has been a client that has been sleeping on the couch for a week and the minor does not want to sleep in the room. Confidential interviews revealed that clients would sleep in their room and there has been a few situations where clients would request to sleep on the couch due to reasons related to trauma. It was indicated in interviews that staff would encourage the clients to sleep in their room but if a client refuses, staff will continue to redirect until the transition is comfortable for the client. Interviews revealed that staff do not force clients to sleep on the couch and it would be the client that would ask to sleep on the couch if they felt uncomfortable in their room. LPA could not determine if a violation occurred due to lack of evidence. Contunue on 9099-C

LPA assessed that all statements were congruent with the method of interventions implemented to ensure that the facility provided proper supervision to support and met the needs of children in placement. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. The Department has determined that the allegations of Neglect/Lack of Supervision are unsubstantiated but if any additional information is received this complaint can be amended and the finding can be changed. There are no deficiencies noted or cited An exit interview was conducted and the report was provided to the Program Director on 07/22/2022.
investigation_findings: 13On July 22, 2022, at 10:30 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Rosslyn Gray made an unannounced visit to conclude the investigation and to deliver the finding. LPA-Gray conducted a Health and Safety asssement of the facility. During the investigation, LPA-Gray interviewed and accounted for all available relevant parties; and gathered pertinent information in reference to the two (2) allegations listed in the complaint. The facility denied the allegations and there were no creditable statements obtain from clients due to phasing out of the program. Information and records obtained revealed that there were no statements or documented evidence to support the allegations that the facility " Staff failed to meet the clients' needs, Staff failed to prevent clients' from self-harm” ever occurred. The internal Investigation revealed that the facility provided evidence of Therapeutic Treatment and various program intervention procedures to prevent self-harm. The staff provided proper supervision and took precautionary measures to ensure the health and safety of clients in placement. Evidence also show that the facility met the requirements of Staff to client Ratio.

narrative:
On November 21, 2023, at 10:00 AM, (LPA) Licensing Program Analyst – Dennis Jarmin made an unannounced visit to Hatteras Group Home to conduct the 2-year Annual Inspection. LPA met Kaz Katseanes (Assistant Regional Program Director) and Toni Rainey (Director of Operations) who granted access to the facility and provided a copy of LIC 500 and LIC 9020. LPA then inspected the entire physical plant of the facility. The Group Home is licensed to provide care/supervision up to six (6) male and female children ages 12-17, Ambulatory only. There is a swimming pool on premises that meets regulations. Home composition: This is a two story, four (4) bedroom, four (4) bathroom home located in a residential neighborhood. There is a swimming pool on the premises that has a fence around the pool with a lock and a latch to make it inaccessible to the clients. There is also a patio next to the pool with a table and an adequate amount of seating. Downstairs (main floor) has the following: There is a living room with a sectional sofa, three (3) bean bags, a flat seating that can seat two (2) with a large TV and a fireplace that is disabled and inaccessible. There is a gym with exercise equipment, an intake room, two (2) therapists' rooms, a storage room, and a laundry room. The dining room has 10 chairs available for seating. The kitchen has several cabinets and knives are stowed properly, and bleach and cleaning materials are locked on one of the upper cabinets. There is a large refrigerator and freezer with an appropriate temperature gauge and an operable stove/oven burner for cooking. There is an emergency doorway to enable evacuation from the intake room, dining room sliding door, living room, and dining door area. The home is equipped equipped with emergency exit signs on each exit. LPA observed two fire extinguishers downstairs to the right of the kitchen fully charged. Bedroom #1: This is equipped with two (2) twin-size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting. Bedroom #2: This is equipped with one (1) twin-size bed. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting. The facility Manager stated room 2 is currently not occupied. Bedroom #3: This is equipped with two (2) full-size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting. This room has an attached bathroom.

Bedroom #4: Is equipped with one (1) twin-size bed. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting. LPA observed all bedroom windows and screens were in good repair. Upstairs (2nd floor) – Designated as the classroom is equipped with 6 Apple desktop computers, adequate amount of seating, and an attached bathroom and a medication room that is locked and only accessible to employees. The facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps, and open porches are unobstructed. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions, and poisons are made inaccessible. There are no firearms/dangerous weapons on site. Temperatures in rooms that clients occupy are maintained suitably between 68 and 85 degrees (F). Hot water temperatures are maintained between 105 and 120 degrees (F), however, a slight deviation in temperature was noted during LPA’s walk through. Maintenance was called to repair the hot water immediately and work order was provided to LPA. Children in care are supervised and protected at all times. The youths attends school and participates in extracurricular activities including cultural and personal enrichment program. All smoke detectors were tested and operable including the two carbon monoxide detectors operating properly at the time of the inspection. The facility has 7 days non-perishable foods and 3 days perishable, and provides nutritional snacks between meals. LPA conducted (3) staff interviews and (2) client interviews and all required posting were met (meal plan, daily activities, required licenses and regulations, personal rights and emergency disaster plan) that are posted in the common area readily accessible to clients. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report is discussed and will be emailed to the Assistant Regional Director.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegations. LPA interviewed all involved staff, clients and witnesses. LPA Jones-Steward reviewed intake assessment and treatment plan for C1. Clients and Staff both report that staff were unaware that the clients AWOLED or that C1 did not return. Both staff persons who were interviewed stated that they did not notice that clients were missing until the next morning when the mother of one of the clients called to report that her daughter was i the hospital. Both staff stated that they overlooked reporting the hospitalization to Community Care Licensing.. Based on the available information, the above allegations are substantiated.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Reporting Requirements The facility shall report to the Department any injury to a child that requires medical treatment or attention Based on interviews and review of incident reports, the facility failed to meet this requirement when it did not report that a child was hospitalized as a consequence of her going AWOL.

Responsibility to provide care and supervision The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. Based on interviews, the facility failed to meet this regulation when overnight staff failed to realize that three clients had AWOLED on the night of 07/04/23.

narrative: On 9/16/24 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Lakescia Smith arrived at the Hatteras facility and conducted an unannounced inspection regarding a case management-other inspection. During the course of the inspection LPA and LPM witnessed a sinking bed for one of the clients. LPA and LPM inspected the bed and found that under the mattress the middle bar of the bed frame was not attached to the rest of the bed frame. LPA and LPM informed and showed Director of Operations (DO) Toni Jackson-Rainey the bed frame and the unconnected pieces. DO said they would take the next steps to address and fix the bed. Also while reviewing the personnel report LPA and LPM found staff on the roster that could not be conformed to have criminal record clearance. LPA and LPM informed DO that all staff must be cleared and any staff not found with clearance can not work in facility. LPA will check guardian to ensure staff clearance and will follow up with DO tomorrow. Exit Interview completed with staff Toni. See next page for Advisory Technical Violation. Report will be emailed to Toni.

On 10/01/2024 at 10:00 am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Lakescia Smith arrived at Hatteras for the purpose of an unannounced case management deficiency inspection. LPA and LPM met with staff to discuss criminal record clearances. On 9/16/24 licensing staff conducted an unannounced visit and learned that several staff working at the facility were not associated to Hatteras. LPA and LPM researched guardian and determined that several staff worked in the facility without being associated. Although staff was associated to Calenda or Ladrillo they must be associated to Hatteras as well prior to working in the facility. Based on interview evidence and records review LPA and LPM discovered that five employees did not have their criminal record clearances transferred to the Hatteras facility. The following deficiency is being cited for violating of California Code of Regulations Title 22, Division 6 Regulation 80019 (e) (3) criminal record clearance. (see page 809 D) Exit interview completed and appeal rights issued. Report will be emailed to staff and LPA and LPM will also forward PIN regarding camera use.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Criminal Records Clearance. All individuals subject to a criminal record review pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1522 shall prior to working, residing or volunteering in a licensed facility:Request a transfer of a criminal record clearance as specified in Section 80019 (f). This requierment is not meet as evidence by: Based on documentation and interview evidence collected the facility failed to transfer staff criminal record clearances to Hatteras facility which poses an immediate health and safety hazard to the clients in care.

Civil Penalty. Notwithstanding Section 80054(a) above, an immediate penalty of $100 per cited violation per day for a maximum of five (5) days shall be assessed if any individual required to be fingerprinted under Health and Safety Code 1522 (b) has not obtained a California clearanceor a criminal record exemption, requested a transfer of a criminal record clearance. A civil penalty has been assesed for 5 staff.

narrative: Facility was cited for lack of a posted menu 84076 (b), requiring clients to participate in meal preparation 84076 (c) (5) (C), and failure to maintain the physical plant in good repair including a missing pantry cabinet, a cracked bedroom door, and a hanging emergency exit sign 80087 (a) (2). During a walk through on 10/1/24 LPA and LPM observed the fixed emergency exit sign and was informed of pending repairs for the cracked door and missing cabinet door. During the walk through on 10/1/24 LPA and LPM also observed a mattress that was longer than the frame and a missing shower door in the bathroom by the entrance. Hatteras staff informed LPA and LPM that they have order a new shower door and will order a new mattress. Exit interview to be completed with staff and a copy of the appeal right issued.
investigation_findings: 13On 10/01/2024 at 10:15 am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Lakescia Smith investigated the above allegations. LPA and LPM interviewed involved staff and clients. LPA and LPM also conducted a walk-through inspection of the facility on 9/16/24. Interview evidence revealed a lack of a monthly written and posted menu since the facility chef resigned on 8/15/24. Since then clients are being required to participate in meal preparation for breakfast, lunch, and dinner.Interview statements reveal that some staff do assist clients in preparing some of their daily meals. During the walk-through LPA and LPM observed a crack in a bedroom door, a kitchen cabinet without a door, and an exit sign hanging loosely from the celling. Based on the available information LPA and LPM gathered from interviews and observation, the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met, therefore the allegations are found to be substantiated. Continued on next page. (see 9099 C).

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Food Service. Written menus shall be posted weekly in an area accessible to the staff and children. This requierment is not met as evidence by: Based on interview evidence and observations the facility has not been creating monthly menus for the clients since the chef resigned which poses a potential health and safety risk to the clients in care.

Food Service. Not require a child to participate in meal preparation. This requierment is not met as evidence by: Based on interview evidence Hatteras staff has been requiring clients to participate in meal preparation for breakfast, lunch, and dinner which poses a potential health and safety risk to the clients in care.

Building and Grounds. The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors. This requirement is not met as evidence by: Observation evidence including a crack in a bedroom door, a kitchen cabinet without a door, and an exit sign hanging loosely from the ceiling which poses a potential health and safety risk to the clients in care.

facility_name: HAVEN OF WALNUT CREEK, LLC, THE
narrative:
On Tuesday 12/14/21 at 11:56AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility to conduct a required annual inspection. LPA met with Facility Manager Mark Pons and informed of the purpose of the visit. The CARES Inspection Tool was used to conduct the inspection. The facility and grounds are clean, well-maintained, and free of obstructions. There are no bodies of water, and there are no firearms on the premises, per Facility Manager. Food is within date and in a quantity to meet the needs of residents in care. Room temperature and hot water temperature measured within permitted range, at 72 F and 105.1 F, respectively. Residents have individual beds with clean linens and mattress pads. Confidential interviews were conducted with both present staff. Residents were at school, and 3 of 4 are nonverbal. Facility, staff, and resident records were inspected and observed to be complete. The following items need to be addressed: 1) Resident R4 (See LIC 811 Confidential Names, dated 12/14/21) file contained an incomplete LIC 405 Record of Client's/Resident's Safeguarded Cash Resources. R4 receives county funding, which is not separated into a separate P&I fund as with Regional Center. However, LPA advises, per California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Section 80070, that cash resources similarly be logged on the LIC 405 to ensure that record is maintained. 2) Resident R3 file had a psychotropic medication, Trazodone, that was logged on the standard Medication Administration Record (MAR - LIC622A) rather than the Psychotropic MAR (PMAR - LIC622B). The facility did already have a psychotropic medication consent form signed by authorized representative. The log was otherwise complete and properly maintained. LPA advises, per CCR, Title 22, Section 84070, that the facility begin using the PMAR for this medication starting January 2022 so as to avoid confusing the records. 3) Resident records did not contain documentation of shared bedrooms. LPA advises, per CCR, Title 22, Section 84087, that the facility document whenever a bedroom is shared to ensure the arrangement is compatible and to maintain this documentation in the file of each resident sharing a bedroom.

There are no citations. Three advisories were issued per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Sections 80070 Client Records, 84070 Children's Records, and 84087 Buildings and Grounds. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Facility Manager Mark Pons, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

facility_name: HAVEN OF WALNUT CREEK, LLC, THE
narrative: On 03/16/2022 at 10:00AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood conducted an unannounced visit to the above listed facility for the purpose of conducting the required annual inspection. LPA met with Mark Pons, Facility Manager, and conducted a walk-through of the facility. There were two staff members and zero clients present at the time of inspection. The facility currently has a census of four clients, one that is a non-minor dependent. The four clients are either fully or partially nonverbal. LPA reviewed the centrally stored medication log, four client files, five staff files, the personnel binder, and the emergency plan. LPA interviewed two staff members. LPA delivered a Technical Violation for CCR 84087(e) due to the lack of documentation on room sharing compatibility. LPA delivered a Technical Assistance for CCR 80066(a)(8) for the lack of duties specified within the staff files. LPA conducted a complete physical site inspection and found no deficiencies. The facility was clean, sanitary, and there was an adequate amount of food for all youth present. LPA toured the youth's rooms and found that they all had adequate space and necessities. LPA conducted an exit interview with Mark Pons at 1:30PM, whose signature confirms the receipt of this document.

facility_name: HAVEN OF WALNUT CREEK, LLC, THE
narrative:
An unannounced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng on 6/2/2022 at 10:00 AM. During the inspection, LPA Ng met with Mark Pons, Facility Manager and inspected the facility inside and out. Administrator Juvy Golub (ADM) later arrived at the facility. LPA interviewed 2 of staff on site at 10:15 AM. LPA interviewed 0 of children currently taking psychotropic medication at 10:45 AM. LPA reviewed 4 of staff personnel files on site at the facility at 11:00 AM LPA reviewed 3 of child’s records on site at the facility at 11:22 AM. At 11:22 AM, LPA Ng and FM began the pill count for the three clients (refer to LIC811 for confidential names). There is a total of three out of four clients on psychotropic medication. When counting medications for C1, there were two pills that were missing from the pill bottle. The total pills that were supposed to be in bottle was 27. LPA Ng and FM counted 25 pills. Both FM and ADM recounted and confirmed there was missing two pills. FM suggested to count the refill bottle that he stated the facility has not touched since picking the prescription up from the pharmacy. The quantity on the label was 60. After counting three times, it was a total of 61 pills. FM asked if he can put the extra pill in the bottle that was missing two, LPA advised both FM and ADM to keep all medication in their assigned bottle and to consult with the pharmacy regarding the quantity in both pill bottles. C2 and C3 bottles contained the correct quantity of pills. ----------CONT ON 809-C---------

LPA conducted exit interview with Mark Pons, Facility Manager at 1:45 PM. LPA provided the Summary Report to Juvy Golub, Licensee upon completion. One deficiency was observed (refer to LIC 809D) and cited from the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, and Health & Safety Codes during the inspection.

facility_name: HAVEN OF WALNUT CREEK, LLC, THE
met_with: Administrator Juvy Golub, Facility Manager Rahanat Abubakar
narrative: On 11/7/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit regarding a deficiency observed at the facility. LPA met with Administrator Juvy Golub and Facility Manager Rahanat Abubakar and informed of the purpose of the visit. During an investigation at the facility, LPA conducted confidential interviews of currently employed staff. During the interviews, LPA observed that multiple staff were aware of their mandated reporter status and what that meant but were unfamiliar with their responsibility to report to outside agencies such as CPS, adult protective services, and the police directly if they observe abuse or neglect. Review of personnel records reflected that all staff had received recent training on mandated reporting and had signed an acknoweldgement of requirement to report child abuse. LPA is issuing an advisory to advise that staff be retrained during an in-house training where staff demonstrate their knowledge of reporting protocols. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and the licensee's appeal rights were provided to Administrator Juvy Golub, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

narrative: PAGE 2 Multiple staff demonstrated the patting that they stated the resident likes, and LPA observed the patting to be less forceful than the patting captured in the video and the resident to not turn their head away or appear bothered at all by the patting. LPA determined that the pat captured in the video was done with excessive force. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegation is found to be substantiated. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 84072 Personal Rights. See LIC 9099-D. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and the licensee's appeal rights were provided to Administrator, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.
investigation_findings: 13On 11/7/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a complaint investigation visit regarding the above allegation. LPA met with Administrator Juvy Golub and Facility Manager Rahanat Abubakar and informed of the purpose of the visit. During the visit, confidential interviews with 7 staff were conducted. LPA attempted an interview of the involved reseident, but due to limited verbal/communication, LPA was unable to obtain a statement. All other residents are nonverbal. The video evidence submitted with the complaint was played for Administrator and Facility Manager. The video shows staff S1 hit a resident in the face and the resident to immediately turn their face away. Based on staff interviews, the resident likes when staff pat the resident's face due to a skin-picking condition the resident has that results in the skin itching but not being safe to scratch. LPA reviewed the involved resident's records and observed medical records reflecting the skin-picking behavior. SEE PAGE

met_with: Michael MIller, Senior Director of Residential Programs and Brian Tungate, Sr. Director of Operations
narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) T. Davis went to Haynes Family of Programs on February 16, 2023 at 9:20am for the purposes of an announced Pre-licensing inspection. The Department has received application materials from the facility to become licensed as a group home licensee at the site. LPA Davis met with Michael MIller, Senior Director of Residential Programs and Brian Tungate, Sr. Director of Operations, and together they toured the facility inside and outside. The facility is located in a residential neighborhood and is seeking to be licensed to provide care to twelve males ages 7-17 years old. The clients will be housed in Gatchell Cottage. There are six bedrooms in the cottage and each room has two twin beds, desk, and closet space. There are telephones available for the clients to use. Sharp knives, medications and cleaning supplies are kept locked in areas inaccessible to children. Overall, the facility appeared clean, safe, and sanitary. LPA observed fully charged fire extinguishers throughout the facility. Exit signs were also visible throughout the facility as well. The outdoor areas were observed to be free of debris and hazards. LPA observed the kitchen area to be clean and the refrigerators were well stocked with ample food supply. LPA also observed adequate perishable and nonperishable food items at the facility. There is a properly secured in-ground swimming pool on the premises enclosed with a self-latching gate. LPA also toured the cafeteria, nurse's station, therapy area, and the on grounds gymnasium. The facility has several indoor and outdoor activities on the premises for the clients. The facility has locked file cabinets for the client files. Smoke alarms were operable throughout the facility. There is adequate space outdoors for the clients to use. LPA spoke with the facility's nurse and inquired about their policies and procedures regarding potential client injuries and incident reports. There is adequate seating in the dining area and the living room. All exits were free of hazards and all doors opened freely. LPA observed six passenger vehicles designated for the residents.

LPA was provided with copies of the minutes from the Board of Director's most recent meeting that was held on September 29, 2022. LPA found no Title 22 deficiencies on this date. Exit interview conducted LPA Davis discussed cold weather conditions and precautions with the provider and provided them with the Department's website address (www.ccld.ca.gov). LPA also conducted a Component III at the facility with Michael MIller, Senior Director of Residential Programs. LPA Joe Martinez observed the Pre-licensing inspection and the Component III.

met_with: Douglas Yost, Vice President of Therapeutic Programs
narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) T. Davis went to Haynes Family of Programs on November 02, 2023 at 12:56pm for the purposes of a Post Licensing inspection. LPA met with Douglas Yost, Vice President of Therapeutic Programs (VPTP), and discussed the nature of today's inspection. The group home is located in a residential neighborhood and currently has five youth in placement. LPA and VPTP toured the facility inside and outside. During the inspection, LPA observed six bedrooms in the residential cottage and each room has twin beds, desks, and closet space. Sharp knives, medications and cleaning supplies are kept locked in areas inaccessible to children. Overall, the facility appeared clean, safe, and sanitary. LPA observed the bathrooms to be in good repair and working order. A menu was posted that itemized the necessary items for dining purposes. There is adequate space in the living room area. LPA observed a game room for the clients' use. LPA observed fully charged fire extinguishers and exit signs inside the facility. LPA also observed a fully stocked linen closed and a laundry room. There is a properly secured in-ground swimming pool on the premises enclosed with a self-latching gate. VPTP stated that there weren't any firearms or other weapons on the premises. The facility currently has five vans and one sedan for client transportation needs. The last fire drill was conducted at two separate times on January 25, 2023 at 7:30am and 5:10pm, respectively. LPA observed the following posted on a bulletin board: personal rights information, emergency disaster plan, evacuation plan information, and the facility license. Smoke alarms were operable throughout the facility. There is adequate space for indoor and outdoor activities. The outdoor areas were observed to be free of debris and hazards. LPA reviewed staff and client files and found the reviewed files to be in order.

The most recent Board of Director's meeting occurred on September 28, 2023. LPA obtained an updated LIC500 (Personnel Report) and a client roster. LPA found no Title 22/ILS deficiencies on this date. Exit interview done

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) T. Davis went to Haynes Family of Programs for the purposes of finalizing the follow up on a Special Incident Report (SIR) that was received by Community Care Licensing (CCL) on July 22, 2024. LPA met with Jazmin Roybal, Quality Assurance Coordinator, and discussed the matter. The incident report stated that client #1 (see Confidential Names form (LIC 811) dated September 27, 2024) reported to his mother during a telephone call at the facility that he was inappropriately touched by another client (LIC 811) at the facility. Information obtained shows that the two clients were in the swimming pool at the facility when the incident allegedly took place. The investigation revealed that staff was available and was providing supervision, but did not witness any inappropriateness. Client #1 contacted his mother about the matter on July 20, 2024. The client's mother came to the facility on July 20, 2024 and decided that she would remove client #1 from the facility. Client #2 indicated that the two clients had been horse-playing in the pool. Information gathered also shows that staff spoke with client #2 and reminded him of personal boundaries and respecting his peers. Information gathered shows that client#1 informed his mother upon returning home that the incident never happened. Based on information and facts obtained in this matter, the Department finds that the clients were in the swimming pool under staff supervision. Client #1 has denied the allegations. His mother has removed him from the facility. The Department is unable to find any evidence of the allegations occurring. Nevertheless, the situation has been stabilized and no further follow up is needed. Exit interview done
