met_with: Michael Miller, Sr. Director of Residential Programs, Jazmin Roybal, Quality Assurance Coordinator, and Nicolas Galarza, Residential Unit Manager
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) T. Davis went to Haynes Family of Programs for the purposes of following up on a Special Incident Report (SIR) that was received by Community Care Licensing (CCL) on March 14, 2025. LPA met with Michael Miller, Sr. Director of Residential Programs, Jazmin Roybal, Quality Assurance Coordinator, and Nicolas Galarza, Residential Unit Manager, and discussed the incident. The incident report stated that client #1 (see Confidential Names form (LIC 811) dated March 20, 2025) was allegedly handed an object by staff #1 (LIC 811) that appeared to have some kind of light. Information obtained shows that the incident occurred at the facility on March 12, 2025 at approximately 2:40am. Staff #1 was on duty at the time and sat in a chair in the hallway when client #1 approached him. Information obtained shows that the client and staff engaged in a close-up conversation and the staff handed the client an unidentified object. The client took the item and placed it in his pocket and then went into the living room area for a brief time. The client then placed the item towards his mouth area and the object proceeded to illuminate. The client returned to the area where the staff was and handed the item in question back to the staff. The investigation revealed that the staff was placed on administrative leave pending the outcome of an investigation. The investigation also revealed that the item in question was a vape pen. The client admitted that the item was a vape pen. The staff did not appear for meetings and/or discussions regarding the matter. Based on information and facts obtained in this matter, the Department finds that the facility has ended their relationship with staff #1 and terminated his employment with the facility. The client cooperated in the investigation and is doing fine. The situation has been stabilized and no further follow up is needed. Exit interview done

An announced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joel Segura on 02/25/20221 at 8:30 am through 10:30 am and resumed at 3:30pm. During the inspection, LPA Segura met with facility manager Taos Vargas and inspected the facility inside and out. Note due to COVID19 mitigation efforts, this inspection occurred via Microsoft Teams. LPA reviewed 3 child/client files prior to the inspection. The facility currently has in placement four children who are part of the child welfare system; however, only three of those children are subscribed psychotropic medication. In the course of reviewing the client documents, LPA Segura discovered the facility Quarterly and Annual reports are not signed by the authorized representative. The facility uses these two documents to meet the requirements of the Need and Services Plan. LPA interviewed the facility manager, Taos Vargas, via the MS Teams from 8:45-9:15 then interviewed the other facility manager Beth Toco at 9:15am to 9:30am. LPA Segura then requested to conduct a medication count. Beth assisted with the medication counts for the three clients taking psychotropic medications. The medication count was quick due the facility using a pharmacy that bubble packs medication. One issue LPA detected in the course of the medication count for C1 (Client 1, see confidential names list dated 02/25/2021) was that it appears the pharmacy indicates there are more pills than are placed in the bubble pack. Continued on 812c

For example the pharmacy sticker states there are 62 pills in the refill; however, they only bubble packed 56 (28 days in February times 2). After this part of the inspection concluded. LPA requested for Mr. Vargas to submit proof of psychotropic medication training for both himself and Beth. LPA conducted an exit interview with Taos Vargas, the facility administrator at 3:30pm and provided a summary report upon completion. Appeal rights were discussed and a copy of their rights provided. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPA Segura sent this report via email requesting a signature.

As of todays inspection the JV223 for C3 is the only JV223 received from the county social workers. narrative:
On Wednesday December 15, 2021 Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Isabel Mendoza made an unannounced inspection to conduct an annual required inspection. LPA met with House Managers Beth Toco and Melinda Kaklia. The facility has a census of four clients. There was one client in care (C1), please refer to LIC 811, dated 12/15/21 for confidential names. (C1) was not feeling well. LPA was unable to interview youth because youth is non-verbal. However, client appeared to be in good spirit. Later in the inspection, all other clients arrived, and LPA interviewed (C2). LPA also interviewed one staff. At 1:25 PM LPA Mendoza toured the facility. The facility is clean, safe and sanitary and in good repair. All passageways are unobstructed. There are no pools or bodies of water. All disinfectants, cleaning solutions and poisons are locked in the garage. Per House Manager there are no firearms in the facility. The inspected bedrooms were furnished accordingly. The kitchen is clean and sanitary. The water temperature measured 110 degrees. The facility has sufficient two day perishable and seven day nonperishable food supply. LPA toured the outdoor premises and observed the backyard fence having several loose, missing, and broken post. LPA Mendoza was informed that the facility had the fence looked out, however the facility was unable to show any proof or record. At 2:00 PM LPA requested to see the facilities complaint procedure. The facility was unable to locate this document, and unable to verify the procedure. Medications were inspected and LPA found no issues. Medications are locked away in the staff office. At 2:22 PM, LPA Mendoza reviewed all 4 client files, and all files were complete. [PLEASE CONT. TO LIC 809-C...]

At 2:51 PM LPA Mendoza reviewed 4 staff files and all files were complete and all staff have required training. Staff training hours meet the minimum requirements. The Administrator, Yuka Uno administrator certificate expired on 07/16/2019. It was learned that the Administrator has been in the process of renewing the certificate but due to COVID there has been several delays. The facility will submit proof to LPA Mendoza no later than Friday 12/17/21. LPA Mendoza requested the facility to submit the following documents to LPA Mendoza via email by Wednesday 12/22/21. LIC 500 (Staff Schedule), LIC 610 (Emergency Disaster Plan), LIC 309 (Administrative Organization), and the Administrator certificate for (S1), and an LIC 308 (Designation of Responsibility). Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 80087(b) Buildings and Grounds. Also, two advisories are being issued. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with the facility.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Building and Grounds(c) The licensee shall prohibit smoking in the facility and on the ground of the facility. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: On 11/5/21 LPA Mendoza found several cigarette buds in the backyard. Interviews could not confirm who they belonged too. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, and personal rights risk to the clients in care.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Isabel Mendoza conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to the facility and met with Facility Manager Melinda Kaklia. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. On October 10, 2021, Child #1 (C1) (see Confidential Names form (LIC 811) dated {March, 01, 2022}). arrived at school with an improper haircut. During investigation, it was learned that another youth in the home (C2) attempted to cut (C1) hair with hair clippers unsupervised. Based on interviews and physical evidence, it was determined that there was a lack of supervision which resulted in (C2) cutting (C1’s) hair. Also, staff allowed (C2) to keep clippers in his possession in his bedroom. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove that minor has access to sharp objects. Therefore, the above allegation is substantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the facility and deficiencies were cited. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was left with the facility.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Buildings and Grounds (g) Disinfectants, cleaning solutions... other items that could pose a danger if readily available to clients shall be stored where inaccessible to clients. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews (C2) cut (C1) hair unsupervised. Also, (C2) stored hair clippers in his bedroom. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, and Personal Rights risk to clients in care.

Personal Duties: Child care staff shall perform the following duties:(1) Supervision, protection and care of children individually and in groups at all times. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews, (C2) cut (C1) hair. This poses an immediate Health, Safety and Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.

narrative: On 6/21/2022 at 11:51 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted an unannounced case management inspection with Heiwa House and spoke with Melinda Kakalia, Facility Manager. The purpose of the inspection was to follow up on why incident reports are not being submitted within the required reporting requirements. LPA Ng reviewed incident reports that have been sent in by the listed facility and found no incident reports sent to the Department in 2022. LPA Ng advised FM that any behavior or injury is considered an incident and should be documented properly and sent to the department within seven days. LPA reminded FM that it lets CCL know what is happening inside the facility, especially when there are complaints related to the incident. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, Section 80061(b)(1)(D) Reporting Requirements. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and emailed to Administrator Yuka Ono.

Based on LPA’s interviews with staff and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations, facility does not supervise visits and ensure that minor has transportation back to the facility after visits is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Facility is being cited for violation of California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6 & Chapter 1: 80022(k): Plan Of Operation and 80078(a) Responsibility for providing care and supervision. Please refer to attached 9099D. Two deficiencies were cited today. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided and discussed, and a copy of this report was given to Melinda Kakalia, Facility Manager.
investigation_findings: 13On 6/21/2022 at 10:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted a complaint inspection at Heiwa House and spoke with Melinda Kakalia, Facility Manager (FM). The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During investigation, shift logs and client files were reviewed, and it was determined that, staff at the facility does not supervise visits or ensure that minor has transportation back to the facility after visits. Based on a review of the facilities Program Statement under Transportation, it says, “Residents will be transported to and from social, recreational, and religious activities in the program vehicle”. In the description of consumer service section of the Program Statement, it says that they provide “Basis General Services and Personal Services”. On the Basis General Services, it says that the facility will “Plan, arrange and/ or provide transportation for home/day passes.” During confidential interviews, it was confirmed that the facility was not providing transportation to and from home visits. It was disclosed that minor in care uses uber to get to and from monthly visits with their family. Since facility staff do not transport minor to his monthly visits, they do not supervise minor to ensure they are safe. ------CONT. ON 9099C-----

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 80022(k): Plan Of Operation (k): The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation and may be cited for not doing so. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on records reviewed, it was discovered that facility has not being transporting clients in a facility vehicle. Clients family have been calling uber every month to return to the facility from home visits. Facilities Program Statement confirms that the facility is responsible for transporting clients to appointments and home/day passes. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.

80078(a) Responsibility for providing care and supervision: (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This requirement was not met as evidence by: Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed, LPA discovered that a client has been using uber to get to and from the facility instead of being transported in the facility vehicle thus, staff are unable to supervise and ensure the clients safety. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.

narrative: LPA also observed client’s head to have some bald spots and dry lips. LPA asked staff how often the client’s hair is washed and what hairbrush they were using. Staff stated every day and showed LPA a wet brush comb used for straight hair. LPA suggested to not wash client’s hair everyday so that their hair can produce natural oils needed for the scalp and suggested they use a bristle brush. LPA Ng did a file review and confirmed there was no notification or incident report sent into the department. Confidential interviews were conducted and revealed that wound was not covered when attending school, teacher was not notified, and staff were aware of the injury but did not submit incident report within the permitted time frame. Based on LPA’s interview with staff and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations, Minor sustained injuries while in care and staff did not properly care for minor’s injury is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Facility is being cited for violation of California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6 & Chapter 1: 80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision and 80075(a) Health Related Services. Please refer to attached 9099D. Two deficiencies and one technical violation was given. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided and discussed, and a copy of this report was given to Melinda Kakalia, Facility Manager.
investigation_findings: 13On 6/21/22 at 11:08 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted a complaint inspection at Heiwa House and spoke with Melinda Kakalia, Facility Manager. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During investigation, needs and service plans and incident reports were reviewed, and it was determined that a minor sustained injuries in care and staff did not properly care for minor’s injury. During a facility inspection dated 5/18/2022, LPA Ng took pictures of client’s arm and surrounding areas when they arrived home from school. LPA also received pictures from witnesses. The observed wound was a one inch in size, vertical on their left arm, and it was a dark red color in the middle and brown scabbing around the wound. Surrounding the wound were healed scrapes. The healed scrapes were circular and had a dark brown tint. During the visit on 5/18/2022, LPA asked staff if she can check to see if there are any injuries on clients arms, staff rolled up the clients sleeve and LPA saw the one-inch wound not covered. -----CONT. ON 9099C------

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 80078(a) Responsibility for providing care and supervision: (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed, LPA went to the facility on 5/18/2022, client came home from school. When LPA asked staff if she can check to see if there are any injuries the clients arms, staff rolled up the clients sleeve and LPA saw a wound. The observed wound was a one inch in size, vertical on their left arm, and it was a dark red color in the middle and brown scabbing around the wound. Surrounding the wound were healed scrapes. The healed scrapes were circular and had a dark brown tint. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.

80075(a) Health Related Services: (a) The licensee shall ensure that each client receives necessary first aid and other needed medical or dental services… This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed, the wound was not covered when attending school and on 5/18/2022, LPA observed no bandage or covering on the wound. Surrounding the wound were healed scrapes. The healed scrapes were circular and had a dark brown tint. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.

narrative:
On 10/11/2022 at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng made an unannounced inspection to conduct an annual required inspection. LPA met with Melinda Kakalia, Facility Manager. The facility has a census of 5 clients. All but one client were at school. LPA observed one client in care. Client is non-verbal. LPA Ng observed the client sleeping in their bed. Bed had appropriate bedding and pillows. Staff were responsive to the clients needs and able to provide care and supervision to the client in care. The CARE Inspection Tool was used to conduct the inspection. The facility and grounds are clean, tidy, and free of obstructions. There are no hazards on the premises and no firearms, per Facility Manager. 4 bedrooms are single rooms and 1 bedroom is double-occupancy. All beds have clean linens and mattress pads. There is enough storage for residents' personal belongings. Food is of good quality, within date, and stored properly. First aid kit was observed to be complete. Room temperature was maintained at a comfortable temperature within permitted range. Water temperature measured at 116.5 which is in the permitted range. The backyard is surrounded by a wooden fence. The facility has a centralized AC unit in the side yard which is inaccessible to clients. No bodies of water on the premises. All walkways were free from debris or hazards. All window screens are in good condition. Facility has comfortable furnishings, accommodations, and ample lighting. At 10:30 AM, LPA observed all client records complete with all of the required documentation. Each client and staff has their own separate folder of all required documents. During a review of a client file, LPA found that one client is 19 years old. LPA Ng asked if client has an Age Exception. Facility Manager stated no. LPA Ng advised to send in a request for an Age Exception by 4:59 PM today. ----------CONT. ON 809C------

Each psychotropic medication was observed to have its own Psychotropic Medication Administration Record (PMAR), as well as individual Centrally Stored Medication Destruction Records (CSMDR). All medications were consistent with these records. At 11:30 AM. LPA Ng conducted two staff interviews. Resident and staff records were observed to be complete and the facility in compliance. At this time, no deficiencies were cited. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was to Facility Manager Melinda Kakalia, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

met_with: Yuka Ono, Melinda Kakalia, Anthony Mongomery, Lilibeth Toco
narrative:
On 12/15/22 at 1:00 PM, CCL met with Regional Center and listed facility for an Informal Meeting. The meeting was held at 2580 North First Street Suite 350, San Jose, CA 95131. The following attended the meeting; CCL: Alyssa Ng - Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) , Carolyn Flynn and Isabel Mendoza - Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Regional Center: Derrick Levingston - Quality Assurance Specialist (QA), Mike Minton - Quality Assurance Supervisor, Kimberly Limato- Case Manager Supervisor Heiwa House: Yuka Ono - Administrator, Melinda Kakalia - Facility Manager, Anthony Montgomery- Manager, Lilabeth Toco -Assistant Administrator Topics that were discussed: Lack of supervision: CCL discussed the pattern of allegations regarding unexplained injuries and the one on one supervision. Reporting requirements: CCL explained the importance of reporting incidences on time. Regional Center discussed missing incident reports. CCL requested all incident reports for the month of November- Present. -----CONT. ON 809C----

Buildings and Grounds: CCL brought up concerns regarding a twin bed for a client who is 6 foot. LPA Ng showed pictures of one of the clients headboard. There is chipping and wooden chips hanging out. Administrator Yuka stated that they have a maintenance person who can do repairs when called. CCL recommended to have a maintenance log. Personal Rights: LPA Ng discussed the concerns of bald spots due to improper brushing and care and wanted to discuss the wooden play structure in the home. Regional Center also had concerns with the supervision and what clients can.are doing inside of the structure unsupervised. Concerns about Administrator: CCL had some concerns regarding the hours of the Administrator. CCL requested to have Administrator present during business hours. A new LIC500 will be sent to CCL that will reflect the hours of the Administrator and will reflect proper supervision with one on one clients. No deficiences were cited. Technical Support Program (TSP) was offered. LPM Carolyn Flynn set the due date for December 23rd 2022 if listed facility wants/needs TSP. The Licensee was also cautioned that if there are continued concerns for similar issues, the licensee could be referred to a Non-Compliance Conference for further action.

investigation_findings: 13On 12/13/22 at 1:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted a complaint inspection at Heiwa House and spoke with Melinda Kakalia, Facility Manager. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During investigation, interviews were conducted, photos obtained, and incident reports were reviewed, and it was determined that Staff is not providing proper supervision to minor’s in care and minor sustained injuries while in care. Based on LPA’s interview with staff, client, and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations, Staff not providing proper supervision to minor’s in care is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Facility is being cited for violation of California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6 & Chapter 1: 80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision and 80072(a)(3) Personal Rights. Please refer to attached 9099D. At this time, two deficiencies were given. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided and discussed, and a copy of this report was sent to Melinda Kakalia, Facility Manager.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 80078(a) Responsibility for providing care and supervision: (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on record review and observation, there are two client that require one on one supervision. During a facility visit dated 11/29/22, LPA Ng saw four clients and two staff present. Two of those clients require one on one supervision. No other staff were present at the time which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.

80072(a)(3) Personal Rights: (a) Except for children’s residential facilities, each client shall have personal rights which include, but are not limited to, the following: (3) To be free from corporal or unusual punishment, infliction of pain… This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on record review and observation, LPA Ng observed C1’s headboard to be chipping and wooden chips hanging out. A review of the shift notes shows C1 engaging in harmful behaviors like headbanging, banging of their hands, etc., which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.

narrative: On 2/10/2023 at 1:10 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield conducted an announced case management inspection to the above facility. The purpose of this inspection is to conduct a Psychotropic Medications Inspection. LPA Belfield met with administrator assistant Lilibeth Toco and facility manager Lelinda Kakalia. At the time of the inspection, two other staff had taken one client on an outing and they returned at the end of the inspection. The facility currently has five clients, two verbal and three non-verbal. The facility currently has four clients that are prescribed psychotropic medications. LPA reviewed two client files, two staff files, and facility files. Review was limited as to not interfere with clients routine. LPA interviewed two staff members while in the facility. While observing the facility and speaking with the facility staff, it was learned that due to clients ripping things off of the wall, the facility no longer had a proper mental health bill of rights and personal rights poster. LPA stated they would provide the link the staff for ordering more posters. There were no issues with the pill count. LPA reviewed the centrally stored medication binder and the Psychotropic Medication Administration Records (PMAR). During a file review there were no training records present in the facility. Medication training was provided for one of the staff however there was no information regarding psychotropic medication. Facility is cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, 84065(i)(3)(M) Personnel Requirements as described on the following page 809D. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with appeal rights will be sent to administrator Yuko Uno and facility manager Lelinda Kakali and administrator assistant Lilibeth Toco.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Personnel Requirements (k)The licensee shall develop, maintain and implement a written plan for the training... (7)Documentation of successful completion of training shall be maintained in the personnel record for each staff member. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review, the licensee did not ensure successful completion of training due to all training materials not being present in staffs personnel record which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.

Personnel Requirements (i)...shall complete a minimum of 24 hours of initial training comprised of (3)...all of the following topics...(M) Medication procedures, assistance with medication...including oversight and monitoring of psychotropic medications... This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review, the licensee did not ensure psychotropic medications initial training was completed due to staff files not indicating initial medications training topics and time spent which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.

Personnel Requirements (j)Annual Training (4)Training topics shall be appropriate for the client population... (A)... psychotropic medications for children in foster care and related topics specified in... This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review, the licensee did not ensure psychotropic medication training is conducted annually due to staff files only presenting psychotropic medication training being conducted in 2021 and 2023 which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.

At 3:25PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madi Fremont traveled to the home above for the purpose of conducting an unannounced Case Management - Deficiencies inspection. LPA met with Staff Lilibeth Toco, who helped facilitate this inspection. Currently in care are 6 ambulatory clients. On 08/27/2021, the San Jose Children's Residential Program Regional Office received a complaint for Heiwa House 2 with one allegation: "Staff member inappropriately restrained resident causing injuries." This complaint was assigned to LPA Fremont on 09/01/2021. On 09/02/2021, LPA Fremont traveled to the facility to open this complaint and notify the Licensee of this allegation. On the evening of 09/02/2021, LPA Fremont received a phone call from Licensee/Administrator Yuka Ono, who was informing LPA Fremont that Heiwa House 2 is no longer operating as a Children's Residential Program Group Home and has now transitioned into an Adult Residential Facility (ARF). Upon investigation of the home's facility file and facility profile on the statewide server, LPA Fremont could not find any record or documentation of this transition. LPA contacted the home's new LPA, Alicia Delmundo of the Oakland Office Adult and Senior Care Program, and was informed by LPA Delmunod that the home completed their application process and was issued a new Adult Residential Facility license on 02/01/2021. LPA Delmundo also forwarded to LPA Fremont an email they had sent to the licensee on 06/25/2020. In this email, LPA Delmundo explained to the licensee that since the facility was licensed as a Group Home at that time, when their new license was granted for the Adult Residential Facility, the license for the group home needed to be forfeited simultaneously. (CONTINUED ON LIC809-C)

LPA Fremont was not notified of this transition until after the home's new license was issued, and the home has since been operating on two separate CCL licenses, a Group Home License and an Adult Residential Facility license. Based on this information, the Licensee did not report an organizational change to the Licensing Agency within 10 days of its occurrence. A deficiency is being cited per Title 22 Regulations, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, Section 80061(e)(1) - Reporting Requirements. Please see the attached LIC9099-D for details. For this deficiency, the Licensee was issued a Plan of Correction of forfeiting their Group Home license to LPA. This POC was fulfilled during this inspection. Because the facility is no longer operating as a Children's Residential Group Home, LPA Fremont confirmed that LPA Delmundo has received this same complaint for the new Adult Residential license, and LPA Delmundo will be investigating the allegation going forward. Due to the above-mentioned details of the home's transition to an Adult Residential Facility, this complaint for the home's Group Home License will be closed without investigation. This agency has determined that although this allegation may have happened or is valid, the allegation "Staff member inappropriately restrained resident causing injuries" is determined to be unsubstantiated at this time pending further investigation by LPA Delmundo, because it was reported under the wrong facility license and therefore will require further investigation by the home's new LPA under their new program license. At this time, one deficiency is being cited. An exit interview was conducted, Appeal Rights provided and discussed, and a copy of this report was emailed to Licensee/Administrator Yuka Ono and Staff Lilibeth Toco, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Michelle Silvas and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Jodean Hall made an announced pre-licensing inspection on 4/1/2025 at 12:00 PM and met with Alfredo Bonifacio, Licensee, Namier Marfino, Administrator, Abigail Bagang, Licensee, and Erwin Bagang, Office Manager to tour the facility inside and out. At 12:08PM, LPA Silvas and LPM Hall began touring the facility and observed that the facility is ready for licensure. LPA Silvas observed that there are four single occupancy bedrooms, two and a half client bathrooms, a dining area, kitchen, extra room, office area. LPA Silvas observed the front entry way closet will store the medications and client files and will be locked at all times to ensure inaccessibility. There is a fully stocked first aid kit available. Clients personal rights, ombudsman information, facility sketch, menu and planned activities are posted. There is enough seating space in the living room. LPA Silvas observed that there are three fire extinguishers one in the front hallway, garage and in the kitchen area that are accessible and were last serviced on 8/19/24. LPA Silvas observed seven dual carbon monoxide and smoke detectors in two hallways and all bedrooms that are working as required.

LPA Silvas observed that there is a two day supply of perishable food and seven day of nonperishable accessible when clients are admitted. LPA Silvas also observed that there are laundry facilities for clients. The outdoor of the facility appears to be safe for clients in care. There is adequate seating space in the backyard. There is a working phone located in the kitchen, receiving room and office area. LPA Silvas advised the facility that they are to notify the Department upon admission of their first client. LPA Silvas also advised that upon acceptance of the last sections of the program statement approval, the Licensee shall submit a final binder of the approved Program Statement to the Department, tabbed and in a binder and turned into LPA by April 8, 2025. LPA Silvas notified the facility that Component III will be scheduled. The mass causality and emergency disaster binder will be completed and proof of this will be sent to LPA vial emailed picture. The front hallway closet door that will store medications will be having a smart lock installed and a picture of this will be emailed to LPA. LPA Silvas and LPM Hall conducted an exit interview and provided a copy of this report to the facility.

On Friday 5/13/22 at 9:17AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility for a required annual inspection. LPA met with Administrator/Licensee Alfredo Bonifacio and informed of the purpose of visit. Safety precautions were taken, including mask-wearing and pre-visit screening call. LPA used the CARE Inspection Tool to conduct the inspection. The facility is a single-story house in a residential neighborhood. There are 4 resident bedrooms and 3 bathrooms. All rooms are single-occupancy, and all beds have clean linens. There are no hazards or bodies of water. There are no firearms on the premises, per Administrator/Licensee. Chemicals are stored in a locked cabinet in the kitchen, sharps are stored in a locked drawer in the kitchen, and medications are stored in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. The kitchen is stocked with food in the quantity and quality to meet the needs of residents in care, and food is stored properly. There are four residents in care, and one is present during visit. All residents are nonverbal. The following deficiencies were found. See attached LIC 809-Ds and LIC 9102s. - Resident R1's (See LIC 811 Confidential Names) medication administration record (MAR) was not consistent with medication label. Medication Risperidone label reads "Take 3 and one-half tablet," and the MAR reads "4 tabs." There is a conservator-signed psychotropic medication consent form dated 7/30/21 that authorizes 4 tablet dosage. The quarterly report indicates 4 tablets as well. LPA is issuing an advisory of California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Section 84075 Health Related Services. - Resident R2 and R3 have no psychotropic medication consent form. R4's form is signed but has no medication listed. LPA is issuing a citation of CCR, Title 22, Section 84070 Children's Records. - All youth have psychotropic medication. Psychotropic medications are not logged on separate log using LIC 622B or version of the form with all required sections. LPA issued a citation of CCR, Title 22, Section 84070 Children's Records.

- Resident R1 needs and services plan, or behavior/treatment plan, dated 4/30/22 is only signed by the administrator and was not developed by Regional Center. There is no plan dated within the last 6 months that is signed by authorized representative. LPA is issuing a citation of CCR, Title 22, Section 84068.2 Needs and Services Plan. - Residents R2, R3, and R4's needs and services plans, or behavior/treatment plans, are older than 6 months. LPA is issuing a citation of CCR, Title 22, Section 84068.3 Modifications to Needs and Services Plan. - Staff training hours meet requirements, but annual training record for 2021 does not indicate all staff attended a training on psychotropic medications. LPA is issuing an advisory of CCR, Title 22, Section 84065 Personnel Requirements. - Staff S1 and S2 (See LIC 811) are not listed on the Guardian roster printed this morning. However, there are state-issued clearance letters for this facility in each staff member's file. LPA connected to Guardian during visit, and there was no clear indication of any changes to their clearances or listing on rosters. LPA is issuing an advisory of 80019 Criminal Record Clearance. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report provided to Administrator/Licensee Alfredo Bonifacio, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

narrative: On 8/22/22 at 11:45AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to deliver notice of a deficiency found during an investigation at the facility. LPA met with Administrator Alfredo Bonifacio and informed of the purpose of the visit. During the investigation, it was learned that a nonverbal resident had sustained bruising on the lower abdomen. Staff observed light redness in the morning when staff noticed that the resident had toy cars in their diaper. The redness progressed to bruising. This incident was documented in facility records but there is no documentation that it was reported to the authorized representative as required until the authorized representative asked the facility about the bruises during a home visit. LPA is issuing a citation per California Code of Regulations, Section 80061. See attached LIC 809-D. Per administrator, the resident has thin skin, and the facility has updated their policy of writing incident reports for this resident where any time redness is observed, since it is more likely for this resident to progress to bruising, the facility will generate incident reports. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Alfredo Bonifacio, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

investigation_findings: 13On 8/22/22 at 11:14AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility to deliver complaint investigation findings regarding the above allegation. LPA met with Administrator Alfredo Bonifacio and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential interviews with staff and authorized representative(s), a nonverbal resident sustained bruising on the lower abdomen. Interviews indicate that staff observed the resident to have toy cars in the resident's diaper when they were woken up for school and that the bruises may have been caused by the resident sleeping on the cars. It is unclear when during the night the resident did this, and this was the first time this behavior was observed. The toys were removed from the resident's room, and there has been no similar incident since. There is not enough evidence to determine if this incident was due to abuse or lack of supervision. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, based on LPA's observations and interviews, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation is

13On 9-13-22, 1:50 PM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) George Karkazis and Alyssa NG conducted a follow-up complaint inspection at Heritage House II and met with Alfredo Bonafacio, Facility Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings of the above complaint allegations. During the investigation, LPA Karkazis conducted confidential interviews with staff members. All clients at this facility are nonverbal. Therefore, LPA was unable to interview clients. However, LPA Karkazis conducted interviews with authorized representatives. In addition, LPA Karkazis obtained and reviewed documentation that pertained to the above allegations. On August 11, 2022, there was a staff note stating that (S3) (see Confidential Names form (LIC 811) dated 9/7/2022, was informed by House Manager (S4) that direct care worker (S5) had locked a client in their bedroom using a child safety lock on the outside of his door. Based on interviews, it was learned that the (S5) had difficulty with the client’s behavior and made an error in judgment. In addition, LPA obtained a copy of the incident report dated August 18, 2022, mentioning that a direct care worker (S5) used a child safety lock on a client’s bedroom door. On August 12, 2022, the staff member was terminated. Based on interviews and physical evidence, it was determined that the Staff locked the minor in the minor's bedroom, and the minor had an inappropriate locking device on the outside of the minor's bedroom door. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove the above allegations. Therefore, the above allegations are substantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the facility, and deficiencies were cited per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 84072(14) Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Alfred Bonafacio.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: To not be locked in any room, building, or facility premises at any time. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Staff member locking client in bedroom with a child lock from the outside. This ap poses a immediate health and safety risk to clients in care.

narrative: On 4/18/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a visit at the facility for a required annual inspection. LPA met with Administrator Alfredo Bonifacio and informed of the purpose of the visit. There are four residents in care, and three are expected to return around 3:30PM-4PM. LPA observed three residents in care. LPA toured the facility and inspected 5 personnel files and discussed with Administrator. During the facility tour, LPA observed the facility to be clean and tidy with sanitary kitchen and bathrooms. Knives and medications were locked away and inaccessible to residents. No hazards were observed. A visit will be conducted on a later date to complete this inspection. During today's portion of the inspection, LPA observed the following: 1) The files for two staff, S1 and S2 (see attached LIC 811 Confidential Names List), had incomplete initial training records that did not reflect the full amount of hours were obtained. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 84065. See attached LIC 809-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 6/5/2024 at 10:06am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood and LPA Kristin Pierotti conducted an unannounced visit to the listed facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct the required annual inspection. LPAs met with Reggie Lanuza, Direct Support Personnel. At 10:35am, LPAs met with Alfredo Bonifacio, Administrator. The facility currently has a census of four clients. At the time of the inspection, three staff members and two clients were present. During the inspection, the staff members and clients left to an outing. LPAs reviewed the client files for four clients in care. LPAs observed that four clients were missing signatures on their discharge procedures. LPAs delivered a Technical Assistance for 84070(c)(2). LPAs observed no other deficiencies with the client files. LPAs did not conduct client interviews because all clients in care are non-verbal. LPAs reviewed staff files for five staff members. LPAs did not observe deficiencies in the staff files. LPAs reviewed emergency binder, centrally stored medication log, posted emergency information, staff schedule, menu, behavioral binders, and daily log binders. LPAs conducted one staff interview. LPAs conducted a walk-through of the facility and observed the physical plant. LPAs observed that each room had a dresser with clothes, a bed with sheets and bedspreads, and a sufficient amount of room. Each client currently has their own room. LPAs observed the sharps, cleaning supplies, and hygiene supplies to be locked. LPAs observed the files and medication to be in a locked cabinet. LPAs observed that there was a sufficient amount of perishable and non-perishable items. The home was clean, tidy, and in good repair. LPAs conducted an exit interview with Alfredo Bonifacio, Administrator at 12:52pm whose signature confirms the receipt of this document.

On 05/01/25 at 11:15am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kristin Pierotti conducted an unannounced required annual inspection at the facility. LPA met with Alfredo Bonifacio, Facility Administrator and informed of the purpose of the visit. The facility currently has 4 clients in care. LPA used the CARE Inspection Tool and conducted a tour of the facility site, review of 6 personnel records and 4 resident records, and confidential interviews with 2 staff members and 0 residents. Residents are nonverbal. LPA observed the facility to be in good condition, clean and well organized. Kitchen and bathrooms are sanitary. The bedrooms contain individual beds for clients and plenty of storage for personal items. The rooms and common spaces are nicely decorated and furnished. Medications, sharps, and chemicals are stored where inaccessible to the residents. LPA reviewed 6 personnel records. Staff have valid intervention and first aid training certifications, and have completed their annual training hours. During personnel record review, LPA observed that S6 does not have background clearance. LPA informed licensee about the need to remove the staff from the premises. LPA reviewed 4 resident records. Residents' records contain current emergency contact information, complete care plans, accurate medication records and cash records. During resident record review, LPA observed C1 to be 18 years of age and does not have an approved age exception. Based on interviews, LPA observed staff to be knowledgeable of facility policies, mandated reporting, and intervention procedures.

LPA identified one area in which there was a Technical Violation. (See associated LIC9102 form). LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Sections 80019(e) Criminal Record Clearance. Additionally, as mandated in Section 80019(g), LPA is assessing an immediate civil penalty of $100 for a maximum of 5 days in violation in which S1 worked on site, for a total of $500. See attached LIC 421BG. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed and a copy of this report, LIC421BG and the LIC9102 were left with Alfredo Bonifacio, Facility Administrator whose signature confirms receipt.

On November 20, 2022 at 12:00pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Monica Pavia conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection of the facility. LPA met and toured the facility with Administrator, Alfredo Bonifacio, Licensee, Marisa Ferolino, and Administrator in Training, Natasha Lovell. This Group Home is a two story facility located in a residential area. The facility consists of 4 client bedrooms and 2 client bathrooms, living and dining areas, kitchen, and laundry room. The facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. All passageways are unobstructed and all doors open freely. There is no pool on the facility premises. Fire arms are not allowed on the facility premises. At the time of visit, the following was observed: Fire extinguishers are throughout the house. Smoke detectors are throughout the house and operational. Carbon monoxide detectors are located in the hallway, outside of the client bedrooms. Each bedroom has a bed, clean linens, and adequate drawer/cabinet space. Facility has a fire clearance. First aid kit was observed. Hot water temperature measured at 108 degrees Fahrenheit.

Staff and client records will be kept locked in a cabinet. Medications will be centrally stored and locked in cabinet in the kitchen. Disinfectants and other toxic materials will be locked in the laundry room. Extra bedding and towels are kept unlocked, in the hallway closet. Knives and sharps will be kept in a locked drawer in the kitchen. Site location has a live in staff bedroom and bathroom that is kept locked, and meets prelicensing requirements. The following requirements need to be addressed and pictures sent to LPA, prior to licensing: - extra mattresses in the garage will be moved out of the home - window sills in the bedrooms will be cleaned - glass window in the backyard will be moved and/or locked in garage - wood with nails in the backyard will be moved and/or locked in garage - extra fence paneling in backyard will be moved to an even surface or secured (not on a hill) - Children's Personal Rights to be posted in a common area - Complaint grievance forms will be posted in a common area This property is ready for licensure, once the above items are corrected and the Licensing Program Manager (LPM) has approved. LPA Pavia will notify licensee of licensure date. Component II: LPA Pavia discussed the following, with Administrator: - Administrator on site hours - facility core services and support - facility emergency intervention plan

On 12/12/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a required annual inspection. LPA met with Licensee Marisa Bonifacio and informed of the purpose of the visit. The facility is still in the process of acquiring a vendor agreement with the local Regional Center. As such, the facility is not yet in operation and has not served any clients. LPA verified that annual fees have been paid. Licensee agrees to notify LPA once the Regional Center vendor certificate is acquired and once the first client is admitted. Using the CARE Inspection Tool, no deficiencies were found. LPA toured the facility site and observed no violations. The facility is well maintained, and outdoor activity space is maintained in safe condition. The facility is readied for client use with four single-occupancy bedrooms, designated storage spaces, and clean linens. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Licensee Marisa Bonifacio, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 12/17/24 at 11:30am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kristin Pierotti conducted an unannounced Annual Inspection at listed facility. LPA met with Alfredo Bonafacio, Licensee/Administrator and toured the facility inside and out. The Group Home is licensed to serve 4 clients. Present during the inspection were 1 staff and 0 clients. At 11:35am, LPA Pierotti toured the facility. LPA Pierotti observed 4 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms. LPA observed facility license, personal rights, facility sketch, meal menu, and other forms posted on the walls throughout the facility. The thermostat read 68 degrees which is within range. Sharps were locked and chemicals were safely stored. There were two days of perishable foods and seven days non-perishable foods present. The medication was also stored and locked in a cabinet in the kitchen. The facility is in good repair and clean. At 11:45am LPA Pierotti toured the backyard. There were no open bodies of water. The backyard was in good repair and clean. At 11:50am LPA Pierotti reviewed 1 client file and 4 staff files. All files were complete and contained all necessary documents. LPA Pierotti interviewed 1 staff and 0 clients. Client was at school during the time of inspection. The CARE Tools was used to conduct this inspection and at this time there are no deficiencies. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to Alfredo Bonafacio, Licensee/Administrator whose signature confirms receipt.

On September 9, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Toni Castillo conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection for Hillside Horizon For Teens, LLA- Richard Street. LPA met with CEO Devon Wayt, Administrator Beau Moore and Compliance Specialist Christina Kiesselbach. LPA will be provided revisions to the application forms as stated during the component III meeting. LPA will review revisions and inform applicant if any further corrections are needed. Administrator Beau Moore has completed the administrator certification and attended the group home orientation on 9/14/21. LPA toured the facility inside and out. The facility is a single story home in a residential neighborhood. The home is about 1,664 square feet. This home will serve males only. The facility is set up as follows: *entry way of the home is equipped with an entry table with log guest sign in book. Posted evacuation and disaster plan, personal rights and grievance procedures and a sample schedule. *Family room equipped with a television, sofa's, and furnishings. *Dining room table with ample seating for 6 clients. *Kitchen equipped with operable appliances and cooking utensils and supplies. There is a locked cabinet for knives and cleaning solutions. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. *Laundry room equipped with washer and dryer and space for folding clothing. Cabinets with extra supplies of linens and hygiene products. *There are three clients bedrooms. Bedroom 1 and Bedroom 3 have their own restrooms. Bedroom 2 will utilize the hallway restroom.

All Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes was used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. All beds contained a mattress, mattress pad, sheets, comforter and pillows. *Nursing and Behavioral Health Technician office, equipped with locked cabinet for storage and locked refrigerator for medication. Medications are locked and centrally stored in the nursing/medical office. The first aid kit was also in the medical office with all required items. *Clinical Office equipped with desk and supplies. Clinical office also has a restroom which will be used for staff only. This office will be used to provide therapy and treatment to clients. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/toys/games were observed for recreation time. There is a basketball court, garden and cazebo on premises. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are hard-wired in and are in appropriate working order All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster in main entrance of the facility. No firearms or weapons are in the facility. Water temperature was tested and was at 118. Trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. Client files will be maintained using the Kipu system which is a portal to store client files and keep all information confidential. Applicant stated licensing will have access to such portal when client files need to be reviewed for any purpose. There is a pool on premises. The mesh fencing meets regulatory standards. The mesh fence is 5 feet tall and does not obscure the pool from view. Mesh fence surrounds entire pool. The mesh fence is self -closing and self latching. The gate swings open away from the body of water. The licensee understands that regardless of whether or not clients are present, the fence will remain permanently in place for the duration of the license.

At this time the physical plant of this facility is within the group home regulations. LPA will review revisions which will be provided no later then 9/16/22. LPA will review revisions and submit for a provisional license. A copy of this report was given and explained to CEO Devon Wayt.

On November 30, 2022 at 10:13 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Val Wilson, made an unannounced post-licensing inspection at Hillside Horizon Group Home- Richard Street. LPA was met at the facility by Behavior Health Specialist (BHS), Bailey Kinsley and Therapist (THR), Erin Bixel, and LPA was provided a work area in the Nursing and Behavioral Health Technician office. LPA provided THR the Entrance Checklist. LPA was greeted by Administrator (ADM), Beau Moore, and Director of Operations/Facility Manager (FM), Marissa Cabrera at 11:00 AM. LPA began a physical plant inspection at 11:15 AM assisted by the ADM and FM. LPA toured the facility inside and out. The facility is a single-story home in a residential neighborhood. The home is about 1,664 square feet and serves males only. The physical plant inspection included the following: The entry way of the home is equipped with an entry table with log guest sign in book. Per Administrator there are no guns or weapons on facility grounds. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, activity schedule, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster in main entrance of the facility. The posted evacuation and disaster plan will be updated with staff responsibilities and permission letters from the two sites that would be utilized in case of evacuation. The family room is equipped with a television, sofa's, and furnishings. The dining room table has ample seating for 6 clients. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are hardwired in and are in appropriate working order. The hot water in the client’s bathroom and kitchen was measured and were within 105-120 degrees Fahrenheit. Trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. The laundry room is equipped with washer, dryer and space for folding clothing. Cabinets with extra supplies of linens and hygiene products are next to the laundry area. The kitchen is equipped with operable appliances and cooking utensils and supplies. There is a locked cabinet for knives and cleaning solutions. All hazardous items have been (continued on page 2)

(continued from page 1) properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and the food menus are posted. There are three client bedrooms. Fire extinguisher is located in the kitchen by the refrigerator. Bedroom 1 and Bedroom 3 have their own restrooms. Bedroom 2 clients utilize the hallway full-bathroom. All Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes was used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. All beds contained a mattress, mattress pad, sheets, comforter, and pillows. There are cameras in the home in the common area and outside the home by the pool and patio areas. LPA looked at the all camera views on the FMs phone and there are no views of the bathroom or bedrooms. The video program, EZ View, has the ability to record and review camera footage for up to seven days. Nursing and Behavioral Health Technician office is equipped with a locked cabinet for storage and locked refrigerator for medication. Medications are locked and centrally stored in the nursing/medical office. The first aid kit was also in the medical office with all required items. The nursing office is also equipped with desk and supplies. Client files are maintained using the KIPU application system which is a portal to store client files and keep all information confidential. Administrator stated licensing has access to the KIPU portal upon request of client files for any purpose. The Clinical office is located separately from the home in the backyard. The office also has a restroom which will be used for staff only. This office is used to provide therapy and treatment to clients and there are no cameras. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space, and all exits were free from obstruction. Sports equipment/toys/games were observed for recreation time. There is a basketball court, garden, extensive backyard, built-in conversation fire pit with bench, and a gazebo on premises. There is a pool on premises with 5 feet tall mesh fencing surrounding the entire pool that meets regulatory standards and does not obscure the pool from view. The mesh fence is self-closing and self-latching. The gate swings open away from the body of water. The licensee understands that regardless of whether clients are present, the fence will remain permanently in place for the duration of the license. LPA observed the pool is clean and well maintained. (continued on page 3)

(continued form page 2) There were no deficiencies observed during today's inspection. Due to time constraints, LPA's will return to complete the inspection at a later date. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided and explained to the Administrator and Facility Manager.

On February 3, 2023 at 4:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Erika Lopez arrived at Hillside Horizon For Teens, LLC Group Home (GH) to imitate a complaint investigation. LPA met Tyler Michaelis who granted LPA access into the facility. LPA conducted a health and safety inspection. During the inspection, LPA observed that there were two staff and three clients present. Additionally, LPA verified that staff/client ratios was in compliance, however, there was no facility manager on site during the duration of the inspection, which was a violation of the Group Home regulations. Therefore, the facility is being cited under Group Home, Title 22, Division 6 Chapter 5 Article 06. Continuing Requirements section 84065, Personnel Requirements. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Facility Administrator, Tyler Michaelis.

Based on interviews and record reviews the allegation that staff distributed a medication to a client (name unknown) from another client (name unknown) who was placed at another facility, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. investigation_findings: 13On December 27, 2023, at 11:20 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility to deliver the findings of the above allegation. LPA met with Victor Hamaker. LPA Erika Lopez conducted an inspection of the facility on February 3, 2023, at 4:30 pm and no immediate deficiencies were observed. Two of four clients (C1, C2, C3, C4), four staff and facility administrator were interviewed. It was reported to Community Care Licensing (CCL) that staff (S1) distributed medication to a client (name unknown) from another client (name unknown) who was placed at another facility. Confidential staff interviews reported that S1 was in charge of distributing the medications during the time of this alleged incident but does not recall administering a client’s medication to another client. Confidential interviews reported that it is unclear which medication and or which client(s) this is regarding. LPA made several attempts to interview all of the clients but due to the clients no longer being placed at the facility, LPA was unsuccessful. Other confidential interviews reported that the allegation was true. The interviews that were provided to the LPA were not consistent regarding the allegation. Continued on page

narrative: Other confidential information received stated that the allegations were true. There was a lack of witnesses and information received to support the allegations and inconsistent statements. Based on interviews and record reviews the allegations that the facility is not providing C1 with proper food service, the refrigerator at the facility is not kept clean and staff (unknown name) did not treat C1 with respect, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Victor Hamaker.
investigation_findings: 13On January 09, 2024, at 9:40am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility to deliver the findings of the above allegation. LPA met with facility manager Victor Hamaker . LPA Erika Lopez conducted an inspection of the facility on March 07, 2023, at 12:25 pm and no immediate deficiencies were observed. Four of the four children (C1, C2, C3, C4), four staff and facility administrator were interviewed. It was reported to Community Care Licensing (CCL) that the facility is not providing C1 with proper food service, the refrigerator at the facility is not kept clean and staff (unknown name) did not treat C1 with respect. Confidential staff interviews reported that the facility orders food from Hello Fresh weekly. Confidential staff interviews reported that the minors are able to choose what they want or anything additional and staff places the orders. Minors are also able to eat or make whatever they like that’s available for them. Confidential staff interviews reported that the refrigerator is cleaned out weekly and any food that is expired will be thrown away. Confidential staff interviews reported that no staff has ever entered a minor’s room without knocking first. CONTINUED ON PAGE

narrative: ***Confidential** S1 worked in the facility 24 days from hire date 12/17/2022 -02/15/2023. S2 worked in the facility 32 days from hire date 01/02/2023 -02/15/2023. S3 worked in the facility 24 days from hire date 01/10/2023 -02/15/2023. ADM confirmed S1, S2, and S3 will not be allowed to work until criminal record clearance has been obtained. Based on confidential interviews, observation, and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and the allegation that uncleared staff (S1, S2, S3) are providing care and supervision is supported and proven by evidence, therefore the allegation is substantiated at this time. The facility is cited for violation of Title 22 Regulations 80019(e)(2) Criminal Record Clearance. investigation_findings: 13On 02/09/2024 at 2:45 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Val Wilson, met with Operations Manager/Facility Manager, Victor Hamaker, to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation at Hillside Horizon Group Home (GH). deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 80019(e)(2) Criminal Record Clearance (e) All individuals subject to a criminal record review pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1522 shall prior to working, residing or volunteering in a licensed facility: (2) Obtain a California clearance or a criminal record exemption as required by the Department This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews, observation, and record review, the facility did not obtain a criminal record clearance for staff 1 (S1), staff 2 (S2), and staff 3 (S3), which poses an immediate health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.

met_with: Program Director/ Facility Manager (PD) Catlin Estrada
narrative: Confidential witness interviews revealed that CT arrived and evaluated C1 and transported C1 by ambulance to the hospital. Confidential interviews indicated that the Program Director (PD) called Riverside University Health Services (RUHS) to obtain additional information regarding C1. Confidential witness interviews revealed that PD was informed that C1 was not admitted at RUHS. Confidential witness interviews disclosed that PD called surrounding hospitals to locate C1. Confidential witness interviews revealed that PD was working with C1’s Adult Relative (A1) and kept A1 informed of the situation. Confidential witness interviews disclosed that C1 was admitted at Inland Valley Medical Center (IVMC). Confidential witness interviews disclosed that C1 was discharged from IVMC and returned to the group home. Confidential witness interviews revealed that C1 was placed on staff-to-client one-on-one status for C1’s safety. Confidential interviews disclosed that C1 was not abandoned by facility staff and that it was a lack of information and misunderstanding. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, that child (C1) was abandoned at the hospital by staff (PD) is unsubstantiated. The allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were explained, and a copy of this report and LIC 811 was provided to Hillside Horizon Program Director/ Facility Manager (PD) Catlin Estrada.

narrative:
On February 29, 2024, at 1:40 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacqueline Garcia and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Ann Valenzuela conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection for Hillside Horizon. LPA and LPM met with Administrator, Blake Larkin. LPA and LPM toured the facility inside and out. The facility is a two story home in a residential neighborhood. The home is about 5,915 square feet. This home will serve 6 males. The facility is set up as follows: Upper level: *A bedroom contains two twin beds equipped with mattress pad, complete sheet set, comforter, extra blanket and pillow. Two night stands, ample lighting, closet with room for storage for clothing and personal belongings. *B bedroom contains two twin beds equipped with mattress pad, complete sheet set, comforter, extra blanket and pillow. Two night stands, ample lighting, closet with room for storage for clothing and personal belongings. Bathroom is located inside the bedroom with full shower and sink/storage. *C bedroom is the master bedroom contains two twin beds equipped with mattress pad, complete sheet set, comforter, extra blanket and pillow. Two night stands, ample lighting, closet with room for storage for clothing and personal belongings. Master bathroom in located inside the bedroom with a master shower and tub. *2 additional bathrooms are located outside of the bedrooms down the hall ways. *2 offices and an additional group office is located upstairs.1 office designated as a therapist office. Private phone call room also located upstairs. ***Continued on next page

*entry way of the home begins in the lower level. Equipped with an entry table with log guest sign in book. Posted evacuation and disaster plan, personal rights and grievance procedures. *Living room furnished with sofas, television, book shelves and home decor. *Dining room area equipped with a large table and seating for 10 people. *Kitchen is equipped with operable appliances, kitchen utensils, pot, pans and dishes, pantry is stocked with dry goods, food menu is posted. Knives are stored in the garage inside a locked cabinet. Kitchen has a nook for casual eating with four additional seats. Lower level: *contains 1 office designated for a nursing station/med room, 1 office designated as a waiting room used for intakes and visitations with families. *Laundry room equipped with washer and dryer and space for folding clothing. *Hallway closet equipped with hygiene supplies and extra linens. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes was used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. Medications are locked and centrally stored in the nursing/med office. Cleansers/chemicals were locked in the cabinet located linen room/laundry room. The first aid kit was also in the medical office with all required items. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment such as pool table/ping pong table/basketball and football equipment available for clients. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are hard-wired in and are in appropriate working order. Water temperature was tested and was at 115. Trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. ****Continued on the next page.

narrative:
Based on confidential interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the allegation that facility staff interacted inappropriately with youths is substantiated. The facility is being cited for violations of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), version 5, section 87072(c)(1) for Personal Rights. Confidential interviews revealed that C1, C2, C3 and C4 were alone inside of the master bedroom playing a spin the bottle game then C1 and C2 proceeded to go inside the closet and touched each other inappropriately. Additionally, confidential interviews revealed that the staff will conduct room checks every 15-30 minutes, however, other confidential interviews revealed that the staff will only periodically do the room checks because they had to. During the investigation, there was no corroborating evidence to support the above allegation. Although the Department received detailed information regarding the allegation, confidential interviews revealed conflicting statements to if the incidents occurred. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that due to lack of supervision resulted in C1 and C2 engaging in inappropriate behaviors with each other, may have occurred, however, is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time.
