investigation_findings: 13On April 1, 2025 at 02:15pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarah Lo met with Sydney Scott, Program Director, to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation at Hillside Horizon Group Home (GH). On 01/24/2024, LPA inspected the facility’s physical plant, and no immediate health and safety hazards were observed. The investigation included interviews with seven staff (S1, S2, S3, S4, S5, S6, S7) and three clients (C1, C3, C4). Three clients (C2, C5, C6) were declined to be interviewed by their authorized representatives. On January 17, 2025, Community Care Licensing received an allegation stating that facility staff (S2) interacted inappropriately with youths. Specifically, it was reported that S2 had all of the clients who identified as LGBTQ+ to line up against a wall according to the size of their genitalia. Confidential interviews confirmed that S2 conducted a group session with only the clients that identified as LGBTQ+ and asked the clients about their level of comfort with the size of their genitalia to determine where the clients stood in line.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: (18) To be accorded dignity in their personal relationships with staff and other persons. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews, S2 conducted a group session with only clients that identified as LGBTQ+ and that questions were asked by S2 to the clients about their level of comfort with the size of their genitalia and to stand in a line.

narrative:
On April 01, 2025 at 09:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarah Lo arrived unannounced to Hillside Horizons Group Home (GH) to conduct a Required Annual inspection of the facility. LPA was greeted by Program Director, Sydney Scott, and was allowed entry into the facility. LPA toured the facility and inspected inside and out with the Program Director. The home is a two-story residence with 3 bedrooms and 5 bathrooms. The home was approved for 6 ambulatory male clients ages 12-17. The Program Director stated current census is six. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. Beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattress in good repair. There are adequate hygiene supplies stocked in the home available for clients. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. The beds and dressers in all the bedrooms are in good repair, and all window screens are attached. LPA observed age-appropriate clothing in the closet of the clients. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. This home contains a therapist office, a group therapy room, a case managers office, a program director office, a nurse office, 2 living room, a foyer, a kitchen. The temperatures in rooms that clients occupy are maintained between 68 degrees F and 85 degrees F. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be within the regulations of 105 degrees F to 120 degrees F in the client bathroom. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. The medications were stored and locked in a locked cabinet in the locked closet inside of the nurse office. Cleaning supplies and chemicals are locked and stored in a locked closet next to the laundry room.

Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked drawer and cabinet in the kitchen. The First Aid Kits are located in the nurse office, dining room area and the staircase area; and contains all required items. The facility's smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detector located in each bedroom and common areas were checked and were operable. Fire extinguishers are located in the living room, kitchen and staircase and were properly charged and serviced. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Visitation policies, and current menu. LPA observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients as well. Refrigerators in the kitchen and garage are maintained in a good temperature. Sports equipment/games/ books were observed for children’s recreation time. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. The facility has no pools or bodies of water on the grounds. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Program Director at this time. Based on record review, the facility is being cited three Type B violations and a Technical Assistance. Due to time constraint, LPA will return at another time to continue with the annual inspection. An exit interview conducted and appeal rights were reviewed and provided. A copy of this report along was provided to the Program Director, Sydney Scott.

On April 02, 2025 at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarah Lo, conducted an unannounced annual continuation visit at Hillside Horizon Group Home (GH). LPA was met at the facility by Program Director, Sydney Scott and Executive Director, Kris Kereluik. The physical plant was inspected on April 01, 2025. LPA reviewed a sample of client and staff files. LPA reviewed files for six clients in care: C1, C2, C3, C4, C5 and C6. All client files were found to have Cash/Property/Valuables records, Medical Consent Forms and signed Needs and Services Plans. LPA reviewed staff files for S1, S2, S3, S4, and S5. All staff files reviewed have Department of Justice (DOJ), Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) and Child Abuse Clearance Index (CACI) clearances, however did not meet the minimum training requirements per Community Care Licensing Regulations. LPA conducted two client interviews and two staff interviews. The facility is being cited for three Type B violation for Personnel Requirements. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 811 Confidential Names List, and Appeal Rights were reviewed and provided to the Program Director, Sydney Scott.

narrative: On July 10, 2025, at 12:35 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmaine Linley met with Felicia Conover, Clinical Director, and Kris Kereluik, Executive Director, for a case management inspection. On July 7, 2025, Community Care Licensing Department received information that S1 had a photo of genitalia on their cell phone while sitting next to C1 and C1 observed the photo on the phone. It was also reported that S1 was watching pornography on their cell phone while C2 was present. The facility did not report the information to the Department. LPA Linley stressed the importance of reporting incidents in a timely manner. This process is necessary to ensure the welfare and well-being of all residents that are in care. The agency is in violation of regulation 80061(b) Reporting Requirements. Please refer to LIC 809-D for detailed deficiency information. An exit interview was conducted and appeal rights were reviewed. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to the facility. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.

On February 28, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Toni Castillo conducted a teams meeting with applicant Hillside Horizons for Teens, LLC. The purpose of the meeting was to complete Component II. Present at the meeting were Devon Wayt, CEO and group home facility Administrator Tyler Michles. During the meeting LPA discussed with CEO and Administrator the overall operation and services provided in the facility. This is a private placement 6 bed group home application that will provides services to females ages 12-17 years old. During the meeting CEO advised LPA that there will be a change in administrator. LPA informed CEO that all forms with new administrator will need to be resubmitted and administrator will need certificate and attend the group home orientation. During the meeting the program statement and application was discussed. Applicants were informed the following items were missing or in need of revision: Application Section A: 1. Application (LIC 200): need with new administrator 2. Applicant information (LIC215): need with new administrator 3. Designation of Administrative Responsibility (LIC308): need with new administrator 4. Administrative Organization (LIC 309): need with new administrator 5. Affidavit Client Cash Resources (LIC 400): completed 6. Monthly Operating Statement (LIC401): need with new administrator

7. Supplemental Financial Information (LIC 401a): completed 8.Surety Bond (LIC 402): completed 9. Balance Sheet (LIC 403): need with new administrator 10. Balance Sheet Supplemental (LIC403a): need with new administrator 11. Financial Information Release (LIC404): account needs to be in applicant name 12. Personnel Report (LIC 500): need with new administrator 13. Personnel Record (LIC 501): need with new administrator 14. Health Screening (LIC 503) with TB: need with new administrator 15. Resume for Administrator/CEO: need with new administrator and need transcripts and copy of degrees. Need Administrator certificate for new administrator 16. Emergency Disaster Plan: need with new administrator 17. Facility Sketch (LIC 999) with dimensions: completed 18. Criminal record clearances: need with new administrator, need to check everyone else has cleared 19. Corporation: Board resolution need with new administrator. Missing by laws & organizational chart 20. Verification of Administrator Qualifications: resume needed for new administrator 21. Job Descriptions, Duties & Responsibilities, Line of Supervision, Job Titles, Qualifications and experience with client population: complete 22. Personnel Policies: Work hours/shifts, hiring practices, abuse reporting procedures: This is not an adult home, remove APS. 23. In Service Training; completed 24. Facility Program Description: completed

25.House Rules: more specific house rules. - Curfew hours on school nights, weekends and holidays; -- Smoking; -- Dating other children in placement; -- Completing homework; -- Cleaning bedrooms and other areas; -- Use of entertainment equipment (the child’s and the facility’s); -- Dress code; -- Laundry; -- General prohibited behaviors 26. Admission Policy: Describe the program’s admission/intake procedures. Include: (gender and age qualifying for admission) -- Criteria for evaluating appropriateness of referrals for placement; -- Information required to assess referrals for placement; -- Timeframe for responding to referring agencies regarding acceptance or rejection of referral; -- Staff position responsible for intake; and -- Procedures for accepting emergency placements on a time-limited and/or trial basis. -- Eviction procedure --More specific on phone use. (hours?) --On visitation policy state hours, will you have a visitation log, check for ID, who will be in charge of visitation? 27. Transportation Procedure: Transportation log, who will maintain? Who will check vehicle or often?

28. Sample Menu: completed 29. Control of property: completed 31. First aid: Need for new administrator 32. water safety certificate: N/A 33. Administrator certificate: Need for new administrator 34. Neighborhood Complaint Procedure: completed 35. Fire Clearance: pending 36. City Planning Approval: completed 300 foot rule 37. Emergency Intervention-missing [Reference: Title 22 CCR 84300(d), 84300.1, and 84322] Include a copy of your agency’s approved Emergency Intervention Plan which must address the following areas: -- Techniques of group and individual behavior management; -- Methods for de-escalating volatile situations; -- Alternative methods of handling aggressive and assaultive behavior; -- Describe the physical techniques of applying manual restraints, if applicable; -- Techniques for returning the child to planned activity following an emergency intervention; -- A written test and evaluation criteria for the hands-on competency test; and -- Include the name and qualifications of the individual who designed the Emergency Intervention Plan. 38: AWOL/Runaway Plan: [Reference: Title 22 CCR 84322.2] Describe the plan for responding to an incident of a child running away. Include:

-- Time frames for determining when a child is absent without permission; -- Continuum of interventions; -- Actions to locate the child; -- Staff training plan; -- Plan to involve law enforcement; and -- Plan to notify the child’s authorized representative. 38. Chores: Describe any chores children are required to perform as part of their regular routine 39. Planned activities and use of community resources: [Reference: Title 22 CCR 80022(b)(13), 84065(e), 84079] Describe the program’s planned SOCIAL and RECREATIONAL activities. Include: -- The plan for indoor and outdoor activities; -- The plan for individual child activities and group interaction activities; -- Which children are involved in the activities; and -- A list of community resources used by the program (for example, YMCA, YWCA, libraries, parks, church groups). Describe the program’s planned educational activities and services. [Reference: Title 22 CCR 84079(a)(5), 84068.2] Include: -- Special education;

-- Use of public and/or private schools; -- On grounds school; and -- Tutoring, if applicable. Provide a SAMPLE DAILY ACTIVITY SCHEDULE for one week, including weekends and holidays. The schedule must include social, recreational and educational activities. 40. Discipline Policy 1. Describe the program’s discipline policy. [Reference: Title 22 CCR 80072(a)(3), (7) - (8), 84072, 84072.1] Include: -- Type(s) of discipline used; -- Conditions under which each type of discipline will be used; -- Types of discipline not permitted (corporal punishment and violation of personal rights); -- Provisions for contact with parents and/or placement representatives (conferences). NOTE: Prone containment and like techniques shall not be included as part of a program’s discipline policy nor written into individual needs and services plans. Such techniques are not to be a planned step in modifying behavior. They are considered to be only last resort emergency physical control techniques designed to prevent injury to the assaultive child or others. Exit Interview was conducted. It was discussed with referenced facility representative that in the event of any other corrections be needed LPA will notify applicant. The above corrections are to be received by the licensing office by the end of business day on March 21, 2022. LPA emailed applicant a copy of this report for signature. Applicant signed report and sent back to LPA.

The facility is a two story home in a residential neighborhood. The home is about 2,772 square feet. This home will serve both male and females. 4 females will be assigned to two bedrooms down stairs and 2 males to one bedroom up stairs. The facility is set up as follows: Upper level: *1 client bedroom, designated for 2 male clients. Bedroom contains two twin beds equipped with mattress pad, complete sheet set, comforter, extra blanket and pillow. Two night stands, ample lighting, closet with room for storage for clothing and personal belongings. *1 full bathroom designated for 2 male clients equipped with operable sink, toilet and shower. *1 half bathroom designated for staff and visitors. *4 offices 1 office designated for a nursing station/med room, 1 office designated as a therapist office, 1 office designated as a waiting room used for intakes and visitations with families and 1 office used for operations/clinical. *entry way of the home begins in the upper level. Equipped with an entry table with log guest sign in book. Posted evacuation and disaster plan, personal rights and grievance procedures.

*Living room furnished with sofas, television, book shelves and home decor. *Dining room area equipped with a large table and seating for 10. *Kitchen is equipped with operable appliances, kitchen utensils, pot, pans and dishes, pantry is stocked with dry goods, food menu is posted. Knives are stored in an upper locked cabinet. Kitchen has a nook for casual eating. Lower level: *2 client bedroom, designated for 4 female clients.(2 clients in each room) Each bedroom contains two twin beds equipped with mattress pad, complete sheet set, comforter, extra blanket and pillow. Two night stands, ample lighting, closet with room for storage for clothing and personal belongings. *1 client bedroom contains its own bathroom for use of those 2 clients. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. Medications are locked and centrally stored in the nursing/medl office. Cleansers/chemicals were locked in the cabinet located in the kitchen. The first aid kit was also in the medical office with all required items. . On February 3, 2023 at 2:29 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Erika Lopez arrived at Hillside Horizon For Teens, LLC Group Home (GH) to imitate a complaint investigation. LPA met Behavioral Health Tech (BHT) Janelle La Placa who granted LPA access into the facility. LPA conducted a health and safety inspection. During the inspection, LPA observed that there were two staff and three clients present and one client asleep at the time. Additionally, LPA verified that staff/client ratios was in compliance, however, there was no facility manager on site during the duration of the inspection, which was a violation of the Group Home regulations. Therefore, the facility is being cited under Group Home, Title 22, Division 6 Chapter 5 Article 06. Continuing Requirements section 84065, Personnel Requirements. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Facility Administrator, Tyler Michaelis.

deficiencies.title:
Personnel Requirements-
(d) The licensee shall designate at least one facility manager to be present at the facility at all times when children are present

narrative: On May 16, 2023, at 3;30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst, Val Wilson, arrived unannounced at Hillside Horizon for Teens Group Home (GH) for case management regarding law enforcement contact. LPA met with the facility manager, Jeni Foster, during this inspection and completed a safety inspection of the facility and observed no safety concerns. During the inspection, facility records and the GH program statement was reviewed. On March 20, 2023, the Department received a serious incident report (SIR) with Law Enforcement Contact (LEC) and restraint usage. The purpose of the case management was to discuss information the Department received regarding the LEC SIR dated March 12, 2023, where staff 1 (S1) put client 1 (C1) in a control position hold for 46 seconds. Specifically, C1 attempted to aggress upon C2 but S1 placed themself between C1 and C2. C1 evaded around S1 towards C2. S1 then put C1 in a manual restraint for 46 seconds while staff 2 (S2) assisted C2 from the dining room to the medication room to maintain separation from C1. A review of the GH program statement regarding the emergency intervention plan does not indicate restraint technique is utilized at the facility. Based on review of records, the licensee is cited for violation of Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Subchapter 3, Article 08, section 84300.1 Emergency Intervention Prohibition. A copy of this report, LIC 809, LIC 809D, LIC 811, and appeal rights were reviewed with Jeni Foster and Blake Larkin, Executive Director, and provided to Jeni Foster.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 84300.1(b) Emergency Intervention Prohibition (b) In addition to techniques specified in Section 84300.1(a), any emergency intervention technique not approved for use as part of the licensee's emergency intervention plan must not be used at any time. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on review of facility records and the program statement, an emergency intervention technique was used on client C1 by staff S1, on 03/12/23, that is not an approved intervention at the group home, which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.

investigation_findings: 13On December 27, 2023, at 11:51 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility to deliver the findings of the above allegation. LPA met with Victor Hamaker. LPA Erika Lopez conducted an inspection of the facility on February 3, 2023, at 4:30 pm and no immediate deficiencies were observed. Two of four clients (C1, C2, C3, C4), four staff and facility administrator were interviewed. It was reported to Community Care Licensing (CCL) that staff (S1) distributed medication to a client (name unknown) from another client (name unknown) who was placed at another facility. Confidential staff interviews reported that S1 was in charge of distributing the medications during the time of this alleged incident but does not recall administering a client’s medication to another client. Confidential interviews reported that it is unclear which medication and or which client(s) this is regarding. LPA made several attempts to interview all of the clients but due to the clients no longer being placed at the facility, LPA was unsuccessful. Other confidential interviews reported that the allegation was true. The interviews that were provided to the LPA were not consistent regarding the allegation. Continued on page

narrative: ****CONTINUED**** 63 days from hire date 11/07/2022 -02/15/2023. S2 worked in the facility 11 days from hire date 01/19/2023 -02/15/2023. S3 worked in the facility eight days from hire date 01/25/2023 -02/15/2023. S4 worked in the facility 60 days from hire date 11/28/22-02/15/23. ADM confirmed S1, S2, S3 and S4 will not be allowed to work until criminal record clearance has been obtained. Based on confidential interviews, observation, and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and the allegation that uncleared staff (S1, S2, S3, S4) are providing care and supervision is supported and proven by evidence, therefore the allegation is substantiated at this time. The facility is cited for violation of Title 22 Regulations 80019(e)(2) Criminal Record Clearance. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report along with LIC 9099D, LIC 421BG, LIC 811, and appeal rights were explained and provided to Victor Hamaker.
investigation_findings: 13On 02/09/2024 at 1:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Val Wilson, met with Operations Manager/Facility Manager, Victor Hamaker, to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation at Hillside Horizon for Teens Group Home (GH). On 02/15/2023 at 3:30 PM, LPA conducted an inspection of the facility, and no immediate health and safety hazards were observed. During the investigation, interviews were conducted with the administrator (ADM), facility manager (FM), and recruiting manager (RM). LPA reviewed LIC 500, Guardian roster report, and staff files. On February 10, 2024, the Department received a complaint that alleged that uncleared staff are providing care and supervision. Specifically, it was alleged that multiple staff are not cleared to work at the facility. Regarding the allegation that uncleared staff are providing care and supervision, record review of staff files and confidential interviews revealed that staff 1 (S1), staff 2 (S2), staff 3 (S3), and staff 4 (S4) did not have a criminal record clearance. (See LIC 811 dated 02/09/2024). S1 worked in the facility ***CONTINUED***

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 80019(e)(2) Criminal Record Clearance (e) All individuals subject to a criminal record review pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1522 shall prior to working, residing or volunteering in a licensed facility: (2) Obtain a California clearance or a criminal record exemption as required by the Department This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews, observation, and record review, the facility did not obtain a criminal record clearance for staff 1 (S1), staff 2 (S2), staff 3 (S3)and staff 4 (S4) , which poses an immediate health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.

On May 15, 2025, at 10:15am, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Julian Lucas and Karen Beal and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Cheraki Davis conducted an unannounced annual inspection for Hillside Horizon for Teens, LLC. Group Home (GH). LPAs and LPM was met by Operations/Facility Manager, Victor Hamaker, and provided a tour of the facility. During the inspection, Program Director,Caitlin Estrada assisted LPAs with the inspection. The facility is set up as follows: The facility is a two-story home in a residential neighborhood on multi-levels. The home is approximately 2,772 square feet and can serve six clients. four clients are assigned to two bedrooms bottom, and two clients are assigned to one bedroom upstairs. There are currently six clients enrolled in the home. At the entrance there is a driveway with a detached garage and a room underneath. The facility van has registration and first aid kit in the vehicle. The entryway of the home begins on the upper level. Equipped with an entry table and log guest sign in book, and one-half bathroom designated for staff and visitors. There is an office designated as a waiting room which is used for family visitation and intakes. There is a fire extinguisher by the front door, in the kitchen, and hallways. LPA observed clients’ bedrooms to be two per bedroom. There are two bedrooms (bedroom one and bedroom two) located upstairs has two twin beds, two night stands, ample lighting, closet with room for storage for clothing and personal belongings. Bedroom two has a full bathroom inside and the clients has access to it. One full bathroom downstairs designated for clients equipped with operable sink, toilet and shower. There is a two-client shared bedroom located downstairs with a full bathroom inside and the clients do not have access to it. The bathroom has a digital lock and only the staff has access to it. The staff enter the bathroom located in bedroom three from the outside of the facility. CONTINUED ON 809 C

Within the living room are sofas, a television, additionally bookshelves and home decorations. There are doors that lead out into an outdoor balcony which is furnished however client do not have access to this area. The dining room contains a large table with six seats. The kitchen has appliances and kitchenware such as pots, pans, and utensils for cooking and eating. There is a pantry which is contains shelved foods with a menu that is posted. There was more than 48 hours of menu items and fresh fruit that are accessible. Knives are stored in a locked cabinet above the refrigerator. Kitchen has an area for casual eating. The pantry, freezer, and refrigerator had plenty of perishable and non-perishable food. Posted evacuation and disaster plan, personal rights, and grievance procedures. Laundry room equipped with washer and dryer and space for folding clothing. Hallway closet equipped with hygiene supplies and extra linens. There are three staff offices. Based on LPA observation at 11:30am, the licensee did not comply with the California Code Regulations, Title 22, section 80087(a)(1) the facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors. (1) The licensee shall take measures to keep the facility free of flies and other insects. The licensee did not ensure that bedroom three window screen in good repair to keep flies and other insects from entering which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to children in care. LPA will return at a later date to interview clients, review client and staff records, review the disaster plan, and emergency intervention plan. Exit interviewed conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were given and explained to Caitlin Estrada, Program Director.

Confidential interviews indicated that the group home ratio is a one staff for three clients. Confidential witness interviews revealed that clients (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, and C6) are placed on a staff-to-client one-on-one status for the client’s safety. Confidential interviews revealed that the facility staff are trained in Crisis Prevention Institute (CPI) when the clients (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, and C6) exhibit self-injurious behaviors and suicidal ideation. Confidential witness interviews disclosed that facility staff are trained to use verbal de-escalation techniques and encourage the clients (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5 and C6) to use their coping skills. Confidential witness interviews indicated that facility staff are trained to intervene and safely restrain a client (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, and C6) when they are danger to themselves or others. Confidential interviews indicated that the facility staff are not supervising clients (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, and C6) and that the clients engage in self-harming behaviors. Confidential witness interviews revealed that facility staff (unknown) are not adequately trained to deal with minors (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, and C6) behaviors. Confidential witness interviews revealed that facility staff are not trained to work with the clients (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, and C6) behaviors. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, the allegations that due to lack of supervision (staff unknown), minors (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, and C6) are self-harming and staff (unknown) are not adequately trained to deal with minors (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, and C6) behaviors are unsubstantiated. The allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were explained, and a copy of this report and LIC 811 was provided to Hillside Horizon Program Director (PD) Victor Hamaker.
investigation_findings: 13On July 15, 2025, at 12:37 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jose Gonzalez conducted an unannounced visit and met with Hillside Horizon Program Director (PD) Victor Hamaker to deliver the findings for the above-stated allegations. LPA inspected Hillside Horizon for Teens at 10:10 am on March 18, 2025; no health and safety hazards were observed. LPA reviewed six client’s records (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, and C6). During the investigation, interviews were conducted with Clients (C1, C2, C3, and C4), Program Manager/ Facility Manager (FM), and Program Director (PD). Interviews were not conducted with C5 and C6 due to illness. On March 10, 2025, the Department received an allegation that due to lack of supervision (staff unknown), minors (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, and C6) are self-harming and staff (unknown) are not adequately trained to deal with minors (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, and C6) behaviors. Confidential interviews disclosed that facility staff monitor the client’s interactions (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, and C6). Confidential interviews indicated that the facility staff are constantly supervising the clients (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, and C6) to ensure that the clients are not engaging in self-harming behaviors.***CONTINUED on LIC 9099C***

narrative: Confidential record reviews revealed that the facility staff notified law enforcement on 01/19/2025. In addition, a confidential record review revealed that on 02/10/2025, C2 was refusing to eat and lost consciousness, fell, and hit their head on the carpet. Confidential record reviews revealed that facility staff called 911. Confidential record reviews revealed that C2 was transported by paramedics to Inland Valley Hospital. Confidential record reviews revealed that facility staff emailed a 24-hour notice to the assigned Licensing Program Analyst and California Department of Social Services Pacific Inland Children Residential Program Special Incident Report Inbox. The facility did not provide the incident reports that LPA requested during the visit. LPA did not observe any incident reports sent to the Department. Based on confidential record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. The allegation that staff are not following reporting requirements is substantiated. The facility is cited for violation of Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 06, Continuing Requirements 80061(b) Reporting Requirements: Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in (1)…, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours. In addition, a written report containing the information specified in (2)…shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event. The facility staff did not submit a written report to the Department within seven days for C1 and C2. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were explained, and a copy of this report and LIC 811 was provided to Hillside Horizon Program Administrator (AD) Victor Hamaker.
investigation_findings: 13On June 26, 2025, at 10:33 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jose Gonzalez conducted an unannounced visit and met with Hillside Horizon for Teens Group Home Program Administrator (AD) Victor Hamaker to deliver the findings for the above-stated allegation. LPA inspected Hillside Horizon at 10:33 am/ on June 26, 2025; no health and safety hazards were observed. LPA reviewed two client records (C1 and C2). During the investigation interview was conducted with the Program Director (PD). Interviews were not conducted with the Clients (C1 and C2). On June 24, 2025, the Department received an allegation that staff are not following reporting requirements. Confidential record reviews revealed that facility staff did not submit a written report for two incidents that occurred at the facility on 01/19/2025 and 02/10/2025. Confidential record reviews revealed that on 01/19/2025, C1 was being aggressive and assaultive and was placed in a Crisis Prevention Intervention (CPI) hold. Confidential record reviews revealed that on 01/19/2025, C1 ran away from the group home, and the facility staff lost sight of C1. **CONTINUED on LIC 9099 C**

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Section 80061(b) Reporting Requirements: 80061(b) Reporting Requirements: Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in (1)…, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours. In addition, a written report containing the information specified in (2)…shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential record review, the facility staff did not submit a written report to the Department within seven days for C1 and C2, which poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to children in care.

narrative:
On October 20, 2022 at 10:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daphne Edison and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Lakescia Smith arrived at Hillsides Group Home for the purpose of conducting a Pre-Licensing Inspection Visit. LPA’s and LPM met with Casey Meinster, Senior Clinical Director and Andrew Hernandez, Director of Cottage Services who granted access into the facility and together a tour was conducted. There is a secured swimming pool located on the main campus. The facility will provide care and supervision to fifty (50) children, male and female, ages 6-17 years, ambulatory only. The census on the day of this visit is thirteen (13). Hillsides Group Home is set up as follows: There are five (5) cottages (Sierra, Tradewinds, Canyon, Arroyo, and Redwood) located on the main campus. Each cottage has a common living area equipped with adequate seating and a television, dining area with adequate seating for family style dining, three (3) – four (4) bathrooms, a laundry room with storage for extra linens, bedding, and comforters, kitchen, and ten (10) bedrooms. Each bedroom is equipped with one (1) twin-size bed, dresser, desk, adequate lighting, and ample closet space. All beds have clean and adequate bedding. Laundry supplies are kept in the laundry room in a locked storage cabinet. Individual personal hygiene boxes are kept in a cabinet in the laundry room. Extra hygiene products are kept in all staff offices. All kitchens are equipped with a four (4) burner gas stove. LPA observed perishable and non-perishable foods for more than a one (1) week supply. Sierra Cottage: Houses 13-17-year-old Co-Ed. Has an attached common area to the living area. Equipped with two (4) bathrooms with tub, shower, and toilet. Bathrooms are clean, sanitary, and operable. Tradewinds Cottage: Currently under construction. Will house 13-17-year-old, Co-Ed. Canyon Cottage: Currently under construction. Will house 14-17-year-old, females only. Continued on LIC 809-C

Arroyo Cottage: Houses 14-17-year-old, male only. Redwood Cottage: Houses 6-12-year-old, Co-Ed. Equipped with three (3) bathrooms with tub, showers, and toilet. Bathrooms are clean, sanitary, and operable. All prescribed and over the counter medications will be kept locked in the central nurse’s office located on Hillsides main campus accessible and administered only by nursing staff. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide alarms were tested and are operable. All regulation fire extinguishers are fully charged. Facility also has a Fire Alarm Pull System. First aid kits are complete with scissors, tweezers, thermometer, and a First Aid manual located in all cottage staff offices. Hot water was tested and is in a safe temperature range. LPA observed the facility to have adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and are free from debris and hazards. Activities include a basketball court, gym, music room, art center, indoor gym, game room and recording studio. Foster Youth Bill of Rights and grievance procedures were posted. All posting requirements have been met. LPA advised that a LIC 508, LIC 9182, and an exemption request, if staff needs an exemption, must be submitted to LPA Edison for Casey Meister and Andrew Hernandez along with a photocopy of their driver license. LPA advised requested documents to be emailed to LPA Edison. The following must be corrected: Sierra Cottage: Bedroom #3 window screen needs to be repaired/replaced. Post a larger visible Foster Youth Bill of Rights. Tradewinds Cottage: Currently under construction. Paint, furniture, and bedroom set-up for placement. Canyon Cottage: Currently under construction. Paint, furniture, and bedroom set-up for placement. Arroyo Cottage: Paint, furniture, and bedroom set-up for placement. Redwood Cottage: Bedroom #3, missing window screen. Bedroom #6, missing window screen. Continued on LIC 809-C

LPA will conduct a follow-up visit once all corrections have been made and facility is placement ready. Provider is converting from a Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) to a Group Home (GH). Exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Senior Clinical Director.

On November 18, 2022 at 10:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daphne Edison and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Lakescia Smith conducted a Component II, Face-to-Face meeting with Hillsides staff. In attendance were the following: Casey Meinster, Division Chief and Andrew Hernandez, Director of Cottages. The purpose of the meeting was to discuss the pending Group Home application and Program Statement review. LPA discussed and advised staff to submit the incomplete documentation by December 7, 2022. The following concerns were discussed with Casey and Andrew: • Submit Administrator Qualification documents and Administrator Certificate for Yadira Lopez • UPDATED LIC 200 was received on 11/18/2022 due to capacity reduction and to correct facility name to: Hillsides Pasadena • LIC 308 – Designate the Administrator • LIC 309 (Section 10) Incomplete • LIC 9165 Requested updated forms for the new facility type • LIC 402 - Surety Bond (was not completed) • LIC 401 Staff must complete a monthly estimate, not an annual estimate. • LIC 404 (LPA will follow up with financial institution) • LIC 508 – Missing for Administrator. LPA received for all staff on 11/18/2022. • LIC 9182 – Missing for Casey, Stacy, and Administrator (LPA received Transfer request for all employees 11/18/2022 Continued on LIC 809-C

• Fire Inspection: LPA was informed inspection completed. LPA will follow up with fire inspector. • LIC 503/TB Screening: Needed for Yadira Lopez, Administrator • First Aid Certificate: Needed for Yadira Lopez, Administrator • LIC 9106 – Group Home Program Statement General Instructions. LPA advised staff to complete and submit the UPDATED LIC 9106 (REVISED 11/2019). Due to major construction being completed in one of the cottages, CCL will be unable to include the capacity for this cottage. Once construction has been completed, submit a new application with the updated capacity so a fire clearance can be requested. Your analyst will conduct a follow up inspection after the construction has been completed. LPA advised Division Chief to submit a camera waiver to CCL to utilize cameras on the premises. LPA will email instructions to Division Chief. A Component III meeting will be conducted virtually on November 29, 2022 from 2p-4p. A follow-up Pre-Licensing Inspection will be conducted by LPA Edison on December 13, 2022 at 10:00am. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was given to the Division Chief.

Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward, visited the facility to determine if a capacity increase can be granted at the licensee's request. The facility currently has 40 beds but wishes to add the 10 beds located in the Tradewinds Cottage. LPA observed the following: Tradewinds cottage consists of 10 bedrooms and 3 full bathrooms. Each bedroom has a single twin bed with linens in good condition. All bedroom windows are operable. There are no security bars on bedroom windows. All bedrooms have working carbon monoxide detectors and sprinkler valves. There is a fire pull station and a fire extinguisher in the cottage. All three bathrooms have equipment that is clean and in working order. Hot water is at a safe temperature. There is a kitchen stove and refrigerator in good working condition. There is a washer and dryer in the laundry room. There are locked storage areas for kitchen utensils and household chemicals. There are two sofas and two dining room tables with a combined seating capacity of 12. Sharp kitchen knives are stored in the central dining hall. Medications are centrally stored in the nursing station. There is a complete first aid kit in the cottage. A capacity increase from 40 to 50 may be granted once an updated LIC 200 and an approved fire clearance are received. This amended report supersedes the report previously issued..

Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward met with Director Andrew Hernandez to follow up on the incident of 03/20/24 wherein a client was restrained to prevent her attempt to go AWOL. Per Director Hernandez, this restraint was necessary because the client had made several suicide attempts that day and had voiced her plan to run into oncoming traffic. Director Hernandez further stated that the client was hospitalized on 03/25/24 and placed on a psychiatric hold. Due to her placement as a Commercial Insurance client her bed has been closed and there is no guarantee that she will be re-admited. After discussing the restraint with the Director, LPA Jones-Steward concluded that the restraint was justified to protect the safety of the client.

On 05/08/2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Andrea Aceves and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Lakescia Smith, made an announced visit to Hillsides Group Home for the purpose of a Case Management- Other. LPA and LPM met with Andrew to conduct a tour of the facility regarding the provider request to operate an additional program to the premises. A tour was conducted to verify that the programs will be operated separately and there will be no co-mingling of clients and staff. A separate entrance was observed that will require card access to enter the premises. LPA and LPM will follow up with Andrew at a later date to discuss any further concerns or questions. Exit interview completed and a copy of the report was provided.

met_with: Andrew Hernandez, Director of Residential Services
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward met with Andrew Hernandez to discuss the Special Incident Report of May 16, 2025 which reported that a client was given the wrong medication by accident. The internal report number is 0001777-FN. LPA also spoke to the LVN who caused the error. The client was discharged on May 27, 2025. The LVN stated that the error was due to the medications being similar in size, shape and color. She also stated that the client did not alert her of the error until a few minutes after taking the medication. Mr. Hernandez provided proof that the LVN has received review training on medication with an internal compliance review pending. The results will be provided to the Department when the review is complete. The facility was cited under Title 22 80078(a)

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Responsibility for providing care & supervision The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. The licensee failed to meet this regulation when an LVN gave an incorrect dosage of medicine to a client. This presents an immediate health and safety risk to clients in care

met_with: Andrew Hernandez, Senior Director of Campus Based Services
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the allegations that staff did not respect C1's religious beliefs, did not treat him with dignity and did not provide him with food appropriate for Ramadan. LPA interviewed C1, S1, S2 and S3. LPA could not interview other clients because they were all relocated due to the closure of the Unaccompanied Minor Program. LPA also reviewed the internal investigation and a copy of the email thread regarding food options and scheduling adjustments for those clients who observe Ramadan. C1 informed this LPA that he felt that his rights were violated and he was the victim of racial and religious based descrimation. However S1, S2 and S3 deny these allegations. LPA Jones-Steward resolved these allegations as unsubstantiated due to inability to interview other clients who were witness to the events, An unsubstantiated finding means that although an allegation my be true, there is not a preponderance of evidence that it is true.

narrative:
On March 5, 2025, at 10am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Robinson and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Cheraki Davis met with HIQMA Residential Home GRV Applicant Adedapo Ajibade to complete Component II of the Group Home (GH) application process, the face-to-face interview. The Applicant attended Component I, the GH orientation, on October 23, 2024. Ade Salau were also in attendance. The purpose of the meeting was to review the GH application process with the applicant, review incomplete licensing (LIC) application forms, and resolve any questions or concerns to ensure that the applicant understands the process and can provide the services outlined in the Program Statement (PS) and Plan of Operation (POO) submitted. LPA verified that the Applicant had applicable clearances and was associated with the GH. During the meeting, LPA reviewed the LIC application forms and the LIC 184 Notification of Incomplete Application, sent to the Applicant on February 12, 2025. During the meeting, LPA received updated LIC forms that were incomplete or missing. LPA informed the Applicant that the PS and POO would require revisions and they have been provided to the Applicant. The LPA discussed the written plans and policies with the Applicant, including the discipline policy, to ensure it aligned with personal rights, trauma-informed emergency interventions, planned activities, administrative organization, staff job descriptions, and the training requirements and qualifications for the Administrator, Facility Manager, and Direct Care Staff. LPA reminded the Applicant of the staff and client ratios and reviewed the regulations outlined in the GH Interim Licensing Standards 84065.5. Regarding the qualifications for the Administrator, the Applicant currently holds an Administrator certificate that is set to expire on April 13, 2025. Applicant verified that they have renewed the certificate prior to expiration and will send the updated certificate once received. (Continued on LIC 809C...)

The Applicant does meet the qualifications for Administrator specified in 84064 by holding a bachelor’s degree. LPA requested documentation of bachelor’s degree from Applicant. Applicant meets work experience and having administration experience. The LPA also discussed alternative financing options with the Applicant to cover the three- month operating cost and informed the Applicant that the funds must be verifiable. LPA and LPM concluded the interview by discussing the next steps in the application process and requesting additional documentation. The Applicant was also provided with Foster Bill of Rights for Youth pamphlet, Employee Rights pamphlet, and Caregiver Training information. The following documents were requested from the Applicant due by March 26, 2025: A Documents LIC 401 Monthly Operating Statement – To be used to provide an estimated operating budget. The number of clients must correspond with the requested capacity of five and all estimated costs shall be reasonable. LIC 403 Balance Sheet Additional Documents Requested Updated Lease Agreement A copy of this report was emailed to the Applicant Adedapo Ajibade for signature. The original copy of the signed report will be placed in the facility file.

On August 5, 2025, at 9:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Robinson conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection at Hiqma Residential Home Grv. The applicant Adedapo Ajibade submitted a Group Home (GH) application with a capacity of five clients. Presently there are no clients in care at the proposed new location. The pre-licensing inspection was conducted with the assistance of Applicants, Adedapo Ajibade and Ademola Salau. The facility is a one-story home with four bedrooms and two bathrooms, and a two-car garage. The facility has a living room and dining room in the kitchen area with a large dining room table. There are three combination smoke detectors and carbon monoxide devices located throughout the home and in working order. There is one sliding door exit in the dining room/living room leading to the backyard. There are no pools of bodies of water present. There is a landline telephone that is in working order that will be available to clients located in the living room. There were no observable hazards or obstructions by the walkways and entries/exits. The backyard has a detached covered patio with electrical connected for lights and fans. The backyard also has a built-in gas fireplace with a television available for entertainment alongside an outside dining table and chairs. The central ac unit is in the backyard behind the house located on the left side of the house right along the built-in fireplace. There is a large storage unit located on the right side of the house that is planned to be used as a storage unit with possible plans to have it renovated as staff space at a unknown future date and all plans will be submitted to Licensing if there are any changes. The large storage unit currently holds storage shelves and there are two entryways into the storage unit which both have locks to be made inaccessible to clients. (Continued On LIC 809C...)

The Applicant has a working fire extinguisher located by the sliding door leading to the backyard. The garage will be made inaccessible to clients and store extra storage items and cleaning supplies. There are two cameras on the outside premise of the home, one is located at the front door and the second is located on the garage for a view of the driveway. The Applicants has sufficient dishes, cups and silverware for client use and the gas stove is in working order. There are three stools off the kitchen island for more available seating. The sharp knives are locked in the kitchen pantry closet. LPA observed games and puzzles for clients. There is one bedroom located off the kitchen area (bedroom #1) that will be used for two clients with an attached full bathroom (bathroom #1) and closet that will be available for client use. There are three bedrooms located off the main hallway (bedroom #2, bedroom #3 and bedroom #4) and one full bathroom located off the main hallway (bathroom #2 ). The bedrooms will be arranged so that no more than two clients are in a room, and there will be one client per bed. Bedroom #2 will be utilized as a staff office and a confidential area for clients to have a private space if needed. Bedroom #2 or the staff office currently has one small desk for a computer and an office chair with plans to purchase more staff office supplies and another office desk for staff to utilize. There is a laundry room located right outside bedroom #4. Applicants plan to purchase a cabinet to house locked cleaning and laundry detergent supplies. All bedrooms observed the individual beds to be in good repair, equipped with good springs, clean mattresses and pillows. There is an adequate closet and dresser space for clients. The bathrooms were observed to be in clean and working order. LPA tested the water, and it read at 106.8 degrees Fahrenheit in the kitchen and 113 degrees Fahrenheit in the bathrooms. The Applicants were advised that the hot water should measure within 105 degrees Fahrenheit and 120 degrees Fahrenheit. The facility has one facility vehicle, a 2013 Toyota Sienna that was observed to be in good working condition. (Continued on LIC 809C...)

The following deficiencies were observed: There were no client folders available to house client records. During the visit applicant Adedapo went to purchase file folders to house the client records. The following discussions were had: The applicant is to ensure that all incoming staff will be associated with facility prior to accepting and working with clients and the facility to be in compliance with staffing to client ratio. The applicant is to provide another working station in the staff office for maximum efficiency and client confidential area. The facility will only accept ambulatory and minor clients. The facility will accept clients from Inland Regional Center once vendorized and will look into County requirements as well. After a final review, the facility will be submitted for licensure. Pre-Licensing inspection was completed, and a copy of this report was given to the Applicant, Adedapo Ajibade.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen conducted the Component II - Face to Face Interview with Chuwang R. Pam, Applicant. Application and program statement was reviewed and discussed with applicant. The applicant will oversee a group home for clients with special health care needs, His kingdom Family Home. The following documents were received and verified by LPA: 1. LPA verified the orientation certificate for Component I. 2. LPA made a copy of Licensee's ID for the records. 3. LPA reviewed criminal record clearance for applicant, and saw that it was incomplete. Applicant will complete for and contact guardian to confirm clearance. 4. LPA reviewed application and informed applicant to update the capacity from 6 to 5 and to make sure the age and gender of clients served matches on both the application and program statement. In addition applicant will also: Update the Board of Directors Statement. Make sure there is no conflict of interest between the administrator, board member and landlord. Update the lease agreement. Update all forms to state the facilities proper name 'His Kingdom Family Home.' Obtain a surety bond and update LIC 401 and 401a to reflect the proper amounts. Update LIC 500 to have a Facility Manager and get a new fire clearance with the proper capacity of 5. Update facility sketch LIC 9099 to only have 5 beds that matches the capacity. Complete the LIC 610 C the emergency disaster plan. Update LIC 9106 by not taking clients who are dependants or wards/delinquents, change staff ratio to 1:2 and 1:3, add staff education qualifications, and sign. 5. LPA reviewed the Program Statement which was out of compliance with Group Home with Special Health Care Needs Regulations and General Licensing Requirements. Applicant will refer to application instructions to revise and adhere to the requirements.

LPA reviewed application and Program Statement and returned to applicant for revision. Applicant will make the following changes to the program statement: Remove all references to: minor parents, child care, TILP's ILP's, fostor care, and things unrelated to a Group Home Facility. Add a land line or designated phone for the facility. Update the capacity from 6 to 5. Remove references to His Kingdom providing mental and healthcare services, those services are to be provided by the client medical professional physician. Will have the Psychiatric Mobil Team (PET) responsible for psychiatric hospitalization of youth. Add attachment or remove mention of attachments where applicable. Add more personal rights for the clients, including but not limited to: education, telephone, and mail rights. Explain birth the accepted forms of discipline and prohibited forms of discipline. Will add confidential/anonymous capabilities to the grievance procedures. Add abuse reporting procedures for staff. Include copies of the updated lease agreement and Board of Directors Statement. Applicant will submit updated and revised application, Program Design, and LIC 200 by 05/20/2025. LPA scheduled a Pre-Licensing visit for for 05/20/2025 at 10AM. Exit interview completed.

On 5/20/25, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen arrived at the above facility, for the purpose of conducting a Pre- licensing inspection for a Group Home Special Healthcare Needs License. LPA met with applicant, Chuwang Pam and landlord Dr. William Chima who granted access into the home. The applicant and LPA toured the facility both inside and out. Currently residing in the home is Dr. Chima who will be moving out before licence is granted. Applicant is requesting to be licensed for 5 clients ages 7-13 ambulatory only. The home was inspected and the following was observed: This is a two-story house, with a front yard, backyard, and a garage in the back. There are working duel smoke/carbon monoxide detector in every bedroom. They are synched throughout the house. Living Room: There is adequate lighting and a ceiling fan. There is a TV and a coffee table. There is a L shaped sofa, and two chairs. There are cabinets for storage. The living room leads to the kitchen, upstairs, and a hallway to the bedrooms. Bedroom #1: For clients. There are two twin beds. There is adequate lighting and a ceiling fan. There is a door that leads to the kitchen. There is adequate closet storage space and two small bedside dressers. Storage space is filled with extra linens. There are two windows in working order. There are anti-burglar bars on the windows that need to be fixed and made able to open from the inside. Applicant will make the necessary changes.

Bathroom #1: is located off of the hallway adjacent to bedroom #1 and #2. It is clear of all cleaning solutions with a working toilet, sink, and shower. There are extra towels in the bathroom. Water temp was measured to be 105 degree F. Bedroom #2: For clients. There is twin bed. There is adequate lighting and a ceiling fan. There is adequate closet storage space and one small bedside dresser. Storage space is filled with extra linens. There are two windows in working order. There are anti-burglar bars on the windows that need to be fixed and made able to open from the inside. Applicant will make the necessary changes. Kitchen/Dinning Room: Is equipped with an operable 4 burner stove, refrigerator/freezer, and small kitchen counter appliances. Applicant will assign locked cabinet for sharps and client medication to be inaccessible to clients in care. Below the sink will be a locked cabinet for cleaning solutions. There are two dinning tables with adequate seating. There is a TV and a fan. Applicant will stock fridge and freezer with and adequate amount of perishable and non-perishable food. Applicant will place in the kitchen a first aid kit was checked to be complete with scissors, tweezers, thermometer, and gauzes, antiseptic. Applicant will also obtain a fire Extinguisher to be fully charged and available in the kitchen. The kitchen leads to bathroom #3, the backyard and the den. Den: There is a den with couches, sofas, and chairs. There is adequate lighting, a ceiling fan, and coffee tables. Applicant will turn the den into an activity/game/hangout room. Applicant will clear out the small bar area in the room. Bathroom #3: This is a half bathroom with a working sink and toilet. There is also a washer and dryer set in the bathroom. Applicant will make this bathroom a staff only bathroom. Up Stairs: Bedroom #3: For clients. There are two twin beds. There is adequate lighting and a ceiling fan. There is adequate closet storage space and two small bedside dressers. Storage space is filled with extra linens. There are two windows in working order.

Bathroom #2: is located upstairs adjacent to bedroom #3. It is clear of all cleaning solutions with a working toilet, two sinks, and a shower. There is a fan. There are extra towels in the bathroom. Water temp was measured to be 105 degree F. Master Bedroom: There is a master bedroom upstairs. It will be converted to an office. It will be locked and made inaccessible to clients. Applicant will have an are to store client and staff files and all other facility paperwork. Office Space: There is a landing area off the stairs that is currently being as an office. There are two computers and two desks. Out Side: Front Yard: There is a front yard with adequate space for clients to run around and hang out. Backyard: There is a back yard has a fountain. There is some outdoor seating. The backyard leads to the side yard and garage. There is a side path that leads to the front yard. There is some excess debris and furniture that applicant will remove. Garage: The garage will be used as excess storage and will remain locked and be made inaccessible to clients. Side Yard: There is a side yard next to the garage and backyard. There is a gate and it can be made locked and inaccessible. Applicant is thinking of making it an outdoor exercise and recreation area. There is some excess storage and debris that needs to be cleared out first. Applicant will keep the area locked and inaccessible until it is cleaned out. LPA will follow up with applicant for Component III orientation. LPA will also return to check all the changes that applicant agreed to. LPA will also be checking the facility vehicle and insurance. Applicant will also provide a facility telephone. Exit Interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to the applicant.

On April 25, 2022 at 8:02 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Noubar Yerkatyan conducted an unannounced inspection at the above facility for the purpose of conducting an annual/required inspection. LPA met with facility Administrator, Ricardo Montes. LPA and Administrator toured the facility. LPA obtained and reviewed the following updated documentation: LIC 500 Personnel and Client Roster LIC 610 C Emergency Disaster Plan Board of Directors report and Program Statement Employee Grievance Policy/ Grievance Procedures Crisis Prevention Intervention Training's Emergency Preparedness: Disaster and Mass Casualties Drills Emergency Evacuation Routes Facility Monthly Activities Calendar Emergency Intervention Plan Complaint Procedures The facility was in full compliance with 7 applicable areas of the Compliance and Regulatory Enforcement (CARE) tools for Children’s Residential Licenses. Annual compliance review consisted of the following domains: Physical plant, operations, disaster preparedness plan, emergency intervention, staffing, and client records. Community Care Licensing (CCL) focuses its efforts on three priority areas: prevention, compliance, and enforcement. One fire extinguisher throughout the facility is fully charged and last serviced on 07/13/2021. The facility has a working telephone that is accessible to clients and staff. All passageways and grounds were free of any obstructions. The medications, cleaning solutions, and knives were locked inside the cabinets in the kitchen inaccessible to the clients. There was perishable foods enough for 3 days and

non-perishable foods enough for client's consumption for more than a week. Each bedroom has one twin bed/extra long with clean sheets and linens. There were drawers and closet space in each bedroom for client use. The hot water temperature was tested and was in working order. At the time of this inspection the facility was observed to be clean, safe, and in good repair. Administrator is on site at least 20 hours a week. The facility has a central administrative file under their main facility: Hope House facility. The facility has a 2010 Volkswagen van used to transport clients. The vehicle has an active insurance policy. The facility maintains an equipment/vehicle safety log in the headquarters office that is monitored by the Maintenance Supervisor. The vehicle is serviced every quarter or as needed. For this review, one (1) San Andreas Regional Center client was selected for the sample to assess the level of care and services they receive. Additionally, LPA reviewed two (2) staff files for compliance with Title 22 Regulations and Interim Licensing Requirements. LPA also conducted interviews with two staff members and one client. Client was unable to be interviewed due to a speech delay. An exit interview was conducted. LPA provided the facility representative above a signed copy the LIC 809 and LIC 811 reports. There were no deficiencies cited at the time of this inspection.

The investigation revealed that the facility staff left a cup of tea unattended causing a non-verbal client 1st and 2nd degree burns from attempting to drink the tea that was severely hot. Facilty staff placed the tea on the coffee table located in the living room and proceeded with his normal work duties. The facilty administrator stated that the client tends to eat and drink other people’s stuff and staff have redirected him many times. Interviews with staff revealed that client was in his room getting ready for bed and may have stepped out of his room to walk around the house and might have seen the cup and drank it when no one was looking. Client is non-verbal. Staff stated that no one heard the client scream or make noises from the injury. Staff stated that there was no observation from the night staff of any possible injuries to client because client might have gone to his room after the incident and went to sleep. Staff stated that visual checks are done during the day and night and the client's lights were off. The facility administrator stated that a morning staff observed redness on clients face when he woke up and contacted him to report the injuries. The facility administrator reported that he immediately took client to urgent care where it was determined client had first degree burns to the middle of upper chest, second degree burns to the bottom lip, chin and right side of his cheek. Therefore, the facility administrator interviewed night staff and terminated that a staff was at fault of leaving his hot tea cup unattended causing negligence on his part. In addition, another night staff that was working the night shift the day of the incident and was unaware as to how the client sustained the injuries because he was attending to the other clients. The facility client was non-verbal and had a history of exhibiting inappropriate behaviors. Based on the information gathered, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation was met, therefore the allegation is substantiated per California Code of Regulations Title 22 – refer to LIC9099-D for deficiencies and a civil penalty of $150 will be assessed in conjunction with the confirmed deficiency. A copy of this report, Confidential Names Form, LIC 9099-D for deficiency and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative.
investigation_findings: 13On February 15, 2023, at 10:25 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Claudia Portillo conducted a follow-up inspection to deliver the findings of a complaint investigation concerning the allegation above. This requirement is not met as evidence by: Based on the information obtained, it was determined that a facility client sustained multiple injuries due to neglect and lack of supervision by staff, a finding which poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.

facility_name: HOPE FOR YOUTH INC. BAIN HOUSE
narrative: On this date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Rodriguez conducted an unannounced case management with Hope for Youth Bain House to discuss a deficiency, and contacted Executive Director, Clinard Fletcher. Due to restrictions of COVID-19, the case management was conducted by telephone. A deficiency was discussed regarding an incident report dated 01/06/2021 provided by the agency. Based on record review the information provided in the incident report did not correlate with the information provided in the police report dated 01/06/2021, regarding the same incident. Reporting requirements were discussed with the agency and the importance of documenting any use of manuel restraints on clients. Based on the above, there is a preponderance of evidence to substantiate a violation of regulations based on California Code of Regulation which are being cited on the attached LIC 809D A copy of the report and Appeal Rights was provided to the agency. This report is being emailed to the Executive Director for a signature and a scan back to CCL on this date.

facility_name: HOPE FOR YOUTH INC. BAIN HOUSE
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Rodriguez contacted, Hope for Youth: Bain House via telephone (in accordance with PIN 20-05-CRP) and spoke with Executive Director, Clinard Fletcher. The purpose of the call was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. The Department has investigated the complaint alleging staff hit minor while in care and staff speak inappropriately towards minor. During the investigation, LPA conducted a record review and interviewed one client and nine staff. All staff’s statements were consistent in that they denied the allegations occurred. The alleged victim recanted his statement when speaking to this LPA; however, did make the allegation to the reporting party. Due to the conflicting information revealed in the interview process, the agency has deemed the allegation to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to provide the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to the Executive Director for signatures.

facility_name: HOPE FOR YOUTH INC. BAIN HOUSE
narrative: Licensing Program Corina Carrillo conducted a case management inspection April 13, 2022 at 9:30AM, based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 9 out of 9 Direct Care Staff and 4 out of 4 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 9 Direct Care Staff and 1 out of 4 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, April 13, 2022.) The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Carrillo observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Clinard Fletcher.

facility_name: HOPE FOR YOUTH INC. BAIN HOUSE
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Corina Carrillo conducted a case management inspection June 25, 2025 at 1:00PM, based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 7 Direct Care Staff and 4 out of 4 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 8 Direct Care Staff and 1 out of 4 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, June 25, 2025.) The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma- informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Carrillo observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Katrina Mason.
