narrative: It was alleged that a facility staff physically abused a facility client by punching the client’s face, chest and slamming the client’s head onto a toilet. It was also alleged that staff improperly restrained the client, and a staff also made inappropriate comments to the client by calling the client a hoarder. Confidential statements obtained indicated that the facility client insisted the allegations occurred. Facility staff interviewed denied the allegations. There were no witnesses identified during the investigation to corroborate the allegations. Furthermore, the facility client’s history of making false allegations against the facility and staff along with the client’s history of self-harming behavior were taken into account in order to make a determination in the investigation. Based on the information gathered, although the allegations may have happened or is valid, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegations was not met, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. A copy of this report, Confidential Names Form and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative via electronic mail. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection.
investigation_findings: 13On May 12, 2021 at 3:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joshua Rarela conducted a follow-up complaint tele-inspection to deliver the findings of a complaint investigation concerning the allegations above. LPA Rarela discussed the findings with the facility administrator. During the course of the investigation, LPA Rarela contacted and interviewed the facility administrator on 1/11/21, the facility client’s biological mother on 1/22/21 and 1/23/21, the facility client’s Regional Center representative on 1/21/21 and 4/1/21, and facility staff on 5/12/21 (see Confidential Names Form dated May 12, 2021). LPA Rarela also reviewed documents on 1/11/21 and 5/12/21 including the police report, the facility client's (FC) Discharge Summary, FC's Individualized Program Plan, Facility Incident Reports, Personnel Files including current staff roster, personnel contact information, job duties descriptions, and personnel disciplinary actions. (Continued)

narrative: An unannounced Case Management Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Larios on 3/10/22 at 3:30 PM. During the inspection LPA Larios met with Facility Manager Jonathan Lopez in person and Administrator Dorothy Gonzalez via facetime. The purpose of the inspection was to issue citations for deficiencies observed by LPA Larios during another assignment regarding the facility. While conducting a record review for Client (C1) on 12/22/21, LPA Larios obtained a copy of one Special Incident Report (SIR) dated 12/12/21 and Progress Notes (PN) dated 12/12/21. The PN state a Two Man Stand and Three to Five Second hold were used on C1. Interviews with staff revealed these are restraint techniques used in Crisis Prevention Intervention (CPI). The SIR, which was submitted to the Department, did not state restraint was used during the incident. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, regulation 84061(h)(2): Reporting Requirements. Record review and staff statements indicate required detailed information including restraints used, how many times restraint was used and staff who provided the restraint were not noted. A copy of this report, LIC809D and Confidential Names form LIC811 dated 3/10/22 were provided to the above-mentioned facility representative. Appeal rights were provided and discussed. Exit interview conducted.

The Department received a complaint alleging Ref. #1 (Confidential Names form LIC 811 dated 3/10/22) sustained multiple injuries in care, was inappropriately restrained by staff and was not allowed to make a phone call. Staff denied the allegations. The investigation revealed Ref. #1 was unable to obtain a laptop that was in a secure location. Ref. #1 then walked to his room, walked out and obtained a phone to make a call. Staff told Ref. #1 he needed to ask for permission to use the phone. Ref. #1 immediately escalated in self injurious, aggressive behavior and was ushered to a nearby room to stabilize. Staff reported Ref. #1 bit himself on the wrist, spit at staff, cursed at staff and lunged at a staff’s legs. As a result of Ref. #1 presenting with behaviors, staff reported using a Two Person Hold to guide Ref. #1 down to a mat and while he was on the floor used Three to Five Second Holds up to four times within a ten to fifteen-minute time frame. After the incident a body check was conducted and Ref. #1 was observed with redness and marks on his neck, stomach and back. A red mark on Ref. #1 neck, staff suggested, could have been obtained from a two-way radio device that was clipped to his collar. The marks on Ref. #1 back, staff suggested, could have been obtained from a police belt worn by Ref. #1 and his body’s movement while on the floor. Statements obtained by staff regarding the use of restraint were consistent. Staff reported utilizing holds as they were trained, to ensure the safety of the resident and staff. Statements obtained from confidential interviews conducted revealed insufficient facts related to the reported incident. Statements obtained from interviews conducted with placing agency workers revealed there were no concerns related to the incident or the allegations reported to the Department. Based on information obtained through interviews conducted and records review, the allegations are Unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid the preponderance of evidence standard was not met. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report and Confidential Names form LIC 811 dated 3/10/22 were provided to the above-mentioned facility representative. No deficiencies were cited.

narrative:
On August 11, 2022 at 08:32 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Noubar Yerkatyan conducted an unannounced inspection at the above facility for the purpose of conducting an annual/required inspection. LPA met with facility Administrator, Dorothy Gonzalez. LPA and Administrator toured the facility. LPA obtained and reviewed the following updated documentation: · LIC 500 Personnel and Client Roster · LIC 610 C Emergency Disaster Plan · Board of Directors report and Program Statement · Employee Grievance Policy/ Grievance Procedures · Crisis Prevention Intervention Training's · Emergency Preparedness: Disaster and Mass Casualties Drills · Emergency Evacuation Routes · Facility Monthly Activities Calendar · Emergency Intervention Plan · Complaint Procedures The facility was in full compliance with 7 applicable areas of the Compliance and Regulatory Enforcement (CARE) tools for Children’s Residential Licenses. Annual compliance review consisted of the following domains: Physical plant, operations, disaster preparedness plan, emergency intervention, staffing, and client records. Community Care Licensing (CCL) focuses its efforts on three priority areas: prevention, compliance, and enforcement. There are 5 fire extinguishers throughout the facility, all fully charged and all last serviced

on 02/07/2022. The facility has a working telephone that is accessible to clients and staff. All passageways and grounds were free of any obstructions. The medications and cleaning solutions were locked inside the cabinets in separate storage rooms. There was perishable foods enough for 3 days and non-perishable foods enough for client's consumption for more than a week. Each bedroom has two twin beds with clean sheets and linens. There were drawers and closet space in each bedroom for client use. The hot water temperature was tested and was in working order. At the time of this inspection the facility was observed to be clean, safe, and in good repair. Administrator is on site at least 25 hours a week and on-call 24/7. Facility currently has two (2) administrator trainees both working 40 hours per week in addition to the 25 hours. The facility has a central administrative file under this main facility: Hope House facility. The facility has a 2022 Honda Odyssey mini-van used to transport clients. The vehicle has an active insurance policy. The facility maintains an equipment/vehicle safety log in the headquarters office that is monitored by the Maintenance Supervisor. The vehicle is serviced every quarter or as needed. For this review, one (1) DCFS/North Los Angeles Regional Center client, and one (1) DCFS/Frank D. Lanterman Regional Center client was selected for the sample to assess the level of care and services they receive. LPA issued an technical advisory, copy left with staff.

On 12/21/2022 Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Dawn Mahecha and Joe Martinez made an unannounced visit to the Hope house group home for the purpose of a case management- incident inspection. LPAs met with Administrator and discussed the following reported incident. Child sustained bruising on left arm: Administrator stated the following- Staff did not observe bruise on child. Staff documented that child reported bruise was obtained at school but then child stated to school staff that bruise was obtained at home. Child had 1 to 1 outside Respit care with an outside contracted agency through Department of children and family services and Regional center. Documents received and reviewed by LPAs identified child having self injurious behavior and documented bug bites on arms. LPAs were unable to meet with child as child was discharged from home. Administrator stated agency was unable to do any follow up with child since child was discharged from home. Information and documents received indicate no incidents occurring where staff interacted with child in manner causing child to have bruising. Based on information received it is unclear as to how or where child obtained bruise. Although the incident may have happened there is not a preponderance of evidence to indicate incident did or did not happen. Exit interview completed, no deficiencies cited and a copy of this report was emailed to Administrator.

On October 18th, 2023, at 10:35 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ashley Ruacho conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the facility and met with the above representative. The purpose of the case management was to follow-up on a Special Incident Report (SIR) received by the Department. Per the SIR the Shift Supervisor(S1) had administered the incorrect medication to Client(C1). LPA Ruacho conducted interviews with Assistant Administrator, S1, and the Health Supervisor(S2). LPA conducted in-person interviews at the Group Home on 10/18/23 to ensure medication was being logged, errors were logged, medications were locked, and all medications were kept separately for each client. LPA reviewed training that were provided after the incident occurred. Based on information collected from the in-person interview, Group Home did not comply with requirements regarding medication distribution. Per Health and Safety Code(HSC) 1507.6(b)(1), Psychotropic medications shall be used only in accordance with the written directions of the physician prescribing the medication and as authorized… A citation was issued during today’s inspection. Plan of correction was discussed and developed with the above representative. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights were given to the Assistant Administrator.

LPA obtained and reviewed the following updated documentation: · LIC 500 Personnel and Client Roster · LIC 610 C Emergency Disaster Plan · Board of Directors report · Employee Grievance Policy/ Grievance Procedures · Crisis Prevention Intervention Training's · Emergency Preparedness: Disaster and Mass Casualties Drills · Emergency Evacuation Routes · Facility Monthly Activities Calendar · Emergency Intervention Plan · Complaint Procedures The facility was in full compliance with 7 applicable areas of the Compliance and Regulatory Enforcement (CARE) tools for Children’s Residential Licenses. Annual compliance review consisted of the following domains: Physical plant, operations, disaster preparedness plan, emergency intervention, staffing, and client records.

Community Care Licensing (CCL) focuses its efforts on three priority areas: prevention, compliance, and enforcement. There are 5 fire extinguishers throughout the facility, all fully charged and all last serviced on 02/01/2024. The facility has a working telephone that is accessible to clients and staff. All passageways and grounds were free of any obstructions. The medications and cleaning solutions were locked inside the cabinets in separate storage rooms. There is perishable food enough for 3 days and non-perishable foods enough for client's consumption for more than a week. 8 bedrooms in total, four had single twin beds, all bedrooms had clean sheets and linens. There were drawers and closet space in each bedroom for client use. The hot water temperature was tested, measured at 116 degrees, and was in working order. At the time of this inspection the facility was observed to be clean, safe, and in good repair. The administrator is on site at least 25 hours a week and on-call 24/7. The facility currently has one (1) administrator trainee working 40 hours per week. The facility has a central administrative file under this main facility: Hope House facility. The facility has two Honda Odyssey mini-vans and one 10 passenger van used to transport clients. The vehicles have active insurance policies and current registration. The facility maintains an equipment/vehicle safety log in the headquarters office that is monitored by the Maintenance Supervisor. The vehicles are serviced every quarter or as needed. For this review, one (1) DCFS- Palmdale/San Gabriel/Pomona Regional Center, three (3) San Gabriel/Pomona Regional Center, and two (2) Central Valley Regional Center clients were selected for the sample to assess the level of care and services they receive. Additionally, LPA reviewed five (5) staff files for compliance with Title 22 Regulations and Interim Licensing Requirements. LPA also conducted interviews with three (3) staff members and no clients were present at the time of the inspection. Clients in the facility were unable to be interviewed due to being at school and non-verbal. An exit interview was conducted. LPA provided the facility representative above a signed copy of the LIC 809 and LIC 811 reports. There were no deficiencies cited at the time of this inspection.

On 11/30/23 the Department received a complaint alleging client in care sustained multiple unexplained injuries and staff did not seek medical attention for client. It was further alleged that client had injuries to client’s back and ankle. The facility did not seek medical attention and failed to report the injuries. Based on the information gathered during confidential interviews, relevant parties denied the allegations indicating client during Thanksgiving week injured self while playing and having behaviors. The client was playing at the park and on a slide when the client scratched client’s back. The client was rubbing a scab on client’s ankle which caused the scab to reopen. Staff indicated client tends to hit self and likes to pick at client’s scabs. Client also does not like to wear shoes due to the shoes bothering client. Staff indicated client when injured is provided first aid by the health staff on site and was taken to the doctor on 11/29/23. Staff indicated a note of the injury was sent to the school in client’s backpack. Others interviewed indicated clients tend to hit self and indicated they have not observed anything concerning. LPA reviewed medical visit form dated 11/29/23 which indicated client was seen for a follow up visit for intentional self-harm by other specified means. Client has an abrasion on his ankle and back. The ankle abrasion seems to be due to rubbing against the surface and the back as well. Client was prescribed Neosporin to the ankle and to the back. LPA reviewed an incident report dated 11/27/23 which indicated client sustained injuries due to self-harm. Client was treated for client’s injuries and incident was reported. LPA reviewed a police report which indicated on 11/30/23 the officer arrived at the facility and observed client had a cut on his left ankle and a healing abrasion that was scabbed on his back. The officer did not observe any other apparent injuries. The officer saw client's shoes and noted that the shoe looked to potentially have a hard rim around the ankle portion, however the inner portion looked softer than the outer material. Facility staff advised that client suffers from Autism, harms himself periodically and is aggressive towards others. Facility staff provided incident reports of previous injuries. Based on the interviews and records reviewed the allegations is/are found unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the allegations. Appeals rights were provided and discussed with the facility representative mentioned above. There were no deficiencies cited.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 84072(d) Personal Rights The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code (WIC) section 16001.9, as applicable…. (WIC 16001.9(a)(1) provides in part: It is the policy of the state that all minors and nonminors in foster care shall have the following rights: To live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home where he or she is treated with respect. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review and interviews, the facility Administrator admitted to refusing to pick up the minor from the hospital which poses an immediate Health and Safety risk to clients in care.

The department has conducted a complaint investigation regarding the allegations: Staff physically abuse minor in care. Staff do not prevent minor from being bullied while in care. During the investigation, six interviews were conducted, which revealed that there was conflicting information on whether or not staff physically abused a minor and if staff did not prevent a minor from being bullied while in care. S1, S2, and S3 don’t see the minor’s actions as bullying, they see it more of teasing and sibling squabble, and they step in to separate them when it gets to far. While FC1 wouldn’t go into detail on whether they and the other minors in facility engage in arguments or bullying, FC3 stated he doesn’t argue or fight with other minors in the facility, and FC2 says he bullies FC3 with FC1 but it just with name calling and there isn’t punching or kicking as that what FC2 describes as bullying. In regard to staff physically abusing minor in care. FC3, S1, S2 and S3 all denied that the staff physically harm anyone in the home and LPA did not observe evidence of minors being abused either in the records or on her visits. While FC1 and FC2 wouldn’t confirm nor deny it. Based on LPA interviews conducted, and records reviewed, the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the above allegations are found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted with, and a copy of this report was provided to John Tarawali Administrator.

On 4/16/25 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman met with John Tarawali, Administrator for the purpose of a Case Management Inspection. LPA reviewed one child's medications and two Non-Minor Dependent's (NMD) medication records. LPA observed one child's Psychotropic Medication Administration Record (LIC622B PMAR) for April for one psychotropic medication (M1) is missing the child's full name and the prescription fill date. LPA observed the facility is missing documentation for April of one NMD's (C2) medication log for one medication (M2) and one psychotropic medication (M3) is documented on the same Psychotropic Medication Administration Record (LIC622B PMAR) but has two different dosages and this PMAR is missing the quantity prescribed, prescription fill date, prescription number and number of refills for one dosage. C2's PMAR for one medication (M4) is missing the quantity prescribed and the prescription name is inaccurate. C2's Medication Administration Record (LIC622A MAR) is missing the quantity prescribed for two medications (M4)(M5). C2's facility record is missing the LIC622 showing the date of destruction for one medication (M6). LPA observed the facility is missing page 3 of the PMAR and MAR for each psychotropic medication for one child and two NMD's. LPA observed the four centrally stored medication and destruction records (LIC622) for one child and one NMD for are pre-filled from the pharmacy and contain different start dates for the same medication. LPA inspected the facility inside and outside. Facility citation violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, regulation 80070 Client Records. LPA provided a copy of this report to John Tarawali, Administrator on this date.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Client Records (b)(10) Each record must contain information including, but not limited to, the following: Record of current medications... (k)(7)(H)The licensee shall ensure the maintenance...of a record of centrally stored prescription medications...includes the following:(H) Instructions, if any, regarding control and custody of the medication. (l)Prescription medications...which are not to be retained shall be destroyed by the facility administrator, or a designated substitute, and one other adult who is not a client.This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Medication records for April for: -C1 is missing for medication (M1) the child's full name and the prescription fill date. -C2 is medication log for medications (M2) and (M3) is documented on the same LIC622B (PMAR) but has two different dosages and is missing the quantity, fill date, prescription number and number of refills. Medication (M4) is missing the quantity and prescription name is inaccurate. C2's LIC622A (MAR) is missing the quantity prescribed for two medications (M4)(M5). C2's facility record is missing the LIC622 showing the date of destruction for one medication (M6). LPA observed the facility is missing page 3 of the PMAR for each psychotropic medication for one child and two NMD's which poses a potential l Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.

narrative: On March 20, 2025, at 2:30 p.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Elena Gonzalez-Soto, arrived unannounced at the facility to obtain additional documentation for a complaint investigation related to the above allegations. LPA requested the following documents for review: six staff files of, Ongoing training log, 40-hour Facility Reliability Training Log, and signed essential job duties . No concerns were noted and training documentation reported staff took applicable training in foster youth personal rights. Confidential interviews were conducted with six individuals, and attempted with two individuals, during the period of 01/08/2025 to 04/24/2025. Interviews with LC, S2, S3, C1, C2, and C3 disclosed that no staff hit youth in care and supervision is adequate. LPA’s interviews conducted, and records reviewed were consistent that facility staff do not threaten youth, slap youth, nor provide inadequate supervision of youth in care . Based on LPA interviews conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur. An exit interview was conducted with and a copy of this report was issued to John Tarawali, Administrator.

On October 4, 2022, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Vanessa Galvan and Lidia Tinoco traveled to HQ children Services. The purpose of the visit is to conduct a pre-licensing Facility Inspection. LPAs were met at the facility by Carlos Hernandez, Umer Qureshi, and Jennifer Garcia. LPAs toured the facility and observed the following listed below. 1. The facility has a staff room and is inaccessible to clients. In the staff room is where medication, sharps/knives, and client files are locked and stored. 2. In the hall closet is where chemicals, disinfectants, and cleaning products are stored in a lock closet inaccessible to clients. 3. In the kitchen LPAs observed a fire extinguisher, first aid kit including all required items and first aid manual are included in the kit. The facility maintained a trash can with a lid in the kitchen. LPAs observed a weekly menu for clients. The refrigerator temperature is 37 degrees and freezer temperature are -1 degrees. 4. The dining room has a table with chairs to accommodate the number of clients. 5. The house has four bedrooms- four ambulatory, single occupancy, all located on one single level. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings and storage space. All rooms are equipped with fire alarms and trash can. 6. The facility has adequate storage space and furniture. 7. The outdoor space has plenty of outdoor space and equipped outdoor furniture. No hazards were observed at the outdoor space. 8. The outdoor of the home was free from hazard and obstructions. 9. Adequate food storage space observed. Perishable and non-perishable foods will be available before client are placed in the facility. 10. Facility has two full restrooms, and all are operable. Facility is to ensure water temperature is maintained between 105 and 120 degrees. All restrooms are stored with hand soap, toilet paper, and paper towels. 11. Appropriate forms posted in the facility. 12. The temperature of the facility was a comfortable temperature of 76 degrees. 13. Facility has extra towels and linens for all clients. 14.The facil ity does not have a firearm or ammunition. Fire clearance has been received from the Stanislaus Consolidated Fire Protection. narrative: On June 24, 2021 Licensing Program Analyst, LPA Donald Martin completed a Case Management inspection to above facility for the purpose of concluding an investigation. LPA met with Ray Jackson. The Complaint Report dated April 8, 2021 disclosed that Staff #1 strangled Child #1. Interviews and documentary evidence did not corroborate that Staff #1 strangled Child #1. During the investigation process, LPA conducted interviews and reviewed Special Incident Report. Statements were consistent that Staff #1 was observed placing her hands-on Child #1 shoulders, near his neck and redirecting him to his bathroom. Staff was suspended and an internal investigation was completed. Internal investigation determined that statements were credible, and Staff #1 inappropriately placed her hands-on Child #1. Staff #1 employment with the facility was terminated. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 80022 - Plan of Operation (k) The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation and may be cited for not doing so.

Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove or disprove that a violation occurred; therefore, the above allegations are Unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies being cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted, Appeal Rights and a copy of this report will be mailed to the facility.

Confidential interviews obtained revealed that former resident, Youth #1’s (Y1) roommate (Y2) at the I am Safe #2 group home, orally copulated Y1 while in care. Youth #1 did not disclose this incident to licensee or facility staff; however, Y1 was overheard telling an outside party about the incident. The Los Angeles Police Department (LAPD) conducted a sexual assault response (SART) exam of Y1 which revealed “no findings” or evidence of sexual abuse. Confidential interviews of clients and staff members further revealed no witnesses to the alleged, as statements obtained found denial observing Y2 behave inappropriately towards Y1 or towards other clients/residents in the facility. The investigation determined no witnesses to corroborate the incident. Based on gathered information obtained and reviewed, the findings are determined Unsubstantiated. A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. There are no deficiencies per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, cited at this time. Exit interview conduced. Appeal rights are discussed. A copy of this report was provided to Licensee.
investigation_findings: 13On April 24, 2024, at 10:50 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Regina Martin conducted a follow-up complaint inspection at I AM SAFE, INC. #2 to deliver investigation findings concerning the above-mentioned allegation. LPA Martin met with Ray Jackson, Licensee to discuss the investigative outcome. On November 13, 2023, CCLD received a complaint alleging Staff did not prevent a youth resident from sexually abusing another youth resident while in care. The investigation included confidential interviews of former resident (alleged victim), facility staff members, licensee, Department of Children and Family Services (DCFS) County Social Worker and DCFS Emergency Response County Social Worker, as well as other outside sources. An attempted interview was made with youth resident #2 (Y2) but was unsuccessful due to them being nonverbal. The investigation further included a review of facility file review history, client records, related reports from DCFS as well as review of related forensic interview. (Continued on page LIC9099-C)

On February 29, 2024 at 2:30pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting an Annual inspection. LPA was met by Facility Manager, Tisha Clemons and allowed into the facility. The home is licensed to care for 4 clients 12-17 ambulatory only. The layout of the home is as follows: Living room: Spacious with furniture in good repair. Two computers and a printer for clients use. A television attached to the wall near the door for clients use. Bedroom #1: Contained two beds, two dressers and two closets that contained enough clothing supply for two clients. Room was clean and in order and also had an air conditioner in the window. There are two bathrooms for clients use. both contain showers and sinks. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. Bedroom #2: The bedroom Contained two beds, two dressers and two closets that contained enough clothing supply for two clients. Room was clean and in order. The room also had a portable heater and an air conditioner in the window as well. Clients had two beds and dressers filled with clothing. Closets were stocked with clothing as well. Dining room: Was very clean and in order. Has a dinner table with seating enough for clients and staff. Cont 9099-C

Kitchen: Was clean and in order. Cleaning supplies were in two locked cabinets which were both well stocked. There is another locked cabinet that contains sharp knives and forks. There is a large washer and dryer in the kitchen as well. The stove was clean and all burners were in good working condition. The refrigerator was clean and the cabinets had the required 2 days perishable and 7 days non perishable foods in them. Backyard: Is very spacious and was clean and in order at the time of the visit. Contained one large shed which stays locked and is inaccessible to the clients. There is an open covered area used for parties and cookouts. There is workout equipment for the clients. Van: Was clean and in good working condition. The registration and insurance was up to date. There were no deficiencies cited at the time of the visit.

On February 28, 2025 at 8:30am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required Facility Inspection. LPA was met by Administrator, Jessie Ayala and allowed into the facility. The facility home is licensed to serve 4 clients ages 12 to 17 years of age, ambulatory only and Non-Minor dependents. The facility appeared to be clean and in good condition. The visit went as follows: Living room: Spacious with furniture in good repair. Two computers on two separate desks and a printer for clients use. There is an additional computer in front of the couch. A television attached to the wall near the door for clients use. Bedroom #1: Contained two beds, two dressers and two closets that contained enough space for two clients. Room was clean and in order and also had a portable air conditioner near the window. There are two bathrooms for clients use. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. Bedroom #2: The bedroom Contained two beds, two dressers and two closets that contained enough space for two clients. Room was clean and in order. The room also had a portable heater and an air conditioner in the window as well. Clients had two beds and dressers filled with clothing. Closets were stocked with clothing as well. Dining room: Was very clean and in order. Has a dinner table with seating enough for clients and staff. Kitchen: Was clean and in order. Cleaning supplies were in two locked cabinets which were both well stocked. There is another locked cabinet that contains clients medications and extra hygiene supplies and sharps. There is a large washer and dryer in the kitchen as well. The stove was clean and all burners were in good working condition. The refrigerator was clean and the cabinets had the required 2 days perishable and 7 days non perishable foods in them. Cont 9099-C

Backyard: Is very spacious and was clean and in order at the time of the visit. Contained two large sheds which stays locked and is inaccessible to the clients. There is an open covered area used for parties and cookouts. There is workout equipment for the clients. Van: Was clean and in good working condition. The registration and insurance was up to date. There were no deficiencies cited at the time of the visit.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPAs) Kellie McKinley and Maie Soliman conducted an announced Pre-licensing inspection on 3/25/2025 at 9:00 AM at the above location, as required for the Group Home (GH) licensure. LPAs met with Annalyn Artadi- Licensee. During the pre-licensing visit, LPAs conducted a Health and Safety inspection using the CARE tool. LPAs observed the facility was clean inside and safe. The outside of the facility has a pool in the back yard that is fully enclosed with a five-foot fence and locking gates. There is a pool house with pump inside. The facilities sits on city property, which also is fenced and enclosed. LPAs observed that there are two floors to the facility. LPAs observed four of client bedrooms, equipped with appropriate furniture, bedding, and supplies for clients. Sufficient storage space for client’s personal belongings was observed in each room. The facility is requesting to be licensed for four clients. Staff will include eight to ten staff hired and ready for the first clients ranging in age from seven to 17 years old. LPAs observed a medication Lock box in the kitchen, which was empty, but locked, and accessible only to designated staff. The kitchen area was equipped with an adequate amount of utensils, dining supplies, and cups for clients. No food was observed as there are no clients, and no pending placements at this time. Facility will verify required food on hand at time of client placement. LPAs observed a staff office space that is locked and inaccessible to clients upstairs, it will be utilized as the staff office for storing inaccessible medications and chemicals, in addition to any other item required to be inaccessible to clients. The staff office has a small fridge that will be dedicated to medications if needed. The facility has an attached garage space which houses a freezer for extra food storage and cabinets with locks for supplies which is inaccessible to the clients at all times. LPAs observed a gas fireplace in the living room with a glass barrier. continued on 809_C page

The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are hard wired and were inspected by the fire department on 2/12/2025. LPAs tested another carbon monoxide detector and found it to be working. A fully equipped first aid kit was reviewed and is placed in the staff office. The Foster Youth Bill of Rights was posted in a conspicuous location. There are 2 bathrooms in the facility that are accessible to clients use. The water temperature was tested and found to be 120 degrees. The facility is ready for licensure as an Group Home and LPAs recommend that the facility be licensed. A signed copy of this report was provided to Annalyn Artadi - Licensee.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Robyn Word retrieved a message from the OD line from house manager ED Lara. LPA called the facility to gather additional information. ED stated that resident Elijah Butler DOB 9/23/2009 asked to go to his room to go to bed, but he started turning on lights and started yelling at staff, staff tried to redirect him. Elijah tried to hit staff with fire extinguisher. Staff tried to calm him down. He gave the staff the fire extinguisher. Elijah called 911 and hung up immediately. The police arrived. He calmed down. The police left. Elijah escalated again. He became upset walked outside and started making allegations that staff were taking things from him. Staff came in and helped him search for his ear buds which he found in his room. he then apologized and went to sleep. IR was sent in.

Attached to the letter was facility's neighborhood complaint policy and LPA's business card. To date, no neighbor has communicated with LPA. Witnesses interviewed by LPA stated child(ren) are left outside in the backyard and heard crying and moaning, early in the morning about 6:00 a.m. Witnesses(es) stated they saw this over a fence top, and it looked as though staff was not providing a distressed child(ren) access to the home and that the child was outside alone. On 11-6-2020, LPA observed the location(s) in the backyard where someone looking onto the property, may not see, because their view could be blocked by a storage shed. LPA observed different locations in the yard where staff situate themselves to maintain supervision. Based on a staff interview, staff maintain close supervision, yet, provide a sibilance of privacy. Based on interviews from staff and former staff, children are always properly supervised. The needs and services plan/IPP of a child indicates the child is autistic, nonverbal, behaves in a self injurious manner, is destructive when escalated, punches walls and causes other property destruction. On 11-6-2020, LPA conducted a facility inspection wherein staff introduced the child to LPA. The child would not look at LPA, there was no eye contact, the child had a blank affect, did not talk, made grunting type noises and paced back and forth within the living area. LPA observed staff/child interaction. The child made waving hand gestures, held the staff's hand then sat on staff's lap. The child hugged and held onto staff. The child began flapping his arms about and jumped up and down. Staff told LPA that the child may be fretful because of the new person in the home (LPA). LPA observed staff interventions and they attempted to keep the child from escalating using soothing actions and words. (Staff helped the child put on shoes then took the child for a drive.)

Based on interviews conducted and based on evidence reviewed/obtained, the allegation that staff do not allow a child access to the home is conflicting. Interviews of current and former group home staff, NBRC staff and biological parents indicate that a child's high level of needs and challenging behaviors are problematic and challenging for the professionals and parents alike. That challenge is acerbated by an apparent inability of the child to communicate needs. According to the evidence obtained, noises that witness(es) heard could be sounds the child makes on a day to day basis and in line with the child's normal actions whether or not the child is distressed. However, there is credible evidence which is conflicting in that witnesses observed/heard what could appear as neglectful and a lack of supervision on more than one occasion. Although the allegation may be true, there is not a preponderance of evidence to substantiate. The allegation is therefore UNSUBSTANTIATED. LPA Eunice delivered this finding virtually to Momo Duoa on November 17, 2020. This report was discussed and delivered in this manner due to COVID-19 pandemic health and safety reasons. LPA conducted an exit interview and provided appeal rights.
investigation_findings: 13On 9-11-2020, Licensing Program Analyst Dawn Eunice (LPA) opened a complaint investigation virtually for the above allegation. This inspection was conducted in this manner due to COVID-19 pandemic health and safety restrictions. LPA reviewed an Emergency Response Referral, Screener Narrative, Special Incident Report, Preplacement Appraisal Information, a child's Individual Program Plan (IPP), a staff calendar, staff training and roster documentation, and Licensing Information System reports. LPA conducted interviews of witnesses who included: the complainant, a neighbor, North Bay Regional Center (NBRC) staff, and former and current staff. LPA conducted a facility inspection 11-6-2020, to observe staff and client interactions and to inspect the buildings and grounds. Additionally, LPA delivered letters of introduction to 3 neighbors describing Community Care Licensing's role in a children's residential program and it invited inquires.

narrative: On 05/06/2021 at 4:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst, Ignacia Villapudua-Soto conducted a case management inspection via facetime with Residential Administrator, Momo Duoa to discuss a home inspection that LPA conducted with House Manager. On 05/05/2021, LPA arrived at the facility and met with House Manager and jointly conducted a home inspection of the home inside and out and found the following deficiencies as follows: · 120 X 72 X 22 inflatable pool, full of water, (approximately, 2 feet of water) and flooding cover in the pool. LPA requested the water to be drained while LPA was present. (zero tolerance) · Air conditioner is not working. The temperature of the home was 90 degrees. · Outside patio, the air conditioner frame had old weathered wooden lattice that is broken and has protruding rusted nails sticking out · In the garage the sprinkler control system mounted to wall has exposed wires Clothing detergent, Air freshener and softener were accessible to clients Refer to 809 D for Title 22 deficiencies cited. Exit interview was conducted and this document will be emailed to Residential Administrator for signature **Appeal rights given**

Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Ignacia Villapudua-Soto and Senior Service Coordinator (SC). North Bay Regional Center, Diana Montes arrived at the facility to conduct a joint case management on 05/18/21 at 2:30 PM. During the inspection, LPA and SC met with Administrator, Momo Dua and discussed the incident. Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an incident report dated May 14, 2021. It was reported that C1 engaged in tantrum behavior, aggression towards staff and self-inflicted injuries due to his behaviors. (Refer to confidential name's list, LIC 811) C1 asked for his IPAD but staff advised C1 that it wasn’t time to play with IPAD. C1 proceeded to go to another staff and ask for the IPAD. The staff again confirmed that it wasn’t time for his IPAD. C1 become assaultive to staff and fell to the floor and attempted to kick staff. Staff immediately utilized verbal prompts to redirect C1 to the backyard of the facility for activities. C1 continued to actively engage in physical aggression towards staff. Support staff evaded, removing furniture and other items from within the C1’s vicinity. Support Staff left the immediate area providing C1 with space and followed the BIP (planned, ignoring/extinction). C1 was in the living room engaging in tantrum behaviors of kicking the floor and biting his hand/arm (laying on his back). Staff continued to provide supervision with no verbal prompts/stimulus toward the consumer. C1 abruptly turned his body 90 degree, and kicked the glass panel of the fireplace and the glass broke and cut C1. Staff utilized first Aid training/protocols to apply pressure to the wound. C1 foot was bleeding profusely. Staff transported C1 to Kaiser Vacaville. Administrator met staff in the hospital lobby to offer support. Administrator assisted nurses and doctors to try to keep C1 calm. C1 become aggressive behaviors with nurses and Administrator. C1 received 3 sutures , and was assessed for 2.5 hours before being released to Administrator.

Administrator stated the facility will continue to provide adequate support and redirection to C1 and assure that client is safe and a safety plan in process. Administrator stated he is in communication with the North Bay Regional Center for additional support and for additional staff for this facility. No deficiencies were cited on today's date. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to Administrator, Momo Dua.

This documented was Amended, the Case Management was conducted on 5/18/21. Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Ignacia Villapudua-Soto arrived at the facility to conduct a case management inspection on 05/18/21 at 3:35. During the inspection, LPA met with Administrator Momo Dua and discussed the incident reports. . Community Care Licensing (CCL) received the following incident reports pertaining to C1. as follows: 3/17/21, incident reports, C1 engaged in noncompliance and tantrum behaviors, staff went to the restroom leaving client outside in the patio, during that time, the client attempted to climb the fence: Incident 4/14/21, C1 become confrontational with roommate and took the facility keys and went to his room. C1 continued his non-compliance and scratched the staff; 04/15/21 incident, C1 began to escalate due to wanted to play games. C1 got the house binders and took them outside. C1 removed documents and ripped them up. The staff tired to redirect him. C1 grabbed the printer and threw it on the floor and broke it. C1 went to the neighbor's fence and grabbed a brick and threw it at the facility van breaking the windshield; 5/10/21 incident: C1 become noncompliant grabbed the daily binders and other objects. Throwing them around the house. Administrator arrived at the facility to provide support to the team. 05/13/21 incident: C1 engaged in noncompliance behaviors and property destruction. C1 swing the refrigerator door open , ripping it off the hinges, destroying containers and the shelves on the door. Administrator stated he is working closely with North Bay Regional Center, Diana Montes for additional support and funding for additional staff for the facility. Administrator stated he also working the Regional office where the facility is going to be remodeling the home for a safer environment. Administrator stated, he is in the process of hiring more staff for the facility. LPA advised Administrator to follow up with LPA with hiring more staff and sharing the plans for the remodeling of the home. LPA is requesting to follow up with the regional center for services for C1. Administrator will follow up with LPA regarding the a plan regarding a safety plan for C1 and Administrator's will follow with the Regional Center regarding additional services for C1. No citations will be given at this time. Exit interview was conducted with Administrator. Administrator will sign and email the signed LIC 809.

RP stated she arrived at work and observed that C1 had numerous bruises and scratches on them. RP specifically saw a large bruise and scratches to the back, bruises and scratches on the right elbow, and bruising around the right eye. Due to C1 being nonverbal, RP could not question C1 about the injuries. However, C2 informed RP that C2 observed C1 was in the back yard and S1 physically grabbed and drug C1 on the ground over cement stairs. C2 reported that S1 treats C1 “bad” and always tells C1 to go to their room and S1 causes C1’s behaviors. RP stated that C1 does at times inflict self-injury but usually does so by biting and the injuries that RP observed did not appear to be self-inflicted. S2 stated they did not know how C1 sustained the large bruise on C1’s back. C1’s bio-mother stated she had never seen any bruising on C1’s face before and is concerned with the bruising. S4 stated that they believed that C2 was telling the truth and witnessed S2 causing the injuries to C1 because C2 was consistent in informing the staff and Administrator of the incident. The Doctor reported that the scrapes and bruising could be caused by C1 being dragged on the concrete. S2 reported they were was present with reporting party when the bruising was discovered on C1’s body. S2 stated the protocol for client behavior is “no hands on”. The staff are trained to block and redirect the clients. S1 denied ever dragging or going “hands on” with C1. S3 stated they did not see C1 fall on the ground or have any behaviors and does not know how the injury happened. Administrator sent IB investigator an audio recording of the phone call between S4, C2, Administrator where C2 confirms that S1 dragged C1 up to the steps” and kicked C1. Based on IB interviews with Administrator, Audio recording, staff and photos the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. The facility is cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, Regulation Personal Rights- 84072(D)(11) To be free from physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and corporal punishment. Refer to 9099D for Title 22 deficiencies cited. Exit interview was conducted with agency Social Worker **Confidential names list provided** **Appeal rights given***
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Ignacia Villapudua-Soto arrived at the facility on 7/12/21 at 3:45 PM for the purpose of delivering complaint investigation findings. LPA contacted Administrator, Momo Duoa via telephone and discussed the findings and deficiencies . Administrator was not available to sign the LIC 9099. Administrator approved for Facility Manager, Linda Dunn to sign LIC 9099 and LIC 9099D On 05/05/21, LPA Villapudua-Soto initiated the complaint investigation at the facility. LPA conducted a file review and requested for the Administrator to email LPA the entire file for C1 and S1. LPA also requested face sheets for the other clients in the home for IB investigator to review. On 05/05/21, LPA advised Administrator that a personal rights violation was reported against the facility and the IB investigator will be contacting them regarding the allegations. Department of Social Services, IB investigator, Joseph Balarie, Badge #26 conducted the complaint investigation regarding “Staff member caused injury to the child”. IB investigator conducted all interviews and reviewed the entire files for C1 and staff, such as, Needs and Service Plan, incident reports, Staff’s Crisis Prevention Institute (CPI) Blue Cards, S1 Employee Profile, and C1 Individual Program Plan. IB investigator reviewed and obtained a copy of Vacaville Police Department Report. During the investigation process IB investigator interviewed Administrator, Reporting Party (RP), C1’s bio-logical mother and father, C2, S1, S2, S3, S4 and doctor. IB Investigator attempted to interview C1, but client is nonverbal.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Personal Rights-84072(D)(11) To be free from physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and corporal punishment. This is not met as evidenced by Based on interviews with staff, C2, Doctor and audio recording, S1 dragged and hit C1 causing injures to C1 This poses an immediate safety or personal rights risk to the clients in care.

narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst, Ignacia Villapudua-Soto arrived at the above group home to conduct unannounced ANNUAL/REQUIRED of the facility on 02/16/22 at 3:00 PM. LPA met with Administrator, Ileya Silva on today’s date and explained the purpose of the visit. LPA Villapudua-Soto and the Administrator conducted a joint inspection of the interior and exterior of the group home. The home is a three bedroom, two bath home. The home is licensed for a capacity of 3 ambulatory clients. The clients are developmentally disabled clients. Currently the group home has one client in care. LPA Villapudua-Soto conducted a joint inspection of the interior and exterior areas of the facility's physical plant. The front and back yard were free of clutter; and the passage ways and egress were unobstructed. No potentially hazardous items or areas were observed. Cleaning supplies and extra hygiene items are located in a locked closet at the end of the hallway. Extra bed linens, towels and washcloths are located in the hallway. Medications are stored in a locked cabinet near the kitchen. A fully stocked first aide kit was observed in the medication cabinet. The kitchen was observed to be stocked with ample perishable and non-perishable foods meeting the requirement of two days of perishable and seven days of non-perishable foods. The facility has a posted menu on the fridge. Under the kitchen sink the cabinet is locked with knives and other sharp items. The living room furniture was observed to be in good repair. The living room allowed enough space for clients to engage in indoor activities.

The front yard is well maintained. The backyard is concrete. There is a patio table and chairs available to clients. However, the patio table was not in good repair, therefore the Administrator will be disposing of the patio table. LPA observed a locked shed with maintenance supplies in the backyard. Hot water temperatures was tested, however, Administrator will obtain services from a Professional Plumber due to the 1st bathroom shower not regulating hot water. The Administrator will be emailing LPA a copy of the Plumber's receipt that the issue has been addressed. . LPA Villapudua-Soto and Administrator conducted a joint inspection of the facility vehicle/van. The van has the proper car insurance and first Aid and is in good repair. The home has a disaster plan, facility sketch and personal rights posting in the home. The facility has two Carbon Monoxide detector and fire detectors. LPA will return to complete the required Annual/Required inspection at a later date.

On Tuesday, October 1, 2024, at 10:15AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Brittany Crass and Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced annual inspection at the facility and met with the Administrator, Patricia Ambriz, who assisted with the inspection. LPA's and Administrator conducted a walk-through of the facility. LPA observed an office in the front entry, a dining area, kitchen, living room, three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a laundry room, two storage closets, and a backyard. The facility was in clean, safe, and sanitary condition, aside from the bedrooms which LPA observed sheets with particles and crumbs on them. The administrator stated the youth clean their rooms and make their beds after school, and that they are currently working towards making their beds before leaving for school. In the bedrooms LPA observed sufficient storage space, clean clothing, and desks for school work. Outside, LPA observed a trampoline with a portion of the outer, protective cushion missing, exposing the metal wire springs. The Administrator stated the youth do not use the trampoline anymore and during the visit, submitted a work order to have the trampoline removed by tomorrow. LPA observed chair cushions that had worn covers, exposing the inside cushion. LPA advised the administrator to replace them. In the kitchen, LPA observed at least the minimum requirement of two days of perishable foods. For non-perishable foods, LPA advised the administrator to purchase a few more non-perishable items such as canned soups, beans, rice, etc., as the 7 day requirement seemed low for the amount of youth in care. The hot water in the main bathroom measured at 112 degrees Fahrenheit maximum, which is within the required range of 105 - 120 degrees Fahrenheit. The carbon monoxide detector and smoke detector were operational. There were no buildings and ground deficiencies. (Continued on LIC 809-C).

LPA observed that the Foster Youth personal rights, food menu, and complaint procedures were not posted at the facility, however the administrator printed and posted them during the visit. LPA reviewed that monthly board meetings are held every month however upon reviewing the minutes, LPA did not observe the topics needing to be discussed as stated in HSC 5021.1(f) being met. On this date, the facility is being cited for violations of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Section 84063(a)(9) on the attached D-Page. LPA also issued multiple Advisory Notes, which are not citations. LPA will return on another date to complete this inspection. An exit interview was conducted with the administrator, and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to them.

On Wednesday, October 2, 2024, at 9:35AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Brittany Crass and Alyssa Burgess, made a subsequent unannounced annual inspection to the facility. LPA's met with Administrator, Patricia Ambriz, who assisted with the inspection. LPA's reviewed three children's files. LPAs found: two youths were missing their signature on their Admission Agreement, one Youth had the medication consent however it was not for Psychotropic Medication. One youth's Psychotropic Medications were not recorded on separate Psychotropic Medication Administration Records (PMAR) as required, and one child had the time missing on their PMAR. For the Needs and Services plans, 3/3 youth files did not list dietary needs, ability to manage their own money, visitation, and planned length of placement. Upon record review, LPA's observed that there was one adult who had a pending fingerprint clearance and was not cleared to work in the facility. The admin stated that effective immediately, this adult will not be at the facility until cleared. LPA's conducted two client interviews, and two staff interviews. Based on interviews, the Facility seemed knowledgeable on their roles, and no personal rights violations were indicated. LPA's recommend re-training on Mandated Reporter Training for all staff. On this date, the facility is being cited for violations of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1 and Chapter 5, Sections 84068(b) and 80019(e) on the attached D-Page. An immediate Civil Penalty in the amount of $500 is being assessed for Background Clearance violation. LPA also issued multiple Advisory Notes, which are not citations. (Report continued on LIC 809-C).

LPA will return on another date to complete this inspection. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator and a copy of this report, confidential names list, and appeal rights were provided to her.

narrative: On Friday, October 4th, 2024, at 10am, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Brittany Crass and Alyssa Burgess conducted a subsequent unannounced annual inspection at the facility. LPA's met with Administrator, Patricia Ambriz, who assisted with the inspection. LPA's reviewed three staff files, one Administrator file, and one Facility Manager file and found the following: current CPR certificates, Health Screening Reports, and 40 hour new hire training certificates. LPA confirmed the Facility Manager has received the Prudent Parent training. LPA reviewed yearly staff performance evaluations. LPA reviewed the facilities Disaster and Mass Casualty Plan. One advisory note is being given today, for HSC 1565, as items from Subsection 7 were missing from the plan, including provision of emergency power, and storage of medications. No deficiencies are being cited today. Exit interview conducted with the Administrator, report and appeal rights were given.

During LPA's interview with Administrator, she explained to LPA that there were new issues with C1's insurance which inhibited the facility's ability to schedule an appointment with psychiatry to establish care and refill prescriptions for C1. Administrator made made many follow-up calls and attained different records to attempt to get the issues resolved, to no avail. C1's medications ran out on 4/29/2024, and on 5/1/2024 Administrator obtained a 10-Day emergency supply. The Administrator informed LPA that they did not obtain this sooner as they thought the coverage would go through before that. Afterwards, the issue was resolved and an appointment was scheduled for 5/23/2024. However, with the knowledge that C1's appointment was not until 5/23/2023, on 5/12/2024 after the 10-day emergency supply of medication ran out, C1 was again without medication until 5/15/2024. An emergency supply was obtained on 5/16/2024 and C1 resumed medications as normal. While the Administrator was diligent in following up with the relevant parties in completing all tasks required to attain a doctor's appointment to establish care for C1, and to then attain prescribed medications, there were two lapses in medications being provided to C1 in which emergency medication supplies were not attained timely, resulting in a total of six days of missed medication. Additionally, during LPA's inspection on 6/20/2024, LPA conducted a review of C1’s medications. LPA found that for two medications (M1 and M2), there were 20 pills in the bottle, 30 originally prescribed, and eight marked as taken, leaving 2 pills unaccounted for for both. Administrator checked with the Facility Manager and the Medication Administration Records added up correctly, however there was no explanation for four the unaccounted for pills. CCL and the authorized representative did not receive an incident report for both missed medication events (4/29/2024 and 5/12/2024) until 6/12/2024, after the Regional Center Service Coordinator brought to the Administrator's attention that an incident report needed to be submitted. The Administrator informed LPA that with everything going on she failed to create and send the incident reports as required. Based on LPA's observations and conducted interviews, the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1 Sections 80078(a) and 80061(b)(1)(E)&(f), are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted with FM and a copy of this report, confidential names list, and appeal rights were provided to her.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannouced complaint investigation inspection at the facility and met with Facility Manager Catalina Correa, who assisted with the inspection. LPA investigated this complaint by reviewing client's facility Incident Report related to this complaint, Medication Administration Records (MARs), Individual Placement Plan (IPP), JV220 and JV223 forms, emergency medical consent form and medication administration consent form dated 12/21/2023, medical consent form from the Regional Center dated 4/16/2024, physical medications at the facility, emails, ER discharge paperwork, and Admission Agreement. LPA conducted interviews with the Administrator and the client (C1) on 6/20/2024 and 6/28/2024. During LPA's interview with the client, C1, they informed LPA that they believed they missed medication due to the facility not receiving timely permission from their legal guardian to have it.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on records review and statements, the facility failed to meet this standard when they improperly managed C1's medications resulting in 6 missed doses of two medications, and when the physical medications reviewed were inaccurate. This is an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.

Reporting Requirements. (b)(1)(E): Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in (1) below, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours...Any unusual incident or client absence which threatens the physical or emotional health or safety of any client. (f) The items specified in (b)(1)(A) through (H) above shall also be reported to the client's authorized representative, if any. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on statements, the facility failed to report two incidents to CCL and the authorized rep., which is a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst, Michelle Silvas, met with Joha Thomas, RBT, to deliver an Order to Licensee/Facility of an Immediate Exclusion from Facility letter. On January 20, 2022 at 10:58am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daphne Edison made an unannounced visit to Inclusion Specialized Programs LLC, for the purpose of conducting an annual required inspection at the above location. LPA met with Raymundo Lopez, Assistant Administrator who granted access to the facility for inspection. The facility is licensed to provide care and supervision for three (3) male and female children, ages 6-17 years old. Three (3) children may be non-ambulatory. The census on the date of this visit is two (2). There is no swimming pool or bodies of water on the premises. The facility has a living room, dining room, family room/staff office, laundry room, three (3) bedrooms, two (2) bathrooms, backyard with detached garage. Living Room: Sofa, love seat and entertainment area (TV, computers, etc.) for residents. All furnishings in good repair. Dining Room: Table with four (4) chairs in good repair for resident dining. Kitchen: Equipped with refrigerator, 4 burner gas stove, oven, and microwave. There is adequate perishable and nonperishable food supply. Facility provides nutritious snacks between meals. Laundry Room: Equipped with a washer and dryer. Locked cabinet space stores laundry products and personal hygiene products. Continued on LIC 809-C

Family room/Staff Office: Equipped with a sofa, TV, desk, locked cabinets for staff/client records. Closet space for extra linens and towels. Bedroom #1: Occupied by one (1) client. Has one (1) full bed in the room. Room is well furnished and has adequate closet space for storage. Bedroom #2: Vacant. Has one (1) full bed in the room. Room is well furnished and has adequate closet space for storage. Bedroom #3: Occupied by one (1) client. Has one (1) full bed in the room. Room is well furnished and has adequate closet space for storage. Bathroom #1: Clean and operable at the time of the visit. Hot water kept at a safe temperature. Bathroom #2: Clean and operable at the time of the visit. Hot water kept at a safe temperature. Backyard: Has no debris or hazardous materials. Detached garage used for storage. During this visit, LPA reviewed two (2) client Records which contained copies of Needs and Service Plans and Medical Authorizations signed by each child and their authorized representative. Children in care are supervised and protected at all times. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. Children can contact the licensing agency or Foster Care Ombudsperson in confidence without threats or punishment for making complaints. It was reported by Facility Manager that children attend school, extracurricular, cultural and personal enrichment activities. LPA will conduct client interviews at a later date. Continued on LIC 809-C

The home was inspected, and the following was observed: The home is clean, safe, and sanitary. Sharp knives, disinfectants/cleaning solutions, and medicines are made inaccessible to the children. Hot water kept at a safe temperature. The beds have comfortable mattresses, clean linens, blankets and pillows, all in good repair. Caregiver maintains a safe and comfortable temperature in the home. First aid kit was checked and found to have appropriate supplies. All fire extinguishers are fully charged. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors tested audible and were working properly. Emergency numbers, facility license, evacuation plan, and first aid information were posted. No guns or weapons are in the home. There is a working telephone accessible to clients for use at all times. Facility vehicle is currently registered and has valid liability insurance and is in good repair. Children’s Personal Rights and house rules are posted. Outdoor activity space is free of obstruction and debris. LPA will review staff records and conduct staff interviews at a later date. LPA requested CARF accreditation and Board of Director’s meeting minutes from the last meeting. LPA reviewed training log for all staff at the facility. Caregiver(s)/adults working/residing in the home have DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances and Child Abuse Index Checks. Emergency Mass Disaster Casualty Plan was available for review. LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. The home is operating within the capacity and limitations of the license. LPA informed Assistant Administrator of licensing fees of $454.00 due by 03/26/2022. No deficiencies were cited. An exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Assistant Administrator.

narrative: Although, C1 engaged in self-injurious behavior which resulted in injury to C1, consistent statements revealed staff administered first aid for C1’s injury. Consistent statements and documentary evidence also reveal paramedics were called to the facility to assess C1’s injury. Although, paramedics assessed C1 and determined that C1 did not require transportation to a hospital emergency room at the time, it was suggested that C1 follow up with urgent care the following day. Confidential interviews revealed staff transported C1 to urgent care on 5/1/2023, the day after the incident. LPA obtained C1’s urgent care discharge documentation, Westside Regional Center incident report, and a copy of the staff communication log. LPA was unable to corroborate the allegation, Staff are smoking marijuana on the premises. Confidential interviews and consistent statements did not reveal staff smoking marijuana on the premises of the facility. LPA obtained staffing weekly schedule. Based on the interviews conducted, documentary evidence and information gathered, LPA was unable to determine if the above said allegations occurred, therefore the allegations are determined to be unsubstantiated, meaning that although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that a violation occurred. If any additional information is received, this complaint can be amended, and the finding can be changed. Based on the observations made during today’s visit, no deficiencies were cited per Title 22, Division 6, of the California Code of Regulations. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Administrator.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegations. LPA interviewed staff at the facility and upper management. LPA Jones-Steward also interviewed C1 and the co-complainant. The original complainant did not return requests for additional information. LPA also reviewed investigations by the Regional Center and the facility as well as photographs of the bruises on C1. The allegations were resolved as unsubstantiated for the following reasons: C1 was vague and contradictory about how he obtained the bruises on his shoulders. The photographs do not support the allegation that the bruises were caused by someone grabbing him by the shoulders. Staff #2 and Staff #3 denied that the allegations occured. Staff #1 cannot be reached due to extended leave, Other sources indicate that C1 has a history of making false allegations against his caregivers. An unsubstantiated finding means that although an allegation may have occurred, there is not a preponderance of evidence that it did occur.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Reporting Requirements The licensee shall report to the Department any unusual incident or client absence which threatens the physical or emotional health or safety of any client. The licensee failed to meet this requirement when staff did not report the bruises on a client or the suspected abuse of client by a staff.

narrative: It was alleged the facility mishandled client (C1) personal funds. House Manager (HM1) denied the allegation and stated C1's Personal and Incidental (P&I) money was never used to purchase meals for himself or other staff. A record review of C1's financial documents revealed C1's authorized representative began overpaying monthly for Board and Care (B&C) by combining B&C with P&I in one payment. Furthermore, financial documents revealed the over payments were reimbursed by the facility. Statements obtained from interviews conducted with CW indicated CW reviewed C1'1 financial records and no discrepancies were observed. It was alleged facility staff authorized monetary transactions regarding C1 without prior consent from authorized representatives. Statements obtained from interviews conducted with HM1 and others provided conflicting statements. HM1 reported an agreement was reached where the facility and C1's authorized representative would split the cost of a gym membership. HM1 reported after two payments the total monthly cost was incurred by the facility. Others interviewed stated there was no agreement to split the cost. It was alleged the facility abandoned C1, did not allow the authorized representatives sufficient time to locate a new placement and broke the placement agreement. Records reviewed revealed the facility provided a thirty-day notice to the authorized representatives citing specific regulations for the bed closure. Statements obtained from interviews conducted with CW did not reveal the placement agreement was violated when the facility closed C1's bed. It was alleged the facility has unqualified staff providing care and supervision for clients. Statements obtained from interviews conducted with CW revealed staff were capable and prepared to work with C1's behaviors. Statements obtained from interviews conducted with HMs indicated staff complete a forty-hour training prior to their first shift and provided C1 a staff ratio of 1:1. Based on statements obtained and records reviewed the allegations were found unsubstantiated. Although the allegations are valid or may have happened the standard of the preponderance of evidence has not been met. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the administrator. There were no deficiencies cited at this time.
investigation_findings: 13On December 23, 2020 at 4:20 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Larios conducted a follow up complaint inspection via telephone and spoke with Administrator, Daniel Herrera-Garcia The purpose of the inspection was to deliver findings for the above-mentioned complaint allegations. During the course of the investigation LPA Larios conducted interviews with one Service Worker (SW) on 12/17/20 and two House Managers (HMs) on 12/22/20, others were interviewed on 8/31/20. LPA Larios was unable to interview one Client (C1) due to hospitalization, and one House Manager (HM2) who was on leave during the investigation. LPA Larios conducted a record review on September 10, 2020 and obtained copies of Special Incident Reports (SIRs), Personal Inventory Logs, Financial Records and C1’s Needs and Services Plans.

narrative: It was alleged the facility mishandled C1’s personal belongings. Statements obtained from interviews conducted with the SW indicated C1’s Personal Inventory List was not reviewed by SW while C1 was placed at the facility. SW reported no knowledge of missing items until C1 was discharged. A review of C1’s personal property records revealed the facility conducted an inventory check on nine out of twenty-four months C1 was placed at the facility. Statements obtained from interviews conducted with HMs indicated the facility is required to conduct inventory of client’s property monthly. Both HMs were unable to confirm the facility conducted clients inventory monthly. Statements obtained from interviews conducted with HMs indicated that C1 destroyed personal property during behavior episodes, outgrew clothing items and had other items taken by the authorized representative. HMs reported the facility documents items which were destroyed in photographs, no photographs were provided to LPA Larios during the investigation. Furthermore, HMs stated upon client discharge, personal property that was returned to the client is verified by the authorized representative signing an inventory log. Records reviewed and statements obtained from facility staff did not evidence staff reviewed inventory with authorized representative. Based on interviews conducted and records reviewed, the allegation was substantiated, the facility did not ensure the clients personal property was handled properly while in their care. Thus, violating the client’s personal rights which is required by California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Div. 6 Sec. 84072(d). The allegation is valid because the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met. A copy of this report and the Appeals rights were provided and discussed with the Administrator.
