deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 84702(d) Personal Rights: The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code section 16001.9, as applicable. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review and statements obtained, the facility failed to properly handle the client’s personal property while in their care. Which poses a potential Safety, Health or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.

met_with: Cecilia Pantaleon, Director of Residential Services
narrative: S3 held on to client and client’s shirt to prevent client from hitting the ground hard. S3 slowly released client after S3 realized it was not possible to pull client back from outside due to client’s weight. S3 exited from the same window and continued redirecting while following client from behind as client returned inside the facility. Client was able to calm down after continued redirection by S3 and another staff on duty (S4). Other staff (S4) involved denied failing to intervene and denied yelling at clients. S4 was supervising two other clients present in another area at the facility while client was escalated and under supervision of S3 inside client’s bedroom. S4 observed S3 redirecting and following client; S4 denied witnessing S3 hit client. S4 assisted S3 in redirecting client after client returned inside the facility. S4 denied yelling at clients in placement. During LPA’s interviews with clients and additional staff, the client (C1) who was escalated was unable to address the allegations. C1 responded by repeating the same questions asked by LPA to LPA. Another client (C2) reported witnessing the allegations but during interviews gave varying accounts of what happened. The other client (C3) in placement reported not witnessing the incident due to being asleep. Other staff interviewed were not able to address the allegations; they were not working when the incident happened. Based on the information gathered, although the allegations may have happened or is valid, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegations was not met, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, Confidential Names Form and Appeal Rights were emailed to the facility representative. LPA requested for the licensing report to be reviewed, signed and emailed back to LPA. There was no deficiency citation issued.
investigation_findings: 13On January 19, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Irene Yamamoto delivered the findings of the complaint investigation by tele-conference call and electronic mail. LPA discussed the findings with the facility representative named above. LPA investigated the allegations by conducting interviews with three staff and one client on 10/14/20, two clients on 10/29/20 and additional staff on 1/7/21 and 1/14/21. LPA reviewed records such as, but not limited to, the client’s Individualized Education Program (IEP), Individualized Program Plan (IPP), Consumer Information Documents, 90-day Report, Special Incident Reports (SIRs). LPA also reviewed photos, placement agency and law enforcement contact reports. It was alleged that staff hit client resulting in injury, other staff did not intervene, and staff yells at clients. One staff (S3) involved denied the allegation that staff hit client resulting in injury. Client became escalated after refusing to use a tablet for a Zoom meeting with a teacher. S3 was able to redirect client to bedroom, away from two other clients, when client attempted to leave through a bedroom window.

narrative:
On February 10, 2022 at 9:30am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Gutierrez, conducted an annual/required inspection at the facility and met Cecilia Pantaleon, Residential Director/Administrator. The facility is a one story home with 4 (four) bedrooms and 3 (three) bathrooms and detached garage. Currently there are 2 clients placed in the facility. At the time of LPA's arrival, no clients present in the facility. Physical Plant LPA started the inspection at about 9:45am. LPA together with a staff toured the facility inside and out. The inspection ended at 10:30am. LPA observed the following: the posted license, emergency disaster plan, personnel schedule, client personal rights, and grievance procedure. The disinfectants, cleaning solutions, sharp objects are inaccessible to clients. The facility maintains supplies of non-perishable foods for at least a week and fresh perishable foods for at least two days. Each bedroom has a single bed with clean sheets and linens. There are adequate drawers and closet space for the client's clothing. There are extra linens, adequate towels and hygiene supplies in the facility. Only one client sleeps in a room. No room commonly used for other purposes is being used as a bedroom. The window screens are in good repair and free of dirt. All medications are stored locked in a metal cabinet inside a room. There is a working telephone for clients use. The first aid kit was complete and readily available. The water temperature is 113 degrees within the temperature allowed by Title 22 Regulations. The smoke/carbon monoxide detectors are working. All passageways are unobstructed. LPA started the interview at 11:30pm. LPA interviewed two (2) clients and three (3) staff members.

Client Records At around 1:00pm, LPA reviewed 2 (two) client records and finished at 2:00pm. All client records are available to licensing agency to inspect, audit upon demand. Client records contain required information including, but not limited to, consent forms, needs and services plan, medical assessment, safeguards for cash resources, personal property and valuables, education records, personal rights forms, and medication administration records. Staff Records At 2:15pm, LPA reviewed 8 (eight) staff records and finished at 4:50pm. All staff subject to criminal records review have been fingerprinted and cleared. There is documentation of the required education and experience requirements and training in the personnel file. The administrator and facility managers meet the required qualification and/or experience. An exit interview was conducted and no citation issued at this time. A copy of this report and LIC 811 were provided to the administrator.. This is an amended report of the original provided to the facility on 02/10/22

An annual required inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tana Kinder on 4/6/2022 with the Facility Administrator. Community Care Licensing file, incident reports, facility roster, facility profile and complaint history were reviewed prior to visit at the facility. The licensing fees are current. The Facility has a capacity of 4 and currently has 3 residents. There are 10 staff members associated to the license and 3 currently working at the Facility. LPA reviewed 5 staff files, all which were reviewed were complete and up to date. Staff files reviewed have required training hours, education, and fingerprint clearances. 3 client files were reviewed. The client’s Individual Program Plan, Behavioral Plan (IBST) and reviews were complete and up to date. Immunization records were current. Medical consent forms were signed by authorized representative and current. Additionally, the client's file had a record of personal property. Personal rights, menu, license and emergency exit plan were posted. The facility was inspected jointly with the Facility Administrator. Client interviews were not possible due to their diagnosis of intellectual disability and/or Autism, the clients are not able to communicate verbally or have limited communication skills. There are 4 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms. Each client has their own bedroom. Each bedroom had a firm mattress, with a bed cover, sheets, blanket and pillows. The common area has couches and chairs to sit in, and a TV. The facility is in good repair. There are locked cabinets in the laundry room with cleansers and detergents. Additional linen if needed for the bedrooms and the bathrooms are kept in a hall closet. Client and staff files are in locked cabinets in the office area. The passageways from the front to the back of the facility are unobstructed. LPA observed in the backyard and saw a patio table with chairs and a scooters for the clients. LPA observed enough perishable/non-perishable food for 3 client for 4 days/2 weeks. Smoke detectors are in working order. There is a carbon monoxide monitor and 1 fully charged fire extinguisher. Sharps were kept locked in the kitchen. The kitchen was stocked with plates, utensils and drinking cups sufficient for 4 clients. The water temperature from the kitchen faucet was 109.5 degrees. The clients’ hygiene kits were stocked and stored in the second bathroom. A fully stocked first aid kit is kept in the kitchen. An exit interview was conducted and discussed with the Facility Administrator. One citation was issued on a D page and a copy of the annual inspection report and appeal process was provided.

Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Tana Kinder conducted a case management inspection on 4/24/23 with the facility administrator related to the incident report dated 4/21/23. C1 came home from school very upset and escalated. C1 had possession of some items that posed a potential threat to C1 and others in the facility. LPA requested clarification regarding the items found in C1's bedroom when C1 returned from school. An unannounced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Tele-Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Claudia Portillo, Jenny Mundo and Pamela Silva on March 15, 2021 at 9:00 AM via Microsoft Teams Meeting. Remote "tele-inspection" of facilities is a part of Community Care Licensing Division’s emergency response to the spread of Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19). During the tele-inspection, LPAs Portillo, Mundo and Silva spoke with Cecilia Pantaleon, Residential Director; Gina Doyle, Facility Manager and Israel Ibañez, Executive Director. All pertinent staff and client records were scanned and emailed to the LPAs prior to the tele-inspection upon request. LPAs reviewed the facility's Plan of Operation prior to the tele-inspection. LPAs reviewed 3 of staff personnel files on March 4th at 1:00 PM. LPAs reviewed 1 child’s records off site on March 4th at 9:30 AM. LPAs conducted a facility tour with Gina Doyle at 10:05 AM. During the review of one child’s records, LPAs observed 1 child (C1) did not have a current JV 220 and JV 223. The Residential Director and facility staff were unable to locate C1’s current JV 220 and JV 223 that provides directions from the prescribing physician and authorizes the use of psychotropic medication (M1, M2, M3 and M4). (continued...)

LPAs observed that the Psychotropic Medication Administration Records (PMARs) for C1 for March 2021 indicates that psychotropic medications (M1) was administered on 3/9/21 but the medication was still intact for that day. S2 issued the medication for 3/16/21 on 3/9/21 but circled that she issued the medication on 3/9/21 on the PMAR. There was no documentation or special incident report explaining actions taken and reasons why the psychotropic medications were not administered on 3/9/21 or why she popped the medication on the wrong date. (3/16/21). The Residential Director and facilty manager were unable to located C1’s initial Needs and services plan and the updated NSP was not signed by the authorized representative. LPA Portillo interviewed 1 staff on 3/15/21 at 12:30 PM. LPA Silva interviewed 1 staff on 3/15/21 at 2:00 PM LPA Mundo interviewed 1 staff on 3/15/21 at 2:30 PM LPA Silva interviewed 1 client on 3/15/21 at 2:30 PM. LPAs conducted an exit interview with Cecilia Pantaleon, Residential Director 3: 30 PM. On April 11, 2022 at 9:15am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Gutierrez, conducted an annual/required inspection at the facility and met Facility Manager (FM) John Hansen. LPA interviewed two clients at 10:15am. One of the clients was non-verbal and not interviewed. Client Records At around 11:00am, LPA reviewed three client records. The facility staff denied the allegations indicated when clients are attempting to harm each other staff will attempt to intervene, redirect and separate clients. Licensing Program Analyst Dina Camara conducted a case management inspection 03/15/23 at 11:07 AM based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 9 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 2 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 9 Direct Care Staff and 0 out of 2 youth were interviewed. Youth are non-verbal. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated 03/15/23). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments and youth case plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Dina Camara did not observe documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Crisis Management Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Guadalupe Galindo, Administrator.

With regards to the allegations of a client having access to marijuana and the facility providing inadequate supervision to a client, there was insufficient evidence to corroborate the allegations. Facility staff denied providing the client with any contraband or neglecting the client resulting in the client obtaining and consuming marijuana. The facility client was unable to provide a meaningful statement as the client was autistic and non-verbal. Facility incident reports indicated that even when the client left the facility without approval, staff were with the client to re-direct the client back to the facility as it would have been a safety risk for the client if the client were left alone at any point in time. With regards to the allegation of improper restraint, there was insufficient evidence to corroborate the allegation. The investigation revealed that the facility client had a history of risk behavior and tendency to either self-harm or harm others in the facility or during outings. Facility staff statements and incident reports reflected that staff acted appropriately during such incidents of risk behaviors with the client. With regards to the allegation of the facility mishandling the client's medication, there was insufficient evidence to corroborate the allegation. The investigation revealed that the facility client was put on a 5150 hold after law enforcement was summoned at an incident where the client became non-compliant and exhibited risk behaviors while he was in the facility vehicle attempting to elope and destroy property. Once the client was at the hospital, a medication change occurred. Once the client returned to the facility and back to school, the facility provided administered the client's medication in a timely manner. Based on the information gathered, the allegations are unsubstantiated as the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegations was not met although the allegations may have happened or are valid. A copy of this report, Confidential Names Form and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection.

On this date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lidia Tinoco conducted a Case Management inspection the Jar-Mill Group Home and met with current Administrator Justin Lyons. The purpose of the inspection was to discuss an incident that was reported to CCL regarding a staff member crashing into the Group Home. On December 14, 2020, the facility Administrator sent in to the CCL incidents email the full report informing CCL that a staff member crashed into one of the rooms in the home. The Administrator reports that no one was in the room at the time this occurred and there were no injuries. The youth was placed in a different room until the repairs could be completed. The Administrator will provide LPA with a copy of the work order and pictures of the repairs. The repairs have already started and are scheduled to be completed by Monday, December 21,2020. According to the Administrator, moving forward staff members are not to park on that part of the house anymore and another parking site has been assigned to prevent accidents like this from occurring again. No Deficiencies were cited on this inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report were provided to the facility.

investigation_findings: 13On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Lidia Tinoco conducted an over the phone Tele-Visit complaint inspection and met with Director Donna Vaughn-Goady for the purpose of delivering the findings for the complaint investigation. Investigator Munoz conducted investigation that included review of documentation, interviews of clients staff and witnesses and based of the information obtained have determined the allegations are

narrative: On 02/24/2021 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lidia Tinoco and Licensing Program Manager (LPM), Melanie Krage conducted a Tele-Visit Informal Meeting with the Jar-Mills Place Group Home and met with Donna Vaughn Goady. The purpose of the inspection was to discuss concerns regarding the group home accepting a new placement in the facility that requires injectable hormones. Donna explained that the youth was an emergency placement by VMRC. According to Donna, VMRC stated that they would be assigning a nurse to administer the shots to the youth, but once the youth got placed this did not happen. In the meantime, the youth's family members who are doctors are coming in and administering the shots, which is a problem too, as the youth has been exhibiting behavioral episodes. Donna also expressed concerns with the conflicting information being received by the different parties involved. LPM Krage reminded Donna that VMRC regulations differ from those of Community Care Licensing (CCL) and although it might not be a violation of the VMRC regulations, it is not in the facilities program to accept youth that need injectable medications. LPM Krage also informed Donna that the facility staff cannot be trained to administer the injections because it is outside of the scope of their training. LPM Krage also addressed other concerns regarding the facility and administrator qualifications and informed Donna that she will address these concerns with the regional manager Nelson Martinez. LPM Krage and LPA Tinoco asked Donna to keep the department informed of any changes or new information as it becomes available regarding this youth. Donna understood and agreed to keep the department updated. Due to COVID-19 An exit interview was conducted over the phone, and a copy of the report was provided to the facility via email. Signatures were also requested via email and will be documented on an LIC812.

On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Lidia Tinoco and Licensing Program Manager (LPM), Melanie Krage met with the Valley Mountain Regional Center (VMRC), Case Manager Jennifer Stone, Katrina Richison, and Brian Bennett, and with the Jar-Mill's Place representative, Donna Vaughn-Goady in order to conduct a case management to address concerns regarding the group home. During the meeting, CCL and VMRC addressed the concerns pertaining to not having an administrator. Donna stated she has been actively looking for an administrator and will continue to post the opportunity, Donna stated she will also work on becoming a certified administrator herself. The facility program statement was brought to Donna's attention as well as having youth near the age of eighteen. Documentation regarding the current administrator will be sent to VMRC and CCL by Donna as well as any changes or updates that occur.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 84072(d) Personal Rights. To be free from unreasonable searches of personal belongings. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on reports received, the facility conducted an inappropriate search of residents' bedrooms which poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.

80075(b) Health Related Services. Clients shall be assisted as needed with self-administration of prescription and nonprescription medications. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on information obtained from the facility, medications were located in a resident's bedroom when a search was performed which poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.

80061(b) Reporting Requirements. Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in (1) below, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours. In addition, a written report containing the information specified in (2) below shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on reports received, notifications were made late to Regional Center and Community Care Licensing which presents a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.

facility_name: JOHN H. ECCLES HOME FOR BOYS
narrative: On July 15, 2022 at approximately 09:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Raymond Wu conducted a visit at the facility for the purposes of initiating a 2 Year Required inspection. LPA met with the representative listed above and discussed the purpose of the visit. During the visit, a walk-through of the facility was conducted. The facility is currently vacant and the last client moved out approximately 1.5 years ago according to the Administrator. PHYSICAL PLANT A walk-through of the physical plant was conducted at approximately 9:30 AM. The facility is a single-story home situated in a quiet residential area. The exterior passageways of the facility was observed to be free from obstruction. After entering the front door, there is a secured staff office towards the right which is also where medication, sharp objects, and chemicals are safely stored. Postings including the License, Emergency Disaster Plan, and Complaint hotline numbers were prominently placed for any potential clients. Left of the office there is a living room with a TV and games. Towards the left of the living room, there is a kitchen, dining area, pantry, and laundry room. These areas were observed to be in good repair for potential clients. Smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were observed to be in working order and fire extinguishers were observed to be serviced. No perishable food was observed due to the facility being vacant. There were a total of 4 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms for client use. All rooms were observed to be clean and furniture was observed to be in good repair. Mattresses were outfitted with mattress covers and linens were clean and tidy. Bathrooms were observed to have paper towel dispensers, trash bins with covered lids, and soap for potential client use. The exterior of the facility contains a basketball court and a large yard for other recreational use. There is also a separate building serving as a game room for client use. No deficiencies were cited during today's visit. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the Licensee.

facility_name: JOHN H. ECCLES HOME FOR BOYS
narrative: On August 29, 2023 at approximately 2:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Raymond Wu conducted a visit at the facility for the purposes of conducting a physical plant inspection. LPA met with the representative listed above and discussed the purpose of the visit. The facility has been vacant since approximately February 2021, and is planning on accepting new clients shortly. PHYSICAL PLANT A walk-through of the physical plant was conducted at approximately 2:00 PM. The facility is a single-story home situated in a quiet residential area. The exterior passageways of the facility was observed to be free from obstruction. After entering the front door, there is a secured staff office towards the right which is also where medication, sharp objects, and chemicals are safely stored. Postings including the License, Emergency Disaster Plan, and Complaint hotline numbers were prominently placed for any potential clients. Left of the office there is a living room for recreational activities. Towards the left of the living room, there is a kitchen, dining area, pantry, and laundry room. These areas were observed to be in good repair for potential clients. Smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were observed to be in working order and fire extinguishers were observed to be serviced. The pantry was stocked with non-perishable foods and the refrigerators and freezers were lightly stocked with perishable food. More food will be purchased prior to clients officially moving in. There were a total of 4 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms for client use. All rooms were observed to be clean and furniture was observed to be in good repair. Mattresses were outfitted with mattress covers and linens were clean and tidy. Bathrooms were observed to have paper towel dispensers, trash bins with covered lids, and soap for potential client use. Hot water temperature measured at 116 degrees Fahrenheit. The exterior of the facility contains a basketball court and a large yard for other recreational use. There is also a separate building serving as a game room for client use. No deficiencies were cited during today's visit. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the Licensee.

On November 1, 2024 at 10:00 am, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Sarina Buchannan, Orlando Areizaga and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez conducted an in person office meeting with Applicant #1 and Applicant #2. The purpose of the meeting was to continue the Group Home application process by conducting the Component II orientation. LPAs and LPM reviewed the following documentation below with both Applicants. Journey of Hope II Group Home Application - Capacity of 4 Ambulatory children, ages 7-17 years old. Fire Clearance granted on 9/30/24 Financial Verification for 3 months was verified, $90k Administrator Certificate for ADEBOLA SANYAOLU expires on 2/23/25 Fees in the amount of $908 were paid on 8/27/24 LIC 215 for Adebola is missing Section D & need to verify Section A & B because already a Licensee LIC 309, second page needs to be completed. LIC 401/401A, review operating costs (Laundry & Dry Cleaning, Personal Hygiene) LIC 500, Need Social worker information and signature/date. LIC 503 is also needed for the Social Worker/Behavior Consultant and any additional staff hired LIC 610C, need to add CCL & contact information on section 2 Verification for Social Worker/Behaviors qualifications is needed (Education, Degree, transcripts. Social worker/Behavior Qualifications Job duties are missing. New Hires need to be fingerprinted and associated to the facility in Guardian Guardian is only showing Adebola and Adouibon. Copies of Drivers License for applicants are missing. (continued on LIC 809C)

First Aid and CPR certification for applicants and all the new staff is needed. LIC 9106 Missing Items still Pending: LIC 503 provider will email health screening for Behavior Consultant and any hired staff Provider will email LPA Buchannan education, degree, and transcripts for Behavior Consultant Provider will email LPA Buchannan First Aid and CPR certification LIC 401/401A provider will review, revise, and email to LPA Buchannan Upcoming: Pre-Licensing will be conducted on November 15, 2024 at 10:00 AM. Exit interview conducted. A copy of this report was provided to the Applicants.

On 11/15/2024 at approximately 10:00 AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Sarina Buchannan, Zaria Turner, Orlando Areizaga and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez made an announced visit for the purpose of conducting a pre-licensing inspection to the above facility. LPAs and LPM met with Licensees, Adebola and Abiodun Sanyaolu and a walk through of the interior and exterior was completed. Physical Plant LPAs and LPM entered from the front door into the entryway that leads into room 1. Room 1 is the living room that has 1 sectional couch, an area rug, a projector, and a Playstation 5. There is a hallway to the right of the living room that has a closet and and the hallways leads to the 3 client bedrooms and 2 bathrooms. In the hallway there is a closet with clean linens, towels, and toiletries. Next to the closet is room 2 which is a shared client bedroom with two 2 twins size beds, 2 dressers, and 2 night stands. Room 2 also has a walk in closet, a small door with a built in ironing board, a bathroom with working fixtures, and water temperature at least 105 degrees. Room 3 is a bathroom with a working shower, toilet, sink, cleaning products locked under the bathroom sink, and running warm water with a temperature of at least 105 degrees. Room 4 is a client bedroom with a twin bed, a night stand, and a dresser. Room 5 is a client bedroom with a twin bed, a night stand, and a dresser. Room 6 is an activity room with 3 couches, large Jenga, books, and connect 4. Room 6 is a dining room with a table, 4 chairs, 2 windows, and all required postings. Room 7 is kitchen with 3 First Aid kits, a locked cabinet for medications, and a fire extinguisher. The kitchen also has a door that leads to the garage. Room 8 is a garage with an office that will store client and staff files, a deep freezer, and will be kept locked at all times. The backyard is gated with an orange tree, two tables, has a walkway leading from the fence entrances. The front yard has the facility trash cans, a non-smoking sign, and 3 cat deterrent devices. The facility does not yet have vehicles and will be using ride sharing until they have actually purchased the vehicles. Report continues on 809-C. (Page 1)

The following required documents were posted, Emergency Disaster Plan, Personal Rights and complaint contact numbers. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are inaccessible to children in care and locked under the bathroom sink. Refrigerator temperature is at or below 45 degrees Fahrenheit. Nonperishable foods one week and fresh perishable foods three days minimum. The Refrigerator is at 41 Degrees and Freezer is at -2 degrees Fahrenheit. There are pots and pans with lids and there are containers to place leftover food. A working cell phone is available at the facility. Carbon monoxide and smoke detectors are in working order. First Aid Kit fully stocked. Hot Water between 105–120 degree Fahrenheit. Fire Extinguishers are up to date and in working order. Toilets, wash basins and shower fixtures in good repair, there are no leaks and hot water is accessible. Bedroom required linen and furnishings are fully stocked. The facility is free of vermin. LPAs and LPM observed the following and have made the required recommendations: 2 broken light fixtures in front of the garage. Licensee will replace or remove the 2 broken light fixtures. A clothing line in the front yard and backyard that are potentially hazardous to client safety. Licensee will remove the 2 clothing lines in the front and backyard. Loose bricks in the backyard easily accessible to clients. Licensee will remove unused bricks and store them away from clients. Christmas lights in the backyard that are potentially hazardous to client safety. Licensee will remove the Christmas lights or place them where inaccessible to clients. The front porch steps were observed to be in bad repair with dirt and ripped carpeting. Licensee will clean the front porch steps or remove the carpeting. The outside walls and windows have cobwebs, dirt, and flies. Licensee will power wash and clean walls and windows. The outdoor window screen in the living room to be falling off and in poor repair. Licensee will replace window screen with a new one. The inside walls and ceilings have cracks. Licensee will repair cracks. The shared client bathroom has a trash can without a lid. Licensee will obtain a lid for the trash can or purchase one with a lid to replace the current one. 2 tiles in the kitchen that are cracked. Licensee will replace or repair cracks in tiles. 1 vent in activity room is not fully secured to the wall and is hanging partly off. Licensee will secure vent to the wall. Report continues on 809-C. (Page 2)

Facility trashes are in the front yard. Licensee will move the trash to the backyard. A shared client bedroom that does not have blinds or properly fitting curtains. Licensee will purchase blinds and curtains for the clients room. A built in ironing board unsecured in clients bedroom. Licensee will secure the ironing board to the wall. A large crack in the cement foundation in the backyard creating a tripping hazard. Licensee will fill the crack. A follow up pre-licensing inspection is needed. LPA Buchannan will conduct a follow up inspection on 11/22/24 to confirm repairs and recommendations have been made. Exit interview conducted. A copy of this report was provided to Licensees, Adebola and Abiodun Sanyaolu. (Page 3)

On 02/11/2025 at approximately 9:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan conducted a virtual meeting with the above facility for the purposes of discussing concerns related to the Journey of Hope 3 new application. Present during the meeting were LPA Sarina Buchannan and Applicant Adebola Sanyaolu. Below is a summary of the topics that were discussed and the answers that were provided by the applicant: 1. Administrator and Board Duties - LPA Buchannan discussed that the Applicant will be a board member, president, and facility administrator for this and two other facilities. Licensee confirmed that they will be hiring another administrator to take over one of the three facilities. They also stated that they have another individual who has the required qualification and will be acting as a backup when needed. 2. Form Updates – Applicant stated they will update all discrepancies on the following forms: · LIC 200 - Missing one of their current facilities on page 2. · LIC 215 - Prior licensor status boxes need to be marked yes for A and B. · LIC 400 - Amount is for 1,000 which does not match the LIC 402. · LIC 402 - Amount is for 1,500 which does not match the LIC 400. Applicant stated they will lower this amount to 1,000 to match the LIC 400. · LIC 401 - Building and Furniture repairs are estimated at 0 dollars. Applicant shared that HOA would do repairs. They will update the form to reflect cost of furniture repairs. (Report continued on LIC 809C)

LIC 403A - state applicants bank has 32,000 in funds but was not verified on the LIC 404. · LIC 404 - Funds were verified to be 2,476 which does not show 3x operating cost. Funds reflected on the LIC 403A need to be verified on this form by the bank. Applicant stated they will update this form to match the 403A. · LIC 9165 - The Board Member forms need to be updated to match new facility and more current dates. Licensee stated they will submit updated forms with current year and new facility information. 3. Required Funds to Operate the Group Home - LPA Buchannan informed Applicant that they will need to show 3x operating cost for approval. Applicant was informed that if the application is withdrawn at this time due to required operating cost not being met, they can re-apply again at any time after. If the department denies the application the applicant will not be able to re-apply until after 1 year from denial. LPA informed the Applicant the process to withdraw. LPA informed Applicant that the application fees are non-refundable and if they wish to apply again, they will need to pay new fees. LPA thanked Applicant for their time and concluded the Virtual Meeting. A copy of this report was e-mailed to the applicant for signature.

On August 15, 2022 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman conducted an announced pre-licensing facility inspection and met with Adebola Sanyaolu, Facility Administrator, and Abiodun Sanyaolu, House Manager. LPA, Administrator and House Manager conducted a joint inspection of the inside and outside of the facility. The group home is requesting to be licensed for a capacity of 4 ambulatory clients, ages seven to 17 years old. There were no clients in care at the time of the inspection. Clients with Special Health Care Needs (SHCN) will not be admitted. The home is a single-story home with two double occupancy bedrooms and one bathroom for the clients and one bedroom and bathroom for the House Manager. The facility backyard has a deck off the sliding glass door and is enclosed with a fence. The front yard is free of clutter; and the passageways and egress were unobstructed. The backyard fence along the right side of the house has bent/broken boards and is leaning over. The right side of the house has debris that needs to be removed and the fence needs to be repaired prior to being licensed. The backyard is missing toy/activity equipment and seating for clients. LPA observed a working Carbon Monoxide detector in the hallway and working smoke alarms in each bedroom, and the living area. LPA observed that there was a fire extinguisher in the kitchen that was charged in February 2022. The house was clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. LPA observed the facility has at least a 7-day supply of non-perishable food, a 3-day supply of perishable food and the freezer was stocked with frozen foods. LPA observed that there were ample dishes, cups, utensils, and items used for cooking meals in the kitchen. Sharp knives are to be kept in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. Cleaning supplies and chemicals are to be stored under the kitchen sink ina locked cabinet. Menus and meal schedules were posted in the kitchen. LPA observed that the medications, multiple first aid kits are stored in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. The client and staff files are kept locked in a file cabinet in the dining room. This client and extra hygiene products are kept locked in the hall cabinet. LPA observed that there was a laundry area, including a

washer and dryer, in the garage. LPA observed the hall closets have stored life vests, extra bedding, comforters, extra towels and wash cloths. The home has an Emergency Disaster Plan, Client Personal Rights and floorplan are posted in the entrance hallway and the floorplans are posted in each client bedroom. The Grievance policy is posted in the living room and the calendar of activities is posted in the kitchen. LPA observed that the bedrooms have two single beds with a mattress cover and pad, fitted sheet, top sheet and blanket and bedspread, a drawer for each client’s personal items, night stand, lamp, and ample closet area. The living room consisted of two couches, a desk, a television and game system. The facility has a working landline phone located in the living room. LPA also observed activity supplies in the living room of board games and video games for the clients. There was one bathroom in the hall for the clients that is equipped with a shower/tub combination and a shower curtain for privacy. The bathroom has a working toilet, shower, and sink faucet and has soap and paper towels for hand washing. The second bathroom was located at the House Manager’s bedroom and is not for clients. The water temperature was measured to be at 90.5 degrees Fahrenheit the water temperature was turned up during the inspection Facility will adjust the water temperature until it reaches between 105-120 degrees Fahrenheit. LPA observed that the dining area was off of the kitchen and the table was set up for placement of four and contained four chairs along with two barstools at the kitchen counter. An exit interview was conducted with Adebola Sanyaolu, Facility Administrator, and Abiodun Sanyaolu, House Manager a copy of this report was left with Adebola Sanyaolu, Facility Administrator, and Abiodun Sanyaolu, House Manager.

On August 22, 2022 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman conducted an announced pre-licensing facility inspection and met with Adebola Sanyaolu, Facility Administrator, and Abiodun Sanyaolu, House Manager. LPA, Administrator and House Manager conducted a joint inspection of the of the facility to inspect technical violation corrections. The group home is requesting to be licensed for a capacity of 4 ambulatory clients, ages seven to 17 years old. There were no clients in care at the time of the inspection. Clients with Special Health Care Needs (SHCN) will not be admitted. The backyard fence on both sides of the house has been repaired, the debris in the backyard along the right side of the house has been removed, the hot water temperature is 109 degrees Fahrenheit. The facility has supplies, equipment and reading material necessary to implement the planned indoor and outdoor activities and has an outdoor seating area for the clients. Facility cited violation of California Health and Safety Code 1565(a)(7)(A) and 1565(a)(7)(E) technical violations. The facility will have 30 days from the date of the inspection on 8/22/22 to complete the corrections. An exit interview was conducted with Adebola Sanyaolu, Facility Administrator, and Abiodun Sanyaolu, House Manager a copy of this report was left with Adebola Sanyaolu, Facility Administrator, and Abiodun Sanyaolu, House Manager. The facility is granted it's provisional license effective 8/22/2022.

On 6/6/23 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman conducted an unannounced inspection. At the time of LPA's arrival there were no children in placement and only one adult who resides in the home was at the facility. LPA observed the sliding glass door handle frame comes off the glass door, the lawn is full of weeds/grass that is approximately two feet tall and the home is cluttered with items on the dining room table, living room table and TV stand and electrical cords are accessible under the glass desk in the living room. LPA observed the clutter in the living room and kitchen table were cleaned up and the lawns were mowed during the inspection. On March 17, 2023, at 8:15 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gloria Meza-Gonzalez conducted an announced inspection. LPA Meza-Gonzalez met with Program Administrator (PA) Jocelyn Irasusta. The purpose of the inspection is to conduct a pre-licensing inspection. This applicant is applying for a group home license with the capacity of 4 ambulatory youths from four to seventeen. The applicant will be receiving Regional Center youth only. LPA Meza-Gonzalez toured the facility with PA Irasusta. The facility is a one-story house with three bedrooms, two bathrooms, two living rooms, a kitchen, a dining room, and a garage. The facility is set up as follows: The first living room has a TV, two couches, a table with three chairs, a coffee table, and a coat closet. LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed games and toys for the client’s use. The second living room has two couches, a floor lamp, and a TV. The kitchen has two counter-high chairs, a refrigerator, a stove, a microwave, a stove, and a dishwasher. LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed the stove, microwave, refrigerator, and dishwasher are in working condition. Sharp knives will be inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet under the kitchen sink. LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed seven days of non-perishable food and two days of perishable food. The dining room has a table and four chairs. The bedrooms are set up as follows: Bedroom # 1: designated for one client, one twin bed, a nightstand, and closet space. Bedroom #2: designated for one client, one twin bed, a nightstand, and closet space. Bedroom #3: designated for two clients, two beds, two nightstands, and closet space. Bedroom #1 and Bedroom #2 share a bathroom in the hallway. Bedroom #3 has a bathroom. Each room has adequate clean linens, pillows, blankets, comforters, mattress pads, and mattresses. The hot water was measured to be 120 degrees Fahrenheit, which is between Community Care Licensing regulations of 105 degrees Fahrenheit to 120 degrees Fahrenheit. See page 2 - LIC809C

LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed additional bed linen and towels for clients’ use. The washer and dryer are located in the garage. LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed cleaning supplies locked in a cabinet in the garage. The garage is designated as the staff office and will be locked when not in use. Clients’ files will be stored in the garage in a locked cabinet. Clients’ medication will be stored in a locked cabinet in the garage. The staff files are located off-premises. The staff and clients will always be available to Community Care Licensing as requested The backyard has a table with five chairs, a patio cover, and a shed. The shed has gardening equipment and is locked. The facility’s smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and were observed to be in working order; the fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. The facility has a fully equipped first aid kit and a first aid manual. The facility does not have cameras. The applicants stated there were no weapons in the home. LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed the following required forms were posted in the facility: menu, personal rights form, grievance/complaint policy, visitation policy, house rules, disaster plan, plan activities, and facility sketch. The fire clearance has been approved. The applicant has been informed that the address of this facility is available to the public. All special incident reports (SIRs) will be sent via e-mail to: cclpaccr@dss.ca.gov. LPA Meza-Gonzalez conducted a component III orientation, a continuing requirement regulation review, with an emphasis on the facility operation and commonly found problem areas. The orientation provided PA Irasusta with sufficient information to operate the facility within substantial compliance, as well as, how to avoid common problem areas for the facility operation. The applicant understands that once the license is approved, all employees and volunteers shall have an approved criminal record clearance for Community Care Licensing and be associated with this facility. Based on this pre-licensing inspection, the facility is in compliance according to Title 22 Regulations. After a final file review, the facility will be submitted for licensure. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was given to PA Irasusta.

On March 14, 2025 at 1:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacob Salem conducted an unannounced visit to the above facility for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection and met with Joceyln Irasusta, Administrator. LPA inspected the facility’s physical plant, including personal rights postings, health-related services, buildings and grounds, food services, telephones, indoor and outdoor activity space, and furniture, fixtures, equipment and supplies. The home is clean, in good repair, and free from observable risks to clients' health, safety, and personal rights. The home is a one story building with three client bedrooms and two client bathrooms which are set up as follows: Bedroom #1 has two twin beds and sleeps two clients, bedroom #2 has one twin bed and sleeps one client, and bedroom #3 has one twin bed and sleeps one client. There is a comfortable family and TV room in the front of the home, kitchen and living room area, multiple locked storage closets, and backyard/patio with table for confidential interviews. LPA reviewed the facility's disaster preparedness plan and staff training, which included all the required information and records. LPA reviewed two client files (C1-C2), which are kept in a locked cabinet. The client files reviewed contain required information and records, including pre-placement screenings, personal rights and facility policy acknowledgements, and medication logs. Due to time constraints, the annual is being extended to complete client and staff file reviews, as well as staff interviews. An exit interview was conducted and a signed copy of this report was provided to Joceyln Irasusta, Licensee.

met_with: Christian Irasusta, Lead Direct Support Professional (DSP)
narrative: On 11/05/2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that due to a lack of supervision, minors sustained unexplained injuries. It was specifically reported that C1 arrived at school with redness on the left side of C1’s forehead and that both the GH and school deny any wrongdoing. During the investigation, multiple confidential interviews determined that C1’s injury may have occurred while being transported to school on the school bus but this was not confirmed. In addition, another confidential interview disclosed that when C1 left the facility that day, the injury was not there. Multiple confidential interviews disclosed that there is no concern for lack of supervision at the GH. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that due to a lack of supervision, minors sustained unexplained injuries is unsubstantiated. The allegation may have happened or be valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Christian Irasusta, Lead Direct Support Professional (DSP).
investigation_findings: 13On 06/30/2025, at 4:00PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maya Chavez conducted an unannounced visit to Joy’s Special Care, LLC Group Home (GH) and met with Cristian Irasusta, Lead Direct Support Professional (DSP) to deliver the investigative finding for the allegation listed above. On 11/14/2024, LPA C. Anderson conducted a health and safety inspection at the GH, and no immediate health and safety hazards were observed. In addition, on 05/15/2025, LPA M. Chavez conducted an additional visit at the GH. LPA Chavez conducted interviews with staff (S1 & S2), C1 and C2’s Regional Workers, and C1 and C2’s School Nurse. LPA Chavez attempted to conduct interviews with C1 and C2 but was unable to due to C1 and C2 being non-verbal.

met_with: Christian Irasusta, Lead Direct Support Professional (DSP)
narrative: **Amendment* On 11/06/2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that facility staff locked minors in their room. It was specifically reported that staff at the group home have reported that the children can be a lot to handle and that sometimes they lock the children in a room. During the investigation, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that staff do not lock C1 and C2 in their bedroom. In addition, a confidential interview disclosed that staff have never mentioned anything about C1 and C2 being locked in their bedroom. Furthermore, a confidential interview disclosed that during showering, bathroom door shall be locked to avoid C1 and C2 running out of the bathroom while wet and naked. LPA did not receive any further information. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that facility staff locked C1 and C2 in their room may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violation, therefore, this allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Christian Irasusta, Lead DSP.

13On Friday 1/22/21 at 1PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Mariah Hawkins and Cheyenne McCambridge met with Administrator Jane Gano to deliver complaint investigation findings. Due to pandemic social distancing orders, this visit was conducted as a televisit. During the investigation, LPAs conducted confidential interviews with the administrator and resident R1's (See LIC 811, dated 1/22/21) regional center case manager (CM) and reviewed incident report and medical report documentation. Based on the confidential interviews and record review, the youth was in a car accident while being transported by a driver from a driving company hired by the youth's school. The facility did not generate an incident report with all required information to send to the youth's CM and to CCL. Instead, the facility forwarded the CM the report generated by the driving company, which did not include all of the information required by applicable regulations. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegation is found to be

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Reporting Requirements (h) Incident Reports must include the following: (3) Analysis of the incident:... (4) Description of the facility's plan for the child, in response to the incident ... (5) What action was taken by facility personnel to re-integrate the child into the general population after the incident. Based on interview and record review, the facility did not provide CCL an incident report and did not document the incident to include the required incident report information. This poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.

narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vaishali Singh-Sood conducted an unannounced inspection of the facility on 6/24/2021 at 8:30 AM. LPA Singh-Sood met with Jane Gano, Administrator. The Group Home is licensed to serve six clients, ages 12-17 years old. The current census is 6 ambulatory clients. The purpose of this inspection was to comply with a regulatory requirement for a yearly required inspection. Adm. took LPA on a walk-through tour of the facility both inside and out. At the time of the inspection, there were 6 clients and 5 staff present. The facility is a single level home, located in San Mateo, CA. The facility consists of five bedrooms, three for clients and two for staff. Staff bedrooms are located in front of the house and are not accessible to clients. There is one bathroom for staff in this area, however it is available to clients if needed. All three client rooms are located in the back of the house with a master bathroom. LPA observed at the time of this inspection, the facility to be clean, safe, and sanitary. LPA observed adequate lighting and space for clothing. The temperature inside the home is 71 degrees Fahrenheit which is in required temperature range, and the water temperature was 117 degrees, which is also in the required range. There was sufficient perishable food for two days and nonperishable food for 7 days. An emergency food supply is kept in the kitchen and garage. Sharps are kept locked in a drawer in the kitchen, and cleaning supplies are kept locked in the garage. The smoke detectors and fire extinguisher are in working order. Nine smoke detectors and two carbon monoxide are all linked in all rooms and hallways located throughout the home. A fire extinguisher is in the kitchen. Medication is stored in locked cabinets in a small office. LPA reviewed the staff and clients files and they had all necessary forms. Four clients are non-verbal, and two speak with very limited ability. However, all clients appeared to be happy with the care they are receiving. The following documents are posted in the facility: facility license, emergency disaster plan, facility sketch, menu, and personal rights. LPA also observed hand sanitizer, lysol and disinfectants in various areas.

LPA reviewed the staff and clients files and they had all necessary forms. The Centrally Stored Medication Log and Medication Administration Records were both observed to be in locked cabinets in a small office. A review of Licensing Information System on June 23, 2021 indicates that all facility staff associated to the facility had DOJ, FBI and child abuse index check clearances. There were no deficiencies cited at today's inspection. Exit interview was conducted at 2:30 PM, and a copy of the report was emailed to Administrator Jane Gano.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cheyenne McCambridge conducted an unannounced inspection of the facility for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required inspection. LPA McCambridge met with Administrator Jane Gano. The Group Home is licensed to serve six clients, ages 12-17 years old. The current census is 6 ambulatory clients. Four clients are non-verbal, and two speak with very limited ability LPA McCambridge toured the facility both inside and out. At the time of the inspection, there were no clients and one staff present. The facility is a single level home, located in San Mateo, CA. The facility consists of five bedrooms, three for clients and two for staff. Staff bedrooms are located in front of the house and are not accessible to clients. There is one bathroom for staff in this area, however it is available to clients if needed. All three client rooms are located in the back of the house with a master bathroom. LPA observed at the time of this inspection, the facility to be clean, safe, and sanitary. Required documents are posted throughout the facility. LPA observed adequate lighting and space for clothing. The temperature inside the home is 71 degrees Fahrenheit which is in required temperature range, and the water temperature was 117 degrees, which is also in the required range. There was sufficient perishable food for two days and nonperishable food for 7 days. An emergency food supply is kept in the kitchen and garage. Sharps are kept locked in a drawer in the kitchen, and cleaning supplies are kept locked in the garage. The smoke detectors and fire extinguisher are in working order. Nine smoke detectors and two carbon monoxide are all linked in all rooms and hallways located throughout the home. A fire extinguisher is in the kitchen. Medication is stored in locked cabinets in a small office. LPA reviewed the staff and clients files and observed to be complete and current with all necessary forms.

LPA observed medication logs to be updated and current. There were no deficiencies cited at today's inspection. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was emailed to Administrator Jane Gano.

On 6/20/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a required annual inspection. LPA conducted a screening call with Administrator Jane Gano and met on site with Facility Manager Mariel Pablo. Administrator arrived shortly after LPA's arrival. The CARE Inspection Tool was used to complete this inspection. All residents were at school at the start of this visit. The faciity serves a developmentally disabled population. LPA conducted a tour of the facility and grounds, interviewed 2 staff, and reviewed 5 staff files and 5 resident files. Two residents arrived from school during the visit and were observed to be clean and dressed in clean, well-fitting clothes. Residents appeared very comfortable with staff, and staff were very attentive to residents and maintained strong supervision of, and engagement with, residents. LPA observed the facility site and grounds to be clean, organized, and free of hazards. Beds have clean linens, including mattress pads and top and bottom linens. Bedrooms are double-occupancy, and each resident has their own bed. The kitchen and bathroom were both in sanitary condition. Chemicals and dangerous items are locked away where inaccessible to the residents in care. Medications are stored appropriately and administration is logged appropriately. The kitchen is stocked with more than enough food to meet the needs of the residents in care. Hot water measured within permitted range. No deficiency citations were issued at today's visit. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Jane Gano, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 7/26/23 at 3PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) met with Administrator Jane Gano and Golden Gate Regional Center Case Manager Martha Tercero. The purpose of the meeting was to discuss the transition plan for residents whose ages exceed the licensed age range. Currently, the facility has 5 residents in care, and three are 18 or older, with one of these residents being age 22. The Licensing agency is not able to approve an age exception for residents 22 or older. The Administrator was previously advised that age exception requests for all residents 18 or older would need to be submitted. As of today, one request has been received, and two are still in progress. Licensee acknowledges that the facility is currently operating out of compliance and agrees to complete the following (refer to LIC 811 Confidential Names): - Licensee will work with R1's authorized representative to locate an adult home placement for resident R1 and transition R1 into new placement within 30 days, by Friday 8/25/23. - If R1 will not be moved to a new placement by 8/25/23, licensee will submit, by 8/25/23, a transition plan to have R1 moved out to an adult placement. - Licensee will submit age exception requests for R2 and R3 with support letters from authorized representatives. These will be submitted by 8/25/23. A copy of this report was provided to Administrator Jane Gano, who agreed to receive a digital copy, sign, and return to LPA.

On 6/14/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility for a required annual inspection. LPA met with House Lead Maria Pablo and informed of the purpose of the visit. LPA toured the facility site and inspected facility records. LPA observed the facility to be clean, dangerous items such as knives, chemicals, and medications were stored where only accessible to staff, and the bathroom and kitchen spaces were clean and sanitary. Resident bedrooms were tidy, offered activity space, and personal items were neatly folded and stored in the closets. LPA also observed residents to be dressed in clean, well-fitting clothes. All residents are nonverbal. LPA observed staff provide close supervision and engagement to each resident and to communicate effectively with each other in caring to each resident's needs as they ate lunch, engaged in individual activities, used the bathroom, and returned from school. LPA observed the resident records to be complete with required documentation. A continuation inspection is required to complete the review of personnel records. However, LPA verified that all staff on site have a background clearance and eligibility to work at the facility. As stated above, a continuation visit will be conducted. No deficiencies were observed during today's inspection. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were discussed, and a copy of this report was left with House Lead.

The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegations are found to be substantiated. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 6, Section 84078, Subsection (b). See attached LIC 9099-D. LPA informed the licensee that due to a violation resulting in serious bodily injury the Licensing Agency may assess an enhanced civil penalty. Should this occur, the licensee will be notified in writing. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and the licensee's appeal rights were provided to Facility Manager Mariel Pablo, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.
investigation_findings: 13On 10/15/24 at 11:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a complaint investigation visit at the facility in order to deliver investigation findings. LPA met with Facility Manager Mariel Pablo and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential observations, interviews, and record review, a nonverbal resident with limited mobility who requires one to one (1:1) supervision during waking hours was left unattended in their bedroom with the door closed for approximately 5 minutes. During this time, the resident sustained an arm fracture. Staff placed the resident on the hardwood floor of the bedroom, and when staff returned, they found a toy car near the resident that had not been present before. The door was closed to prevent other residents from entering the resident's bedroom. Other staff on shift were supervising the other residents in care and did not witness anyone else enter the resident's bedroom. The investigating parties believe the resident may have sustained the injury from falling on the toy car. On the basis of the resident requiring 1:1 supervision and being left unattended, LPA determined that the allegations are true.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision (b) The licensee shall provide those services identified in each child's needs and services plan... as necessary to meet the child's needs. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on observation, interview, and record review, licensee did not ensure provision of services in needs/services plan due to staff not providing required 1:1 supervision to resident who then sustained fracture while unattended. This poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to...

narrative: On November 22, 2024 (11/22/24) at 10AM, the Children's Residential Program San Jose Regional Office held a scheduled office meeting with the licensee at the San Bruno local unit licensing office. The purpose of the meeting was to discuss a recent complaint and the facility's compliance history. In attendance representing the licensing agency were Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Isabel Diego and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins, and representing the licensee were Administrator Jane Gano and Facility Manager Mariel Pablo. On 10/15/24, the Department of Social Services, Community Care Licensing Division concluded an investigation into the allegations that a child sustained an unexplained injury while in care and that facility staff did not ensure adequate care and supervision was provided to a child in care. The investigation found that non-ambulatory and non-verbal child C1 (See LIC 811 Confidential Names) sustained an arm fracture during a lapse in supervision. C1's care plan and Regional Center case manager indicated that C1 required one to one (1:1) supervision wherein one staff member provides direct care to solely C1. The investigation found that while the supervising staff member was aware of this requirement, they left C1 unattended for a period of approximately 5 minutes in C1's bedroom with the door closed. During this time, C1 sustained a fracture of the right proximal humerus bone. On 10/15/24, the Department issued substantiated findings and a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 6, Section 84078, Subsection (b). The incident and the reason for closing the door were discussed as well as the actions that the licensee has taken to retrain staff and to meet with the Regional Center case manager to confirm staff retraining on C1's care needs. LPM and LPA also discussed the plan of correction developed on 10/15/24 and the licensee's satisfactory completion of the plan of correction. LPMand LPA also discussed the possibility of an assessment of civil penalties due to the nature of the incident and explained the civil penalty process. A copy of this report was provided to with licensee, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On December 13, 2024 (12/13/24) at 11:15AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins met with Administrator and Director Jane Gano at the facility. The purpose of the visit was to meet with Jane to discuss the assessment of an Enhanced Civil Penalty. On 10/15/24, the Department of Social Services, Community Care Licensing Division concluded an investigation into the allegations that a child sustained an unexplained injury while in care and that facility staff did not ensure adequate care and supervision was provided to a child in care. The investigation found that non-ambulatory and non-verbal child C1 (See LIC 811 Confidential Names) sustained an arm fracture during a lapse in supervision. C1's care plan and Regional Center case manager indicated that C1 required one to one (1:1) supervision wherein one staff member provides direct care to solely C1. The investigation found that while the supervising staff member was aware of this requirement, they left C1 unattended for a period of approximately 5 minutes in C1's bedroom with the door closed. During this time, C1 sustained a fracture of the right proximal humerus bone. On 10/15/24, the Department issued substantiated findings and a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 6, Section 84078, Subsection (b). The Department has concluded an analysis of applicable laws and regulations and has determined that an Enhanced Civil Penalty is warranted for a violation resulting in serious bodily injury. Therefore, on this date, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1548(f)(1)(C), the Department has issued a civil penalty of $2,500. See attached LIC 421. The above information and appeal rights were discussed during the meeting, and a copy of this LIC 809 report, the LIC 811, the LIC 421, and the licensee's appeal rights were provided to Administrator and Director Jane Gano, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

investigation_findings: 13On 3/21/25, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a complaint investigation visit in order to deliver investigation findings. LPA met with Facility Manager Mariel Pablo and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential interviews, observation, and record review, a client in care sustained injuries to the face and hands. The injuries were photographed and appeared to be minor. No witnesses observed the cause of the injuries, and the client is nonverbal. The client's care plan indicates the client has eczema and skin-picking behavior. No injuries had been observed by staff but once made aware of the injuries, the facility staff were prompt in their follow-up, including cleansing the client's injuries and speaking with identified potential witnesses. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, based on LPA’s observations and interviews, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and the licensee's appeal rights was provided to Facility Manager Mariel Pablo.

narrative: On 6/11/25, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a required annual inspection. LPA met with Administrator Jane Gano and informed of the purpose of the visit. Using the CARE Inspection Tool, LPA inspected the facility site and grounds and reviewed 5 staff files and 4 client records. LPA observed the facility site and grounds to be maintained in safe condition. There is a large supply of food in the refrigerator, freezers, and cabinets. Bathrooms and kitchen are sanitary. There are three double-occupancy bedrooms, currently sleeping four clients. There are activities and toys available to the clients. LPA observed client records and staff records to be complete. Clients' medications are stored appropriately and medication administration records reflect correct administration. Staff have current first aid and crisis intervention training. All clients in care are nonverbal/non-conversational, so LPA did not conduct any client interviews. LPA did not conduct staff interviews due to time and staff being preoccupied with assigned job duties. LPA conducted observations of all clients and present staff. Staff contact information and schedule were obtained. No deficiency citations were issued at today's inspection. Two areas where technical assistance may be beneficial were noted. See LIC 9102s dated 6/11/25. See also LIC 811 Confidential Names dated 6/11/25. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report, attachments, and licensee's appeal rights were provided to Administrator.

investigation_findings: 13On 7/18/25, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted an unannounced complaint investigation visit at the facility. LPA met with Staff Norman Mabulay and informed of the purpose of the visit. The purpose of the visit was to deliver findings for the investigation of the above allegation. LPA conducted 1 confidential interview. Based on all confidential interviews, observations, and record review, the allegation pertains to black bruising around a nonverbal client’s eyes. The client had seizure activity a few days prior to the observation of bruising and also engaged in head-banging self-injurious behavior. The client was observed interacting with staff and did not show signs of neglect, abuse, or discomfort around staff. The facility took the client to the hospital in a timely manner in response to the seizure. Facility staff reportedly did not observe the bruising, but upon being made aware of the bruising, staff consulted medical professionals and took the client to the doctor for assessment. SEE NEXT PAGE

narrative: The investigation revealed C1 has a history of frequent falls requiring medical attention for sutures on and around the head and face area. Medical records show an MRI was ordered on 6/7/19, the MRI was re-ordered on 9/10/19, and a helmet and wheelchair were ordered on 9/10/19 as well. The MRI was completed on 11/27/19. A second follow-up MRI was re-ordered by Dr Boyd on 1/23/2020. Per Care Coordinator, the MRI ordered on 1/23/2020 was not completed as of 6/12/20. Further, an x-ray of client’s right shoulder was ordered on 5/15/20, there is no record of an x-ray completed as of 6/12/2020. The client received a baseline EEG on 6/25/20 at Children’s Hospital in Oakland but was a no-show for the 1:00 pm appointment on 7/27/2020 in the neurology department. Staff confirmed the client’s medical needs became greater than the facility could met, therefore a plan to relocate the youth was initiated. Staff stated the youth wore a protective helmet when reminded by staff. Medical records indicate the following occurred: on 12/14/19 skin above the eyebrow was glued after a cut from a fall and on 1/10/20 youth received 2 staples to the head; both incidents occurred at school. On 5/15/20 medical care was sought for right shoulder pain after a fall, an x-ray was order but youth did not go to the appointment. On 6/2/20 youth required 6 staples to the head after falling in the facility. On 1/23/20 Dr. Boyd ordered a new helmet for better protection. As of 6/12/20 records indicate C1 last received a helmet in September 2019. Based on interviews conducted and medical records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the allegations that staff did not follow up on medical appointments and the proper care was not provided are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. The facility is cited under Title 22 Group Homes, Division 6, Chapter 5, Section 84072(d) - Personal Rights and Section 84078 - Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. An exit interview was conducted with Rhonda Reid. A copy of this report and of the Appeal Rights are being provided to the facility.
