The complaint investigation was reassigned to LPA Robin Sullivan on 5/7/2020. LPA Sullivan reviewed the facility’s history of relevant incident reports, complaints, Needs and Services and medical records. Individuals interviewed as part of this investigation were three staff, the client, and the Care Coordinator between 6/2/20 – 8/11/2020.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: PERSONAL RIGHTS (d) The licensee shall ensure that each child…is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code section 16001.9. [WIC (4) To receive medical, dental, vision, and mental health services.] This requirement was not met as evidenced by the following: Based on medical records, facility did not ensure client was taken to scheduled medical appointments. This poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to clients in care.

Responsibility for providing care and supervision (b)The licensee shall provide those services identified in each child's needs and services plan and in the individualized health care plan for each child with special health care needs as necessary to meet the child's needs. This requirement was not met as evidenced by the following: Based on medical records the facility did not ensure the child received and wore proper protective head gear to meet health care needs. This poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk clients in care.

narrative: An unannounced annual required inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tana Kinder on 12/06/2021 at 11:15 AM. LPA Kinder confirmed prior to the inspection that no staff or clients were experiencing health symptoms related to Covid19. Criminal record clearances were reviewed, and the facility is in compliance. The licensing fees are current. Community Care Licensing file, unusual incident reports, facility roster, facility profile and complaint history were reviewed prior to inspecting the facility. The Group Home is licensed for 4 youth and has 2 youth currently placed. There are 7 staff members currently working at the facility. The facility is in the process of hiring 2 additional staff for Sunday shifts. LPA reviewed 5 staff files. Files reviewed were incomplete. 2 child files were also reviewed. Documentation included emergency contact information, date of placement and personal rights. The charts were complete. The facility was inspected jointly with LPA and Administrator, Rhonda Reid, and the facility is in compliance. A copy of the license, personal rights and emergency exit plan are prominently posted. Client and staff files are in locked cabinets, located in the office. Smoke detectors are in working order, there is a carbon monoxide monitor located in the hallway. A fully charged fire extinguisher is located in the entry and laundry room. There are 4 bedrooms with 1 bed in each bedroom. Each client is provided with a bed, dresser, closet space and a night stand. The 2 bedrooms in use had personal affects. There is 1 bathroom accessible to the clients. There is a hall closet with additional linen if needed for the bedrooms and the bathroom. The kitchen was accessible by the clients. There is a monthly menu posted that is being followed. There was enough perishable/non-perishable food for 2 clients to last 3/8 days. LPA tested the water temperature at multiple faucet locations the reading was between 107.1-110.8 degrees. There is a back patio area, accessible by the youth. The walkway from the front to the back of the facility was clear. The facility vehicle has current insurance and registration. Exit interview conducted and discussed with Rhonda Reid, Administrator, and a copy of the inspection report was provided, including violations and technical violations.

Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Tana Kinder conducted an unannounced inspection for the purpose of reviewing documentation for the technical violations from the Annual Inspection dated 12/6/2021. LPA reviewed the documentation for staff and client files. The documentation is consistent with CCL regulation requirements. No citations were issued. A copy of this report was provided to the facility.

Documentation will be submitted prior to the pre-inspection. All clients (3) have been moved from the current facility to appropriate placements that were coordinated with the Regional Center and their families. There was no evidence of clients living on the premises. All personal belongings and furnishings were removed. No citations were issued. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided.

However, reporting party stated, the facility has been low on food and has photos to that were printed out to show the lack of food. S1 stated since they had a change of management there has been a lack of food in the facility. LPA Villapudua-Soto reviewed the pictures provided with the complaint and while they do show an almost bare refrigerator, the LPA was not able to determine the circumstances surrounding the pictures or the reliability of the pictures”. Due to LPA Moreno and LPA Villapudua-Soto observations and inconsistent statements and lack of corroborating evidence the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur. investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ignacia Villapudua-Soto conducted a complaint investigation inspection via tele-visit with Richard Herrera, Administrator on October 13, 2020 beginning at 10:25 AM. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver complaint investigation findings. Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that Facility is not providing adequate food to residents. LPA Cynthia Moreno conducted a file review on 05/14/20. LPA Cynthia Moreno obtained grocery receipts and photos of the facilities via email. LPA Moreno conducted a joint tele-visit inspection with House Manager inside and out. LPA Moreno did not find any deficiencies or issued any citations at that time. During the investigation process, LPA Moreno interviewed House Manager, Director, reporting party, S1 and S2. LPA Villapudua-Soto interviewed the House Manager, S2, C1, and C3. C-2 was not verbal enough to give a statement to LPA. House Manager and S2 denied that they have been low on food at the facility. S2 stated, I order the facility food supply from Walmart online and we pick up the food on a weekly basis. S2 produced grocery receipts and emailed them to LPA. House Manager and Director stated, the home is always well stocked with food. House Manager stated, if S2 goes on vacation, then I will monitor the food supply and make the orders at Walmart for the week. LPA interviewed C1 and C3; C1 and C3 stated, that they never experienced a lack of food and have not heard any discussion in the home that there isn’t enough food.

narrative: All incident reports were documented and sent out properly. Medication logs were audited daily, and all medicine was verified and double checked by another staff member before administering to clients. All staff members have certification to administer medication to clients. Staff client ratios were met and scheduled according to the census of the facility LPA observed medication timers and medication logs filled out on time and signed. Facility has a checks and balances system for administering medication to the clients. No errors were found in medication logs. Staff schedule always had over the client to staff ratio scheduled. LPA found that the allegation was UNSUBSTAINTIATED. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. A copy of this report was left with administrator Jai Thompson

LPA conducted interviews on 11/20/23, 11/21/23, 2/28/24, and 3/5/24 with the reporting party, four staff and observed the client due to them not being able to participate in an interview. Three out of five confidential interviews reported the client is well groomed and has difficulties allowing the staff to trim their nails due to their diagnosis. Records reviewed showed the client’s nails are checked daily and from 6/20/22-8/21/23 the client had marks on their neck on five separate occasions from being self-inflicted. One the day in question, the client had gotten into make-up and it had stained their skin. LPA observed the client to be well groomed and their fingernails did not appear long or uncut. Based on LPA’s observations, interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur. No title 22 regulations were cited during today’s inspection. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was left with Marissa Corral Administrator.

On 12/7/23 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman met with Amanda Gulley, Senior Director, for the purpose of conducting a case management inspection. After a review of Kavere Services Pine Brook, Pinetown and Princeton facility’s January - July 2023 incident reports for 17 separate medication errors for the Kavere Services Pine Brook, Pinetown and Princeton facilities LPA discovered seven occurred while the clients were on home visits, one occurred while the clients were at school, eight occurred in the facility due to staff errors and one incident occurred at the facility and at school. LPA reviewed the 17 incident reports and the Kavere Medication Policy PowerPoint Slides, three client’s medication logs. LPA observed the PowerPoint has 72 slides and observed some slides have information that is duplicated on multiple slides, some information is inconsistent such as the number of Medication Rights varies between five to eight. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tana Kinder conducted an announced pre licensing inspection with the President, Regional Administrator and Senior Administrator on 2/24/2023 at 10:30 am at the facility. LPA conducted the walk through of the facility with the above named staff and observed 4 bedrooms, 1 garage, 2 common areas, 3 bathrooms, a kitchen, laundry room, staff office and a locked walk-in closet for medication, staff and client files and client funds. All spaces were clean, sanitary, free of insects, and had unobstructed pathways. LPA observed the refrigerator was 31 degrees and the freezer was 0 degrees. The hot water from the kitchen sink was 119.3 degrees. The facility does not utilize protective separation rooms. All the bedrooms are furnished with a bed, dresser, night stand, closet, beanbag chair and are well-lit. One bedroom is set up for 2 clients and the others are for one client. The front yard and back yard are fenced in with an accessible gate to the front of the property. The grounds have a recreation area with a basketball hoop, and a secured swing set that will be set up by April. There is a concrete patio area. There are 2 patio tables in the garage that will be assembled by April to be placed on the patio. There are 4 cameras on the outside of the facility. There are no inside cameras at the facility. The water source is well water that has been analyzed and is safe for consumption. There are 2 fully charged fire extinguishers, one on the first floor, one on the second floor. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide monitor are linked and in working order. There are locked storage cabinets in the garage. There is a shed in the backyard that is empty. A lock will be put on it. The backyard is fenced off with extra yard on the other side that is not accessible to the clients at this time. On the other side of the locked side yard there are 2 locked workshops that are not in use or accessible to the clients. The facility is using a mini-van to transport clients. There are currently no clients at the facility. Continued...

LPA has observed the following that need to be brought into compliance before issuance of the license: Expand facility sketch Post Grievance policy Lock on office closet LPA suggested the following: Move knives from hutch Remove glass from hutch and cabinet doors Remove lock from 3rd cabinet in laundry room LPA reviewed the following forms with the facility staff:

On 04/15/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lyta Vue arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Marissa Corral, Program Manager. The purpose of the visit was to conduct a Required Annual Inspection of the facility. This is the first Annual inspection for the facility and a Pre-Licensing was done on 08/31/23. LPA utilized the CARE Tool to complete the Annual inspection. The facility is licensed to provide treatment services for ambulatory children ages six (6) to Seventeen (17) years. The facility currently has (0) clients. Zero (0) client was present during the inspection. The facility is licensed for a maximum capacity of five (5). Staff to client ratio is depended on how many clients. For one (1) client, there will be staff working 168 hours per week and for two (2) clients, there will be staff working 224 hours per week, LPA conducted an inspection of the physical plant and checked for all necessary requirements. The facility had no noticeable odor and maintained an acceptable room temperature. There are a total of four (4) bedrooms available for clients, with one (1) bedroom being a shared bedroom of two (2) clients. The fifth bedroom is used for a locked staff office. LPA observed the client bedrooms, living room, kitchen, three (3) bathrooms, the backyard, the garage, and the staff office to be clean and organized. LPA observed each client bedrooms to have a closet, a dresser, and a clean mattress. Sheets, blankets, and pillows were in good condition. No bedrooms were decorated yet because the facility currently does not have any placement. LPA observed a locked staff office with a locked closet where files and medications will be stored. LPA observed the proper postings including facility license, complaint hotline, menu, and emergency disaster plan. Smoke alarms were in working order, fire extinguishers were current, and a first aid kit was fully stocked. The facility has no outstanding fees. LPA observed some snack items in cabinets but did not observe any food in the kitchen and in the additional refrigerator in the garage because the facility does not have any placement yet. Report continued on 809c

Disinfectants and cleaning solutions will be made inaccessible and will be locked in locked cabinets in the garage. There will be extra non-perishable food stored in a pantry in the garage. LPA reviewed zero 0 client files due to the facility not having any placement yet. LPA reviewed zero (0) staff files due to no hired staff yet. LPA interviewed zero (0) staff on site. LPA interviewed zero (0) clients. The facility has no placement and no hired staff. No citations were given on this date. A signed copy of this LIC-809 and LIC 809c report was provided to Marissa Corral, Program Manager.

On August 19, 2024 Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Sarina Buchannan and Sara Luman-Gonzalez arrived at the Kavere Services Cherryland Home. LPAs were greeted by Marissa Corral who granted LPAs access. LPA's conducted a tour of the inside and outside of the facility where LPA's observed the following deficiencies: · Part of the chain link fence in the backyard is sticking out exposing metal. LPA Buchannan received pictures from the facility on 8/27/24 showing that the part of the chain link that was exposing metal has now been removed and the remainder of the fence is in good repair. On September 12, 2024 LPA Luman-Gonzalez observed the broken portion of the chain link fence was removed and is in compliance. · The rear fence gate to the remainder of acreage is unlocked exposing debris and unused building material. LPA Buchannan received pictures from the facility on 8/27/24 showing the fence now has a lock on it and acreage is no longer accessible to clients in care. On September 12, 2024 LPA Luman-Gonzalez observed a lock to be on the gate blocking the rear acreage. · Pieces of metal are on the ground along the fence line exposing sharp metal. LPAs Buchannan and Luman-Gonzalez observed the metal be removed while at the facility on August 19, 2024. On September 12, 2024 LPA Luman Gonzalez confirmed the metal to be removed and the area is in compliance. · One bottle of cleaning product was left under the sink without a lock. LPA Buchannan received pictures from the facility on 8/27/24 showing the administrator informed staff of the mandatory training and screen shots of staff taking the training via Zoom. On September 12, 2024 LPA Luman-Gonzalez observed all cleaning products to be locked up and in compliance. (See LIC 9102 TV) This case management that was initially open on August 19, 2024 is now closed. The facility is in full compliance. An exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was left with Marissa Corral.

Lastly, LPA Buchannan was unable to gather any further information from the reporting party due to them being anonymous and not having any contact information for them. Although the allegation may have happened or may be valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. Exit interview conducted, copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were discussed and provided to the licensee.
investigation_findings: 13On September 12, 2024 at 12:32 P.M., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sara Luman-Gonzalez made an unannounced visit to deliver findings to the above Group Home and met with Marissa Corral, Facility Administrator. Prior to the meeting LPA Buchannan conducted the 10-day inspection of the Group Home on 8/19/2024. No deficiencies were cited during that inspection. LPA Buchannan requested the following documents: staff rosters, staff schedule, staff training hours, and client face sheets. LPA Buchannan attempted 1 confidential interview and conducted 7 interviews between 8/19/2024-8/28/2024. Based on evidence obtained and confidential interviews conducted during the investigation process the above allegation cannot be substantiated. 6 out of 7 interviews confirmed that they have never seen, heard, or witnessed any facility staff vaping or smoking on the premises. LPA Buchannan also confirmed during the inspection that there was no designated smoking area at the facility

narrative: 6 out of 8 interviews confirmed that the staff member accidentally touched the client’s stomach while extending their hand to prevent the client from leaving without permission. LPA Buchannan also found that due to the client’s trauma history, they can react strongly to any type of touch, perceiving it as harmful. This can lead the client to fabricate stories about the staff who triggered these feelings. Finally, the client stated that the touch was unintentional, explaining that they walked into the staff member's hand, but that they viewed it as a harmful touch. Although the allegation may have happened or may be valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. Exit interview conducted, copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were discussed and provided to the licensee

narrative: On March 20, 2025 at approximately 11:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zaria Turner, made an unannounced visit to the above Group Home. LPA Turner met with Facility Administrator, Justin Ma'ae. During the visit, LPA Turner was notified of a recent change in the administration at the facility on March 17, 2025. The department was not notified of the change. According to regulation, Reporting Requirements-84061(e) Effective January 1, 2000, the licensee shall notify the Department, in writing, within ten (10) days of any change in the facility administrator. (f) The licensee shall notify the licensing agency in writing within ten business days of acquiring a new member of the board of directors. The notification shall include the following: (1) Name and residence and mailing addresses of the new administrator. (2) Date he/she assumed his/her position. (3) Description of his/her background and qualifications, including documentation of required education and administrator certification. This case management will remain open until all required documentation needed to formalize the change of administrator has been completed and submitted to the assigned LPA, Sarina Buchannan, via email. An exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was left with Justin Ma'ae, Facility Administrator.

An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie on 04/30/2025 at 10:00 am. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Goldie met with Justin Maae, Administrator and inspected the facility inside and out. LPA reviewed 1 of 1 child’s records and 5 of 5 staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPA reviewed 1 of 1 child’s psychotropic medications and medication records. LPA interviewed 5 of 5 of staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA interviewed 1 of 1 children currently prescribed psychotropic medication. During the inspection the LPA observed one type B deficiency (see attached 809D page). LPA Goldie cited California Code of Regulations Division 6 Chapter 5 84070(b)(15) Children's Records). LPA Goldie issued one technical violation. This is not a deficiency. LPA conducted exit interview with Justin Maae, Administrator. LPA discussed and provided a copy of documents and appeal rights

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Children's Records 84070(b)The following information regarding the child shall be obtained...A copy of the current court order... for each psychotropic medication, as defined in Section 84001(p)(4).This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interview, observation and records reviewed, it was observed that one of one client's (C1) JV 220 form was expired which poses a potential risk to health, safety and/or personal rights risk to persons in care.

narrative: On May 8, 2025, at 2:30 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan arrived unannounced at the above facility for the purpose of conducting a management inspection. LPA met with Betty Saeyang, Lead Staff, who assisted LPA with the inspection. LPA conducted a walk-through of the facility, and no deficiencies were noted. On April 9, 2025, the facility received an email dated April 6, 2025 with a number of allegations regarding staff and safety of client in care. LPA was informed that the facility was unaware that the information was reportable and therefore did not report to CCL in a timely manner. Facility also stated that the Regional Center had begun an investigation and the original report was addressed to CCL therefore, they believed CCL was already informed. However due to reports not being submitted timely, a technical violation was issued to address the concern. This Case Management is now closed. The facility is being issued a technical violation for Reporting requirements. (see LIC 9102 TV). Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report and provided to the Betty Saeyang, Lead Staff.

On 4/28/2025 at 11:30 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan made an unannounced visit with the purpose of conducting an annual inspection to the above facility using the Compliance and Regulatory Enforcement (CARE) tool. LPA met with Justin Maae, Facility Administrator and a walk through of the interior and exterior was completed. Physical Plant Room 1 is is a staff office with a copier, bathroom, and closet containing client files and medications and is inaccessible to clients. There is a hallway outside of the office which has 3 locked closets that contain cleaning products and extra toiletries. Room 2 is a living room with 4 couches, 1 TV, and board games. Room 4 is a client bedroom with a twin bed, a dresser, and a night stand. Room 5 is a dining room with a table that seats 6, cotton ball intervention program, and a sliding door leading to the backyard. Room 6 is the kitchen which is connected to the washer dryer area, a client bathroom, and a garage. Room 7 is a client bedroom with a twin bed, 2 dressers, and a night stand. Room 8 is a client bedroom with a twin bed, dresser, and night stand. Room 9 is a loft and has a TV and a desk for activities. Room 10 is a client bedroom with a bed dresser and a night stand. The upstairs hallways has a closet with client toiletries and a bathroom. There are three total bathrooms, one located in the staff office area with a working toilet, and running warm water with a temperature of 115 degrees. There other two bathrooms are client bathrooms with working toilets and running warm water with a temperature of 115 degrees. (report continued on LIC 809C)

The backyard is gated with a basketball court, swing set, and a gazebo with a bench. The backyard is clear of debris and clean. The garage has a fooseball table, swing, and a deep freezer. There is a 2020 Chrysler Pacifica Hybrid in good working condition, properly maintained, lights, tires, registration/insurance and working seat belts and is available to transport clients if needed. The following required documents were posted, License and Personal Rights. Disinfectants/cleaning solutions inaccessible to children in care. Refrigerator Temperature at or below 45 degrees. Nonperishable foods one week and fresh perishable foods two days minimum. Menu present and posted in the kitchen area on the fridge. Working telephone is available at the facility. Carbon monoxide and smoke detectors are in working order. First Aid Kit fully stocked. Medication centrally stored, locked/inaccessible to children. Hot water between 105–120 degrees Fahrenheit. Fire Extinguisher up to date and in working order. Toilets wash basin, bath, and shower fixtures in good repair/no leaks/hot water temperature. Soap and Paper towels are available to clients. Bedrooms required linen and furnishings are fully stocked. Facility free of vermin. The following domains were also reviewed during today’s inspection, Operations, Disaster Preparedness, Staffing, Emergency Intervention, and Client Records. A total of 5 staff files and 4 client files were reviewed. LPA also conducted 3 client interviews, 2 staff interviews, and attempted 1 client interview. A review of the Licensing Information System indicates the facility is up to date on their facility fees. All the staff were fingerprint cleared to the facility. Based on confidential interviews conducted there are no concerns for follow up were noted.

On July 10, 2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan made an unannounced follow up case management inspection at the above facility and met with Carlos Cotto, Direct Support Professional, who assisted LPA with the inspection. A walk through of the interior and exterior of the facility was conducted and no deficiencies were noted. On July 3, 2025 (LPA) Sarina Buchannan initiated a case management to follow up regarding an incident that took place in May 2025 in which a client was asked to clean their room before school and when they did not comply their tablet was taken away. Based on interviews conducted and documentation obtained it was confirmed that staff do follow the appropriate procedures as outlined by the clients’ individualized placement plan (IPP). The IPP states that the staff are allowed to inform clients that they will not earn time on the facility tablets if they do not complete certain tasks or engage in certain behaviors. LPA also confirmed that the facility does not take away facility tablets as a form of discipline and once clients have earned time it also cannot be taken away. In addition, LPA was unable to confirm the date the alleged incident took place and the client involved stated the facility does not take away their electronics. No further investigation is needed. This case management is now closed. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Carlos Cotto, Direct Support Professional.

On July 10, 2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan made an unannounced follow up case management inspection at the above facility and met with Carlos Cotto, Direct Support Professional, who assisted LPA with the inspection. A walk through of the interior and exterior of the facility was conducted and no deficiencies were noted. On May 27, 2025 CCL received an incident report with the same date in which staff did not administer three of a client’s morning medications. LPA requested the following documentation: Medication Log for May 27th, 2025, staff roster with contact information, staff medication training for staff in question, write ups for staff in question, and a copy of the related incident report. Based on interviews conducted and documentation obtained it was confirmed that the client missed three doses of their prescribed medication on May 27, 2025. LPA was informed that there was a communication error between staff, and they believed the medication had already been administered. During the afternoon shift medication audit staff notified the Facility Administrator of the error. The facility immediately interviewed both staff involved and followed protocol by reporting the appropriate parties. Also, the facility immediately gave both staff involved 2-day suspension and conducted medication training's with both staff on June 3, 2025. Due to the medication errors, facility is being cited a Type A violation (See LIC 809D). This case management that was initially open on July 3, 2025 is now closed. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Carlos Cotto, Direct Support Professional.

Based on evidence gathered and confidential interviews conducted during the investigation, the allegations above cannot be substantiated because there were inconsistent statements throughout the investigation process. 7 out of 9 interviews stated that staff do have an appropriate relationship with clients. It was confirmed that in December 2022 an incident occurred in which a staff member took a client to their family gathering. However, it was also verified that this incident took place at a different facility, where the staff member was employed and the client resided at the time, not at the above facility. In addition, LPA was unable to confirm or deny instances of staff taking clients to their home to complete labor, or the client doing any labor while at the family gathering. Also, the investigation was unable to prove or disprove that the facility staff were being discouraged from and not reporting incidents in a timely manner. LPA could not confirm details regarding incidents, or dates of the incidents, which were not being reported. Also, the facility confirmed that there were no formal complaints from staff regarding them being discouraged from reporting and all staff interviewed stated they felt they could report incidents. Lastly, LPA could not determine whether staff mismanaged clients’ money and then falsified minors’ records. LPA could not establish a time frame in which clients’ money was allegedly mismanaged causing staff to falsify the related documentation. Also, a record review did not show any errors in client funds or any missing receipts during the time frame of March 1, 2025, to May 7, 2025. Although the allegations may have happened or may be valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. Exit interview conducted, copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were discussed and provided to the licensee.

On 2/2/23 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman met with Marissa Corral Administrator for the purpose of a Case Management Inspection from two incidents that occurred on 1/29/23 regarding medication errors. LPA conducted record reviews of two client files. On 1/29/23 staff failed to conduct a medication audit to verify if the correct amount of medication was given during a home visit. This medication audit was not conducted until 1/31/23 causing the facility to report the incident later than is required by regulation. Facility is cited Facility citation violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, regulation 80061(b) Reporting Requirements. Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in (1) below, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours. In addition, a written report containing the information specified in (2) below shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence. LPA provided a copy of this report to Marissa Corral Administrator on this date.

On 3/5/24 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman met with Sonia Gomez, House Lead, for the purpose of a case management inspection regarding an incident that occurred on 12/12/23. During the Case Management investigation LPA interviewed eight staff and two clients. During the investigation it was determined that the restraint was justified per California Code of Regulations, Title 22 regulation 84300(b) as the client was exhibiting assaultive behavior exposing an immediate danger to themselves or others. facility_name: KAVERE SERVICES INC, PINETOWN CRISIS HOME
narrative: VRMC Admission Agreement, Facility Admission Agreement, and Incident Reports for two youths in care. For one youth, LPA requested the following for review: Needs and Services Plan, Photos of injuries, Weekly Case Notes, description of Injuries, and medical documentation. No serious concerns noted. Confidential interviews were conducted with seven individuals, two children, and five adults, and attempted with two adults during the period of 9/18/2024 to 10/21/2024. An investigation was conducted regarding the allegation: Minor sustained unexplained injuries while in care. Five out seven interviews conducted were consistent that minor did not sustain the injuries while in care. S1, S2, S3, S4, and C2 reported that C1 did not sustain bruising in care but would have normal bruising. C1 is non-verbal, has a history of self-injurious behavior and would go on home visits frequently. Additionally, documents reviewed, including Weekly Case Notes, description of Injuries and Needs and Services plan supports the allegation may not have happened. The facility noted all bruises that were visible on the minor and documented the bruising before and after the child was in care. Based on LPA interviews conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur. An exit interview was conducted with and a copy of this report was provided to Marissa Corral, Administrator.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shoua Xiong conducted an unannounced tele-inspection visit to the facility on 1/04/221 beginning at 4:15 pm. LPA spoke with the Administrator Najon Saina and explained the purpose of today's contact was to conduct a Case Management regarding an incident report that the department received. on 12/28/20. The date of the incident was 12/27/20 in which a youth reported their thumb being injured by a staff. On today's date, LPA interviewed the Administrator and conducted an interview of the youth. LPA was unable to interview the staff named in this allegation as they had been placed on leave. LPA will contact staff on a different date and time. Further interviews need to be conducted to determine if further investigations and actions is needed by the Department. Exit interview and a copy of this report was sent to the Administrator via email for signature.

During interviews with staff, AD stated that C1 did not share much information but did name S1 as the staff who had bent their thumb back and was the staff who had placed their knee on C1 during a containment. Staff S1 stated they only worked with C1 maybe about 3 times and did recall one day in particular that C1 had alot of behavior episodes. However, S1 stated they have never placed C1 in a containment before and denied having bent C1’s thumb or placing their knees on C1. Staff S2 who was present during this shift stated that at no point was C1 placed in a containment. S2 stated that S1 did not injure C1 and did not witness S1 bending C1’s thumb or placing their legs/knees on C1’s body. In an interview with BB, they stated that C1 reported that a male staff had placed their knee on C1 but that C1 did not provide a name or provide details of the event. LPA attempted to interview C1 twice but C1 refused to speak to LPA. During review of the police report, C1 refused to be interviewed by local law enforcement officers. In reviewing C1's file, although C1 had previous containment incidents prior to the date of this allegation, none involved the staff S1. Based on LPA’s observations, interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur. No title 22 regulations were cited during today’s inspection. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report along with Appeal Rights was emailed to Najon Saina, Administrator, with a request for the report to be signed and returned electronically to LPA.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shoua Xiong conducted an unannounced inspection visit to the facility on 10/20/21 beginning at 12:00 PM. LPA met with Najon Saina, Administrator, and explained the purpose of the visit was to conduct an Annual/Required inspection of the facility. At the time of this visit, present in the home was one client in care, two staff members, and the Administrator. On today's date, LPA completed a physical inspection of the home, inside and outside. This facility is a two story home with three client bedrooms, one office room with a bathroom, two client bathrooms, a living room, kitchen, garage, and a front and back yard area. The locked staff office was observed to contain staff and client files. There are current two clients placed in the facility. Each client was provided their own bedroom with beddings, dressers, closet space, and lamps. Smoke detectors were operational and observed in bedrooms, office, hallways, and the common area. There is a charged and serviced fire extinguisher, working carbon monoxide detector, and a complete first aid kit with a manual present in the facility. The facility's water temperature was tested and was within the required range of 105-120 degrees F. The facility was observed with the required two days' worth of perishable and seven days' worth of non-perishable food items. The facility was observed to have an extra refrigerator and pantry shelf in the garage for extra food supplies. The outside areas was observed to be well maintained and free of safety hazards. On today's date, LPA reviewed ten staff files. All staff files were found to be complete with the required documents present. LPA was unable to finish the Annual inspection and will return on another date and time to continue the inspection. No deficiencies were cited on today's date. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was given to Najon Saina, Administrator.

On today's date, LPA completed the rest of the inspection along with reviewing two client files. During client file review, LPA observed that each file was complete with the required documentation. LPA interviewed three staff members and one client in care. LPA was unable to interview the second client as they were currently still at school. The second client is also non-verbal. On 10/13/22, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Uchenna Ajaero, paid an unannounced annual/required inspection visit and met with the facility administrator (AD), Kate Rush. LPA Ajaero introduced herseld to the AD and informed her of the purpose of the visit. Entrance checklist was provided to the administrator. The licensing fees are current. The facility is licensed for 2 youths and has 2 youths currently placed. The facility has a third bed in the case of an emergency. At 12:45 am we toured the bedrooms and they were neat. The beds were made, they had sheets, bed covers, comforter and top sheet with 2 pillows. The rooms were bright and lighted, the dressers were neat and closed appropriately, there were clothes hanging in the closet and more clothes folded away in the dressers. In the hall way there were clean folded linens, towels and personal toiletries. AD checked the alarm in the rooms and hall way and we observed that they all worked. At 1:05 am, we toured the kitchen. It was clean and organized. There were fresh fruits on the counter for the residents. The fridge was clean, there were no open foods. There was perishable food for about two days and nonperishable food for about 5 days in the kitchen area and more in the garage. There were client's rights poster on the wall, the youths activities and a menu on the refrigerator. AD stated she has clients who are traumatized by the wording of the Foster Kids on the current personal rights poster so she has a smaller sized current version from the Department of Social Services site posted alternatively. Continued on next page.

At 1:25 am we inspected the garage. It was clean. There was hand washing sink in the garage, cleaning supplies were locked up in a cabinet, there was an extra fire extinguisher in the garage, there was a fridge with perishable food items and boxes of emergency foods and house items. At 4:00 pm LPA Ajaero interviewed AD, and S1, FY1 and FY2. LPA reviewed Community Care Licensing file, unusual incident reports, facility roster, facility profile and complaint history. LPA reviewed 2 client files. All documents were compliant per regulations. No deficiency is cited today. The annual required investigation is not complete. The Department has investigated the complaint that facility staff inappropriately restrained a minor. When discussing restraints with the clients, staff and other individuals, the youth are restrained only when they are a danger to themselves or other individuals in the home, it is a last resort and other de-escalation techniques have failed. A copy of Kavere Services Emergency Interventions Plan is located within the Program Statement which outline the use of restraints. The Reporting Party (RP) was following up on the use of restrains to confirm whether it was against regulations, which was determined that the home can use restraints. This was determined by Pro Act training records, Program Statement, Emergency Intervention Plan, and confidential interviews. On December 27, 2023, C1 was restrained using the prone method (restrained person is on their stomach) by staff and the restrain lasted for five minutes and C1 had no marks. The reporting party stated that a second incident occurred on December 29, 2023, where the prone method was used again by staff and C1 was restrained for five minutes, and no marks were observed. Later the same day, December 29th, C1 was restrained again using the prone method by staff C1 was restrained for two minutes, released and no marks were observed. When clients are restrained, the staff is watching their breathing and talking with them. The reason C1 was restrained was due to self-harming and staff aggression. This agency has investigated the complaint regarding the above allegation. We have found that the complaint was Unsubstantiated, meaning that the allegation was false, could not have happened and/or is without a reasonable basis. No title 22 regulations were cited during today’s inspection. A copy of this report and appeal rights were given to the agency.

The Administrator stated that they did not take the client's laptop, and only asked the client if they could charge the laptop while the client slept at night. The client would stay up all night playing games on the laptop. The staff LPA interviewed stated the client would stay up late until 2:00 AM, and they would ask the client to turn in their laptop for the night so that they can go to sleep, however the client felt it was their right to use it. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted with FM and a copy of this report, confidential names list, and appeal rights were provided to him.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced complaint investigation inspection at the facility and met with Chiang Thompson Facility Manager (FM) who assisted with the inspection. LPA investigated this complaint by reviewing incident reports, and by conducting confidential interviews with the Reporting Party, the Administrator, one staff, three clients, one client's parent, and the client's Regional Center Service Coordinator (SC) between 1/24/2025 and 6/10/2025. During LPA's interview with the client, they stated that staff took their laptop on one or two ocassions overnight due to the client not going to sleep; staff have not kept the laptop, and staff have not prevented the client from doing anything they needed to do on it. The client's parent confirmed that the client had a hard time sleeping and their grades at school were suffering, so during an IEP meeting they arranged for the school to only allow the Wi-Fi to work while at school since the facility could not take the laptop from the client. Additionally, the parent stated that the facility staff were not supposed to take the laptop at night.

narrative: During the course of the investigation, LPA also conducted interviews with the following individuals: School Staff (PS), Reporting Party (TE), and facility staff S2. LPA attempted to interview C1 and Staff S1. LPA also obtained video recordings of the incident which took place. During an interview with the Reporting Party (TE), they stated that during a Zoom session with C1 who was in their own bedroom, loud banging noises was heard and then a staff (S1) was observed entering C1’s bedroom. TE stated that this staff swung something that was in their hand towards C1. TE stated they are unsure if C1 was hit, but another voice outside the frame of the video was heard telling S1 to shut the laptop and C1 was heard saying “no” at the end right before the laptop was closed. During an interview with AD, they stated that they had questioned S1 about the incident. AD stated that per S1, S1 banged the pan on the wall as a scare tactic to be louder that C1 and did not hit C1 with the pan. In an interview with Staff S2 who was on shift the day of this incident, S2 stated that they observed S1 use a pan to bang on the wall, closet door, and bed. S2 stated that S1 did not use the pan to hit Client C1. S2 stated they had asked S1 to close the laptop so that S2 could calm both C1 and S1 down. LPA attempted interviews with Client C1 but C1 did not provide information regarding the incident and ended the interview after only a few minutes. After multiple attempts, LPA was unable to make contact with Staff S1 for an interview. LPA was able to obtain a copy of the Zoom Session recording for review. S1 was observed with a pan in their hand, held high in a strike-like motion. At the end of the video, S1 is observed swinging the pan down and hitting something before S1 closes C1’s laptop. It is unclear what was hit. The recording showed evidence that the Staff S1 did not handle the situation or C1 appropriately during this incident. Based on LPA’s observations, interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. The facility is cited on the attached LIC9099D under the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6 Chapter 5, Section 84072(d)(11) Personal Rights: (d)…the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights: (11) To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment, infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature… Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights were emailed to the Administrator, Najon Saina.

LPA had initiated the complaint investigation at the facility on 1/15/2021. On this date, LPA had completed a Health and Safety inspection of the facility, inside and outside. LPA conducted an interview with the Administrator (AD). LPA also requested for documents from Staff S1’s files and from Client C1’s files for review purposes. These documents included S1’s LIC501, Annual Performance Evaluations, Training Logs, disciplinary action reports or termination letters, C1’s Admission/Intake forms, Needs and Service Plans, and Incident Reports. deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 84072(d)(11) Personal Rights: (d)…the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights: (11) To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment, infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature… This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on LPA’s observations, interviews, and records reviewed, facility Staff S1 failed to handle group home child in an appropriate manner during an incident. This poses a potential Health and Safety Risk to clients in care.

During the inspection, LPA Stidman & Whitlow interviewed one staff on site. Due to restrictions of COVID-19, this inspection was conducted via Facetime. LPA conducted exit interview with Najon Saina, Administrator at 8:30am. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shoua Xiong conducted an unannounced inspection visit to the facility on 10/19/21 beginning at 10:30 AM. LPA met with Najon Saina, Administrator, and explained the purpose of the visit was to conduct an ANNUAL/REQUIRED inspection. At the time of arrival, there was one staff on shift and zero clients present, as they were currently in school. On today's date, LPA conducted a physical inspection of the home. LPA observed that each client was provided their own bedroom with beds, beddings, dressers, closet space, and adequate lighting. Extra linen and hygiene supplies was observed in hall closets. Smoke Detectors was present in each bedroom, in the hall, in the common area, and was in working condition. LPA observed an operating carbon monoxide detector and a charged fire extinguisher in the home. LPA observed that the facility had two refrigerators and stocked kitchen cabinets which contained more than two days' worth of perishable food items and seven days' worth of non-perishable food items. Knives, cleaning solutions, and medications were stored in locked closets. A complete First aid kit along with the manual was present in the facility. All sink faucets and toilets was observed to be in working order. The hot water was tested and was within the required range of 105 degrees F and 120 degrees F. The outside area was clean and free of safety hazards. LPA also conducted a review of two client files. LPA observed that the files were complete and had all the required documents. LPA conducted one staff interview. Two residents in care arrived from school around 3:15 PM. LPA attempted to conduct interviews with residents but was unable to complete the interviews due to one resident ending the interview early and the second resident refusing to speak with LPA. LPA was unable to begin reviewing staff files. LPA informed Administrator that they will return on another date and time to complete the Annual inspection process. No deficiencies were cited on today's date. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was given to Najon Saina, Administrator.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shoua Xiong conducted an unannounced inspection visit to the facility on 10/20/21 beginning at 10:15 Am. LPA met with Najon Saina, Administrator, and explained the purpose of the visit was for an Annual Continuation of the inspection visit which began on 10/19/21. On today's date, LPA reviewed ten staff files. All staff files were found to be complete with the required documents present. However, LPA had technical difficulty and was unable to access and continue using the CARES inspection tool document. LPA will return on a different date and time to complete the inspection process. No deficiencies were cited on today's date. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was given to the Administrator, Najon Saina.

An unannounced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Jean Stidman and Cecilia Warren on 5/20/22 at 10am. During the inspection, LPAs met with met with Najon Saina Administrator and inspected the facility inside and out. LPAs reviewed one child’s records on site at the facility at 10am. LPAs reviewed three staff personnel files on site at the facility at 10am.. LPAs interviewed three staff on site at 10am. LPAs did not interview any children currently taking psychotropic medication. LPA conducted exit interview with Najon Saina Administrator at 1:00pm and provided the Summary Report upon completion. One deficiency was observed in three out of three staff files reviewed (refer to LIC 809D), the staff files are missing documentation of Initial and Annual Psychotropic Medication training which poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to children in care. Facility cited from the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, 84065(i)(3)(M) and 84065 (j)(4) during the inspection

On 8/17/22, Licensing Program Analysts, (LPAs) Uchenna Ajaero and Connie Goldie, paid an unannounced annual/required inspection and met with the facility administrator (AD), Kate Rush. LPAs introduced themselves and informed the AD of the purpose of their visit. Entrance checklist was provided to the administrator. The licensing fees are current. The facility is licensed for 3 youths and has 2 youths currently placed. At 11:05 am, the LPAs and the AD toured the home. The kitchen was clean and organized, There were fresh fruits on the counter for the residents. The fridge was clean, there were no open foods. There was perishable food for about two days and nonperishable food for about 5 days. There were client's rights poster on the wall but it was outdated but the AD posted a current one. AD stated she has clients who are traumatized by the wording Foster Kids on the current personal rights poster so she printed a current version from the Department of Social Services site. At 11:30 am we inspected the garage. It was clean. There was hand washing sink in the garage, cleaning supplies were locked up in a cabinet, there was an extra fire extinguisher in the garage, there was a fridge with perishable food items and boxes of emergency foods. At 11:45 am we toured the bedrooms and they were neat. The beds were made, they had sheets, bed covers, comforter and top sheet with 2 pillows. The rooms were bright and lighted, the dressers were neat and closed appropriately, there were clothes hanging in the closet and more clothes folded away in the dressers. In the hall way there were clean folded linens, towels and personal toiletries. AD checked the alarm in the rooms and hall way and we observed that they all worked. Continued on next page.

At 2:00 pm LPA Ajaero interviewed AD, S1 and S2. LPA's reviewed Community Care Licensing file, unusual incident reports, facility roster, facility profile and complaint history. LPAs reviewed 2 client files. All documents were compliant per regulations. One technical advisory was given and we explained to the AD that a technical advisory is not a deficiency. No deficiency is cited today. Exit interview was conducted, a copy of the report was provided, appeal rights were discussed and emailed.

On 8/18/22, Licensing Program Analysts, Uchenna Ajaero and Connie Goldie returned to the facility to complete the Annual Continuation Inspection visit that began on 8/17/22. LPAs met with the Administrator Kate Rush, AD. to assist with completion of inspection. No deficiencies were cited. At 1:10 pm LPAs interviewed C1 as he had a minimum day at school. LPA reviewed 2-staff records, and Administrator's training records and documents, and the LIC 500. LPAs interviewed C2 at 3:40 pm. Exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were discussed and document emailed to Administrator and return receipt requested.

An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Katherine Rush, Administrator on 5/25/23 at 9:30am. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Stidman met with Katherine Rush, Administrator and inspected the facility inside and out. LPA reviewed zero child’s records and two staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPA did not review any child’s psychotropic medications and medication records due to the clients are not dependents of the courts (aka foster children). LPA interviewed two staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA did not interviewed any children currently prescribed psychotropic medication due to the clients are not dependents of the courts (aka foster children). LPA observed the backyard fence on the left side of the yard (as you're facing the house from the street) has a board missing. The administrator provided documentation of a work order to have this repaired has been requested. LPA provided a copy of this licensing report to Katherine Rush, Administrator. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPA conducted exit interview with Katherine Rush, Administrator..

On 05/30/2023, at 08:40 AM, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Uchenna Ajaero, met with the Administrator Kate Rush to conduct an unannounced Annual / Required inspection of the facility. This facility is a Group Home. LPA Ajaero gave the Administrator the Entrance Checklist Form LIC 9239. The facility consists of three bedrooms and two bathrooms. There are a total of two clients. At 11:30 am, we started a walk through of the facility for the inspection. The facility was observed to be clean, organized, and free of debris and clutter. The home contained a living room, a kitchen, dining room, and office. The dining room and multi-media room had a table for the clients to sit and eat, and complete activities and homework. The clients bedrooms were observed to be bright, contain an individual bed, clean linens, clothes were organized in the closet and there were multiple storage space for client property. It was observed that several documents were posted on the board for easy access. The facility license, facility sketch, emergency plan, emergency telephone numbers, and fire clearance were observed to be posted in a prominent place. The fire extinguisher was observed to be charged and up-to-date and was last serviced in May 15, 2023. In the hallway were two closets. One contained extra blankets and linens. The other one contained client activities, games, books and craft items. The refrigerator and freezer had enough food to last more than 2 days. The pantry held enough nonperishable food that will last more than 5 days. There were varieties of snacks in the home.

LPA Ajaero completed the Personnel Review of two staff working at this facility. LPA compared them to the list of staff on Guardian who are associated with this facility and who are cleared and eligible to work in the facility and there were no discrepancies. LPA Ajaero completed the LIC 859 file review for 2 staff members ensuring their documents were up to date and in compliance. LPA Ajaero Reviewed the medications of both youths at this facility. The following were checked for compliance: First aid kit available and it had an adequate supply of items. Clients' medication kit stored and MARs updated. Cleaning Supplies: Adequate, locked and stored. Water temperature was below 110 degrees F. Facility kitchen had knives and other accessories in a locked cabinet. Adequate food supply including perishable and non-perishable items Fire extinguishers checked; smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are working but not checked due to the clients being at home. Emergency Exit Plan and Mass Casualty Disaster Plan, menu, and activity schedule were posted in the facility. Telephone: Available and in operable condition. Staff and Client files: Reviewed and all required documents were present. Staff gave LPA the LIC 9239 with required documents. Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Uchenna Ajaero completed an exit interview today. No Title 22 citations were issued during this inspection. A copy of this report, has been provided to the Administrator, Kate Rush.

The Department has investigated the complaint that the client sustained unexplained injuries and client was sexually assaulted. Client sustained unexplained injuries. It was reported during a restraint on 1/9/2024 that C1 had visible scratches on C1’s neck, as well as a bloody noise, and was complaining about leg pain. During a confidential interview with the Department’s Investigation Bureau Investigator, (IB) Jorge Jauregui C1 stated that C1 had been restrained by staff due to C1’s behavior. C1 did not remember when the incident occurred. C1 did not mention any unexplained injuries. C1 stated that C1 felt safe at Kavere. The reporting party stated that there was not any evidence that supported the current allegation and believe the force that staff used to restrain C1 was appropriated to guarantee not only the staff’s safety but also C1’s safety. The reporting party stated the scratches that C1 sustained were minor and did not require medical treatment. The reporting party did not see any injuries to C1’s legs or bruises. The social worker has no concern about the staff. Based on the investigation, observation, records reviewed, and interviews conducted, the complaint findings are UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Client was sexually assaulted. During confidential interviews C1 stated that C1 had not been touched inappropriately by Kavere staff. C1 also stated C1 felt safe at the home. The reporting party did not see any evidence that supported the allegation. C1 also stated to the reporting party that C1 made up the allegation. C1 was upset for not being allowed to play music videos. The social worker for C1 stated that he did not have any concerns regarding staff. Based on the investigation, observation, records reviewed, and interviews conducted, the complaint findings are UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. No title 22 regulations were cited during today’s inspection. A copy of this report and appeal rights were given to the agency.

Investigator, (IB) Jorge Jauregui, interviewed the reporting party, social worker, Intern and C1. Continued LIC9099C
