The Department has investigated the complaint that Staff used prohibited restraints on a youth causing marks. C1 was not interviewed for the purpose of this complaint. The bio-parents thought it was best for C1 not to be interviewed. C2 is non-verbal and LPA was unable to establish a rapport. C3 did not want to talk about being restrained. When discussing restraints with the staff and other individuals, the youths are restrained only when they are a danger to themselves or other individuals in the home, it is a last resort and other de-escalation techniques have failed. A copy of Kavere Services Emergency Interventions Plan is located within the Program Statement which outline the use of restraints. Staff conducted a body check on C1 and found several marks on C1’s lower back and a small mark on C1’s chin. Staff stated the injuries could have occurred before the restraint. C1 grabbed staff’s glasses, started swinging on staff, biting, and grabbing staff. The Pro Act trainer reviewed the Incident Report dated 2/11/2023 and stated that the injuries could have occurred when C1 wedged himself between the bed and door. Staff interviewed stated they never put pressure to the back when doing a restraint. Based on the investigation, observation, records reviewed, and interviews conducted, the complaint findings are UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. No title 22 regulations were cited during today’s inspection. A copy of this report and appeal rights were given to the agency.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mary Shelton conducted a visit to the home on 4/24/2024 at 12:30 PM, and LPA spoke with the Administrator, to deliver findings of the investigation on the complaint allegation as stated. LPA Shelton informed the complaint investigation included a Physical Plant Inspection of the home on 1/10/2024. The initial 10-day complaint inspection was conducted by LPA Mary Shelton, at the agency on 1/10/2024 included a review of the facility and obtaining of relevant documents: documentation related to the clients and staff at the facility to include client roster, face sheets, staff roster, including staff contact information and schedule for current month, facility sketch, Pro-Act certificates, restraint logs, and Needs and Services Plan and case notes for C1. Continued LIC9099C

narrative: Allegation 1. Staff inappropriately restrained minor resulting in injuries. During the initial interview of FC1 at school, FC1 revealed that S1 pushed FC1 down and tried to choke FC1. During the second interview, FC1 stated there were two staff members who choked FC1. When LPA questioned FC1 about the inconsistency, FC1 declined any further response to the LPA’s questions. Staff denied restraining FC1. Based on LPA’s confidential interviews and documents reviewed, the allegation that Staff inappropriately restrained minor resulting in injuries is unsubstantiated, meaning that the allegation lacks a preponderance of evidence to prove that the violation occurred. Allegation 2. Staff inappropriately spoke to minor in care. It was alleged that S1 made inappropriate threats to FC1 during an altercation. FC1 did not recall the alleged statements when LPA interviewed FC1 on both occasions. Staff denied the alleged threats to FC1. Based on LPA’s confidential interviews and documents reviewed, the allegation that Staff inappropriately spoke to minor in care is unsubstantiated, meaning that the allegation lacks a preponderance of evidence to prove that the violation occurred. Allegation 3. Staff refused to provide food to minor. During LPAs interview with FC1, FC1 stated that staff refused to provide a second helping of food to FC1. FC1 got angry and began to destroy things at the facility. S1 stated the FC1 never requested a second helping of food but began picking on FC2 while at the table and then directed his anger to staff once he got up from the table. S2 and S3 did not observe the incident but was later told of the incident by S1. Based on LPA’s confidential interviews and documents reviewed, the allegation that Staff refused to provide food to minor is unsubstantiated, meaning that the allegation lacks a preponderance of evidence to prove that the violation occurred. Exit interview was conducted with Noel Maldonado, the DSP. A copy of the report and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On 5/30/24 about 4:15 PM, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Uchenna Ajaero conducted an unannounced complaint investigation visit to deliver finding for this allegation. LPA Ajaero met with Noel Maldonado, the DSP and informed him of the purpose of the visit. On 3/12/2024, LPA Ajaero visited the facility and met with the Administrator. LPA requested and received client file (C1) and obtained copies of Identification Sheet, Needs and Service Plans, IEP, and Progress Reports from January to March 2024. LPA interviewed the Administrator, (AD) and one staff member, (S1). LPA Ajaero interviewed FC1, FC1’s teacher and three staff between 3/13/24 and 3/21/24. LPA reinterviewed FC1 on 4/1/2024. FC2 is nonverbal and could not be interviewed.

narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst made an unannounced annual inspection at the facility and met with staff Yvonne Hernandez who assisted with the inspection. Administrator Sonia Gomez arrived shortly after and assisted LPA with the inspection. LPA conducted a walk-through of the facility with staff Noel Maldonado and observed the following: one dining area, kitchen, hallway, living room, two client bedrooms, two bathrooms, the garage, one staff office, and the backyard. The clients' bedrooms met requirements and had the necessary personal storage space, with clean, complete bedding. Clients had appropriate clothing, in reasonable quantities. One client's closet doors were off track and possibly needed to be repaired. The food at the facility met the standards for a minimum of 2 days perishable and 7 days non-perishable, with a variety of meals and snacks. The facility's menu was posted, as well as their activity plan. The carbon monoxide detector and smoke detector were tested and operational. There was no hot water sign indicating hot water above the coffee machine and water machine as required. There were three (roughly 4 inch) holes in the ground near the perimeter of the house in the backyard which need covers. There was one section of fencing in the backyard which staff stated was rotting due to the sprinkler, resulting in exposed rusty nails. The inside of the home was clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. The temperature inside the home was comfortable for clients, staff, and guests. The facility has a cordless phone on the premises for client use. Client files, money, and medications were locked up/inaccessible to clients as required.

The Board of Directors meets on at least a quarterly basis as required. The meeting notes were available to LPA to inspect. The board either did not discuss, or did not document, current complaints and incident reports reviewed for each facility. The facility is conducting fire and disaster drills at least quarterly for each shift as required. The facility's emergency disaster plan/mass casualty plan is complete, meeting all requirements. It had not been signed off on as having been reviewed however, since 10/2023. On this date, the Administrator reviewed and signed. The plan stated the facility will utilize an ice chest and "blue ice" to preserve any medications which require refrigeration in the event of a power outage, however the facility did not have an ice chest. One client was not able to communicate with LPA, and the other client did not want to speak to LPA on this date. LPA will attempt to speak with the client on another date. The staff files and training records are maintained at another one of the licensee's facilities, and due to the time, LPA could not review them on this date. LPA advised for the records to be present at this facility for when LPA returns to complete the annual. No citations were issued during today's inspection. LPA is issuing advisory notes, which are not citations. An exit interview was conducted with the Administrator, and a copy of this report was provided to her.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced annual continuation inspection to continue the annual started on 5/30/2025. LPA met with Administrator Sonia Gomez who assisted with the inspection. LPA reviewed 5 personnel files: 3 Staff, 1 Facility Manager, and 1 Administrator, and found the following: All staff are fingerprint cleared and associated as required. All staff are trained with the additional 1 hour of Facility Manager Training. All staff have current Pro-Act Training for emergency interventions. All staff have received the required annual training hours. The Administrator's duties were missing from her file, which she put in the file during this inspection. All staff reviewed have had a Health Screening and TB test as required. All staff are qualified for their roles, and evidence of such was in their files as required. The facility has consultants who meet with the clients as required including BCBAs and interns, a Psychiatrist, and a Recreation Therapist. All staffs' First Aid and CPR are current. All staffs' drivers' licenses are current. LPA reviewed two client files and found: All client records are present, except for the signed discipline policy. Both clients' files have the required Needs and Services Plans, Immunizations, TB test, Cash Resources/records, Medication Administration Records, authorization from parents/guardians to take psychotropic medications, and identifying information. The Cash Resources Log for C2 was off by $2, due to staff missing the receipt saying $17 for a haircut that usually cost $15. This was corrected during this inspection.

LPA interviewed one client, one staff, and the Administrator. Staff/Administrator were knowledgeable about the clients and facility practices. LPA advises staff be given a refresher on the Mandated Reporting process. No citations were issued. LPA issued Advisory Notes for Technical Violations, and these are not citations. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator and a copy of this report and confidential names list were provided to her.

At 9:05 AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Isabel Mendoza made an unannounced inspection to this facility to conduct an annual required inspection. LPA met with Direct Care staff John Yap and Lead Staff Daisy Garcia. Shortly after Administrator Rochelle Rivera arrived. The facility currently has a census of 3 clients. All clients were in school during todays inspections. At 9:33 AM LPA and the Administrator toured the facility inside and out. The facility is clean, safe and sanitary and in good repair. All passageways are unobstructed. All disinfectants, cleaning solutions and poisons are locked in the laundry room. Per Administrator, there are no firearms in the facility. The kitchen is clean and sanitary. The facility has sufficient two day perishable and seven day nonperishable food supply. The inspected bedrooms were furnished accordingly. LPA noticed that two bedrooms (bedrooms 2 and 3) ceilings and walls had several stains/markings, so LPA advised the facility to do a good cleaning on the walls/ceiling. During inspection at 11:01 AM staff started wiping down the walls in both bedrooms. There is an outdoor space for the clients, and no hazards or broken items. The facility has another house/detachment which is separate from the facility. This area is prohibited from clients and is used by staff members/live-ins. LPA advised the facility to submit an updated fire clearance sketch and include the backyard detachment house. The facility will submit the sketch no later than 10/01/21. There are no pools or bodies of water. LPA inspected medications, and they appeared fine. Medications are located in the kitchen area [ PLEASE REFER TO LIC 809 C...]

in a locked cabinet. All items are fully documented. LPA noticed that the facility was using MAR LIC 622 A for psychotropic medication. LPA gave a copy of LIC 622 B to the Administrator so the facility can separate non-psychotropic from psychotropic MARS per requirements. The facility ensured they will start incorporating the LIC 622B, and make all necessary changes. LPA Mendoza reviewed all three client files. All files were organized and had all required documents. LPA found a few items were documents were not fully complete, so LPA reminded the facility to ensure that all LIC forms must be completed and if an item does not apply to write "N/A". At 12:10 PM LPA inspected three staff files and (S1), (S2), and (S3) (Please refer to LIC 811, dated 09/17/21 for confidential names) did not have Health Screening or TB test results on file. The administrator confirmed that all three staff member have not and they will make an appointment. All staff have required training on file. The Administrator (S4) certificate expired back in 2018 and the Administrator stated that she tried to renew it in 2019 but did not complete the correct administrator courses, so was unable to get it renewed. LPA obtained copies of all documentation that was submitted back in 2019. During inspection, the Administrator confirmed she is currently registered for a recertification class that will be on 09/22/21 and submitted proof to LPA. LPA went over Guardian association list that was printed on 09/16/21 with Administrator, and (S5) Daisy Garcia is not showing associated. The facility confirmed that (S5) has worked at the facility for about 5 months. During inspection, LPA obtained a copy of criminal record transfer request, which was submitted to CCL main office back in April. LPA advised the facility to resubmit form to CCL main office again, and LPA obtained a copy and will take back to the office for processing. LPA Mendoza also introduced Administrator to CCL's new background portal called Guardian. LPA obtained copies of LIC 500, LIC 610, LIC 309, and Administrative documents for Rochelle Rivera. Per Title 22 regulations, deficiencies were cited at this visit, and three LIC 9102 Technical Violations, and one Technical Assistance was issued. Exit interview conducted, appeal rights printed, and a copy of this report was left with the Administrator.

On 9-29-22 10:10AM, Licensing Program Analysts George Karkazis conducted an unannounced Annual/Required inspection at the listed facility. LPA's met with Co-Administrator Adora Ancheta and toured the facility inside and out. Safety precautions were taken, including screening call and mask-wearing. The Group Home is licensed to serve 6 clients. Present during the inspection were two staff and no clients present. All clients were at school and all clients are non-verbal. At 11:03AM, LPA Karkazis toured the facility. LPA Karkazis observed five bedrooms and three bathrooms. LPA observed the facility license, personal rights, facility sketch, meal menu, and other forms posted on the walls throughout the facility. LPA Karkazis tested the water temperature and found it to be 110 degrees, which is within range. The thermostat read 68 degrees which is within range. Sharps were locked, and chemicals were safely stored. There were two days of perishable foods and seven days of non-perishable foods present. The medication was also stored and locked cabinet. LPA checked medication and found no issues. The facility is in good repair and clean. LPA Karkazis interviewed two staff and no clients. At 12:20PM LPA Karkazis toured the backyard. There were no open bodies of water. The backyard was in good repair and clean. At 1:30 PM LPA Karkazis reviewed client and staff files. Client files were complete and had all required documents. LPA Karkazis reviewed staff files and the following items were missing: (S1) did not have a current CPR training certificate, (S2) had no first aid training, fingerprint clearance, no education history, no personnel record, no job application, no health screening, no medical training, no tuberculosis clearance. (S3) had no first aid training certificate, valid fingerprint clearance, education history, health screening, employee rights, medical training, and tuberculosis clearance. (S4’s) CPR certificate expired. (S5)had no first aid certificate, personnel record, no health screening, no training record, no education history, and no tuberculosis clearance.

Also, staff (S3) was present at the facility and was not associated to the facility. The Co-Administrator showed LPA a copy of the DOJ Applicant Fingerprint Response sheet, however, (S3) was not showing associated to the facility nor had a profile on Guardian. At this time, there were deficiencies cited, Title 22 Group Home Regulations 84365(d)(1), 84365(d)(1)(A Emergency Staff Intervention Training, 84365(d)(1)(B), 84365(d)(1)(C) Emergency Staff Intervention Training, 80066(a)(3),80066(a)(10) Personnel Records, 80066(a)(11 Health Related Services, 80075(f) Personnel Records, 80066(a)(5, 80066(a)(6) Personnel Records, and 80019(e) Criminal records clearance, civil penalty assessed. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was given to Adora Ancheta, Director.

narrative: On 8/31/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a required annual inspection. LPA met with Administrator Rochelle Rivera, and informed of the purpose of the visit. The CARE Inspection Tool was used to completed this inspection. During inspection, LPA toured the facility site and inspected facility records. LPA observed the facility to be clean. No hazards were observed. The kitchen is fully stocked with food within date. Bedrooms have clean linens. Bathrooms are maintained in sanitary condition. A continuation visit is required to complete this inspection. LPA observed the following deficiencies during today's inspection: - Staff S1 (See LIC 811 Confidential Names) does not have a background clearance. - The facility has not completed emergency drills in at least 8 months. - All four residents are above the licensed age range, and the facility has not been granted age exceptions. - There was no current register/roster of residents, and licensee needed to generate a new one. - The facility manager (S1) personnel file did not include facility manager training, and administrator stated the training plan in the plan of operation (POO) was not followed. - The personnel file for staff S2 did not reflect 20 hours of annual training nor any training since January 2022. - The file for resident R4 did not contain medical consent forms nor a medical assessment/physician's report. LPA is issuing citations of Health and Safety Code, Section 1565(c) and (e) and California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Sections 80019(e), 80010, 84065(d) and (j), 84070(b), and 80069. See attached LIC 809-D pages. Additionally, LPA is assessing a civil penalty of $3000, pursuant to Section 80019, for the second criminal record clearance violation in 12 months. See LIC 421BG. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Rochelle Rivera, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 8/31/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit at the facility to follow-up on a submitted incident report. LPA met with Administrator Rochelle Rivera and informed of the purpose of the visit. During the visit, LPA conducted 1 staff interview with Administrator and observed footage from facility staff of the incident detailed in the incident report. In the footage, a staff member is shown restraining a resident in the prone position with their hands behind their back and with the staff member seated on top of the resident. Administrator initially stated she did not believe this was a restraint and confirmed that the program prohibits staff from performing restraints. LPA explained that this was a restraint and that it was prohibited in the plan of operation. LPA also discussed the dangers of the type of restraint performed and how it is a personal rights violation. Additionally, on 8/15/23, LPA requested a revised/supplemental report be submitted, as not all required information for the restraint incident was included in the original report. On 8/29/23, Administrator stated that no restraint was performed and so the requested information was not submitted to LPA, including the type of restraint used. Lastly, no correction or retraining of staff has been completed yet. LPA is issuing citations of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Sections 84072 Personal Rights, 84365 Emergency Intervention Staff Training, 84061 Reporting Requirements, and 80022 Plan of Operation. See attached LIC 809-D pages. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Rochelle Rivera, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Personal Rights (d) ...the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights:(11) To be free from physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and corporal punishment. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review, observation, and interview, licensee did not ensure personal rights accorded due to staff performing restraint where they sat on client while client in prone position with hands behind back, which poses an immediate health, safety or personal rights risk to residents in care.

Emergency Intervention Staff Training (f) When an inappropriate manual restraint technique is used..., the licensee must develop a corrective action plan... This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review, observation, and interview, licensee did not ensure corrective action plan (CAP) completed following improper restraint due to no CAP completed, which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to residents in care.

Reporting Requirements (h)(6) When the Incident Report is used to report the use of manual restraints, the report must include the following: (C) Description of what manual restraints were used, and how long the child was restrained. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review, observation, and interview, licensee did not ensure restraint was reported correctly due to not reporting the type of restraint used, which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.

Plan of Operation (k) The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation and may be cited for not doing so. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review, observation, and interview, licensee did not ensure plan of operation (POO) followed due to performing restraint when restraints are prohibited in POO , which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.

deficiencies.title: Reporting Requirements (h)(6) When the Incident Report is used to report the use of manual restraints, the report must include the following
deficiencies.description: (C) Description of what manual restraints were used, and how long the child was restrained.

met_with: Director Adora Ancheta, Administrator Rochelle Rivera
narrative: On Monday, September 25, 2023 (09/25/23), a scheduled office meeting was held with the licensee to discuss the licensee's current population and the facility's plan to either transition the residents to adult homes or convert the facility into an adult residential facility (ARF). In attendance were Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Lidia Tinoco, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins, Administrator Rochelle Rivera, Director Adora Ancheta, and Golden Gate Regional Center (GGRC) Social Workers Martha Tercero, Anita Yen, and Blanca Rivera del Valle. The facility currently has three residents in care whose ages exceed the facility's licensed age range. The licensee was instructed to submit age exception requests with placement agency support letters, and all were received this month. The licensee stated they will be converting the home into an adult home. The licensee agreed to complete the following: 1) By Friday 10/27/23, the licensee will submit their ARF application to the CCLD Adult & Senior Care Program Centralized Application Bureau. 2) Following submission of the ARF application, the licensee will send LPA the assigned license number for the ARF application so that LPA may check in internally on the application review. 3) The licensee will continue to provide monthly updates until the ARF has been licensed. A copy of this report was provided to Administrator Rochelle Rivera, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 01/18/24 at 11:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Celeste Aparicio conducted a case management inspection at the facility to follow-up with a health and safety check due to the information provided by San Mateo County's fire inspection conducted on 12/12/23. LPA met with Administrator Rochelle Rivera and informed her on the purpose of the visit. LPA conducted an interview with the Administrator, a walk through of the facility, and requested documentation regarding recent incident reports. During the facility walk through, LPA observed sharp plastic and cement debris in the backyard that was accessible to clients. LPA also observed mold around a broken ceiling vent inside one of the clients bedroom. LPA is issuing two citations of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, section 80087 Buildings and Grounds. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Rochelle Rivera, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Buildings and Grounds The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on observation and interview, the licensee did not ensure that the facility remains safe and in good repair, that could pose a danger to residents due to the mold and a broken vent in a residents bedroom, which poses an emmediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.

Buildings and Grounds All outdoor and indoor passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps, open porches and other areas of potential hazard shall be kept free of obstruction. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on observation and interview, the licensee did not ensure that the outdoor area was free from potential hazard due to the hazardous debris accessible to clients in the backyard, which poses an emmediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.

narrative: On 01/23/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Celeste Aparicio made a visit to the facility and observed deficiencies for which this case management report was generated. LPA met with Licensee Adora Ancheta and informed on of the purpose of the visit. During the visit, LPA observed construction and alterations made to the back house. LPA explained to the licensee that prior to construction or alterations, licensee shall notify the licensing agency of the proposed change and secure a building permit. LPA is issuing citations of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, section 80086 Alterations to Existing Building or New Facilities. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Licensee Adora Ancheta, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Alterations to Existing Building or New Facilities (a) Prior to construction or alterations, all licensees shall notify the licensing agency of the proposed change. This requirment is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review, interview, and observation, licensee did not ensure the licensing agency was notified due to the observed alterations made to floor plan, which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.

Alterations to Existing Building or New Facilities (c) Prior to construction or alterations, state or local law requires that all facilities secure a building permit. This requirment is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review, interview, and observation, licensee did not ensure a building permit was acquired due to the construction of unpermitted building, which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.

narrative: On 03/14/24 at 9:45AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Celeste Aparicio and Mariah Hawkins conducted a quarterly case management inspection, per the agreed upon terms of the December 2023 noncompliance conference (NCC). LPAs met with Licensee Adora Ancheta and acting Administrator Rochelle Rivera and informed both on the purpose of this visit. Per the NCC terms, the facility was to be subject to quarterly inspections at which personnel and resident records will be reviewed for completion. In addition, the facility was to designate a qualified and currently certified administrator, and to implement interview review of records conducted by the licensee or director with documentation of the review available on site. Lastly, the facility is to maintain overall compliance with applicable regulations. At visit, LPAs reviewed all personnel and resident records and observed them to be complete. Administrator Rivera agreed to submit R3's current IPP and ISP to LPA Aparicio by 3/15/24 at 4:30PM. LPAs observed that Administrator Rivera has completed the required administrator continuing education hours and submitted an administrator recertification application to the Department in October 2023, which the Department has not yet processed. LPAs advised the licensee that technically the acting administrator is not currently certified. See LIC 9102. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were discussed, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Rochelle Rivera, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 6/7/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management inspection. LPA met with Facility Manager Dela Luna at the facility and Administrator Rochelle Rivera over the phone and informed of the purpose of the visit. Per the December 2023 noncompliance conference (NCC), the following conditions apply and/or shall be met: 1) The facility shall be subject to quarterly case management inspections. Today is the facility's 2nd quarterly inspection. 2) Personnel records shall be complete with background clearance documentation, initial training, annual training, intervention training, first aid training, mandated reporter training. LPA observed all staff listed on the LIC 500 to have a background clearance. All files were complete, and all staff have valid first aid and CPI intervention certifications and have complete annual, initial, and other required training. 3) Resident records shall be complete with accurate cash/valuables records and current care plans updated at least every 6 months. LPA observed all resident files to be complete, including care plans updated within the last 6 months and detailed and accurate cash/P&I records. 4) Monthly reviews, beginning January 2024, of all personnel and resident records conducted by the director/licensee shall be documented and available on site. LPA observed all personnel and resident files to be complete and the main facility binder to be current and up to date. Administrator agreed to create a specific checklist to document the administrative review by Administrator and/or Director. SEE LIC 809-C.

5) Administrator shall have complete training and certification. Administrator has a valid administrator certificate reflecting complete administrator training. 6) The facility shall be maintained in compliance. The licensee was required by the fire department to complete work on the physical plant. An inspection was conducted by the fire department on 5/29/24, and per Administrator, only small corrections are still needed. Administrator agreed to send LPA the list of needed corrections once received. Lastly, all residents in care are above the facility's licensed age range. However, age exception requests are pending, and the facility is actively working towards adult residential facility licensure. No deficiencies were observed during the tour of the facility and grounds nor during review of facility records. No citations were issued at today's visit. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Facility Manager Conrado Dela Luna, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 9/19/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a required annual inspection. LPA met with Licensee Adora Ancheta and informed of the purpose of the visit. LPA toured the physical plant. LPA observed the facility to be clean and organized. Bedrooms and living spaces are tidy. Kitchen and bathrooms are maintained in sanitary condition. The bathroom is accommodating for the population served. There are 3 double-occupancy bedrooms. Both residents are nonverbal, and residents are currently not sharing a room. The outdoor space is well-maintained, and no immediate or potential hazards were observed. Using the CARE Inspection Tool, no deficiencies in physical plant were observed. LPA inspected facility records. LPA observed 5 staff files to be complete. All files have documentation of valid background clearance, required certifications, and 20 hours of annual training in the past year. LPA observed resident files to be complete. All files have current and accurate documentation for medications and care plans. Using the CARE Inspection Tool, no deficiencies in facility records were observed. LPA interviewed Licensee and Facility Manager and observed both residents. No citations were issued at today's visit. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Licensee.

On 9/27/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit in order to deliver notice of deficiency(ies) found during the course of an investigation at the facility. LPA met with Administrator Rochelle Rivera and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential observations, interview, and record review, the facility did not maintain a current medication administration record due to logging the administration of a medication (Doxycycline) despite not administering this medication, as it is no longer prescribed nor maintained in the resident's current medication bin. LPA issued a citation of California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Section 80070(b)(10). LPA discussed this matter with Administrator and reviewed the medication records. Administrator confirmed observing the mistake and correcting staff. Administrator stated the mistake was discussed with staff and staff write-ups will be issued. LPA observed the records to have been corrected, the old records maintained for recordkeeping purposes, and the pharmacy medication orders reflecting the medication had not been ordered to be maintained with the records. LPA identified one additional area, food services and menus, in which technical support may be beneficial. See attached LIC 9102. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were provided, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 80070(b) Each record must contain information including, but not limited to, the following: (10) Record of current medications, including the name of the prescribing physician, and instructions, if any, regarding control and custody of medications. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential observation, interview, and record review, licensee did not ensure current medication record due to logging the administration of a discontinued medication, which poses a potential heath, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.

narrative:
On 9/27/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit. LPA met with Administrator Rochelle Rivera and informed of the purpose of the visit. Per the December 2023 noncompliance conference (NCC), the following conditions apply and shall be met: 1) The facility shall be subject to quarterly case management inspections. Today is the facility's 3rd quarterly inspection. 2) Personnel records shall be complete with background clearance documentation, initial training, annual training, intervention training, first aid training, mandated reporter training. LPA observed that all staff listed on the LIC 500 have a background clearance and that all files were complete with valid first aid and CPI intervention certificates and complete training records. 3) Resident records shall be complete with accurate cash/valuables records and current care plans updated at least every 6 months. LPA observed that the resident files for both residents in care are complete and contain current care plans and inventory logs. Resident cash resources were counted and observed to be accurate to the records. 4) Monthly reviews, beginning January 2024, of all personnel and resident records conducted by the director/licensee shall be documented and available on site. LPA observed all personnel and resident files to be complete and the main facility binder to be current and up to date. Administrator agreed to create a specific checklist to document the administrative review by Administrator and/or Director.

5) Administrator shall have complete training and certification. LPA observed that Administrator has completed the 40-hour administrator training program. However, Administrator has not yet received the renewal certificate. Administrator submitted the application in June 2024 and is showing on the pending renewal list published to the Administrator Certification Bureau's site. 6) The facility shall be maintained in compliance. The residents in care are currently above the facility's licensed age range. The final submission needed for the age exceptions was received on 9/27/24, and the facility is nearing the end of the adult residential facility licensure process. No deficiencies were observed, and no citations were issued at today's visit. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Rochelle Rivera, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

investigation_findings: 13On 9/27/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a complaint investigation visit regarding the above allegation. LPA met with Administrator Rochelle Rivera and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential interviews, observations, and record review, two youth in care are above the licensed age range. The facility has provided support letters for age exceptions but had not provided a written request for age exceptions meeting licensing requirements. Licensing records reflect previous contacts, but interviews with management reflect not being aware further action was needed. Additionally, the facility is currently nearing the end of the licensure process to become an adult residential facility and has kept the licensing agency up to date on their progress with this. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegation is substantiated. LPA determined that the violation is considered a technical violation, and no citation is being issued at this time. Administrator submitted the age exception requests on 9/26/24. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were provided, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator.

narrative: On 10/28/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a visit to the facility. LPA met with Administrator Rochelle Rivera and informed of the purpose of the visit. During the visit, LPA became aware that an incident occurred on 10/17/24 where an intervention method constituting a manual restraint was performed by staff. LPA observed that no incident report had been submitted for this incident, and no incident report was located in the resident's records. Administrator confirmed that no report had been generated. After discussion with Administrator, LPA clarified that due to the restriction of the resident's movement during the intervention, the intervention method used constituted a restraint. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Subchapter 3, Article 8, Section 84361 Documentation and Reporting Requirements. See attached LIC 809-D. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and the licensee's appeal rights were provided to Administrator Rochelle Rivera, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Documentation and Reporting Req... (a) Each use of manual restraints must be reported to the Department...no later than the next working day... A written incident report must be submitted...within seven (7) days, as required in Section 80061. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on observation, interview, and record review, the licensee did not meet reporting requirements due to not reporting restraint within 7 days to the Department, which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.

narrative:
On December 31, 2020, at 1:00pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Kevin Sauk, made an unannounced visit to Key Housing for the purpose of conducting a Required Annual Inspection. LPA, Sauk met with the Program Director (PD), who granted access into the facility, and who provided a tour of the facility inside and out. Due to the Coronavirus Pandemic, this inspection was conducted via Facetime. The facility is licensed to provide care and supervision for six (6) children ages 12 through 17, ambulatory only. There are no pool or bodies of water on the premises. The home is set up as follows: This is a two story house located in a residential area. There are three (3) client bedrooms, five (5) bathrooms, a living room, laundry room, kitchen, staff office, dinning area/family room, a attached garage and backyard. There are no security bars on the windows. All three bedrooms were observed with equipment to be in good condition, sufficient lighting, drawer and closet space, comfortable mattresses, and clean lines, blankets, and pillows. Bedroom #1: sleeps C1 and C2. This bedroom is located downstairs towards the end of the hallway, has an attached full bathroom, and is equipped with two queen-size beds, which were observed to be put together. LPA Sauk advised that these beds be separated in order to take preventive measures towards limiting the spread of COVID-19. Bedroom #2: sleeps C3 and C4. This room is located upstairs, has an attached full bathroom, and is equipped with one bunk bed, and one queen-size bed. LPA instructed PD to replace the bunk bed with one bed, because there shall be a maximum of 2 beds per bedroom. Bedroom #3: is vacant. This room is located upstairs, has an attached full bathroom, and is equipped with two queen beds, and one full-size bed. LPA instructed PD to remove one of the beds, because there shall be a maximum of 2 beds per bedroom. Bathrooms: There are three (3) bathrooms downstairs and two (2) bathrooms upstairs. All bathrooms were checked and were in clean, safe, and in good repair. (Continued on LIC809-C, page 2)

Living Room: There are two sofas, two sofa chairs and a small center table with a bookshelves to the side. The living room area is also used as a waiting area. Laundry Room: Is located downstairs under the stairs. There is a washer/dryer. Laundry detergents are stored in a locked cabinet above the washer and dryer. Staff Office: The downstairs converted bedroom, located to the left when entering the hallway from the family room, is used as an office space and is kept locked. Staff files and medication are stored in a closet. Kitchen: There is a stove with six (6) burners and center grill all working at this time. There is a detached oven currently working at this time. There is a microwave and refrigerator/freezer. There is an adequate supply of perishable/nonperishable foods. All trash cans have tight lids on. Dining Area/Family Room: There is a table with six (6) chairs. There is also ample seating space for clients to sit and watch TV. The TV is mounted to the wall and there is also a covered fireplace. Garage: The garage can be accessed through the inside of the house and is currently being used as a recreation area. LPA Sauk observed a ping pong table, gym equipment, weights, and a punching bag. There is also an extra refrigerator, and deep freezer that is used to store extra food. Backyard: LPA Sauk.observed an outdoor seating area with a table and six (6) chairs. Outdoor activity space is free of obstructions. The home was inspected and the following was observed: The facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. Medicines, disinfectants, and cleaning solutions are made inaccessible to clients in care and are stored inside staff office. No more than two (2) children share a bedroom. There are no weapons in the facility. Sharp knives are stored in the staff office, and made inaccessible to children. Adequate supervision is provided for clients in care. Staff ensure three nutritious meals and snacks. All smoke detectors are operable. Facility has one or more functioning carbon monoxide detector that meet statutory requirements. Fire extinguishers were fully charged; one is located downstairs mounted to the wall in the kitchen area. The other fire extinguisher is mounted to the wall upstairs in the hallway. The facility also has extra fire extinguishers kept inside one of the kitchen cabinets and staff office. The first aid kit was checked to be age-appropriate, and complete with scissors, tweezers, thermometer, and gauzes, All posting requirements were met not met. The weekly menu and clients' personal rights were posted; however the facility License and the Grievance Procedure were not. The License shall be posted in a prominent, publicly accessible location in the facility, and the Grievance Procedures shall be posted in a location in the facility which is accessible to children and their authorized representatives. The facility is in clean, safe, and in good repair. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. Exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to PD. Signature will be on file.

On 09/28/2021 at 9:40 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zena Phillips made an unannounced visit to Key Housing for the purpose of an Annual/Required Licensing Inspection. LPA Phillips met with Artis Carhee 111/Program Director and conducted a tour of the facility. There is currently 1 child placed in the facility. The program accepts clients from Private Placement's. This GH is licensed to serve 6 children ages 13-17 years of age, ambulatory only. The facility is located in a residential area a two story residence , 3 bedrooms, 3 1/2 bathrooms, kitchen/dining room, 1 laundry room , den area with ample outdoor space. There was adequate closet and storage space for the clients. Overall, the facility appeared clean, safe and sanitary. The building is in good repair. The Facility has Office space for the Administrator and staff. All beds are in good repair. Each client has adequate closet and ample clothing. Each client has complete sets of towels, sheets, blankets and bedspreads. There is adequate hygiene and grooming supplies in client's bedroom. The kitchen is sanitary and in good repair. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. LPA Phillips conducted confidential interview with Program Director and resident present at facility. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. LPA will return to interview additional staff and that were not present during the initial inspection. Exit Interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left at facility

On 09/29/2021 at 10:10AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zena Phillips made an announced visit to Key Housing for Annual Continuation licensing Inspection. LPA met with Artis Carhee 111, Program Director who granted access to the facility. LPA Phillips reviewed the following during the inspection: Staff records review and client record review.. LPA Phillips observed first aid kit, fire extinguisher, and private bathroom. Facility vehicles was operable, clean, free of damage and had current registration and insurance. LPA reviewed Criminal Records and confirmed that all current staff were cleared. LPA Phillips reviewed staff records and client records. LPA interviewed staff present during this inspection. Only i staff file had mandatory reporter training and current CPR card. All other staff files did not have complete required documents. LPA Phillips advised Artis Carhee 111 Program Director of the missing required documents for staff files. LPA Phillips advised training certificates, job duties . Program Director stated would update filed immediately and add required documents to file.

On 11/16/2023 at 09:30 AM, (LPA) Licensing Program Analyst - Dennis Jarmin made an unannounced visit to Key Housing Group Home to conduct the annual required inspection. LPA met with Jack Muldoon, Program Director, who granted access to the facility. LPA then inspected the entire physical plant of the facility. The Group Home is licensed and provides care and supervision for six (6) children, ages 12-17, Ambulatory only. There are no bodies of water on the premises and security camera surveillance are placed outside area of the home. The Group Home Administrator confirmed that there are no guns or weapons stored on the premises. The facility is a two story home with 3 bedrooms and 3 full bathrooms plus 2 (1/2) bath. LPA observed the facility clean and sanitized with clean linens, appropriate drawer storage and closet available for clients clothing. The 3 and 2 (1/2) bathrooms were observed clean and sanitary with the required hot water temperature within the regulation. The dining room and living room area had appropriate seatings, and furniture were in good repair condition. The facility has central air conditioning unit that provides suitable air temperature throughout the home with appropriate lighting. LPA observed all the windows in good condition and observed 5 window screens that had tears but a work order to replace the screens today was submitted today. There were no bars on the windows in the event of an emergency evacuation and all passageway, stairs and porches were clear of obstruction and debris. All required posting were met (meal plan, daily activities, required licenses and regulations, personal rights and emergency disaster plan) that are posted in the common area readily accessible to clients.

LPA observed cleaning supplies solutions, bleaches and disinfectants are properly stored under the sink that is locked. Sharp knives were also observed locked and inaccessible on a separate cabinet. All the clients prescribed medications are in locked cabinet in the administrative office. LPA observed 8 battery operated smoke detectors and Carbon Monoxide, tested by the facility manager to be operable and audible. The garage is use for inside activity area and there is an on-site laundry area to the rear side of the house that is maintained cleaned and sanitized. The facility has a working telephone and clients can use the telephone when needed. There are appropriate supply of perishable (2 days) and (7 days) non perishable food. Clients are accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. The Facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. Facility has a current, written plan of operation. Facility personnel are instructed to report violations of personal rights. Licensee will report changes in the plan of operation affecting service to clients. Licensee will report client injuries requiring medical treatment and other incidents. LPA conducted two (2) Staff interviews and no Client interviews due to clients are all in school. LPA reviewed eight (8) Personnel files and five (5) Client records. During this inspection, LPA observed the facility to be clean, safe and sanitary. There were no deficiencies cited at this time only technical advisory. Exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to Evan Powell.

investigation_findings: 13On July 18, 2024, 11:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Rosslyn Gray made an unannounced visit to conclude the complaint investigation. Prior to entering the facility LPA Gray conducted a health and safety risk assessment. During the investigation, LPA Gray conducted confidential interviews, reviewed documentary evidence and photos. Licensee denied knowledge of the allegation. Based on confidential interviews and review of documentary evidence, statements were inconsistent. Documentary evidence indicated that during the pre-licensing inspection and fire inspection no garage was observed, and the facility was not found to have any compliance or safety concerns. Statements indicated that the property owner did not disclose to the Licensee that the garage was converted into a sound room when facility was leased. Statements indicated that the property owner completed this conversion without authorization from the City of Malibu and received a citation December 12, 2022.

On 3/06/2025 at 10:30 AM Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Kim Dear made an unannounced visit to the KEY TREATMENT 1, LLC facility for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection. LPA Dear was greeted by Jason Sobel, Lead Resident Advisor, who granted access into the facility. A health and safety assessment was conducted. The Executive Director, Elnaz Mayeh and shortly after, Matthew Cox the Program Director met with LPA dear and provided the current census, 5/6 clients. LPA Dear requested the LIC 500 and client roster; both documents were provided at time of inspection. The facility is a two story structure with five (5) bedrooms and three and half bathrooms located in a residential neighborhood. The facility is currently using three (3) bedrooms for clients, (1) room as a school room and (1) room for a lower office space. During the inspection LPA Dear conducted (2), two confidential interviews, reviewed three (3) staff files, and two (2) client files. The files were electronic and reviewed with the Program Director. LPA Dear observed the files to be in compliance. The facility kitchen has a double sink with garbage disposal, dishwasher, adequate cabinet and drawer space for dishes, utensils, and food storage. There is a large refrigerator and freezer combo in the kitchen with the weekly menu posted. The sharps are locked away in the staff office and used by the facility chef. The stove top has six (6) burners that LPA Dear observed to be functioning properly. There is a working land line (310) 589- 5588. Facility phone is located in the laundry room. One of four fire extinguishers was located on west wall facing the dining area, (1) in the kitchen were there is a small staff dining area with seating for six (6). LPA Dear observed the personal rights poster laminated and mounted on the wall. The Emergency Disaster Plan is posted on the staff dining room wall. Facility has a complaint box for clients to submit anonymous concerns located near the school room. Continued on 809- C

There is a common area with a non- operable fireplace. LPA Dear observed a large sofa, chairs, tables with lamps and adequate seating for (12), twelve. There is a half bathroom downstairs for staff use. LPA Dear observed a storage closet with adequate hygiene products, paper goods and a fully stocked pantry located at the front door. There is a second locked storage room for cleaning supplies located to the right of the stairs. The first bedroom (downstairs), has two (2) double beds with clean linens, lamps, table, a wall mounted television and a six (6) piece drawer dresser with adequate closet space for storage. The laundry room has an industrial sized washer, dryer and additional refrigerator and freezer combo for food storage. This room is locked with lockable cabinets for medicine storage and (4), four first aide kits thermometers included. There is an additional sink with counter providing adequate storage use. The second bedroom has two (2) double beds with clean linens, table, lamps, and a wall mounted television. LPA Dear observed two full bathrooms (downstairs), to have a tub and shower combo, toilet and sink. The water temperature was measured and found to be within safe temperatures, (at 105) Fahrenheit. LPA Dear observed the upstairs bedroom with two (2) double beds with clean linen, a (6), six dresser drawer, tables, lamps, with a full bathroom attached. Adequate closet space for storage was also observed. LPA Dear observed (8), eight working smoke/ carbon monoxide detectors. LPA Dear requested the detectors to be activated for testing. All units were confirmed operational. LPA Dear observed the facilities emergency drill log with dates and participants listed. All windows were in good repair with screens and blinds attached. LPA Dear observed the facility to have four (4) fire extinguishers, fully charged and wall mounted. The facility has a pool with a self latching locked gate. The gate's height was within compliance requirements. LPA observed the facility exterior grounds to be landscaped, well maintained and clear of all clutter, obstruction or debris. LPA reminded Matt Cox of reporting requirements. LPA Dear observed the facility to be clean, safe and sanitary. An exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to facility Elnaz Mayeh/ Executive Director and Matt Cox/Program Director.

investigation_findings: 13On July 17, 2025, at 1:15PM, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA), Justine Armstrong conducted an unannounced visit to the Key Treatment 1, LLC facility for the purpose of delivering findings for a complaint investigation alleging, 1) Staff did not provide adequate supervision, resulting in minors having inappropriate sexual interactions. 2) Staff did not intervene when minors had altercations with each other, and 3) Staff made an inappropriate comment to a minor. This complaint was received by the Department on February 7, 2024. Upon arrival, LPA was granted access to the facility by the Executive Director Elnaz Mayeh. This amended report reflects the original findings that were previously reviewed with and signed by the facility on January 23, 2025. The report is now being issued as the official version. The investigation conducted by LPA K.Dear included confidential interviews, as well as a review of incident reports, supervision logs, and other relevant documentation. Concerning the supervision issues, both interviews and documents did not support the claim that staff failed to adequately monitor clients. The statements provided were inconsistent and lacked corroborating evidence. Additionally, the allegation that staff failed to intervene during peer altercations was not substantiated; both records and interviews indicated that staff responded appropriately to these incidents. Lastly, the claim that a staff member made an inappropriate comment to a minor could not be confirmed. The statements were conflicting, and no witnesses were able to verify the allegation. Based on the confidential interviews and review of documentary evidence collected by LPA K.Dear, the Department has decided that the allegations are

13On July 17, 2025, at 1:15PM, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA), Justine Armstrong conducted an unannounced visit to the Key Treatment 1, LLC facility for the purpose of delivering findings for a complaint investigation alleging, (1) Staff forced minor in care to sleep on the floor (2) Staff did not provide adequate services to minor in care. This complaint was received by the Department on January 16, 2025. Upon arrival, LPA was granted access to the facility by the Facility Executive Director Elnaz Mayeh. The investigation conducted by LPA J. Armstrong included confidential interviews with staff and relevant documentation.Documentary evidence confirmed that staff did not force the minor in care to sleep on the floor. Furthermore, the allegation that staff did not provide adequate services to the minor was not supported, as records and interviews revealed inconsistent statements that could not be corroborated by evidence. The conflicting statements provided did not have any witnesses to verify the allegations. Based on the confidential interviews and review of documentary evidence collected by LPA J. Armstrong, the Department has decided that the allegations are

13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lourey Bartolome conducted a follow-up complaint investigation inspection and met with Facility Manager Amanda Chairez. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. Based on the interviews and review of documentation, there are inconsistencies in explanations of the above allegations. The allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the above-mentioned allegations. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time.

13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lidia Tinoco conducted an unannounced visit to the Kids First Alborada Group Home in Visalia in order to deliver the findings of the above allegations and met with Amanda Chairez, Administrator. On July 8, 2021 the above allegation was referred to Community Care Licensing for investigation. The investigation included interviews, facility inspection and a review of facility and children's records. The complaint alleged that group home staff inappropriately restrained youth. Based on the interviews conducted and the information reviewed there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Amanda Chairez along with appeal rights.

13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lidia Tinoco conducted an unannounced visit to the Kids First Alborada Group Home in Visalia in order to deliver the findings of the above allegations and met with Amanda Chairez, Administrator. On June 30, 2021 the above allegation was referred to Community Care Licensing for investigation. The investigation included interviews, facility inspection and a review of facility and children's records. The complaint alleged that a child in placement received an unexplained bruise while in care. Although the minor did have a bruise, there is no evidence to show how it happened. Therefore, the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Amanda Chairez along with appeal rights.

narrative: An unannounced annual inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's) Lidia Tinoco, Cynthia Galindo, and Vanessa Galvan traveled to Kids First Alborada in Visalia, CA. LPA's met with Administrator Amanda Chairez and inspected the facility, inside and out. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials observed. The facility is maintained at 75 degrees. All facility smoke detectors are in appropriate working order, fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods. All required forms are posted. Medications are locked and centrally stored. Individual beds were observed. No firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Fence surrounding the pool is in compliance. There are no pets at the facility. LPA's reviewed client files and conducted staff. Client interviews were not conducted due to the client being non-verbal. Deficiencies were cited on todays visit, see LIC809-D. A copy of this report was left at the facility at the conclusion of inspection.

On 5/24/23 at 10:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson conducted an announced, prelicensing inspection. LPA Wilson met with the applicant, David Yasutake, Facility Manager Chris Thompson and Assistant Manager Xiomara Lopez. The proposed facility will provide care and supervision for 6 ambulatory only female children, ages 12 through 17 years old. The facility is one-story home which contains three (3) bedrooms, and two (2) bathrooms. The home has a fully equipped kitchen and a spacious living room and dining room, that can be utilized as a multipurpose room for homework and activities. The front yard, and side yard was observed to be secure with a cement fence 7ft in height , free of obstructions, and neat. The facility maintains one facility vehicle, Honda Odyssey not at the facility at the time of the inspection. There are (2) charged fire extinguishers through the facility, last inspected on 3/25/23. (1) Carbon monoxide and (5) smoke detectors were tested and fully functioning. Detergents and cleaning supplies were observed to be locked and inaccessible to minors. Medication closet located in staff office was observed to be secured and inaccessible to minors. Facility files will be maintained within the staff office. LPA observed the following during inspection: Living Room: the living room is a large open space that functions as a area for relaxation, with plenty of seating for 8+ people, a TV will be purchased, books and games are available and a functioning window is without a screen .There is a working smoke detector and a carbon monoxide detector in this space Dining Area: Has a table with seating for (4) as well a a bar with seating for (4) with cabinet space. Kitchen: equipped with a stove (2) burners, microwave, oven, refrigerator, plenty of cabinet space, and enough plates/cups/utensils for all clients. Trash cans are covered. Dishwashing machine is in working order and will not be used. Hallway: The hallway has a (1) linen closet and maintains enough linen and towels for all residents. There is a working smoke detector in this space. (Continued on 809C)

Bedroom #1: Is adjacent to the living room, will be occupied by two clients with two twin size beds, dressed with clean linens, on each side of the room. There are adequate closets and (2) drawers (2). The bedroom does not serve as a passageway to any other part of the facility. Bedroom #2: will be occupied by two clients with two twin size beds, dressed with clean linens, on each side of the room. There are adequate closets (2)and (2) drawers. There is a functioning smoke alarm. The bedroom does not serve as a passageway to any other part of the facility. Bedroom #3 :will be occupied by two clients and maintain two twin beds, There is adequate closet (1) and (2) drawers. There is a functioning smoke alarm.. There is no window screen. Bathrooms- there are two (2) bathrooms throughout the facility, each with operational plumbing and running water that meets temperature requirements. Peach bathroom is shared with Bedroom 3 and staff. Blue bathroom is used for Bedrooms 1&2. Outdoor Space- the outdoor space has concrete. The Licensee communicates that it will be used " for clients to come outside and paint" There is a gazebo structure, with an empty, non-functioning covered spa. Laundry: located in the driveway area in a open shed and equipped with a washer and dryer in working order, Laundry detergents and cleaning supplies are kept in locked hallway closet and are inaccessible to clients without supervision. Backyard - there is an enclosed cement fence that extends around the perimeter of the facility that meets height requirements. There is no body of water on the premises. The front and side of the facility appeared clean and orderly with no hazards. Medication station- medications will be stored in a locked cabinet, in a closet in the staff office. The policy for medication administration will be posted on the inside of the door and was reviewed by LPA. Medication boxes were kept locked within the locked cabinet, with a standard key lock. Staff office- this office is located near the driveway and has laptops, a desk, and chairs. This space will be utilized for staff to conduct administrative duties, and where client records will be stored. LPA observed that door does lock. This area also functions to hold locked storage space for sharps, cleaning supplies, hygiene supplies and extra bathroom linen. There is no additional bathroom designated for staff. Licensee indicates that Bathroom #2 will be used by staff and clients. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was discussed emailed to the licensee.

(1) Carbon monoxide and (5) smoke detectors were tested and fully functioning. Detergents and cleaning supplies were observed to be locked and inaccessible to minors. Medication closet located in staff office was observed to be secured and inaccessible to minors. Facility files will be maintained within the staff office. LPAs observed the following during inspection: Living Room: the living room is a large open space that functions as a area for relaxation. There is a new couch with plenty of seating for 8+ people, a TV will be purchased, books and games are available and a functioning window is still without a screen .There is a working smoke detector and a carbon monoxide detector in this space Dining Area: Has a table with seating for (4) as well a a bar with seating for (4) with cabinet space. Kitchen: equipped with a stove (2) burners, microwave, oven, refrigerator, plenty of cabinet space, and enough plates/cups/utensils for all clients. Trash cans are covered. Dishwashing machine is in working order and will not be used. Water temperature is 111 degrees. Hallway: The hallway has a (1) linen closet and maintains enough linen and towels for all residents. There is a working smoke detector in this space. (Continued on 809C Page 2)

Bedroom #1: Is adjacent to the living room, will be occupied by two clients with two twin size beds, dressed with clean linens, on each side of the room. There are adequate closets and (2) drawers (2). The bedroom does not serve as a passageway to any other part of the facility. Bedroom #2: will be occupied by two clients with two twin size beds, dressed with clean linens, on each side of the room. There is a new area rug. There are adequate closets (2)and (2) drawers. There is a functioning smoke alarm. The bedroom does not serve as a passageway to any other part of the facility. Bedroom #3 :will be occupied by two clients and maintain two twin beds, There is adequate closet (1) and (2) drawers. There is a functioning smoke alarm.. There is still no window screen. Bathrooms- there are two (2) bathrooms throughout the facility, each with operational plumbing and running water that meets temperature requirements. Peach bathroom is shared with Bedroom 3 and staff. Blue bathroom is used for Bedrooms 1&2. Water temperature is 111 degrees. Outdoor Space- the outdoor space has concrete. The Licensee communicates that it will be used " for clients to come outside and paint" There is a gazebo structure, with an empty, non-functioning covered spa. There are wires dangling from the building that pose a safety risk when clients are in care. AM stated he will find a way to secure wires to mitigate safety risk. Laundry: located in the driveway area in a open shed and equipped with a washer and dryer in working order, Laundry detergents and cleaning supplies are kept in locked hallway closet and are inaccessible to clients without supervision. Backyard - there is an enclosed cement fence that extends around the perimeter of the facility that meets height requirements. There is no body of water on the premises. The front and side of the facility appeared clean and orderly with no hazards. Medication station- medications will be stored in a locked cabinet, in a closet in the staff office. The policy for medication administration will be posted on the inside of the door and was reviewed by LPA. Medication boxes were kept locked within the locked cabinet, with a standard key lock. Staff office- this office is located near the driveway and has laptops, a desk, and chairs. This space will be utilized for staff to conduct administrative duties, and where client records will be stored. LPA observed that door does lock. This area also functions to hold locked storage space for sharps, cleaning supplies, hygiene supplies and extra bathroom linen. There is no additional bathroom designated for staff. Licensee indicates that Bathroom #2 will be used by staff and clients. There is a functioning smoke alarm. (Continued on 809C page 3)

LPA Wilson and LPA Haynes inspected the following: Conducted a review of staff records, Program Statement, Plan of Operation and Emergency Plans. LPAs conducted a staff interview with (AM). There are no clients residing in the facility at this time. Core Theraputic Services: No clients receive core theraputic, psychiatric and medical services, as part of their needs and services plan. There are no clients in care Special Health Care Needs:There are no clients with special health care . There are no clients in care PER California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Chapter 7.5 Version 3, The following deficiencies were cited at this time. Six (6) Technical Advisories will be given on this day.(See LIC809-D) ILS 87072(c)(6)(A ILS 87072(c)(6)(B ILS 87087.2(a) ILS 80066(a)(8) ILS 87065.1(d)(1)(A) ILS 87065.1(d)(1)(D)(4) Three (3) Type B violations will be given on this day. (See LIC809-D) An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was discussed emailed to the licensee.
