narrative:
On March 29, 2024 at 10:00am, a Non-Compliance Conference Meeting was held virtually, with the El Segundo Regional Office. Those In attendance were: · Regional Manager (RM), Kellee Coleman · Licensing Program Manager (LPM), Kevin Sauk · Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Christine Wilson · CEO/Administrator, David Yasutake · Facility Manager, Chris Thompson · Facility Manager, Madison Pennington · Assistant Manager, Vanessa Duarte The office meeting was called to discuss the Licensee's attempts and efforts at obtaining a Mental Health Program Approval (MHPA), in order to determine whether an extension shall be provided for the provisional license. RM Coleman provided an overview of Community Care Licensing's (CCL's) history of support towards the licensee. Kids to Kids has not yet been able to obtain a MPHA, and discussions with CCL's legal department will explore whether the Licensee will be able to extend their provisional license expiration date. The meeting included a discussion of the attempts and challenges the Licensee has been facing with regard to obtaining an MPHA, and with staffing. Continued on 809C page 2 of 2.

Page 2 The licensee (CEO) agreed to the actions specified below: Licensee is to Provide LPM and LPA weekly contact with updates each Friday. Licensee is to continue communications with DHCS and Kern County. Licensee is to explore other facility types. Licensee is to send CCLD update and/or copy of CARF Accreditation Approval. Licensee is to ensure all staff are associated to this facility through the use of Guardian. The Regional Office can support with association transfers. Licensee is to submit a closure plan if the Licensee is unable to obtain a MPHA approval by the 12-month expiration date. This meeting ended at 11:22am. Exit interview completed, and a copy of this report was emailed to the Licensee.

On 05/31/24 at 09:50AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jhane Haynes made an unannounced visit to the above facility for the purpose of conducting annual inspection. LPA met with Madison Pennington (FM) who granted access to the facility and provided tour of the home. It is a three bedroom and two bathroom home in a residential area. LPA observed the following: Office is inaccessible to clients unless allowed for 1:1 or privacy. It contains desk, chairs, client hygiene boxes,two exterior exits,staff fridge, secured freezer for extra food stock, board with client and facility information. It also contains a secured closet that holds client medications, sharps, extra hygiene products, client files and electronics. Hall connects both bathrooms and two bedrooms. The wall contains emergency contact numbers, complaint procedures, personal rights and license. It also contains a secured closet that contains cleaning supplies. Bathroom #1 is called the peach bathroom containing functional toilet, sink and tub/shower combo. Bedroom #1 rooms C2 and contains two twin beds, two dressers and closet. Bathroom #2 is called the blue bathroom and contains functioning toilet, sink, and tub/shower combo. Bedroom#2 rooms C3 and contains two twin beds, 2 dressers, and closet. Kitchen/Dining Area contains operational kitchen appliances table and adequate seating for clients during meal times. Menu is posted on fridge. Fridge maintains perishables for at least two days. Cabinets maintain non-perishables for up to a week, adequate plating and silverware for clients. There is an exterior exit. Bedroom #3 rooms C1 and C4. It contains two twin beds, dresser, shelf, three closets and desk. Living Room contains two couches, TV, and shelf with books and games. There are two exterior exits. Exterior is free of debris and contains utility shutoffs. Laundry appliances are stored on side of the home and functional. Facility utilizes 2007 Chevrolet Tahoe with current registration and insurance to transport clients. (Continued on LIC809-C)

Due to time constraints. LPA will return to complete file review. No deficiencies will be cited today. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

On 05/31/24 at 09:50AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jhane Haynes made an unannounced visit to the above facility to conduct a case management inspection for the purpose of documenting deficiency observed 04/30/24. LPA met with Madison Pennington (FM) who granted access to the facility. On 04/30/24 It was observed during initial complaint inspection that 11 out of 17(S1-S11) staff did not obtain criminal record clearance. Per Title 22 Division 6 Chapter 1, one deficiency will be cited. See LIC809-D for details. A copy of this report and appeal rights were left at the facility.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: All individuals subject to a criminal record review pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1522 shall prior to working, residing or volunteering in a licensed facility obtain a California clearance or a criminal record exemption as required by the Department This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on a record review, the licensee did not comply with the section cited above by 11 out of 17 staff membersdid not obtain criminal record clearance. This poses an immediate health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.

investigation_findings: 13On 2/12/24, at 9:45 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nestor Gomez made an unannounced inspection to the above facility for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegations and deliver the findings. LPA spoke with Facility Manager, Madison Pennigton and together, discussed the investigative findings. During the investigative process by Licensing program Analyst (LPA), Nestor Gomez, all relevant parties have been accounted for and interviewed. During the confidential interviews, the validity of the allegations could not be determined. The parties interviewed either confirmed or denied the allegations. Staff/client accounts of the incident were conflicting. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. Exit Interview conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

narrative:
On March 29, 2022, at 3:33pm Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Enrique Hernandez and Nancy O’Connell made an announced inspection to the Kids to Kids- Serenity House for the purpose of conducting Pre-Licensing inspection. LPAs met with applicant David Yasutake and facility representatives Madison Pennington Facility Manager (FM), Danny Bakst Head of Service (HS) who granted access to the facility. The entire physical plant was inspected. This is a three-bedroom, two-bathroom, single story family residence that includes a living room, dining area, kitchen, laundry area and a carport. There is no swimming pool or bodies of water on the premises. The home is currently vacant and there is no food in the home at the time of inspection. LPAs inspected the facility with the Licensee and observed the following: Bedroom #1: Is vacant, it has two twin sized beds, adequate closet and drawer space. Bedroom #2: Is vacant, it has two twin size beds, adequate closet and drawer space. Bedroom #3: Is vacant, it has two twin size beds, adequate closet and drawer space. Bathrooms: The home is equipped with three (2) Bathrooms. Bathroom one (1) is located next to bedroom #1 is equipped with one sink, shower and a toilet. Bathroom #2 is located adjacent to the master bedroom with one sink, a toilet bathtub and shower. All bathrooms were operable at time of inspection. LPA tested the hot water temperature during the time of the inspection the water temperature is 110 degree which meets the requirements. Living Room: There was an attached room space which will be utilized as game room/study room. There is a fireplace with the cover on. There was a rug and TV on the floor. There were a total of (3) fire extinguisher in the throughout the house. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and operable at time of inspection. Continue on LIC809-C

Hallway: linen closet for extra storage. The carport is detached to the home is where the facility van is kept and additional refrigerator is stored. Kitchen: There was one (1) refrigerator, one (1) stove one (1) microwave and all appliances were operable at the time of the inspection. Laundry room equipped with a sink, one (1) washer and one (1) dryer. The outdoor space is free of debris and any hazards. Emergency disaster plan and personal rights are posted at the facility. Cleaning solutions, disinfectants, and sharp knives were locked at the time of the inspection. An advisory was provided to obtain locked box for knives due to knives being stored in drawer with other non-cook ware items. Area is designated for medication and will be locked and accessible only to employees supervising stored medications. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and operable at the time of inspection. LPAs observed two fire extinguishers in the kitchen and around the home that were operable at the time of inspection. The first aid kits are fully stocked. The bathrooms were inspected and found to be clean. The facility has a working telephone. Licensee states that there is no weapons or guns on the premises. During the time of inspection, the facility vehicle wasn't at the facility and is being utilized by their other facility until clients are present in the current facility. The home is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. LPA O'Connell received a copy of the CPR and First Aid certificate which was completed on 03/25/2022. Applicant stated that he would: Paint the interior of the facility, clean the vent grate in the main hallway Obtain new shower head in bathroom #1 Clear out backyards weeds Get rid of desk in dining room Continue on LIC809-C

Place work order for the following needs: Missing cabinet drawer in closet for Level 4 bedroom Secure cabinet doors to close tightly where chemicals are stored Fire Clearance still pending. The licensee was informed that once the Licensing Program Manager receives and reviews this report, then a provisional license will be granted. Due to technical difficulties with the LPA's printer, a copy of this report will be emailed to the applicant.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kuliema Calloway and Licensing Program Manager (LPM), Kevin Sauk made an announced inspection to the Kids to Kids- Faith House on June 30, 2022 at 1:00pm for the purpose of conducting a Post Licensing Inspection. LPA/LPM met with FA who granted access to the facility. The entire physical plant was inspected. The facility is licensed to care for six (6) female clients, ages 12-17 years, ambulatory only (See confidential name list LIC811 dated 6/30/2022). This is a three-bedroom, two-bathroom, single story family residence that includes a living room, dining area, kitchen, laundry area and a carport. Annual fee is current. LPA inspected the facility with the S1 and observed the following: Bedroom #1: Is occupied by Client (C4) Bedroom #2: Is occupied by Clients (C1 and C3), Bedroom #3: Is occupied by Client (C2) There is no swimming pool or any other bodies of water on the premises. The passageways, stairways, and open porches are unobstructed. The rules, menu, regulations, licenses, emergency disaster plan and personal rights are posted at the facility. The outdoor space is free of debris and any hazards. Cleaning solutions, disinfectants, medication and sharp knives are inaccessible to the clients. Medication is locked and accessible only to employees supervising stored medications. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detector were tested and operable at the time of inspection. LPA/LPM observed a fire extinguisher in the kitchen and in near the front door of the facility that was operable at the time of inspection. Report continues on LIC-809C

The first aid kit is fully stocked. The bathrooms were inspected and found to be clean. The facility has a working telephone. FA states that there is no weapons or guns on the premises. Clients are allowed to use the telephone unless restricted by court order. Clients are accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. Clients live in a safe, healthy, comfortable facility and are treated with respect. Clients attend school, extracurricular, cultural, and personal enrichment activities. Clients can contact Community Care Licensing or Foster Care Ombudsman office in confidence without threats or punishment. Facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. Facility has a current, written plan of operation. Facility personnel are instructed to report violations of personal rights. Licensee will report changes in the plan of operation affecting service to clients. Licensee will report client injuries requiring medical treatment. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit Interview was conducted with FA and a copy of this report was left with Facility Administrator.

On July 28, 2022, at 09:30am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olivia Rosas conducted an unannounced inspection to Kids to Kids- Serenity House Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) for the purpose to continue with open complaint investigation. LPA Rosas and Staff#1 (S1), Staff#2 (S2) discussed the allegations details on the open complaint investigation (See confidential name list LIC811 dated 07/28/22). During the course of this inspection LPA Rosas, interviewed S1, S2, Client#1 (C1), Client#2 (C2). Client#3 (C3). LPA Rosas did record review and did facility inspection. Additional interviews with pertinent parties will be conducted on later date. Based on the interview, information gathered, and documentation received there was insufficient information to support that the above allegation occurred. This complaint allegation needs further investigation. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left to S#1.

On August 25, 2022, at 12:30 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Kuliema Calloway, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM), Kevin Sauk, conducted an unannounced Case Management Deficiency Inspection at Kids to Kids Serenity House located at the above address. David Yasutake, Facility Administrator (FA), granted access into the facility and together conducted a tour of the entire facility, inside and out. The purpose of this inspection is to document deficiencies that were observed, on 06/30/2022, during the Post-Licensing inspection. On 06/30/2022, LPA and LPM observed 16 out of 24 staff members (S1 through S16) from the LIC-500 provided to licensing staff that did not have criminal background clearance. (See confidential name list LIC-811 dated 08/25/2022). On 8/25/2022, LPA and LPM observed the following items: An outside vent cover is ripped that allows access underneath the house. The carpet in two of the bedrooms was ripped and in disrepair. The walls have stains and need painting. Board Member's wife, (PJ) came into the facility to cook with the staff and was not fingerprint cleared to be in the facility. The following deficiencies were observed, and cited. (See LIC 809-D) Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left with Madison Pennington, Facility Manager.

On September 1, 2022, at 09:30am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olivia Rosas conducted an unannounced inspection to Kids to Kids- Serenity House Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) for the purpose to conduct a Case Management-Other (Medication) inspection. During the inspection, LPA Rosas met with Staff#1 (S1) and inspected the psychotropic medication. LPA reviewed two (2) client records on site at the facility. During the review of clients records, LPA Rosas observed 1 out of 2 clients (Client #1) taking Psychotropic Medication did not have a current JV 223. Facility stated, C1 arrived to the facility with expired JV 223 and they are currently waiting updated one from County of placement. The updated JV 223 was submitted to County of Placement on August 18, 2022. Based on record review on 09/01/2022, LPA Rosas observed C1 did not have a current JV 223 which poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care. One deficiency was observed (refer to LIC 809D) and facility is cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Version 4, Article 6. Children’s Records 87070(b)(11) A copy of the current court order, or written authorization of the child’s parent or guardian, for each psychotropic medication. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

On September 20, 2022, at 1:15 PM., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Kuliema Calloway, arrived to conduct a Plan of Correction (POC) follow-up inspection in order to see if the deficiencies cited on 8/25/2022 were corrected. There are three clients in care and five staff members. LPA observed the carpet in Bedrooms #1 and #2 were in still in disrepair. In Bedroom #3, the ceiling fan and the ceiling need cleaning. In Bedroom #1 and Bedroom #2, the stains on the wall were still visible. Bedroom #1 and Bedroom #2 were not painted as previously advised. Bedrooms #1, #2, and #3 had clothes in the middle of the room and floor. The outside vent still was not closed off. LPA took photos. There was a POC due date of 9/15/2022 which was not met. LPA asked licensee about the reason for not correcting the deficiency and the licensee stated, "There was a COVID outbreak in the facility on 9/5/2022 and a handyman could not come on site to do the painting during that time. We are currently prepping to paint which is why everything is in the middle of the floor. I got in touch with a local carpet cleaning and repair place on 8/25/22 and as of now there isn't an appointment set for them to come out and it is the only company so far that I have contacted. It should take us at least two days to finish painting. The repair man was on vacation and will be out to seal the outside vent this week. The original request was made on 6/30/2022.." LPA obtained a copy of the repair request list. The facility was given another POC due date of 10/10/2022. Exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report were left at the facility with FA.

On October 10, 2022, at 10:30 AM., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Kuliema Calloway, arrived to conduct a Plan of Correction (POC) follow-up inspection in order to see if the deficiencies cited on 8/25/2022 were corrected. LPA was greeted by S1. Client C4 is in care with Staff member, S1, and FA. [See LIC 811- Confidential Names List dated 10/10/2022]. LPA observed the carpet in Bedrooms #1 and #2 has been cleaned. In Bedroom #3, the ceiling fan and the ceiling has been cleaned. In Bedroom #1 and Bedroom #2, the walls were painted. Bedroom #1 and Bedroom #2 were painted as previously advised. The outside vent was closed off. LPA took photos. Therefore, the POC due date of 10/10/2022 was met. Exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report were left at the facility with FA.

On January 8, 2023 at 10:10 AM, Associate Governmental Program Analyst (AGPA) Tonya L. Barnes-Woodard conducted an announced case management other visit at Kids to Kids - Serenity House. During today's inspection, AGPA Woodard conducted a tour of the facility with Vanessa Bracamontes, and the following deficiencies were observed (see LIC 809D). Plan of corrections were discussed with staff and a copy of this report was left.

On March 9, 2023, at 12:45 PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs), Olivia Rosas and Christine Wilson made an unannounced visit to Kids to Kids- Faith House Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) for the purpose of conducting an Annual inspection. LPA Rosas and Wilson met with Staff#1(S1) who granted access to the facility and an inspection of the facility was conducted together. Individuals mention in this report are identify on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated 03/09/2023. LPAs met with Staff#1 (S1), who granted access into the home, and who provided a tour of the entire physical plant. This facility has a provisional Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) license to provide care and supervision for six (6) female children ages 13-17 years old, Ambulatory only. There is no pool or bodies of water on the premises. The facility currently pending Accreditation with CARF International. The facility is in the process of obtaining a Mental Health Program Approval contract with the Department of Health Care Services and Ventura County. Staff confirmed that there are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the facility. The facility is current with their annual fees. LPA Rosas inspected the following: This is a one (1) story (STRP) Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program, located in a residential neighborhood. This is a three (3) three-bedroom, two (2) bathrooms, one (1) staff office in single story family residence that includes a living room, dining area, kitchen, backyard, and an attached garage used for storage. There are two (2) facility vehicles parked outside inspected to be in good operating condition. Outdoor Area: There was no swimming pool or bodies of water on the premises. The activity space is free of hazard materials and debris. LPA observed a staff displayed the utility shut-off valves. The facility is surrounded by brick fence and wire fence is observed to be good condition. The passageways and porches are unobstructed. Report continues on LIC 809-C Page 1 of 4

Laundry Area: The washer and dryer units are located next to the kitchen. The laundry is equipped with a washer and dryer unit that was observed to be in good condition. The laundry detergent is made inaccessible to the children and is disputed according to the load of the laundry. Disinfectants and chemicals are locked and made inaccessible to clients in the staff office. Dining Area/Kitchen: There is adequate furniture which appears to be in good condition. The living room has dining table and televisions. The facility has one living room areas used for recreating and activity room, which provide the necessary space and/or separation to promote and facilitate the program of planned activities and to prevent such activities from interfering with other functions. The living area has game board games, books, DVDs, magazines and art supplies. Kitchen: There is a gas stove/oven with four (4) burners, all operating. There is a dishwasher, microwave, refrigerator with freezer and a toaster oven. LPAs observed adequate perishable/nonperishable food supplies. The facility supplies a staple nonperishable food for a minimum of one week and fresh perishable foods for a minimum of two days shall be maintained on the premises. Sharp knives, disinfectants/cleaning solutions made inaccessible to the youth locked in the staff office. Water temperature measured within safe temperatures, at not less than 105 and did not exceed 120 degrees Fahrenheit. Staff Office: The office is equipped office furniture (i.e desk, computers, printers). Medication is kept locked inside of the staff office. The client and staff files are kept in a locked in file cabinet. LPA observed a key locked closet that stored hygiene supplies, cleaning solutions, and medication. Additional disinfectants, chemicals, hygiene supplies and medication are locked in storage closet in the living room making inaccessible. The office has additional a deep freezer for food. LPA observed overstock of nonperishable food, frozen food, snacks, and supplies. Bedroom # 1: Currently occupied by two (2) clients, has two (2) twin sized beds and comfortable mattresses, linen, blankets and pillows; adequate drawer and one (1) walk in closet. There is adequate lighting, and the windows have horizontal slide locked with curtains observed to be in good condition. Report continues on LIC 809-C Page 2 of 4

Bedroom # 2: Currently occupied by one (1) client, has two (2) twin sized beds and comfortable mattresses, linen, blankets and pillows; adequate drawer and one (1) walk in closet. There is adequate lighting, and the windows have horizontal slide locked with curtains observed to be in good condition. Bedroom # 3: Is vacant. The bedroom has two (2) twin sized beds and comfortable mattresses, linen, blankets and pillows; adequate drawer and one (1) walk in closet. There is adequate lighting, and the windows have horizontal slide locked with curtains observed to be in good condition. Bathrooms: There are two (2) bathrooms. Bathroom #1 is a full-sized bathroom with a toilet, sink, and shower. Bathroom #2 is full-sized bathroom with a toilet, sink, and shower. Water temperature measured within safe temperatures, at not less than 105 and did not exceed 120 degrees Fahrenheit. Garage: The garage is kept locked and only staff uses has access to the garage. The attached two car garage is used as storage and is kept locked. The garage has additional fridge and deep freezer for food. LPA observed overstock of supplies. There are two (2) vehicles available to transport youths; make and model are a Honda 2006, and 2007 Chevrolet Tahoe. The vehicles used to transport clients appeared to be in a safe operating condition. The registration of the vehicles was valid. The vehicle has full coverage auto insurance with HUB International Insurance Services Inc. During the facility was inspected, the following was observed: LPA observed a key locked closet that stored hygiene supplies, and cleaning solutions. All windows were in good condition with screens and blinds. There were no security bars on the windows. There are two (2) fire extinguishers and was fully charged and carbon monoxide detectors were working properly in the facility. LPA observed ample towels and linen closet. LPA observed several First Aid Kit complete with scissors, tweezers, thermometer, gauzes, antiseptic and a 1st Aid Manual in the staff office, medication cabinet, and garage. All posting requirements were met (food menu, regulations, licenses, emergency disaster plan, Children’s Personal Rights, and Ombudsman). The Emergency Evacuation Plan is posted). The home has a working telephone and youths can use the telephone unless restricted by court order. The living room and staff office is utilized for clients to make phones calls and the Phone Call Log is kept near the facility phone. The youth reported having their own cell phone to be able to make phone calls. Report continues on LIC 809-C Page 3 of 4

LPA Rosas reviewed following during the inspection: LPA Rosas requested the following forms for review, Register of Youth (LIC 9020), Current Census, Personnel Report (LIC 500), Emergency Disaster Plan (LIC610C), Emergency Intervention Plan, vehicles registration and auto insurance. In addition, written menus, staff weekly and schedule. Staff Records Review: LPA ensured Administrator Certificate was current. LPA reviewed the Personnel Report (LIC 500) and confirmed that Direct Care Staff Ratio present for the three (3) clients in placement. LPA confirmed that all staff have required criminal record clearance. DOJ, FBI and Child Abuse Response, which meet qualification. LPA Rosas was not able to complete staff file, client file review,and staff interviews and will need to return to facility to complete the staff file review. A review of Facility's Personnel Report Summary on 03/07/2023 indicates that all personnel have criminal record clearance has obtain the necessary clearances with DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse Response. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

investigation_findings: 13On March 7, 2023 at 9:20am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O’Connell made unannounced inspection to the above said facility for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegation and deliver the finding. LPA O’Connell met with FM and discussed the investigative finding. On 11/29/22, the Department received a complaint alleging that minor did not receive therapeutic services while in care. During the investigative process, LPA O’Connell conducted confidential interviews with all relevant parties and collected information on the above allegations. After reviewing all the statements and the information obtained, the above allegation is supported, as the confidential interviews confirmed that the minor was transferred to the above facility, at which time, was not enrolled into therapeutic services. Further confidential interviews revealed that the facility did not retain records that could confirm the provision of therapeutic services during the time that the minor was residing in the facility. Based on LPAs observations and interviews which were conducted and record reviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, one deficiency is being cited on the attached LIC 9099D Exit Interview conducted, and sent copy of this report was sent to the facility.

narrative: On 12/20/2023 at 10:45 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jhane Haynes, initiated a case management inspection at the above-said facility and met with Direct Care Staff(DCS) Venessa Duarte, in response to a Special Incident Report that was reported to Community Care Licensing (CCL) on 12/19/2023. The purpose of this inspection is to inform the facility that an investigation is being conducted regarding a possible Neglect/Lack of Supervision violation, involving the death of client (C1) on 12/13/2023, after C1 had been hospitalized due to a drug overdose, from 12/03/2023 to 12/13/2023. After conducting a quick walk-through of the facility, LPA acquired a current staff and client roster. LPA requested a copy of C1's death certificate, as well as a completed Death Report (LIC624A form) be submitted to Community Care Licensing, as soon as possible. Further investigation is required in order to resolve the investigation. There are no deficiencies to be cited at the time of this inspection. continued from 9099 page 1 It was reported that FM stated the PO said to keep C1 home from school so that they wouldn’t have to track C1 at school, and in other interviews it was communicated by FM with management and staff that the PO said to keep C1 home. deficiencies.plan_of_correction: PERSONAL RIGHTS The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, as applicable. WIC 16001.9 (a)(13) states a client has the right to attend school and participate in extracurricular, cultural, and personal enrichment activities, consistent with the child's age and developmental level, with minimal disruptions to school attendance and educational stability. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews conducted on December 2nd with S1, S2, FA, and PO and on the 3rd with FM, the licensee did not allow C1 to attend school and gave C1 false information in order to keep C1 home. This posed an immediate Personal Rights risk to clients in care.

narrative: Confidential statements and documentary evidence, including review of medical records determined Y1 overdosed on Fentanyl and recovered within two days after being admitted to the hospital. Y1 was then placed on watch by the hospital staff; however, Y1 was able to obtain drugs and overdosed a second time resulting in Y1’s death. Based on gathered information obtained and reviewed, there is not enough evidence to support neglect/lack of supervision; therefore, the findings are determined Unsubstantiated. A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. investigation_findings: 13On April 9, 2024, at 4:45 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Regina Martin conducted a follow-up complaint inspection at Kids to Kids – Serenity House to deliver findings concerning the above-mentioned allegation. LPA Martin spoke with David Yasutake, Administrator via telephone to discuss the investigative outcome. The investigation was conducted by Investigator Peter Zertuche of the Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) Investigations Branch. The investigation, including confidential interviews of three residents, three staff members, Facility Manager, Youth #1’s (Y1) assigned Social Worker, Therapist, assigned Detective, Ventura Police Department, review of Y1’s records and review of related medical reports revealed on December 21, 2023, CCLD received a complaint allegation concerning neglect/lack of supervision related to Y1. Youth #1 was first placed at Kids to Kids – Serenity House on September 6. 2023. On December 6, 2023, CCLD received a self-reported incident indicating that on December 3, 2023, staff found Y1 at the facility at “6:06 am” of an apparent drug overdose. Y1 was unresponsive so 911 emergency was called. Staff performed Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPR) until paramedics arrived then transported Y1 to the hospital where Y1 recovered. (Continued on page LIC9099-C)

narrative: On 05/31/24 at 09:50AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jhane Haynes made an unannounced visit to the above facility for the purpose of conducting a case management inspection to ensure location is not in operation. LPA spoke with A1 and S1 who confirmed home was vacant. No deficiencies will be cited today. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegations. LPA Jones-Steward interviewed several staff, several witnesses and the alleged victim (C1). LPA also reviewed police reports and the facility's runaway plan. LPA did not find a Special Incident Report for this incident. During the course of the investigation LPA Jones-Steward determined that the staff on duty during the incident waited for several hours after the onset of C1's crisis to contact law enforcement and paramedics. Likewise it was determined that staff are not adhereing to the facility's runaway plan. Staff often waits in excess of an hour to report missing clients even though the runaway plan indicates that missing clients will be reported to law enforcement within 30 minutes. It was also determined that the facility had no clear plans for accompanying C1 to the hospital or supervising her while she was there. Based on information found during the investigation, the above allegations are resolved as substantiated, meaning that the “preponderance of the evidence” standard has been met.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Care & Supervision The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. The licensee failed to meet this requirement by not obtaining timely emergency medical attention for the client and also by not having a clear plan to accompany her to the hospital or supervise her during her hospitalization

Runaway Plan The licensee must develop, maintain and, when necessary, execute a written runaway plan. The licensee failed to meet this requirement. During the investigation it was revelaed that the facility staff are failing to meet the written runaway plan by not making missing persons reports as outlined in the plan.

Reporting Requirements The licensee shall report any unusual incident or client absence which threatens the physical or emotional health or safety of any client to the Department. The licensee failed to meet this requirement by not reporting the incident to the department.

investigation_findings: On March 27, 2025, at 10:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Justine Armstrong arrived at the facility to deliver the findings of a complaint investigation. narrative: Confidential interviews revealed that C1 has a shower daily and that C1 is able to take care of C1’s own bathroom needs. Confidential interviews and personal observation revealed that the clients backpacks are cleaned out daily and the staff know to look for dirty clothes and food in backpacks. Other confidential interviews state that the clients would let the staff know if there was food sent home as they like to eat it. A confidential witness still maintains that the allegations are true. The allegation that facility staff did not ensure the group home child was adequately and cleanly dressed specifically refers to C1 having dried feces on sweat pants, C1 not wearing underwear, and that C1 has worn the same shorts twice in one week. Confidential interviews revealed that the clients clothes are washed if not daily every other day. Confidential interviews also revealed that while the staff lay the clothes out for C1 for the day C1 will dress self and that C1 owns three sets of the exact same shorts so it seems that C1 is wearing the same shorts more than once a week however they are a new clean pair of shorts. Other confidential interviews revealed that they have not seen C1 wear the same clothes more than once without being washed. A confidential witness still maintains that the allegations are true. The allegation that group home children are not being adequately supervised specifically refers to the sexualized behavior between C1 and C2. C1 is constantly trying to touch C2’s butt and breasts and C1 will thrust pelvis at C2. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 and C2 have separate living rooms. When they are in the same room together there is always a staff member between them. None of the clients are allowed to sit on the same couch. All clients have their own bedrooms and no client is allowed in another client’s room. The staff at night have a clear field of vision down the hallway and are able to monitor the clients. A confidential witness still maintains that the allegations are true. Based on confidential interviews and record reviews, the allegations that facility staff is not meeting C1’s hygiene needs, facility staff did not ensure that C1 was adequately and cleanly dressed, and C1 and C2 are not being adequately supervised may have occurred, however, they are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to House manager Jesse Lozano.
investigation_findings: 13On August 27, 2021 at 2:20 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Linda Haynes met with Koa Home house manager (HM) Jesse Lozano to deliver the investigation findings for the above stated allegations. LPA conducted confidential interviews with HM Jesse Lozano, Clinical Director (CD) Samee Arastu, Staff 1 and 2 (S1 adn S2) and social worker (SW) Wing Kwong . LPA also attempted to interview client 1 (C1) and client 2 (C2) however they are both non-verbal and could therefore not be interviewed. LPA also obtained and reviewed copies of Applied Behavior Analysis Consultation for C1 and C2. On June 1, 2021 a complaint was received alleging that facility staff is not meeting group home child’s hygiene needs, facility staff did not ensure that group home child was adequately and cleanly dressed, and group home children are not being adequately supervised. The allegation that facility staff is not meeting group home hygiene needs specifically refers to C1 having old toilet paper stuck to butt, C1 having a foul odor, C1 having a dry scalp, and that C1 takes food home from school and it is not cleaned out of C1’s backpack and returns to school the next day with spoiled food in backpack. (Continued on next page)

narrative:
On Friday September 24, 2021 at 10:05 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Linda Haynes and LPA Lisi Leon conducted an annual inspection of the facility. At time of inspection LPA met with Direct care staff Andrea Bonilla. The facility was toured inside and out with Direct Care Staff Andrea Bonilla. The home is a one-story residence with four bedrooms and three bathrooms. One client was present at time of inspection. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than one client is in a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. The medications were stored and locked in a cabinet in the Staff Office. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in closet in hallway above Washing Machine. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the Kitchen. The First Aid Kit is located in the staff office and contained all required supplies. The facility's smoke detectors in each bedroom were checked and were inoperable. The carbon monoxide detector located in living room and was inoperable. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Direct Care Staff Andrea Bonilla. LPA observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients as well. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Visitation policies, and current menu. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. Four of four client files were reviewed during the inspection and noted to have documents required per regulations in file. Four of four clients are non-verbal and therefore could not be interviewed.

Based on the facility inspection and file reviews this date, there are two deficiencies being cited at this time. This inspection was not able to be completed on this day. LPA will return to complete day two of the annual inspection at a later date. A copy of this report and appeal rights was reviewed and given to Direct Care Staff, Michael Covarrubias.

Confidential interviews revealed that C1 and C2 have separate living rooms. When they are in the same room together there is always a staff member between them. None of the clients are allowed to sit on the same couch. All clients have their own bedrooms and no client is allowed in another client’s room. The staff at night have a clear field of vision down the hallway and are able to monitor the clients. Based on confidential interviews and record reviews, the allegation that lack of supervision resulted in inappropriate interaction between minors C1 and C2 may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the above allegation is unsubstantiated. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to House manager Jesse Lozano.

narrative: An unannounced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Val Wilson, on May 12, 2022 at 11:20 AM. During the inspection, LPA Wilson met with Samee Arastu, PsyD, Clinical Director/Administrator, and Fernando Melendez, House Manager, inspected the facility inside and out. During the tour of the facility, at 11:30AM, LPA Wilson observed the medication cabinet, medication bottles, medication storage cabinet, and the office holding medications were locked. LPA reviewed four of the four children’s records on site at the facility at 12:30PM. During the review of children’s records, LPA Wilson observed 4 out of 4 children did not have a separate log for each psychotropic medication prescribed with the date and time of each dose taken by the child. LPA reviewed 3 of the staff personnel files on site at the facility at 3:00PM. LPA interviewed 3 of the staff on site at 4:00PM. LPA attempted to interview 4 of 4 children currently taking psychotropic medication at 2:00 PM. Each child was unable to answer the questions due to cognitive ability and their interviews ended at question 3. LPA conducted exit interview with Michael Covarrubias, DSP, and by phone with Samee Arastu, at 4:49PM. LPA provided the Summary Report to Michael Covarrubia, DSP, upon completion. One deficiency was observed (refer to LIC 809D) and cited from the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5. Group Homes, Article 6. Continuing Requirements and Health & Safety Codes during the inspection.

On June 10, 2022 at 1030AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Val Wilson, arrived Koa Home Group Home (GH) for an unannounced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection. The purpose of the inspection was to complete the continuation SB 484 inspection that was initiated on May 12, 2022. The LPA was met by Samee Arastu, PsyD, Clinical Director/Administrator, and Fernando Melendez, House Manager. During this SB 484 inspection continuation: LPA reviewed Policy and Procedure and Program Design. LPA reviewed four of four client (Client 1- C1; Client 2- C2; Client 3- C3; Client 4- C4) Needs and Services Plans to ensure they contained all required documentation. During the review of children’s records, LPA Wilson observed 4 out of 4 children now have a separate log for each psychotropic medication prescribed with the date and time of each dose taken by the child. LPA conducted exit interview with Samee Arastu, at 12:20PM. LPA provided the Summary Report to Samee Arastu upon completion.

On 11/02/22 at 09:05 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarah Lo arrived at Koa Group Home (GH). LPA Lo was met and granted access by House Manager (HM), Fernando Meledez. The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the facility. At the time of inspection LPA met with HM Meledez and was given a tour inside and out. The home is a one-story residence with four bedrooms and three bathrooms. One client was present at time of inspection. At 09:10 am, LPA started the Physical Plant and bedrooms are arranged so that no more than one client is in a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. The medications were stored and locked in a cabinet in the Staff Office. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in closet in hallway above the washing machine. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the Kitchen. The First Aid Kit is located in the staff office and contained all required supplies. The facility's smoke detectors in each bedroom were checked and were inoperable. The carbon monoxide detector located in living room and was inoperable. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by HM Meledez. LPA observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 3-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients as well. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Visitation policies, and current menu. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. At 09:22 am, LPA observed four holes in the walls in the living room. Per ILS 84487(f) The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair at all times. HM Meledez stated there was an incident that happened last night with a client. HM Meledez stated a maintenance order has been sent out and will be here to fix in two days. Continue of LIC 809-C

There is fully fenced backyard with adequate outdoor activity space, free of clutter or debris and well maintained. The outdoor area included a patio set with seating areas for clients to enjoy and relax and a trampoline on the grass area. At 09:30 am, LPA observed a rip on the surface of the trampoline. Per CCR 84087.2(a) Children shall have access to safe outdoor activity space. HM Meledez stated the neighbor’s cat teared the trampoline surface. HM Meledez stated will have his worker take apart the trampoline. The trampoline was disassembled by 10:05am. Five of five staff files were reviewed during the inspection and noted to have documents required per regulations in file. Staff interviews were completed with the two staffs that were available at the time. Four of four client files were reviewed during the inspection and noted to have documents required per regulations in file. Four of four clients are non-verbal and therefore could not be interviewed. There was no deficiency cited for Operational Requirement, Disaster Preparedness, Emergency Intervention Plan, Staffing Records, Client Records, Core/Therapeutic Services and Client with Special Health Care Needs. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 809D and appeal rights were provided to House Manager, Fernando Meledez.

Confidential interviews and document reviews revealed that while C1 did have a black eye when C1 went to school, it could be explained. Per the Special Incident Report (SIR) dated 12/31/2021, another client slipped on C1’s blanket outside their door and fell over C1. C1 had redness and scratches around their right eye. Confidential interviews reported that the staff took C1 to the doctor to have C1’s eye checked. Confidential interviews stated that the medical staff performing the forensic evaluation showed no signs of abuse. The Department also received an allegation that the facility does not meet the minor’s (C1) hygiene needs. It was reported that C1 comes to school soiled. Confidential interviews revealed that when C1 leaves home, C1 is clean; however, C1 sometimes has wet or soiled themselves before reaching school on the school bus. Confidential interviews reported that when C1 leaves the facility to go to school, C1 is clean, and C1’s diaper is not soiled. The Department also received an allegation that the facility is not ensuring that minor (C1) have their mobility device at school. It was reported that C1 is being sent to school without their motorized scooter. Confidential interviews revealed that while C1 is not being sent to the school with their motorized scooter, they are sending C1 to school with a mobility device of a stand-up walker. The Individualized Education Program (IEP) for C1 states that C1 is to use a stand-up walker at school. Confidential interviews reported that staff was following the directives in C1’s IEP regarding the device C1 was allowed to use while at school. Based on confidential interviews and record reviews, the allegations that the minor (C1) has an unexplained black eye, the facility does not meet minor’s (C1) hygiene needs, and the facility is not ensuring that the minor (C1) has their mobility device at school may have occurred, however, it is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated. A copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were given to Koa Home DSP II Richard Perreno..
investigation_findings: 13On November 18, 2022, at 04:15 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Linda Haynes met with the Koa Group Home DSP II Richard Perreno to deliver the investigation findings for the above-stated allegations. This complaint involves Client 1 (C1), listed on the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated 11/18/2022. On 01/27/2022, LPA conducted a health and safety inspection, and no immediate deficiencies were observed. LPA also obtained and reviewed copies of the needs and services plans for Client 1 (C1), a copy of the Individual Education Plan (IEP) for C1, and a Special Incident Report (SIR) for C1. LPA conducted confidential interviews with House Manager (HM), Medical staff, and C1’s Bus Driver. LPA Attempted to interview C1 but was unsuccessful due to C1 being unable to communicate verbally. On January 19, 2022, the Department received a complaint alleging that the minor (C1) had an unexplained black eye. It was reported that C1 went to school with a black look, and C1’s right eye was dark red all around the eye. Continued on next page

narrative: Confidential interviews reported that initially, there was no explanation for the cause of the injuries to C1. Confidential interviews reported that later, an explanation was provided that C1 scratched themself, causing minor cuts on C1’s face. Confidential interviews disclosed that a cabinet door was opened near C1’s face, which caused the minor cuts. The facility provided a Special Incident Report (SIR), which explained the scratches on C1’s face. Confidential interviews reported that although C1 is allowed to move about the facility freely without facility staff, sometimes, as C1 is moving freely throughout the facility, C1 may open a door or cabinet. These actions sometimes cause scratches on C1’s face. As part of their safety plan, the facility staff will place child-proof locks on cabinet doors to prevent C1 from sustaining injuries on C1’s face. There are no corroborating statements that were disclosed that C1 injuries were caused due to lack of supervision. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, the allegation that the minor sustained unexplained injuries while in care, may have occurred, however, is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights was explained and given to Administrator Fernando Melendez.
investigation_findings: 13On 02/23/2023 at 10:01 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joon Choi made an unannounced visit to deliver the investigative findings for the allegation listed above and met with Koa Home Group Home (GH) Administrator Fernando Melendez. narrative: The facility provided a Special Incident Report (SIR), which explained the scratches and bruising on C1’s forehead and left eye. Confidential interviews reported that although C1 is allowed to move about the facility freely without facility staff, sometimes, as C1 is moving freely throughout the facility, C1 may open a door or cabinet. These actions sometimes cause scratches and bruising on C1’s face or body. As part of their safety plan, the facility staff will place child-proof locks on cabinet doors to prevent C1 from sustaining injuries on C1’s face. There are no corroborating statements that were disclosed that C1 injuries were caused due to lack of supervision. Based on confidential interviews and SIR, the allegation that the child sustained unexplained injuries while in care, may have occurred, however, is not supported or proven by evidence. investigation_findings: 13On 02/23/2023 at 09:19 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joon Choi made an unannounced visit to deliver the investigative findings for the allegation listed above and met with Koa Home Group Home (GH) Administrator Fernando Melendez. On 05/10/2022, LPA Linda Haynes conducted an initial health and safety inspection of the facility. No immediate health and safety hazards were observed. On 02/07/2023, LPA Choi conducted a follow-up visit to the facility, and no immediate health and safety hazards were observed. LPA Haynes interviewed the Clinical Director (S1), and LPA Choi interviewed the Administrator (S2) and three Direct Care Staff (S3, S4, and S5). LPA attempted to interview Client 1 (C1) but could not be interviewed due to the inability to communicate verbally. On 05/06/2022, Community Care Licensing received an allegation that the child (C1) sustained unexplained injuries while in care. Confidential interviews reported that C1 had a scratch and a bruise on their left eye about an inch long, three bruises on C1’s forehead about two inches long, and the color was reddish-brown. CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE

narrative: Confidential interviews reported that C1 acted agitatedly on previous returns to the facility while on the school bus. Confidential interviews reported that C1 was not agitated when S4 and S5 entered the school bus to assist. Other confidential interviews reported that the facility staff (S4 and S5) were called by the bus driver and C1’s school aide, as they were having difficulty escorting C1 off of the bus. Confidential interviews reported that although the school bus driver and the school aide were responsible for escorting C1 off the bus, the facility staff members (S4 and S5) agreed to assist. Confidential interviews reported that two facility staff members (S4 and S5) utilized their Crisis Prevention Intervention (CPI) training, to escort C1 off of the bus, in the least restrictive manner. Confidential interviews reported that S4 and S5 did not have to use any physical force. S4 and S5 stood on each side of C1 and held C1’s arms and shoulders to ensure C1 did not fall while walking off the bus. Confidential interviews reported that after this incident, the facility staff was instructed that C1 would be escorted off the bus, by the bus driver and/or C1’s school aide only. Confidential interviews reported that no injuries were observed on C1 because of this incident. Confidential interviews reported that a Special Incident Report (SIR) submitted by the facility, was obtained, which was consistent with the statements from the confidential interviews. Based on confidential interviews and SIR obtained, the allegation that a staff member (S4) handled the minor (C1) in a physically aggressive manner, may have occurred, however, is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights was explained and given to Administrator Fernando Melendez

narrative: Confidential witnesses revealed to LPA that staff provide appropriate supervision to C1 and the other clients. Furthermore, confidential witnesses stated that facility staff were always present and engaged with the clients. CSW indicated that C1 would have tantrums and C1 would roll on the ground. CSW added that C1 was physically aggressive toward staff and peers and staff were always appropriate with C1 with redirection. CSW didn’t believe there was a lack of supervision resulting C1 sustaining an injury. Other confidential witness interview revealed that they had observed C1 with unexplained injuries. Based on confidential interviews and record reviews, the allegation that due to lack of supervision C1 had a bruise on C1’s back on September 8, 2022, may have occurred, however, it is not supported or proven by evidence. investigation_findings: 13On September 28, 2023, at 2:21 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Michael Almaraz, arrived at the facility and met with facility staff, Fernando Melendez, to issue the finding for the above stated allegation. The complaint investigation was jointly conducted by LPA J. Choi, LPA L. Haynes, and LPA M. Almaraz. On September 20, 2022, at 2:30 PM, LPA Choi arrived at the facility to initiate the investigation and conducted a safety inspection. During the safety inspection, LPA Choi also reviewed one client’s (C1) records see confidential names list (LIC 811) dated September 28, 2023. Additionally, LPA Almaraz conducted interviews with four staff, a county social worker (CSW), three confidential witnesses, and four of four clients. LPA didn’t receive responses from three of four clients due to being non-verbal. On September 12, 2022, the Department received a complaint that alleged a minor sustained a bruise while in care. More specifically, it was alleged that due to lack of supervision C1 had a bruise on C1’s back on September 8, 2022. During the course of the investigation, confidential witnesses stated that C1 tends to have tantrums where C1 will roll on the ground. (continued on page 2...)

narrative:
A confidential interview stated they witnessed two staff grabbing C1 by the feet and dragging C1 into the room. Other confidential interviews stated that the staff at the facility did not grab and drag C1 into the room and it is not the standard of care at the facility. Confidential interviews stated that C1 drops to the ground often when C1 is having behavior issues and C1 will stay on the ground banging the head to the ground or swinging the arms and grabbing a hold of someone that’s standing close by and bite their ankles. Additionally, the confidential interviews stated when C1 drops to the ground, the staff would have to lift C1 off the ground and carry C1 into the facility sometimes with force and it is the only way to handle C1 due to the behavior issues; and in the eyes of bystanders may look like the staff is grabbing and dragging C1 into the room. Community Care Licensing also received an allegation stating that the facility staff made an inappropriate/threatening comment to minor. Specifically, it was reported that a staff was heard saying to C1, “I guess you don’t want to eat today.”. A confidential interview stated they heard a staff denying food to C1 because C1 was having behavior issues and did not want to get up from the ground. Other confidential interviews stated that the staff would never make inappropriate or threatening comments to minor at the facility. Additionally, the staff do not use food as a source of punishment or reinforcement. Furthermore, C1 is healthy and has been gaining weight since placement and there is no concerns of the staff at the facility. Community Care Licensing also received an allegation stating that the facility staff does not provide assistance to minor (C1) when getting off the bus. Specifically, it was reported that the staff does not pick up C1 from the bus and the school aide had to physically take C1 to the facility due to C1 refuses to get off the bus. A confidential interview stated the facility staff should pick up C1 from the school bus door due to liability issues. Another confidential interview stated it is the responsibility of the school district staff to assist C1 off the school bus and use the walker to get from the school bus to the front door of the facility and one of the facility staff will assist C1 into the facility. Additionally, a confidential interview stated due to the safety of C1 and to prevent C1 from dropping on the ground due to behavior issues, it was agreed the school district staff was to drop C1 off at the facility door. *continued on LIC 9099c*

Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, the allegations that the minor (C1) was roughly handled (grabbed and dragged) at the facility, the facility staff made an inappropriate/threatening comment to C1 and facility staff does not provide assistance to C1 when getting off the bus may have occurred, however, is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were explained, and a copy of this report and LIC 811 was provided to Irma Holguin, Direct Staff Personnel.

narrative: On Tuesday November 21, 2023, at 11:01 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Linda Haynes conducted day one of an annual inspection of the facility. At time of inspection LPA met with House Manager (HM) Fernando Melendz. The facility was toured inside and out with HM. The home is a one story residence with four bedrooms and three bathrooms. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than one client is in a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. Hot water in bathroom number one measured to be 108.6, bathroom number two 105.4 and bathroom number 3 105.8. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. The medications are stored in a locked cabinet in the office. Cleansers/chemicals are stored in a locked cabinet above the washing machine. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. The First Aid Kit is located in the office and contained all required supplies. The facility's smoke detectors / Carbon Monoxide detectors in each bedroom were checked and were operable. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by HM. The following required posted items was accessible to clients: Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, and Visitation policies. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. There is no pool or other body of water. A technical Advisory will be issued for the following. The oven was broken a new one has been ordered. There was one window that was broken it has been ordered and covered with plywood for a temporary fix. The fire extinguisher needs to be replaced a new one has been ordered and will be picked up today. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights was discussed and provided to HM on this date.

Regarding the allegation that C1’s hair was not groomed appropriately. Confidential witnesses stated staff assisted C1 with grooming C1’s hair. Confidential witnesses added that staff ensured all clients were groomed appropriately. CSW4 informed LPA that she had never observed any clients to not be groomed appropriately. Other confidential witnesses stated that they had observed C1 with her hair not groomed appropriately on several occasions. Concerning the allegation that staff did not provide C1 with feminine products. Confidential witnesses stated that facility staff had always provided C1 and the other clients with all their hygiene products. CSW4 had no concerns that the facility staff was not ensuring that clients had the hygiene products that they needed. LPA received other information that C1 did not have feminine hygiene products provided to C1 by facility staff. With regard to the allegation that facility staff did not communicate C1’s medication needs to C1’s school. Confidential witnesses stated that facility staff did communicate with C1’s school. CSW4 stated that there was good communication between client’s schools and the facility. LPA received other information that the facility was not ensuring that C1’s school was aware of C1’s medication and mental health needs. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegations that C1’s hair was not groomed appropriately, staff did not ensure that C1 had feminine hygiene products, and staff did not communicate with C1’s school regarding C1’s medication may have occurred, however, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Yusif Rizk.

narrative:
On 7/14/22 at 9:48am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephanie Lor and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriouez conducted a Pre-Licensing Inspection, Component II and Component III at the above facility. LPA Lor and LPM Rodriguez met with the Administrator and Director. The facility consisted of a formal living room equipped with a set of couches, a covered fireplace, a desk for staff, a formal dining room equipped with a large table with 6 chairs. There is a resting area/second living room area equipped with a TV, a covered fireplace, board games, a shelf, and 3 couches. The kitchen was equipped with counter space, a working stove, locked cabinets to store the sharp objects/knives and dish soaps, plates, utensils, cups, silverware, and a large trash can with lid on. There is an area with 6 desks/chairs and 1 desk for staff, 1 office room will be used for staff and to lock the files and medication. There were hygiene products and cleaning supplies in the closet. There are 3 bedrooms equipped with two twin size beds, closets, 2 dresser, 2 night stand and storage. Bedroom #1 is equipped with a private bathroom. Laundry room equipped with a washer/dryer and lock cabinets to store the laundry/detergent soap. The backyard has a shed used for storage. There is small river creek accessible to clients and a sitting area with a table and chairs. There is a green thumb area for planting vegetables. The front yard was clean and free of hazards. The telephone land line and internet service were in working order. The water temperature was tested and it was at 140 degrees. There was plenty of perishable/non-perishable food available. The hallway cabinet has linens and towels. The garage has 2 freezers, 1 refrigerator filled with food, exercise equipment. There were can goods stored in the garage. There are cameras in the living room, garage, classroom area, dining room and hallway. (see 2nd page)

It was observed during a physical inspection of the facility that the staff office was unlocked and a filing cabinet inside the staff office, containing the client records, was left unlocked, allowing clients and other unauthorized visitors to have potential access to the client files. A Technical Advisory - Technical Violation was issued related to the inspection and California Code of Regulations, Title 22, division 6, chapter 1, section 80070(c)(1) The licensee shall be responsible for safeguarding the confidentiality of record contents.
