met_with: Bill Ryland, Homes for Teens Director
narrative: Confidential interviews were conducted with nine individuals during the period of 09/16/2022 to 01/26/2023, and attempted with seven individuals during the period of 11/21/2022 to 01/26/2023. LPA’s observation, interviews conducted, and records reviewed were inconsistent that facility staff did not prevent youths in care from engaging in physical altercations. The facility accepts clients with severe behavioral and mental health diagnosis, and most of the incidents and physical or verbal altercations in the facility stem from clients antagonizing one another. Clients interviewed reported they like residing at the facility, feel safe and that staff separate them during altercations, and ensure their needs are met. There is evidence that the two incidents which occurred on 09/10/2022 were addressed appropriately by staff on shift to ensure safety of all clients in care, when clients escalated and engaged in physical altercations with one another. The facility Program Statement states, “When residents become engaged in physical altercations (fights) in which they do not respond to staff’s verbal directives, staff may use physical interventions that include standing between the combative clients and/or physically breaking up the fight by holding back a client by his/her shoulders while verbally re-directing him/her.” And “In cases where a client(s) … does (do) not respond to re-direction… de-escalation techniques are used and law enforcement and/or the case manager is contacted depending upon the seriousness of the incident.” Review of other documentation described the client’s behaviors and needs which were outlined on their Individual Needs and Services Plans, and facility staff completed Safety Plans with clients in care, to identify triggers to behaviors and ways for clients to regulate their feelings. Upon review of the Incident Reports, and information gathered through interviews, at the time of the altercations, staff had offered coping strategies to clients, separated the clients per facility policy and the Police Department was contacted to support in de-escalating the aggressing clients. Through interviews, multiple staff reported that the Police Department will be contacted by request support at the facility when clients are a danger to themselves or others. The department has conducted a complaint investigation regarding the allegation: Facility staff did not prevent youths in care from engaging in physical altercations. Based on LPA interviews conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur. No citations were issued during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted with and a copy of this report was provided to Bill Ryland, Homes for Teens Director.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephannie Verna conducted an unannounced complaint inspection with the above agency on January 26, 2022 at 1:15 PM and met with Bill Ryland, Homes for Teens Director. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver complaint findings for the above allegation. On September 16, 2022 at 11:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephannie Verna arrived at the above facility to initiate a complaint investigation related to the above allegation. LPA met with Diana Macneill, Interim Facility Administrator and Yasmeen Sandoval, Facility Administrator. LPA completed a physical inspection of the group home, inside and out. During the course of the investigation, the following documents were gathered and reviewed: Incident Reports for three youth, Police Reports regarding the 09/10/2022 Incidents involving FC1, and FC3; Resident Assessments for three youth, Face Sheets for two youth, Needs and Services Plans for four youth, Placement Referrals (Kaiser) for three youth, Client census log, Staff Roster and Schedules, Program Daily Schedule, Safety Plan for FC3, Emotional Regulation Action Plan for FC1 and FC4, and the Pre-Teen Behavioral Health Program Statement. continued on 9099-c

met_with: Bill Ryland, Homes for Teens Director
narrative:
Confidential interviews were conducted with twelve individuals during the period of 09/16/2022 to 01/26/2023, and attempted with seven individuals during the period of 11/21/2022 to 01/26/2023. The department has conducted a complaint investigation regarding the allegation: Staff restrained minor in care. There was insufficient evidence to state that staff inappropriately restrained a minor in care. Upon review of incident reports, and based on information gathered during interviews, restraints are permitted to be conducted as a last resort when there is a safety concern of danger to a youth or others, and is to be conducted by two CPI trained staff, including pertaining FC1. Per review of the facility Program Statement, “Physical intervention should only be used as a last resort, when all other attempts to defuse the crisis situation using non-physical means have been tried and found ineffective. They will only be used when an individual presents a danger to self or others and when the risks posed when an individual presents a danger to self or others.” Staff who utilized restraints were CPI trained, and Incident Reports reviewed documented there was one restraint conducted in the month of September 2022 (on 09/28/2022). Incident Reports and staff interviewed both stated that there was a need for the restraint due to the youth being a danger to self or others, and after other de-escalation techniques were attempted and unsuccessful. Based on LPA interviews conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Bill Ryland, Homes for Teens Director.

Confidential interviews were conducted with twelve individuals during the period of 09/16/2022 to 01/26/2023, and attempted with seven individuals during the period of 11/21/2022 to 01/26/2023. The department has conducted a complaint investigation regarding the allegations: Staff did not provide a safe environment for children, Facility has insufficient staffing to meet children's needs, Staff do not report incidents as required, and Staff are not adequately trained to meet the needs of children in care. Based on interviews conducted, a staff reported they were asked to go home without completing an Incident Report on 09/10/2022, and another staff reported that they do not recall filling out an incident report for the incident involving FC1 on 09/10/2022. Review of incident Reports for three youth in care included incidents involving youth absence without permission, youth aggression and threats, and property destruction. The Incident Report pertaining to FC1 on 09/10/2022, could not be provided from the facility, and there is no evidence that the Law Enforcement Incident Report had been completed or submitted to the department as required. There was sufficient evidence to support that the facility had insufficient staffing to meet the children’s needs. Based on review of clients’ Needs and Services Plans and Assessments, documentation of the need for clients to have one on one or additional staff was not documented. Upon review of the facility’s Program Statement, it states “During awake hours a minimum of two staff will be on duty at all time, 24 hours and day, 7 days a week. Depending on occupancy, the targeted awake ration is 1 staff to 2 youth.” Based on review of staff schedules and time sheets, there were times when serious incidents occurred, but there was only one staff on shift, leaving youth in care with unmet safety needs. The physical environment of the facility was observed to be free of hazards during the Department’s physical inspection of the facility, however through interviews and record reviews it was determined that staff present during multiple interventions were not sufficiently trained or capable in their skills to support the needs of the children in care, therefore not providing a safe environment. Upon review of Crisis Prevention Intervention (CPI) certificates, nine staff who worked at the facility did not complete training and obtain their certificates until 09/28/2022, however this was within the required 90 days after their hire date. continued on 9099-c

Based on LPA observations, documentation reviewed, and interviews which were conducted, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. The facility is being issued three citations related to the complaint investigation and pertaining to deficiencies to the following regulations, Group Home ILS section 84065.5(c) If the children require special care and supervision because of age, problem behavior or other factors, the number of on-duty child care staff shall be increased; section 84061(i) The licensee shall submit reports to the Department, using form LIC 624-LE or a report containing all the information required in LIC 624-LE, regarding any incident that involves law enforcement contact with a child residing in the facility; and section 84065(i)(2) Sixteen hours of training shall be completed by new child care staff within 90 days of hire. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Bill Ryland, Homes for Teens Director.

Through record review of time sheets, it was determined that these staff completed their shifts while on shift with at least one CPI trained staff person during the month of September. Upon review of the facility’s Program Statement, “If assaultive behavior continues to be displayed and a clear risk is perceived, staff may employ a team physical intervention as a last resort. Generally, this will involve the use of the CPI Team Control technique, with two staff members involved ensuring that the service user’s upper and lower body strength is restricted, along with their mobility.” Based on review of Incident Reports, assaultive behaviors from FC1 and FC3 did occur at the facility during the month of September, and while there was a minimal or inconsistent amount of CPI trained staff present, presenting an unsafe environment for clients in care, as well as staff. Due to staff not being able to physically intervene when appropriate, utilizing CPI curriculum, staff contacted Law Enforcement as an alternative to de-escalate youth who were threatening, or acting aggressively, toward youth in care and staff present, as a way to de-escalate unsafe situations. There was consistent evidence to determine that staff are not adequately trained to meet the needs of children in care, including interviews conducted with two staff who stated they did not receive initial or thourough training, felt unprepared and unsupported and were not given additional time to complete required training while on shift. Based on a review of the facility’s Program Statement, it stated,” All direct care staff shall receive two full days training in CPI Nonviolent Crisis Intervention® within three months of commencing in their post..” and “An additional 16-Hour training will be completed of the new direct care staff within 90 days of hire.” Upon review of CPI certificates, nine staff who worked at the facility did not complete and obtain their certificates until 09/28/2022, however this was within the required 90 days after their hire date. Additionally, based on a review of training documents and certificates, it was determined that at the time of the incidents occuring in September 2022, the required 16 hour initial training for new staff was not yet due, with the due date being 90-days after their hire date. However, this training was either not completed or was not completed within the 90-day time-frame, as of February 07, 2023, for five out of ten staff whose training documentation was reviewed for a second time. continued on 9099-c
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephannie Verna conducted an unannounced complaint inspection with the above agency on February 07, 2023 at 02:00 PM and met with Bill Ryland, Homes for Teens Director and Canaan Sampson, Facility Administrator Supervisor. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver complaint findings for the above allegations. On September 16, 2022 at 11:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephannie Verna arrived at the above facility to initiate a complaint investigation related to the above allegation. LPA met with Diana Macneill, Interim Facility Administrator and Yasmeen Sandoval, Facility Administrator. LPA completed a physical inspection of the group home, inside and out. During the course of the investigation, the following documents were gathered and reviewed: Incident Reports for three youth, Police Reports regarding the 09/10/2022 Incidents involving FC1, and FC3; Resident Assessments for three youth, Face Sheets for two youth, Needs and Services Plans for four youth, Placement Referrals (Kaiser) for three youth, Client census log, Staff Roster, Schedules, Time sheets, Program Daily Schedule, Safety Plans for three youth, and the Pre-Teen Behavioral Health Program Statement. continued on 9099-c

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 84061(i) The licensee shall submit reports to the Department, using form LIC 624-LE or a report containing all the information required in LIC 624-LE, regarding any incident that involves law enforcement contact with a child residing in the facility. This regulation was evidenced as unmet by: Upon review of facility documentation provided, the Incident Report pertaining to FC1 on 09/10/2022, could not be provided from the facility, and there is no evidence that the Law Enforcement Incident Report had been completed or submitted to the department as required, creating a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk for clients in care.

84065.5(c) If the children require special care and supervision because of age, problem behavior or other factors, the number of on-duty child care staff shall be increased. This regulation was evidenced as unmet by: Based on a review of Incident Reports, assaultive behaviors from youth in care did occur at the facility during the month of September, and while there was a minimal or inconsistent amount of CPI trained staff present, presenting an unsafe environment for clients in care, as well as staff. Additionally, there were times when serious incidents occurred, but there was only one staff on shift, leaving youth in care with unmet safety needs, creating a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk for clients in care.

84065(i)(2) Sixteen hours of training shall be completed by new child care staff within 90 days of hire. This regulation was evidenced as unmet by: Upon review of staff training documentation and certificates, it was found that initial training (16 hours) was not completed within the 90 day time frame allotted, creating a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk for clients in care.

narrative: On 8/1/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephanie Lor made an unannounced visit at the agency for the purpose of completing a required Annual Inspection. LPA met with Office Manager who gave a tour of the facility. LPA conducted a walk-through of the facility inside and out. LPA observed working smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors. The living room was observed to have adequate furniture and lamps. LPA observed 3 bedrooms and staff office. Bedroom 1 will have all required mattresses and bedding once client is placed. Kitchen cabinet will be fixed once facility is in operation. All bathrooms were tested and working. Laundry room equipped with a washer/dryer and lock cabinets to store the laundry/detergent soap. There were 3 fire extinguishers on site and a first aid kit with all required items. The front yard was clean and free of hazards. The backyard has a shed used for storage. The water temperature was tested and it was at 117 degrees. There is currently no staff or client at this facility, therefore LPA did not review any files or conducted interviews. LPA reviewed the physical, operations and disaster plan domain. An exit interview was conducted with the Office Manager. A copy of the report was provided to the facility.

Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Sara Luman-Gonzalez and Sarina Buchannan made an unannounced inspection on 08/01/2024 at 11:00 A.M. During the inspection LPA met with Canaan Sampson, Facility Supervisor who assisted with the inspection.LPAs conducted a walk-through of the facility inside and out. Facility staff-client ratio at time of inspection was observed to be 0 clients with 1 staff member present. Number of staff interviewed 1 Number of clients interviewed 0 LPAs observed 3 bedrooms and 3 bathrooms LPAs Sara Luman Gonzalez & Sarina Buchannan inspected and/or reviewed the following: Physical Plant LPA's observed the necessary documentation such as Personal Rights, Facility License, Grievance Policies, Chores, Laundry and other documentation posted on the wall. All disinfectants/cleaning solutions were observed to locked away in a closet. Sharps were also locked away in the kitchen area. Fridge, Freezer and pantry were observed to be adequately stocked with both perishable and non-perishable foods. Fridge was observed to be below 45 degrees and Freezer was observed to be below 0 degrees. A back up fridge and freezer in the garage area. There are 2 vans registered to the facility, one was leaving for the shop upon LPA's arrival and the other was registered and in compliance. Hot water was tested throughout the facility and was observed to 124 degrees. A working phone was observed to be in the living room area. Carbon monoxide/Smoke detectors were tested and observed to be fully functional. Fire extinguishers were observed to be serviced and fully charged. All common area furniture was observed to be in good repair with adequate room for seating for the capacity. The medications area is observed to in the locked office in a locked drawer. (Page 1 of 2)

Bedrooms were furnished and in good repair with linens in the hallway closet. All bathroom fixtures were observed to in good repair with soap and paper towels in each. There is a locked shed in the rear yard with holiday decorations and maintenance equipment. LPAs observed the facility to be free of vermin. Operations Complaint procedures were reviewed along with Board Minutes. All observed to be in compliance. Disaster Preparedness Disaster and Mass Casualty Plan was observed to be posted. Drills are conducted monthly. Emergency Intervention Due to the facility not having any clientele there was no manual restraint log on file however, Facility Supervisor was able to provide one online. There are no staff assigned to the facility but training for the Facility Supervisor was up to date. The following items were reviewed for compliance in the regional office prior to the facility inspection: · Annual fees · Administrator Certificate for: Katie Danner & Canaan Sampson · Emergency Disaster Plan (per H&S Code 1565) · Mental Health Program Certificate Expires: 2025 · Annual Emergency Intervention Log · Personnel Roster, Facility Sketch, LIC 500, LIC 610C and LIC 308 An exit interview was conducted with Canaan Sampson and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

7 out of 11 interviews stated that there were room checks every 10-15 minutes throughout the night as well as if youths are in their room together. Also, there were no internal reports regarding any inappropriate interactions with staff and youth during the time frame that C1 was placed at this location. Lastly, due to C1’s history of not telling the truth, their guardian reportedly held no concerns over their placement there. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did occur therefore the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted, and Appeal Rights were discussed with Terri Anderson, Facility Administrator. A copy of this report and Appeal Rights were left at the facility.

narrative: On April 23, 2025 at 10:15 am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maie Soliman and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Dara Campos made an announced visit for the purpose of converting the facility type from a Group home to a SHORT TERM RESIDENTIAL THERAPEUTIC PROGRAM (STRTP) LPA and LPM met with Canaan Sampson, Facility Administrator Supervisor, Sara Busse, Program Director, Alyssa Miller, Office Manager, Aimee MarieL. Zapata, Clinical Facility Administrator. The facility provided the Group Home license to LPA/LPM. There are no clients in the home.

On November 22, 2021 at 12:00PM License Program Manager, Rosa Rodriguez (LPM), and License Program Analyst, Yuvi Diaz (LPA) conducted Prelicensing Inspection of this facility. LPM and LPA met with administrator, Bill Ryland who gave a tour of the interior and exterior areas of the facility's physical plant. The backyard has a pool with a fence that is at least five feet tall that meets Title 22 regulations, the fence does not obscure the view, and it has a self latching device. The front and back yards were free of clutter; No potentially hazardous items or areas were observed. The facility consisted of a kitchen, dining room space, living room space with clean couches, large TV, game room/group room, three bedrooms furnished with two beds, night stand and dresser, two bathrooms, one staff bathroom ,one office space and clinician office. License, personal rights, and disaster plan were all posted in the facility. The temperature in the room was at 70. Fire extinguisher was up to date. LPA and LPM also noted the facility had two refrigerators with at least 7 days worth of non-perishables and 3 days worth of perishables. LPA/LPM noted locked cabinets for client files and medications to be stored in a safe location.. No structural defects to the house was observed by LPA/LPM: the windows and window screens were in good repair and there were no unfinished areas. Fire alarms and carbon monoxide alarms were working. First aid was fully stocked. All domain of the tool were completed: Physical plan, operations, disaster preparedness, and client records. An exit interview was conducted with administrator. A copy of this report will be emailed to the administrator.

On 8/4/22 at 10:30am, License Program Analyst, Stephanie Lor (LPA) conducted a post-licensing inspection at the above facility. LPA met with Facility Administrator who gave a tour of the interior and exterior areas of the facility. All required posters were posted by the front entrance. Bedroom 1, 2, and 3 have 2 twin size beds, closets, trash cans with lids, and working lights. All 3 bathrooms had running water and the water temperature was at 117. There is 1 staff office. The hallway closet consisted of hygiene products and towels. Living area 1 consisted of a couch, desk and a piano. Living area 2 consisted of 2 couches, 2 tables, tv, locked cabinets, art supplies storage, a locked closet for the washer and dryer, and a locked closet for an extra refrigerator and pantry with at least 7 days’ worth of non-perishables and 3 days’ worth perishable. The backyard has a pool with a fence that is at least five feet tall that meets Title 22 regulations, and it has a self-latching device. The locked shed consisted of youth’s personal belongings. There were cameras observed in the common areas. Fire alarms and carbon monoxide alarms were working. There were 2 fire extinguishers and 1 first aid kit. LPA reviewed 2 youth files, 3 staff files, and interviewed 1 youth. Two technical assistance were provided during this inspection. All domains of the tool were completed: Physical plan, operations, disaster preparedness, emergency intervention, staffing, and client records. An exit interview was conducted with administrator. A copy of this report will be emailed to the administrator.

On 12/19/22, License Program Analyst, Stephanie Lor (LPA) conducted an annual inspection at the above facility. LPA met with Facility Administrator who gave a tour of the interior and exterior areas of the facility. Prior to the inspection, LPA reviewed: annual fees, administrator certificate, accreditation, expiration date, waivers and exception, and personnel roster. All required posters were posted by the front entrance. Bedroom 1, 2, and 3 have 2 twin size beds, closets, trash cans with lids, and working lights. LPA Lor observed a hole in bedroom #1. Administrator provided a work order proof of the work in progress. All 3 bathrooms had running water and the water temperature was at 105 degree. There is 1 staff office. The hallway closet consisted of hygiene products and towels. Living area 1 consisted of a couch, desk and a piano. Living area 2 consisted of 2 couches, 2 tables, tv, locked cabinets, art supplies storage, a locked closet for the washer and dryer, and a locked closet with an extra refrigerator and pantry with at least 7 days’ worth of non-perishables and 3 days’ worth perishable. The backyard has a pool with a fence that is at least five feet tall that meets Title 22 regulations and it has a self-latching device. The locked shed consisted of youth’s personal belongings. There were cameras observed in the common areas. Fire alarms and carbon monoxide alarms were working. There were 2 fire extinguishers and 3 first aid kits. The 2 vehicles were observed to be in good repair. LPA reviewed 2 youth files, 5 staff files, interviewed 2 clients, and interviewed 2 staff. 2 type B citations were given for torn window screens and a broken door closet. A Technical Violation was given to install screen windows to bedroom#3. This report was discussed with the Facility Administrator and a copy was provided to the facility.

On 12/30/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Stephanie Lor conducted a case management over the phone to follow up on the annual inspection on 12/19/22. LPA Lor spoke with the Administrator regarding their phone call and house rule policy. The Administrator went over their policy with LPA Lor. The requested documents were emailed to LPA Lor on 12/21/22. LPA Lor reviewed the Program Statement and it was determined that no violations have occurred. An exit interview was conducted with the Administrator and a copy of this report will be emailed to the facility. This case management investigation is closed.

On this day January 29, 2024, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Sara Luman-Gonzalez and Farhaan Sarangi conducted a Case Management-Other inspection. LPAs met with Facility Administrator, Jordan Myers and was granted access into the facility. During the Case Management-Other inspection, LPAs observed that the pool fence did not have a lock on it. LPAs educated the Administrator regarding the importance of having locks on the pool (See LIC 9102-Technical Violation). No deficiencies were cited during today's Case Management-Other inspection. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was given to the Administrator.

It was reported during the interview process that C1 did not have a history of lying. Staff confirmed that clients were not being monitored every fifteen minutes during the night, and the facility was not able to provide video footage to prove that the room checks were consistently completed throughout the night. Lastly, Staff reported that C2 has a history of inappropriate behavior. Based on LPA observation and interviews which were conducted and records review, Preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore, the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, 84072(d)(19) Personal Rights is being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. Exit interview was conducted, Appeal Rights were discussed with Juan Magallon, Facility Administrator and copy of this report were left at the facility.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Personal Rights: licensee shall ensure that each child... accorded the personal rights:to be free of physical, sexual…abuse… exploitation… intimidation… threat, mental abuse or other actions of a punitive nature.This requirement is not met as evidenced by: C1 was sexually abused by C2 on multiple occaisons during nighttume around Christams of 2023. narrative:
Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Orlando Areizaga and Sara Luman-Gonzalez made an unannounced Annual inspection on Thursday December 19, 2024 at 9:20 AM. During the inspection LPAs met with Canaan Juan Magallon, Facility Adminsitrator who assisted with the inspection. LPAs Areizaga and Luman-Gonzalez conducted a walk-through of the facility interior and exterior. Facility staff client ratio at time of inspection were 2 staff to 3 youths in care. Number of staff interviewed 3 Number of clients interviewed 3 LPAs observed # 3 bedrooms, # 3 bathrooms LPAs Areizaga and Luman-Gonzalez inspected and/or reviewed the following: Physical Plant: LPA's observed the necessary documentation, such as the Emergency ID form, License, Personal Rights, and Grievance Policies. There are 3 working phones throughout the facility. Cleaning/Disinfectants were locked along with Laundry Supplies. Smoke Detectors/Carbon Monoxide were tested and observed in working order. Fire Extinguishers were charged and in two locations in the facility. Multiple First Aid Kits were observed throughout the facility to be fully stocked. Fridge was below 45 degrees and Freezer was below 0. Hot water was tested at 110 degrees. Menu for the week was posted on the door. 2 weeks of Non-perishable items and 5 days of perishable items were observed in the kitchen area. Common areas were easily accessible with plenty of seating space for staff and youths placed at the facility. Medication centrally stored is locked/inaccessible. Office is locked. Toilets wash basin, bath and shower fixtures in good repair/no leaks. Soap and Paper towels in the restroom. Laundry Facilities with schedule in a central area. (Page 1 of 3)

Bedrooms-required linen and furnishings were observed in the home. Bedroom (required bedding/furniture, furniture were observed in good repair. Two Motor Vehicle properly maintained , lights, tires, registration/insurance and working seat belts. Facility free of vermin. Locked Facilities (open locked storage area/building/sheds) were accessible to the Department. Operations: Complaint Procedures For Youth Reviewed and are posted in the entryway. Board Minutes Reviewed. Disaster Preparedness: Disaster and mass casualty plan updated and available in the entryway. Quarterly Drills conducted and documented in a separate binder. Disaster preparedness supplies verified in a closet in the office. Emergency Intervention: Review of manual restraint log; No restraints within the year. Staff training is up to date. Staffing/Volunteers: Number of Staff files reviewed: 5. All Criminal Record Clearances, First Aid, CPI, Job Title/Qualifications. and Training were verified. Administrator Certificate verified. Client Records: Clients files reviewed: 5. Needs an Services Plans, Psychotropic Medications, Centrally Stored Medications, Cash Resources and Compatibility Assessment were observed in their respective binders. Core/Therapeutic Services: Trauma Informed Practices are implemented as a part of the core of the Facility. Other forms of therapy, Equine, are used with the youths. (Page 2 of 3)

The following items were reviewed for compliance in the regional office prior to the facility inspection: · Annual fees: $454.00 · Administrator Certificate for: Juan Magallon · Emergency Disaster Plan (per H&S Code 1565) · Annual Emergency Intervention Log · Personnel Roster, Facility Sketch, LIC 500, LIC 610C and LIC 308 · Waivers and Exceptions An exit interview was conducted with Juan Magallon, Facility Administrator and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

On 7/14/22 at 1:00PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephanie Lor and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez conducted a Pre-Licensing Inspection, Component II and Component III at the above facility. LPA Lor and LPM Rodriguez met with the Administrator. The facility consisted of a living room equipped with a set of 3 couches, TV and a staff desk, a formal dining room equipped with a large table with 2 chairs and 2 benches. There is a fire place in the dining room, which staff was informed to cover up. The kitchen was equipped with counter space, locked cabinets to store the sharp objects/knives and dish soaps, plates, utensils, cups, silverware, and a large trash can with lid on. 1 office room upstairs will be used for the Therapist, the room included a desk, 2 couches, and 1 first aid kit. The 2nd office room upstairs will be used for staff and to lock the files. The 2nd office room contains 2 desks, 2 trash cans with lid, 2 first aid kits, closet for supplies, and storage for staff personal items. There is a working land line in the facility. The garage contains a washer and dryer, 2 refrigerators, a cabinet for detergent, and storage for can goods. There are 3 bedrooms equipped with 2 twin size beds, closet (curtain will be installed) dresser, night stand, and trash can with lids. The 2 bathrooms have trash cans with lids. The bathroom upstairs will be used for staff and the one downstairs will be used by clients. Both bathrooms were in good repair, the water temperature was tested and the temperature was between 105-120 degrees. The hallway cabinet was filled with board games, blankets, towels, and hygiene products. The backyard has a pool with a cover that meets the Regulations. The cover was tested by having a staff walked over the cover. There was a basketball court area. There was an electric extension cord connected from the house to the pool cover motor, which can cause tripping hazard. Staff was notified to remove the cord. Staff was also notified to cover the pool pump area with a gate to make it inaccessible to clients. Staff will remove the cinder blocks, wood pieces and tree branches from the backyard. (see next page)

During the pre-inspection, LPA Lor and LPM Rodriguez observed the following: 3 first aid kit with all items, 2 fire extinguishers located in the second floor hallway and in the kitchen area, carbon monoxide and smoke detector were tested and were in working condition. There were 4 cameras observed in the home. A camera was located on the stairway, downstair hallway, living room and dining/kitchen area. There is no waiver on file to indicated that it was previously approved by CCL, LPA will check the Regulations to ensure a waiver is not needed. Component II was completed on 6/15/22 with the Director via Teams and the following areas were discussed: table of content LIC 9106 page 7 age range, section 4 Education Rights, section 12 House Rules, section 13 Discipline Policies, and section 18 Chores. Component III was also completed during today's inspection and the following forms were reviewed with the Regional Program Director: LIC198A -Child Abuse Central Index Check for State Licensed Facilities (family child care homes; children’s residential homes and facilities; and adult residential facilities if, through an approved exception or a specialized license, they provide care to a person under age 18), LIC198B - Out-of-State Child Abuse/Neglect Report Request, LIC 306-Reporting Requirements to Department. of Social Services, LIC 308 - Designation of Facility Responsibility, LIC 500 - Personnel Report, LIC 501 - Personnel Record, LIC 503 - Health Screening Report (including TB Clearance), LIC 508 -Criminal Record Statement, LIC 508D - Out-of-State Disclosure & Criminal Record Statement, LIC 613B - Personal Rights, LIC 624 -Unusual Incident/Injury/Death Report, LIC 627B - Consent for Medical Treatment, LIC 9058 - Applicant/Licensee Rights, LIC 9182 - Criminal Background Clearance Transfer Request, LIC 9188 Criminal Record Exemption Transfer Request, Appendix D - A Guide to Safeguarding Resident/Client Cash Resources, LIC 311B - Records to be Maintained in a Group Home, LIC 311E - Records to be Maintained in a Small Family Home, LIC 313 - Evidence of Program Consultant (Group Homes), · LIC 601 Identification and Emergency Information, LIC 602 - Physician’s Report for Community Care Facilities, LIC 603 (See next page)

- Preplacement Appraisal Information, LIC 622 - Centrally Stored Medication and Destruction Record, LIC 625 - Appraisal/Needs and Services Plan, LIC 9106 - Group Home Program Statement, LIC 9106A - Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Statement General Instructions, LIC 9128 - Foster Family Agency Program Statement, Neighborhood Complaint Policy The following items needed to be completed before issuing the license: electrical extension cord need to be removed, wood and cinder block need to be removed, pool pump covered must be inaccessible to clients with a lock, all bedrooms must have curtains in the closet, all the required forms to appoint the new Administrator to this facility. Administrator will email all the requirements to LPA Lor. Exit interview conducted with Administrator and a copy of the report will be emailed by 07/15/2022.

On November 04, 2022 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephannie Verna arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of conducting confidential interviews, with clients and staff, related to a complaint investigation at another facility. LPA Verna met with Katie Danner, Facility Administrator. LPA completed an inspection of the facility and there were no deficiencies observed. LPA completed 3 interviews. Clients to be interviewed have been discharged from the facility and could not be interviewed during this visit. Further investigation is needed to complete the complaint investigation at another facility. A signed copy of this LIC-809 report was provided to the facility. An exit interview was conducted.

In addition, there were no documentations of meeting with responsible parties to discuss the client’s discharge from the program. Lastly, the responsible party was not aware or informed of any 14 days’ discharge notice from the placement. Based on LPA’s observations and interviews which were conducted and record reviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5 are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted with the Administrator. A copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were provided to the agency.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 84061(b)(1)(2) (b) The licensee shall ensure that the child's authorized representative is notified no later than the next business day if the following circumstances have occurred without the authorized representative's participation: (1) The child has been placed in the facility under emergency circumstances. (2) The child has been removed from the facility. This standard is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and document reviews, responsible party was not notified of an incident, which posed a potential Health, Safety of Personal Rights to residents in care.

84068.4(b) The licensee shall ensure that the child and his/her authorized representative(s) are offered the opportunity to participate in the development of a discharge plan for the child. This standard is not met as evidenced by: Based on LPA Lor’s observation, there were no documentations of meeting with responsible parties to discuss the client’s discharge from the program, which posed a potential Health, Safety of Personal Rights to residents in care.

narrative: Based on interviews conducted during the investigation process, these allegations cannot be substantiated because the facility has already been cited for the same allegations on complaint received April 03, 2023. Another youth confirmed that staff never left them alone at the hospital. In addition, S2 denied leaving youth at the hospital. When interviewing other facility staff, staff could not confirm whether C3 was left alone or not at the hospital. It was reported that they’ve only heard of the incident from other staff. Lastly, 4/4 client interviews confirmed that during the day of the incident, staff were following them and making sure they were safe. (see next pg)

narrative: On the allegation of “staff did not file incident report,” there were collaboration that youth burned their hand while on an outing. Youth confirmed that the incident occurred and stated that the youth denied first aid kit. Although it was reported that staff offered first aid kit to the youth, there were no records of incident report submitted for this incident. Amended section: Although the injury did not appear to require medical attention, a burn is still considered an unusual incident requiring an incident report as burns can develop well within the next 24 hours of the incident. During the investigation it was determined that section 80061 (b)(D) was cited incorrectly under the section of the regulations. Therefore, the department will change the regulation to the correct regulation 80061 (b)(1)(E), which states that any unusual incident or client absence which threatens the physical or emotional health or safety of any client be reported. Based on LPA’s observations and interviews which were conducted and record reviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6 Chapter 1 are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted with the Administrator. A copy of this amended report was provided to the agency.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Reporting Requirements (b) Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in..(1) Events reported shall include the following: (E) Any unusual incident or client absence which threatens the physical or emotional health or safety of any client. This standard is not met as evidenced by: Based on document review, an incident report was not submitted to Community Care Licensing for the incident where youth burned their hand, which posed a potential Health, Safety of Personal Rights to residents in care.
This deficiency has been dismissed.

narrative: On December 26, 2023 at approximately 09:15 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Farhaan Sarangi arrived unannounced at Koinonia BHP-Rocklin for the purpose of conducting a Case Management-Deficiencies inspection. LPA was greeted at the door by Mental Health Support Worker, Dustin Blum, and was granted access into the facility. During the Case Management-Deficiencies inspection, LPA reviewed documents and observed that a Needs and Services Plan was not retained in client files and there was no Needs and Services Plan completed for the child in care due to the previous clinician walking off the job. LPA was made aware that the clinician walked off the job in Late October, 2023 (See LIC 809D). Deficiencies cited from the California Code of Regulations. Appeal rights were given. Failure to correct the deficiency and/or repeated deficiencies within a 12-month period may result in civil penalties. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was signed and given to the Mental Health Support Worker, Dustin Blum

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Children's Records: (c) If it is determined that the facility can provide the services necessary to meet the child's needs, the following additional information shall be maintained in the child's record: (1) A copy of the child's original needs and services plan; verification, signed by the child and his/her authorized representative(s), that they were offered the opportunity to participate in plan development; and verification that the authorized representative(s) have approved the plan. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observation, LPA reviewed documents and observed that a Needs and Services Plan was not retained in client files and there was no Needs and Services Plan completed for the child in care due to the previous clinician walking off the job. LPA was made aware that the clinician walked off the job in Late October, 2023.

narrative: On April 11, 2024 at 9:00 A.M. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Sara Luman-Gonzalez made an unannounced inspection to conduct a case management regarding two incident reports received by the Department on 3/21/24 and 3/27/24 regarding medication error, client 1 and client 2 were provided over the counter medication without parental consent on 3/15/24 and it was discovered on 3/20/24 for client 2. deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code section 16001.9, as applicable…to be free of the administration of medication or chemical substances, unless authorized by a physician. narrative: On May 6, 2024, at approximately 2:45 P.M., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sara Luman-Gonzalez arrived at the above Facility for the purpose of conducting a Facility Inspection. LPA met with Facility Administrator (FA), Linda Wagner and toured the facility. No deficiencies were noted at this time. LPA asked FA about the incident on 4/15/24 where a youth in care had access to exposed wiring and nails. FA clarified that Youth had kicked in the outlet area near the door of their bedroom exposing the nails and wiring. After calming the youth in care, FA placed a call to maintenance who arrived the next day to fix the issue. FA clarified that they had covered the hole with cardboard and tape overnight until maintenance arrived. LPA observed the call log on FA's personal phone. LPA observed no deficiencies at this time. An Exit Interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sara Luman-Gonzalez made an unannounced inspection on July 18, 2024 at 10:35 A.M. During the inspection LPA met with Hannah Erb, Facility Adminstrator Assistant and Canaan Sampson, Facility Supervisor who assisted with the inspection. LPA Luman-Gonzalez conducted a walk-through of the facility inside and out. Facility staff-client ratio at time of inspection 6 staff & 2 children. Four (4) staff interviewed & Two (2) clients interviewed. LPA observed Three (3) bedrooms, Three (3) bathrooms. LPA inspected and/or reviewed the following: Physical Plant License and Personal Rights are posted in the entry way. All medications and cleaning solutions are locked up separately. Fridge was below 45 degrees Freezer was below 0 degrees. LPA observed plenty of perishable and nonperishable foods. In the kitchen area is where the menu is posted and the phone is on the staff desk near the dining area. Smoking and Carbon Monoxide were observed in working order. First aid kits were observed throughout the home all fully stocked. Common area and dining area are adequately furnished and in good repair. Offices are upstairs and locked. Upstairs bathroom and downstairs bathrooms water was tested at 110 degrees; fixtures were all in good repair. Soap was accessible, paper towels were available, and bath towels were found in each child's box. Bedroom linens are in the closet by the bedrooms; observed to be clean. Bedroom furniture was observed to be in good repair. One facility van was in the shop for maintenance at the time of LPA's visit. Other facility vehicle was observed to be in good repair with current documentation. Locked shed outside houses crates and lawn care equipment. LPA observed the facility to be free of vermin. (Page 1of 3)

Operations Board minutes from the past two (2) quarters reviewed. Complaint procedures were reviewed. Disaster Preparedness Disaster and Mass Casualty plan was available for review and Monthly disaster drills are conducted. Disaster preparedness supplies were available in the garage area. Emergency Intervention Manual Restraints log was reviewed; Staff training was up to date and LPA observed the schedule for new trainings. Staffing/Volunteers Six (6) staff files were reviewed with Criminal Record Clearances, First Aid Certificates all up to date. Qualifications and Trainings were verified and up to date. Administrators certificate was observed to be current. Client Records Two (2) client files reviewed. Medications and Parent permissions were signed off and current. Both forms were filled out correctly. Cash Resources were observed to be up to date and Needs and Services Plans were signed. Core/Therapeutic Services Trauma Informed and Trust Based Relational Interventions are practiced within the facility and on outings/activities. Youths were observed returning from Equine Therapy upon LPA's arrival. Special Health Care Needs (SHCN) Staff have received training's for caring for youths with incontinence and enuresis. Staff cleans and disinfects home. (Page 2 of 3)

The following items were reviewed for compliance in the regional office prior to the facility inspection: · Annual fees · Administrator Certificate for: Linda Wagner · Emergency Disaster Plan (per H&S Code 1565) · Annual Emergency Intervention Log · Personnel Roster, Facility Sketch, LIC 500, LIC 610C and LIC 308 · Waivers and Exceptions An exit interview was conducted with Canaan Sampson, Facility Supervisor and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

10 out of 12 interviews stated that staffing ratios assured that the youths were not left alone with each other long enough for a sexual assault to occur. 10 out of 12 interviews confirmed that there were bed checks every 10-15 minutes and that doors had to be left open where the staff could see inside the room to verify where youths were. Also, there were no internal reports regarding any inappropriate interactions between staff and youth during the time of C1’s placement at this location. Lastly, due to C1’s history of not telling the truth, their guardian reportedly held no concerns over their placement there. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did occur therefore the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted, and Appeal Rights were discussed with Terri Anderson, Facility Administrator. A copy of this report was left at the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On February 21, 2025 at 12:45 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan conducted an unannounced visit to the above facility to deliver the findings of a complaint investigation. LPA met with Terri Anderson, Facility Administrator and was granted entry. During the investigation, LPA Luman-Gonzalez and LPA Orlando Areizaga conducted the 10-day inspection of the facility on 11/06/2024. LPA obtained Staff Roster and Child Roster from September 2022 to May 2023, Facility Sketch, Case Notes for C1. 12 confidential interviews were conducted between November 2024 and February 2025 by LPA Luman-Gonzalez and Investigator Brianna Abeyta. Based on interviews conducted throughout the investigation, LPA and IB Investigator received inconsistent statements. (Report continued on LIC 9099C)
